This is without prejudice to Article 6.5 of the AntiDumping Agreement and Article 12.4 of the SCM Agreement.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Provided it does not unnecessarily delay the conduct of the investigation, each interested party in an antidumping or countervailing investigation\n4\n shall be granted a full opportunity to defend its interests.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 3.3\n\n\n\nConsideration of public interest and lesser duty\n\n\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party's authorities shall consider information provided in accordance with the Party's law as to whether imposing an antidumping or countervailing duty would not be in the public\u00a0interest.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0After considering the information referred to in paragraph 1, the Party's authorities may consider whether the amount of the antidumping or countervailing duty to be imposed shall be the full margin of dumping or amount of subsidy or a lesser amount, in accordance with the Party's law.\n\n\n\n\nSECTION B\n\n\n\nGlobal safeguard measures\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 3.4\n\n\n\nGeneral provisions concerning global safeguard measures\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties reaffirm their rights and obligations concerning global safeguard measures under Article XIX of GATT 1994 and the Safeguards Agreement.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Protocol on rules of origin and origin procedures shall not apply to global safeguard measures.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 3.5\n\n\n\nTransparency\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0At the request of the exporting Party, the Party initiating a safeguard investigation or intending to adopt provisional or definitive global safeguard measures shall immediately provide:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the information referred to in Article 12.2 of the Safeguards Agreement, in the format prescribed by the WTO Committee on Safeguards;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the public version of the complaint filed by the domestic industry, where relevant; and\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a public report setting forth the findings and reasoned conclusions on all pertinent issues of fact and law considered in the safeguard investigation. The public report shall include an analysis that attributes injury to the factors causing it and set out the method used in defining the global safeguard measures.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0When information is provided under this Article, the importing Party shall offer to hold consultations with the exporting Party in order to review the information provided.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 3.6\n\n\n\nImposition of definitive measures\n\n\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party adopting global safeguard measures shall endeavour to impose them in a way that least affects bilateral trade.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The importing Party shall offer to hold consultations with the exporting Party in order to review the matter referred to in paragraph 1. The importing Party shall not adopt measures until\u00a030\u00a0days have elapsed since the date the offer to hold consultations was made.\n\n\n\n\nSECTION C\n\n\n\nGeneral provisions\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 3.7\n\n\n\nExclusion from dispute settlement\n\n\n\nThis Chapter is not subject to Chapter TwentyNine\u00a0(Dispute Settlement).\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER FOUR\n\n\n\n\n\nTECHNICAL BARRIERS TO TRADE\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 4.1\n\n\n\nScope and definitions\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This Chapter applies to the preparation, adoption, and application of technical regulations, standards, and conformity assessment procedures that may affect trade in goods between the Parties.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This Chapter does not apply to:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0purchasing specifications prepared by a governmental body for production or consumption requirements of governmental bodies; or\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a sanitary or phytosanitary measure as defined in Annex A of the SPS Agreement.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Except where this Agreement, including the incorporated provisions of the TBT Agreement pursuant to Article 4.2, defines or gives a meaning to a term, the general terms for standardisation and conformity assessment procedures shall normally have the meaning given to them by the definition adopted within the United Nations system and by international standardising bodies taking into account their context and in the light of the object and purpose of this Chapter.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0References in this Chapter to technical regulations, standards, and conformity assessment procedures include amendments thereto, and additions to the rules or the product coverage thereof, except amendments and additions of an insignificant nature.\n\n\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Article 1.8.2\u00a0(Extent of obligations) does not apply to Articles 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9 of the TBT Agreement, as incorporated into this Agreement.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 4.2\n\n\n\nIncorporation of the TBT Agreement\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The following provisions of the TBT Agreement\u00a0are hereby incorporated into and made part of this Agreement:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Article 2\u00a0(Preparation, Adoption and Application of Technical Regulations by Central Government Bodies);\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Article 3\u00a0(Preparation, Adoption and Application of Technical Regulations by Local Government Bodies and NonGovernmental Bodies);\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Article 4\u00a0(Preparation, Adoption and Application of Standards);\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Article 5\u00a0(Procedures for Assessment of Conformity by Central Government Bodies);\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Article 6\u00a0(Recognition of Conformity Assessment by Central Government Bodies), without limiting a Party's rights or obligations under the Protocol on the Mutual Acceptance of the Results of Conformity Assessment, and the Protocol on the Mutual Recognition of the Compliance and Enforcement Programme Regarding Good Manufacturing Practices for Pharmaceutical Products;\n\n\n\n\n\n(f)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Article 7\u00a0(Procedures for Assessment of Conformity by Local Government Bodies);\n\n\n\n(g)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Article 8\u00a0(Procedures for Assessment of Conformity by NonGovernmental Bodies);\n\n\n\n(h)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Article 9\u00a0(International and Regional Systems);\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Annex 1\u00a0(Terms and their Definitions for the Purpose of this Agreement); and\n\n\n\n(j)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Annex 3\u00a0(Code of Good Practice for the Preparation, Adoption and Application of Standards).\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The term \"Members\" in the incorporated provisions shall have the same meaning in this Agreement as it has in the TBT Agreement.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0With respect to Articles 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9 of the TBT Agreement, Chapter TwentyNine\u00a0(Dispute Settlement) can be invoked in cases where a Party considers that the other Party has not achieved satisfactory results under these Articles and its trade interests are significantly affected. In this respect, such results shall be equivalent to those as if the body in question were a Party.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 4.3\n\n\n\nCooperation\n\n\n\n\n\nThe Parties shall strengthen their cooperation in the areas of technical regulations, standards, metrology, conformity assessment procedures, market surveillance or monitoring and enforcement activities in order to facilitate trade between the Parties, as set out in Chapter TwentyOne\u00a0(Regulatory Cooperation). This may include promoting and encouraging cooperation between the Parties' respective public or private organisations responsible for metrology, standardisation, testing, certification and accreditation, market surveillance or monitoring and enforcement activities; and, in particular, encouraging their accreditation and conformity assessment bodies to participate in cooperation arrangements that promote the acceptance of conformity assessment results.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 4.4\n\n\n\nTechnical regulations\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties undertake to cooperate to the extent possible, to ensure that their technical regulations are compatible with one another. To this end, if a Party expresses an interest in developing a technical regulation equivalent or similar in scope to one that exists in or is being prepared by the other Party, that other Party shall, on request, provide to the Party, to the extent practicable, the relevant information, studies and data upon which it has relied in the preparation of its technical regulation, whether adopted or being developed. The Parties recognise that it may be necessary to clarify and agree on the scope of a specific request, and that confidential information may be withheld.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party that has prepared a technical regulation that it considers to be equivalent to a technical regulation of the other Party having compatible objective and product scope may request that the other Party recognise the technical regulation as equivalent. The Party shall make the request in writing and set out detailed reasons why the technical regulation should be considered equivalent, including reasons with respect to product scope. The Party that does not agree that the technical regulation is equivalent shall provide to the other Party, upon request, the reasons for its decision.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 4.5\n\n\n\nConformity assessment\n\n\n\nThe Parties shall observe the Protocol on the mutual acceptance of the results of conformity assessment, and the Protocol on the mutual recognition of the compliance and enforcement programme regarding good manufacturing practices for pharmaceutical products.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 4.6\n\n\n\nTransparency\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall ensure that transparency procedures regarding the development of technical regulations and conformity assessment procedures allow interested persons of the Parties to participate at an early appropriate stage when amendments can still be introduced and comments taken into account, except where urgent problems of safety, health, environmental protection or national security arise or threaten to arise. Where a consultation process regarding the development of technical regulations or conformity assessment procedures is open to the public, each Party shall permit persons of the other Party to participate on terms no less favourable than those accorded to its own persons.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties shall promote closer cooperation between the standardisation bodies located within their respective territories with a view to facilitating, among other things, the exchange of information about their respective activities, as well as the harmonisation of standards based on mutual interest and reciprocity, according to modalities to be agreed by the standardisation bodies concerned.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall endeavour to allow a period of at least 60 days following its transmission to the WTO Central Registry of Notifications of proposed technical regulations and conformity assessment procedures for the other Party to provide written comments, except where urgent problems of safety, health, environmental protection or national security arise or threaten to arise. A Party shall give positive consideration to a reasonable request to extend the comment period.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If a Party receives comments on its proposed technical regulation or conformity assessment procedure from the other Party, it shall reply in writing to those comments before the technical regulation or conformity assessment procedure is adopted.\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each\u00a0Party shall publish or otherwise make publicly available, in print or electronically, its responses or a summary of its responses, to significant comments it receives, no later than the date it publishes the adopted technical regulation or conformity assessment procedure.\n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall, upon request of the other Party, provide information regarding the objectives of, legal basis and rationale for, a technical regulation or conformity assessment procedure, that the Party has adopted or is proposing to adopt.\n\n\n\n7.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party shall give positive consideration to a reasonable request from the other Party, received prior to the end of the comment period following the transmission of a proposed technical regulation, to establish or extend the period of time between the adoption of the technical regulation and the day upon which it is applicable, except where the delay would be ineffective in fulfilling the legitimate objectives pursued.\n\n\n\n8.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall ensure that its adopted technical regulations and conformity assessment procedures are publicly available on official websites.\n\n\n\n\n\n9.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If a Party detains at a port of entry a good imported from the territory of the other Party on the grounds that the good has failed to comply with a technical regulation, it shall, without undue delay, notify the importer of the reasons for the detention of the good.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 4.7\n\n\n\nManagement of the Chapter\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties shall cooperate on issues covered by this Chapter. The Parties agree that the Committee on Trade in Goods, established under Article 26.2.1(a) shall:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0manage the implementation of this Chapter;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0promptly address an issue that a Party raises related to the development, adoption or application of standards, technical regulations or conformity assessment procedures;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0on a Party's request, facilitate discussion of the assessment of risk or hazard conducted by the other Party;\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0encourage cooperation between the standardisation bodies and conformity assessment bodies of the Parties;\n\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0exchange information on standards, technical regulations, or conformity assessment procedures including those of third parties or international bodies where there is a mutual interest in doing so;\n\n\n\n\n\n(f)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0review this Chapter in the light of developments before the WTO Committee on Technical Barriers to Trade or under the TBT Agreement, and, if necessary, develop recommendations to amend this Chapter for consideration by the CETA Joint Committee;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(g)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0take other steps that the Parties consider will assist them to implement this Chapter and the TBT Agreement and to facilitate trade between the Parties; and\n\n\n\n(h)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0report to the CETA Joint Committee on the implementation of this Chapter, as appropriate.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If the Parties are unable to resolve a matter covered under this Chapter through the Committee on Trade in Goods, upon request of a Party, the CETA Joint Committee may establish an ad hoc technical working group to identify solutions to facilitate trade. If a Party does not agree with a request from the other Party to establish a technical working group, it shall, on request, explain the reasons for its decision. The Parties shall lead the technical working group.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0When a Party has requested information, the other Party shall provide the information, pursuant to the provisions of this Chapter, in print or electronically within a reasonable period of time. The Party shall endeavour to respond to each request for information within 60 days.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER FIVE\n\n\n\nSANITARY AND PHYTOSANITARY MEASURES\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 5.1\n\n\n\n\n\nDefinitions\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purposes of this Chapter, the following definitions apply:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the definitions in Annex A of the SPS Agreement;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the definitions adopted under the auspices of the Codex Alimentarius Commission\u00a0(the \"Codex\");\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the definitions adopted under the auspices of the World Organisation for Animal Health\u00a0(the \"OIE\");\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the definitions adopted under the auspices of the International Plant Protection Convention\u00a0(the \"IPPC\");\n\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0protected zone for a specified regulated harmful organism means an officially defined geographical area in the European Union in which that organism is not established in spite of favourable conditions for its establishment and its presence in other parts of the European Union; and\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(f)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a competent authority of a Party means an authority listed in Annex 5A.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Further to paragraph 1, the definitions under the SPS Agreement prevail to the extent that there is an inconsistency between the definitions adopted under the auspices of the Codex, the OIE, the IPPC and the definitions under the SPS Agreement.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 5.2\n\n\n\nObjectives\n\n\n\nThe objectives of this Chapter are to:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0protect human, animal and plant life or health while facilitating trade;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0ensure that the Parties' sanitary and phytosanitary\u00a0(\"SPS\") measures do not create unjustified barriers to trade; and\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0further the implementation of the SPS Agreement.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 5.3\n\n\n\nScope\n\n\n\nThis Chapter applies to SPS measures that may, directly or indirectly, affect trade between the Parties.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 5.4\n\n\n\nRights and obligations\n\n\n\nThe Parties affirm their rights and obligations under the SPS Agreement.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 5.5\n\n\n\nAdaptation to regional conditions\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0With respect to an animal, animal product and animal byproduct:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the Parties recognise the concept of zoning and they have decided to apply this concept to the diseases listed in Annex 5B;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0if the Parties decide on principles and guidelines to recognise regional conditions, they shall include them in Annex 5C;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0for the purpose of subparagraph\u00a0(a), the importing Party shall base its sanitary measure applicable to the exporting Party whose territory is affected by a disease listed in Annex 5B on the zoning decision made by the exporting Party, provided that the importing Party is satisfied that the exporting Party's zoning decision is in accordance with the principles and guidelines that the Parties set out in Annex 5C, and is based on relevant international standards, guidelines, and recommendations. The importing Party may apply any additional measure to achieve its appropriate level of sanitary protection;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0if a Party considers that it has a special status with respect to a disease not listed in Annex 5B, it may request recognition of that status. The importing Party may request additional guarantees for imports of live animals, animal products, and animal byproducts appropriate to the agreed status recognised by the importing Party, including the special conditions identified in Annex 5E; and\n\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the Parties recognise the concept of compartmentalisation and agree to cooperate on this matter.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0With respect to a plant and plant product:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0when the importing Party establishes or maintains its phytosanitary measure, it shall take into account, among other things, the pest status of an area, such as a pestfree area, pestfree place of production, pestfree production site, an area of low pest prevalence and a protected zone that the exporting Party has established; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0if the Parties decide on principles and guidelines to recognise regional conditions, they shall include them in Annex 5C.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 5.6\n\n\n\nEquivalence\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The importing Party shall accept the SPS measure of the exporting Party as equivalent to its own if the exporting Party objectively demonstrates to the importing Party that its measure achieves the importing Party's appropriate level of SPS protection.\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Annex 5D sets out principles and guidelines to determine, recognise, and maintain equivalence.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Annex 5E sets out:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the area for which the importing Party recognises that an SPS measure of the exporting Party is equivalent to its own; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the area for which the importing Party recognises that the fulfilment of the specified special condition, combined with the exporting Party's SPS measure, achieves the importing Party's appropriate level of SPS protection.\n\n\n\n4. \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purposes of this Chapter, Article 1.7 (Reference to laws) applies subject to this Article, Annex 5-D and the General Notes under Annex 5-E. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 5.7\n\n\n\nTrade conditions\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The importing Party shall make available its general SPS import requirements for all commodities. If the Parties jointly identify a commodity as a priority, the importing Party shall establish specific SPS import requirements for that commodity, unless the Parties decide otherwise. In identifying which commodities are priorities, the Parties shall cooperate to ensure the efficient management of their available resources. The specific import requirements should be applicable to the total territory of the exporting Party.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Pursuant to paragraph 1, the importing Party shall undertake, without undue delay, the necessary process to establish specific SPS import requirements for the commodity that is identified as a priority. Once these specific import requirements are established, the importing Party shall take the necessary steps, without undue delay, to allow trade on the basis of these import requirements.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purpose of establishing the specific SPS import requirements, the exporting Party shall, at the request of the importing Party:\n\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0provide all relevant information required by the importing Party; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0give reasonable access to the importing Party to inspect, test, audit and perform other relevant procedures.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If the importing Party maintains a list of authorised establishments or facilities for the import of a commodity, it shall approve an establishment or facility situated in the territory of the exporting Party without prior inspection of that establishment or facility if:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the exporting Party has requested such an approval for the establishment or facility, accompanied by the appropriate guarantees; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the conditions and procedures set out in Annex 5F are fulfilled.\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Further to paragraph 4, the importing Party shall make its lists of authorised establishments or facilities publicly available.\n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party shall normally accept a consignment of a regulated commodity without preclearance of the commodity on a consignment basis, unless the Parties decide otherwise.\n\n\n\n7.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The importing Party may require that the relevant competent authority of the exporting Party objectively demonstrate, to the satisfaction of the importing Party, that the import requirements may be fulfilled or are fulfilled.\n\n\n\n8.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties should follow the procedure set out in Annex 5G on the specific import requirements for plant health.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 5.8\n\n\n\nAudit and verification\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purpose of maintaining confidence in the implementation of this Chapter, a Party may carry out an audit or verification, or both, of all or part of the control programme of the competent authority of the other Party. The Party shall bear its own costs associated with the audit or verification.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If the Parties decide on principles and guidelines to conduct an audit or verification, they shall include them in Annex 5H. If a Party conducts an audit or verification, it shall do so in accordance with any principles and guidelines in Annex 5H.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 5.9\n\n\n\nExport certification\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0When an official health certificate is required to import a consignment of live animals or animal products, and if the importing Party has accepted the SPS measure of the exporting Party as equivalent to its own with respect to such animals or animal products, the Parties shall use the model health attestation prescribed in Annex 5I for such certificate, unless the Parties decide otherwise. The Parties may also use a model attestation for other products if they so decide.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Annex 5I sets out principles and guidelines for export certification, including electronic certification, withdrawal or replacement of certificates,\u00a0language regimes and model attestations.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 5.10\n\n\n\nImport checks and fees\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Annex 5J sets out principles and guidelines for import checks and fees, including the frequency rate for import checks.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If import checks reveal noncompliance with the relevant import requirements, the action taken by the importing Party must be based on an assessment of the risk involved and not be more traderestrictive than required to achieve the Party's appropriate level of sanitary or phytosanitary protection.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Whenever possible, the importing Party shall notify the importer of a noncompliant consignment, or its representative, of the reason for noncompliance, and provide them with an opportunity for a review of the decision. The importing Party shall consider any relevant information submitted to assist in the review.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party may collect fees for the costs incurred to conduct frontier checks, which should not exceed the recovery of the costs.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 5.11\n\n\n\nNotification and information exchange\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party shall notify the other Party without undue delay of a:\n\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0significant change to pest or disease status, such as the presence and evolution of a disease listed in Annex 5B;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0finding of epidemiological importance with respect to an animal disease, which is not listed in Annex 5B, or which is a new disease; and\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0significant food safety issue related to a product traded between the Parties.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties endeavour to exchange information on other relevant issues including:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a change to a Party's SPS measure;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0any significant change to the structure or organisation of a Party's competent authority;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0on request, the results of a Party's official control and a report that concerns the results of the control carried out;\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the results of an import check provided for in Article 5.10 in case of a rejected or a noncompliant consignment; and\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0on request, a risk analysis or scientific opinion that a Party has produced and that is relevant to this Chapter.\n\n\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Unless the Joint Management Committee decides otherwise, when the information referred to in paragraph 1 or 2 has been made available via notification to the WTO's Central Registry of Notifications or to the relevant international standardsetting body, in accordance with its relevant rules, the requirements in paragraphs 1 and 2, as they apply to that information, are fulfilled.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 5.12\n\n\n\nTechnical consultations\n\n\n\nIf a\u00a0Party has a significant concern with respect to food safety, plant health, or animal health, or\u00a0an SPS measure\u00a0that the other Party has proposed or\u00a0implemented, that Party may request technical consultations with the other Party.\u00a0The Party that is the subject of the request should respond to the request without undue delay. Each Party shall endeavour to provide the information necessary to avoid a disruption to trade and, as the case may be, to reach a mutually acceptable solution.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 5.13\n\n\n\nEmergency SPS measures\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party shall notify the other Party of an emergency SPS measure within 24 hours of its decision to implement the measure. If a Party requests technical consultations to address the emergency SPS measure, the technical consultations must be held within 10 days of the notification of the emergency SPS measure. The Parties shall consider any information provided through the technical consultations.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The importing Party shall consider the information that was provided in a timely manner by the exporting Party when it makes its decision with respect to a consignment that, at the time of adoption of the emergency SPS measure, is being transported between the Parties.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 5.14\n\n\n\nJoint Management Committee for Sanitary and Phytosanitary Measures\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Joint Management Committee for Sanitary and Phytosanitary Measures\u00a0(the \"Joint Management Committee\"), established under Article 26.2.1(d), comprises regulatory and trade representatives of each Party responsible for SPS measures.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The functions of the Joint Management Committee include:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0to monitor the implementation of this Chapter, to consider any matter related to this Chapter and to examine all matters which may arise in relation to its implementation;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0to provide direction for the identification, prioritisation, management and resolution of issues;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0to address any request by a Party to modify an import check;\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0at least once a year, to review the annexes to this Chapter, notably in the light of progress made under the consultations provided for under this Agreement. Following its review, the Joint Management Committee may decide to amend the annexes to this Chapter. The Parties may approve the Joint Management Committee's decision, in accordance with their respective procedures necessary for the entry into force of the amendment. The decision enters into force on a date agreed by the Parties;\n\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0to monitor the implementation of a decision referred to in subparagraph\u00a0(d), above, as well as the operation of measures referred to under subparagraph\u00a0(d) above;\n\n\n\n(f)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0to provide a regular forum to exchange information that relates to each Party's regulatory system, including the scientific and risk assessment basis for an SPS measure; and\n\n\n\n\n\n(g)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0to prepare and maintain a document that details the state of discussions between the Parties on their work on recognition of the equivalence of specific SPS measures.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Joint Management Committee may, among other things:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0identify opportunities for greater bilateral engagement, including enhanced relationships, which may include an exchange of officials;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0discuss at an early stage, a change to, or a proposed change to, an SPS measure being considered;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0facilitate improved understanding between the Parties on the implementation of the SPS Agreement, and promote cooperation between the Parties on SPS issues under discussion in multilateral fora, including the WTO Committee on Sanitary and Phytosanitary Measures and international standardsetting bodies, as appropriate; or\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0identify and discuss, at an early stage, initiatives that have an SPS component, and that would benefit from cooperation.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Joint Management Committee may establish working groups comprising expertlevel representatives of the Parties, to address specific SPS issues.\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party may refer any SPS issue to the Joint Management Committee. The Joint Management Committee should consider the issue as expeditiously as possible.\n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If the Joint Management Committee is unable to resolve an issue expeditiously, it shall, at the request of a Party, report promptly to the CETA Joint Committee.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n7.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Unless the Parties decide otherwise, the Joint Management Committee shall meet and establish its work programme no later than 180 days following the entry into force of this Agreement, and its rules of procedure no later than one year after the entry into force of this Agreement.\n\n\n\n8.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Following its initial meeting, the Joint Management Committee shall meet as required, normally on an annual basis. The Joint Management Committee may decide to meet by videoconference or teleconference, and it may also address issues out of session by correspondence.\n\n\n\n9.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Joint Management Committee shall report annually on its activities and work programme to the CETA Joint Committee.\n\n\n\n10.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Upon entry into force of this Agreement, each Party shall designate and inform the other Party, in writing, of a contact point to coordinate the Joint Management Committee's agenda and to facilitate communication on SPS matters.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER SIX\n\n\n\nCUSTOMS AND TRADE FACILITATION\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 6.1\n\n\n\nObjectives and principles\n\n\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties acknowledge the importance of customs and trade facilitation matters in the evolving global trading environment.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties shall, to the extent possible, cooperate and exchange information, including information on best practices, to promote the application of and compliance with the trade facilitation measures in this Agreement.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Measures to facilitate trade shall not hinder mechanisms to protect a person through effective enforcement of and compliance with a Party's law.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Import, export and transit requirements and procedures shall be no more administratively burdensome or trade restrictive than necessary to achieve a legitimate objective.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Existing international trade and customs instruments and standards shall be the basis for import, export and transit requirements and procedures, except if these instruments and standards would be an inappropriate or ineffective means for the fulfilment of the legitimate objective pursued.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 6.2\n\n\n\nTransparency\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall publish or otherwise make available, including through electronic means, its legislation, regulations, judicial decisions and administrative policies relating to requirements for the import or export of goods.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall endeavour to make public, including on the internet, proposed regulations and administrative policies relating to customs matters and to provide interested persons an opportunity to comment prior to their adoption.\n\n\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall designate or maintain one or more contact points to address inquiries by interested persons concerning customs matters and make available on the internet information concerning the procedures for making such inquiries.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 6.3\n\n\n\nRelease of goods\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall adopt or maintain simplified customs procedures for the efficient release of goods in order to facilitate trade between the Parties and reduce costs for importers and exporters.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall ensure that these simplified procedures:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0allow for the release of goods within a period of time no longer than that required to ensure compliance with its law;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0allow goods, and to the extent possible controlled or regulated goods, to be released at the first point of arrival;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0endeavour to allow for the expeditious release of goods in need of emergency clearance;\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0allow an importer or its agent to remove goods from customs' control prior to the final determination and payment of customs duties, taxes, and fees. Before releasing the goods, a Party may require that an importer provide sufficient guarantee in the form of a surety, a deposit, or some other appropriate instrument; and\n\n\n\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0provide for, in accordance with its law, simplified documentation requirements for the entry of lowvalue goods as determined by each Party.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party, in its simplified procedures, may require the submission of more extensive information through postentry accounting and verifications, as appropriate.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall allow for the expedited release of goods and, to the extent possible and if applicable, shall:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0provide for advance electronic submission and processing of information before physical arrival of goods to enable their release upon arrival, if no risk has been identified or if no random checks are to be performed; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0provide for clearance of certain goods with a minimum of documentation.\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall, to the extent possible, ensure that its authorities and agencies involved in border and other import and export controls cooperate and coordinate to facilitate trade by, among other things, converging import and export data and documentation requirements and establishing a single location for onetime documentary and physical verification of consignments.\n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall ensure, to the extent possible, that its import and export requirements for goods are coordinated to facilitate trade, regardless of whether these requirements are administered by an agency or on behalf of that agency by the customs administration.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 6.4\n\n\n\nCustoms valuation\n\n\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Customs Valuation Agreement governs customs valuation applied to reciprocal trade between the Parties.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties shall cooperate with a view to reaching a common approach to issues relating to customs valuation.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 6.5\n\n\n\nClassification of goods\n\n\n\nThe classification of goods in trade between the Parties under this Agreement is set out in each Party's respective tariff nomenclature in conformity with the Harmonized System.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 6.6\n\n\n\nFees and charges\n\n\n\nEach Party shall publish or otherwise make available information on fees and charges imposed by a customs administration of that Party, including through electronic means. This information includes the applicable fees and charges, the specific reason for the fee or charge, the responsible authority, and when and how payment is to be made. A Party shall not impose new or amended fees and charges until it publishes or otherwise makes available this information.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 6.7\n\n\n\nRisk management\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall base its examination, release and postentry verification procedures on risk assessment principles, rather than requiring each shipment offered for entry to be examined in a comprehensive manner for compliance with import requirements.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall adopt and apply its import, export and transit requirements and procedures for goods on the basis of risk management principles and focus compliance measures on transactions that merit attention.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Paragraphs 1 and 2 do not preclude a Party from conducting quality control and compliance reviews that can require more extensive examinations.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 6.8\n\n\n\nAutomation\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall use information technologies that expedite its procedures for the release of goods in order to facilitate trade, including trade between the Parties.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall:\n\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0endeavour to make available by electronic means customs forms that are required for the import or export of goods;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0allow, subject to its law, those customs forms to be submitted in electronic format; and\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0if possible, through its customs administration, provide for the electronic exchange of information with its trading community.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall endeavour to:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0develop or maintain fully interconnected single window systems to facilitate a single, electronic submission of the information required by customs and noncustoms legislation for crossborder movements of goods; and\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0develop a set of data elements and processes in accordance with the World Customs Organization\u00a0(\"WCO\") Data Model and related WCO recommendations and guidelines.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties shall endeavour to cooperate on the development of interoperable electronic systems, including taking account of the work at the WCO, in order to facilitate trade between the\u00a0Parties.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 6.9\n\n\n\nAdvance rulings\n\n\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall issue, upon written request, advance rulings on tariff classification in accordance with its law.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Subject to confidentiality requirements, each Party shall publish, for example on the internet, information on advance rulings on tariff classification that is relevant to understand and apply tariff classification rules.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0To facilitate trade, the Parties shall include in their bilateral dialogue regular updates on changes in their respective laws and implementation measures regarding matters referred to in paragraphs 1 and 2.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 6.10\n\n\n\nReview and appeal\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall ensure that an administrative action or official decision taken in respect of the import of goods is reviewable promptly by judicial, arbitral, or administrative tribunals or through administrative procedures.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The tribunal or official acting pursuant to those administrative procedures shall be independent of the official or office issuing the decision and shall have the competence to maintain, modify or reverse the determination in accordance with the Party's law.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Before requiring a person to seek redress at a more formal or judicial level, each Party shall provide for an administrative level of appeal or review that is independent of the official or the office responsible for the original action or decision.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall grant substantially the same right of review and appeal of determinations of advance rulings by its customs administration that it provides to importers in its territory to a person that has received an advance ruling pursuant to Article 6.9.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 6.11\n\n\n\nPenalties\n\n\n\nEach Party shall ensure that its customs law provides that penalties imposed for breaches to it be proportionate and nondiscriminatory and that the application of these penalties does not result in unwarranted delays.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 6.12\n\n\n\nConfidentiality\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall, in accordance with its law, treat as strictly confidential all information obtained under this Chapter that is by its nature confidential or that is provided on a confidential basis, and shall protect that information from disclosure that could prejudice the competitive position of the person providing the information.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If the Party receiving or obtaining the information referred to in paragraph 1 is required by its law to disclose the information, that Party shall notify the Party or person who provided that\u00a0information.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall ensure that the confidential information collected under this Chapter shall not be used for purposes other than the administration and enforcement of customs matters, except with the permission of the Party or person that provided that confidential information.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party may allow information collected under this Chapter to be used in administrative, judicial or quasijudicial proceedings instituted for failure to comply with customsrelated laws implementing this Chapter. A Party shall notify the Party or person that provided the information in advance of such use.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 6.13\n\n\n\nCooperation\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties shall continue to cooperate in international fora, such as the WCO, to achieve mutuallyrecognised goals, including those set out in the WCO Framework of Standards to Secure and Facilitate Global Trade.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties shall regularly review relevant international initiatives on trade facilitation, including the Compendium of Trade Facilitation Recommendations developed by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development and the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe, to identify areas where further joint action would facilitate trade between the Parties and promote shared multilateral objectives.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties shall cooperate in accordance with the Agreement between Canada and the European Community on Customs Cooperation and Mutual Assistance in Customs Matters, done at Ottawa on 4 December 1997\u00a0(the \"CanadaEU Customs Cooperation Agreement\").\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties shall provide each other with mutual assistance in customs matters in accordance with the CanadaEU Customs Cooperation Agreement, including matters relating to a suspected breach of a Party's customs legislation, as defined in that agreement, and to the implementation of this Agreement.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 6.14\n\n\n\nJoint Customs Cooperation Committee\n\n\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Joint Customs Cooperation Committee, which is granted authority to act under the auspices of the CETA Joint Committee as a specialised committee pursuant to Article 26.2.1\u00a0(c)\u00a0(Specialised committees), shall ensure the proper functioning of this Chapter and the Protocol on Rules of Origin and Origin Procedures, as well as Article 20.43\u00a0(Scope of border measures) and Article 2.8\u00a0(Temporary suspension of preferential tariff treatment). The Joint Customs Cooperation Committee shall examine issues arising from their application in accordance with the objectives of this Agreement.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For matters covered by this Agreement, the Joint Customs Cooperation Committee shall comprise representatives of the customs, trade, or other competent authorities as each Party deems appropriate.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall ensure that its representatives in Joint Customs Cooperation Committee meetings have an expertise that corresponds to the agenda items. The Joint Customs Cooperation Committee may meet in a specific configuration of expertise to deal with rules of origin or origin procedures matters\u00a0either as the Joint Customs Cooperation CommitteeRules of Origin or the Joint Customs Cooperation CommitteeOrigin Procedures.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Joint Customs Cooperation Committee may formulate resolutions, recommendations, or opinions and present draft decisions to the CETA Joint Committee that it considers necessary for the attainment of the common objectives and sound functioning of the mechanisms established in this Chapter and the Protocol on Rules of Origin and Origin Procedures, as well as Article 20.43\u00a0(Scope of border measures) and Article 2.8\u00a0(Temporary suspension of preferential tariff treatment).\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER SEVEN\n\n\n\nSUBSIDIES\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 7.1\n\n\n\nDefinition of a subsidy\n\n\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purposes of this Agreement, a subsidy means a measure related to trade in goods, which fulfils the conditions set out in Article 1.1 of the SCM Agreement.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A subsidy is subject to this Chapter only if it is specific within the meaning of Article 2 of the SCM Agreement.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 7.2\n\n\n\nTransparency\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Every two years, each Party shall notify the other Party of the following with respect to any subsidy granted or maintained within its territory:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the legal basis of the subsidy;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the form of the subsidy; and\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the amount of the subsidy or the amount budgeted for the subsidy.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Notifications provided to the WTO under Article 25.1 of the SCM Agreement are deemed to meet the requirement set out in paragraph 1.\n\n\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0At the request of the other Party, a Party shall promptly provide information and respond to questions pertaining to particular instances of government support related to trade in services provided within its territory.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 7.3\n\n\n\nConsultations on subsidies and government support \nin sectors other than agriculture and fisheries\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If a Party considers that a subsidy, or a particular instance of government support related to trade in services, granted by the other Party is adversely affecting, or may adversely affect its interests, it may express its concerns to the other Party and request consultations on the matter. The responding Party shall accord full and sympathetic consideration to that request.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0During consultations, a Party may seek additional information on a subsidy or particular instance of government support related to trade in services provided by the other Party, including its policy objective, its amount, and any measures taken to limit the potential distortive effect on trade.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0On the basis of the consultations, the responding Party shall endeavour to eliminate or minimise any adverse effects of the subsidy, or the particular instance of government support related to trade in services, on the requesting Party's interests.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This Article does not apply to subsidies related to agricultural goods and fisheries products, and is without prejudice to Articles 7.4 and 7.5.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 7.4\n\n\n\n\n\nConsultations on subsidies related to agricultural \ngoods and fisheries products\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties share the objective of working jointly to reach an agreement:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0to further enhance multilateral disciplines and rules on agricultural trade in the WTO; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0to help develop a global, multilateral resolution to fisheries subsidies.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If a Party considers that a subsidy, or the provision of government support, granted by the other Party, is adversely affecting, or may adversely affect, its interests with respect to agricultural goods or fisheries products, it may express its concerns to the other Party and request consultations on the matter.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The responding Party shall accord full and sympathetic consideration to that request and will use its best endeavours to eliminate or minimise the adverse effects of the subsidy, or the provision of government support, on the requesting Party's interests with regard to agricultural goods and fisheries products.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 7.5\n\n\n\nAgriculture export subsidies\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purposes of this Article:\n\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0export subsidy means an export subsidy as defined in Article 1(e) of the Agreement on Agriculture; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0full elimination of a tariff means, where tariff quotas exist, the elimination of either the inquota or overquota tariff.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party shall not adopt or maintain an export subsidy on an agricultural good that is exported, or incorporated in a product that is exported, to the territory of the other Party after the other Party has fully eliminated the tariff, immediately or after the transitional period, on that agricultural good in accordance with Annex 2A\u00a0(Tariff Elimination), including its Tariff Schedules.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 7.6\n\n\n\nConfidentiality\n\n\n\nWhen providing information under this Chapter, a Party is not required to disclose confidential\u00a0information.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 7.7\n\n\n\nExclusion of subsidies and government support \nfor audiovisual services and cultural industries\n\n\n\nNothing in this Agreement applies to subsidies or government support with respect to audiovisual services for the European Union and to cultural industries for Canada.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 7.8\n\n\n\nRelationship with the WTO Agreement\n\n\n\nThe Parties reaffirm their rights and obligations under Article VI of GATT 1994, the SCM\u00a0Agreement and the Agreement on Agriculture.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 7.9\n\n\n\nDispute settlement\n\n\n\nArticles 7.3 and 7.4 of this Chapter are not subject to the dispute settlement provisions of this\u00a0Agreement.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER EIGHT\n\n\n\nINVESTMENT\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSECTION A\n\n\n\nDefinitions and scope\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 8.1\n\n\n\nDefinitions\n\n\n\nFor the purposes of this Chapter:\n\n\n\nactivities carried out in the exercise of governmental authority means activities carried out neither on a commercial basis nor in competition with one or more economic operators;\n\n\n\naircraft repair and maintenance services means activities undertaken on an aircraft or a part of an aircraft while it is withdrawn from service and do not include socalled line maintenance;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nairport operation services means the operation or management, on a fee or contract basis, of airport infrastructure, including terminals, runways, taxiways and aprons, parking facilities, and intraairport transportation systems. For greater certainty, airport operation services do not include the ownership of, or investment in, airports or airport lands, or any of the functions carried out by a board of directors. Airport operation services do not include air navigation services;\n\n\n\nattachment means the seizure of property of a disputing party to secure or ensure the satisfaction of an award;\n\n\n\n\n\ncomputer reservation system services means the supply of a service by computerised systems that contain information about air carriers' schedules, availability, fares and fare rules, through which reservations can be made or tickets may be issued;\n\n\n\nconfidential or protected information means:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0confidential business information; or\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0information which is protected against disclosure to the public;\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in the case of information of the respondent, under the law of the respondent;\n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in the case of other information, under a law or rules that the Tribunal determines to be applicable to the disclosure of such information;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\ncovered investment means, with respect to a Party, an investment:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in its territory;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0made in accordance with the applicable law at the time the investment is made;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0directly or indirectly owned or controlled by an investor of the other Party; and\n\n\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0existing on the date of entry into force of this Agreement, or made or acquired thereafter;\n\n\n\ndisputing party means the investor that initiates proceedings pursuant to Section F or the respondent. For the purposes of Section F and without prejudice to Article 8.14, an investor does not include a Party;\n\n\n\ndisputing parties means both the investor and the respondent;\n\n\n\nenjoin means an order to prohibit or restrain an action;\n\n\n\nenterprise means an enterprise as defined in Article 1.1\u00a0(Definitions of general application) and a branch or representative office of an enterprise;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nground handling services means the supply of a service on a fee or contract basis for: ground administration and supervision, including load control and communications; passenger handling; baggage handling; cargo and mail handling; ramp handling and aircraft services; fuel and oil handling; aircraft line maintenance, flight operations and crew administration; surface transport; or catering services. Ground handling services do not include security services or the operation or management of centralised airport infrastructure, such as baggage handling systems, deicing facilities, fuel distribution systems, or intraairport transport systems;\n\n\n\nICSID means the International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes;\n\n\n\nICSID Additional Facility Rules means the Rules Governing the Additional Facility for the Administration of Proceedings by the Secretariat of the International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes;\n\n\n\nICSID Convention means the Convention on the Settlement of Investment Disputes between States and Nationals of other States, done at Washington on 18 March 1965;\n\n\n\n\n\nintellectual property rights means copyright and related rights, trademark rights, rights in geographical indications, rights in industrial designs, patent rights, rights in layout designs of integrated circuits, rights in relation to protection of undisclosed information, and plant breeders' rights; and, if such rights are provided by a Party's law, utility model rights. The CETA Joint Committee may, by decision, add other categories of intellectual property to this definition;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\ninvestment means every kind of asset that an investor owns or controls, directly or indirectly, that has the characteristics of an investment, which includes a certain duration and other characteristics such as the commitment of capital or other resources, the expectation of gain or profit, or the assumption of risk. Forms that an investment may take include:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0an enterprise;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0shares, stocks and other forms of equity participation in an enterprise;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0bonds, debentures and other debt instruments of an enterprise;\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a loan to an enterprise;\n\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0any other kind of interest in an enterprise;\n\n\n\n(f)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0an interest arising from:\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a concession conferred pursuant to the law of a Party or under a contract, including to search for, cultivate, extract or exploit natural resources,\n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a turnkey, construction, production or revenuesharing contract; or\n\n\n\n\n\n(iii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0other similar contracts;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(g)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0intellectual property rights;\n\n\n\n(h)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0other moveable property, tangible or intangible, or immovable property and related rights;\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0claims to money or claims to performance under a contract.\n\n\n\nFor greater certainty, claims to money does not include:\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0claims to money that arise solely from commercial contracts for the sale of goods or services by a\u00a0natural person or enterprise in the territory of a Party to a natural person or enterprise in the territory of\u00a0the other Party.\n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the domestic financing of such contracts; or\n\n\n\n(iii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0any order, judgment, or arbitral award related to sub-subparagraph (i) or\u00a0(ii).\n\n\n\nReturns that are invested shall be treated as investments. Any alteration of the form in which assets are invested or reinvested does not affect their qualification as investment;\n\n\n\n\n\ninvestor means a Party, a natural person or an enterprise of a Party, other than a branch or a representative office, that seeks to make, is making or has made an investment in the territory of the other Party;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nFor the purposes of this definition, an enterprise of a Party is:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0an enterprise that is constituted or organised under the laws of that Party and has substantial business activities in the territory of that Party; or\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0an enterprise that is constituted or organised under the laws of that Party and is directly or indirectly owned or controlled by a natural person of that Party or by an enterprise mentioned under\u00a0paragraph (a);\n\n\n\nlocally established enterprise means a juridical person that is constituted or organised under the laws of the respondent and that an investor of the other Party owns or controls directly or indirectly;\n\n\n\nnatural person means:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in the case of Canada, a natural person who is a citizen or permanent resident of Canada; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in the case of the EU Party, a natural person having the nationality of one of the Member States of the European Union according to their respective laws, and, for Latvia, also a natural person permanently residing in the Republic of Latvia who is not a citizen of the Republic of Latvia or any other state but who is entitled, under laws and regulations of the Republic of Latvia, to receive a noncitizen's passport.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nA natural person who is a citizen of Canada and has the nationality of one of the Member States of the European Union is deemed to be exclusively a natural person of the Party of his or her dominant and effective nationality.\n\n\n\n\n\nA natural person who has the nationality of one of the Member States of the European Union or is a citizen of Canada, and is also a permanent resident of the other Party, is deemed to be exclusively a natural person of the Party of his or her nationality or citizenship, as applicable;\n\n\n\nNew York Convention means the United Nations Convention on the Recognition and Enforcement of Foreign Arbitral Awards, done at New York on 10 June 1958;\n\n\n\nnondisputing Party means Canada, if the European Union or a Member State of the European Union is the respondent, or the European Union, if Canada is the respondent;\n\n\n\nrespondent means Canada or, in the case of the European Union, either the Member State of the European Union or the European Union pursuant to Article 8.21;\n\n\n\nreturns means all amounts yielded by an investment or reinvestment, including profits, royalties and interest or other fees and payments in kind;\n\n\n\nselling and marketing of air transport services means opportunities for the air carrier concerned to sell and market freely its air transport services including all aspects of marketing such as market research, advertising and distribution, but does not include the pricing of air transport services or the applicable conditions;\n\n\n\nthird party funding means any funding provided by a natural or legal person who is not a disputing party but who enters into an agreement with a disputing party in order to finance part or all of the cost of the proceedings either through a donation or grant, or in return for remuneration dependent on the outcome of the dispute.\n\n\n\nTribunal means the tribunal established under Article 8.27;\n\n\n\nUNCITRAL Arbitration Rules means the arbitration rules of the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law; and\n\n\n\nUNCITRAL Transparency Rules means the UNCITRAL Rules on Transparency in Treatybased InvestorState Arbitration;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 8.2\n\n\n\nScope\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This Chapter applies to a measure adopted or maintained by a Party in its territory\n5\n relating to:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0an investor of the other Party;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a covered investment; and\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0with respect to Article 8.5, any investments in its territory.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0With respect to the establishment or acquisition of a covered investment\n6\n, Sections B and C do not apply to a measure relating to:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0air services, or related services in support of air services and other services supplied by means of air transport\n7\n, other than:\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0aircraft repair and maintenance services;\n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the selling and marketing of air transport services;\n\n\n\n\n\n(iii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0computer reservation system\u00a0(CRS) services;\n\n\n\n(iv)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0ground handling services;\n\n\n\n(v)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0airport operation services; or\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0activities carried out in the exercise of governmental authority.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the EU Party, Sections B and C do not apply to a measure with respect to audiovisual services. For Canada, Sections B and C do not apply to a measure with respect to cultural industries.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Claims may be submitted by an investor under this Chapter only in accordance with Article\u00a08.18, and in compliance with the procedures set out in Section F. Claims in respect of an obligation set out in Section B are excluded from the scope of Section F. Claims under Section C with respect to the establishment or acquisition of a covered investment are excluded from the scope of Section F. Section D applies only to a covered investment and to investors in respect of their covered investment.\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This Chapter does not affect the rights and obligations of the Parties under the Agreement on Air Transport between Canada and the European Community and its Member States, done at Brussels on 17 December 2009 and Ottawa on 18 December 2009.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 8.3\n\n\n\nRelation to other chapters\n\n\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This Chapter does not apply to measures adopted or maintained by a Party to the extent that the measures apply to investors or to their investments covered by Chapter Thirteen (Financial\u00a0Services).\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A requirement by a Party that a service supplier of the other Party post a bond or other form of financial security as a condition for supplying a service in its territory does not of itself make this Chapter applicable to measures adopted or maintained by the Party relating to the supply of that crossborder service. This Chapter applies to measures adopted or maintained by the Party relating to the posted bond or financial security to the extent that such bond or financial security is a covered investment.\n\n\n\n\nSECTION B\n\n\n\nEstablishment of investments\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 8.4\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party shall not adopt or maintain with respect to market access through establishment by an investor of the other Party, on the basis of its entire territory or on the basis of the territory of a national, provincial, territorial, regional or local level of government, a measure that:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0imposes limitations on:\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the number of enterprises that may carry out a specific economic activity whether in the form of numerical quotas, monopolies, exclusive suppliers or the requirement of an economic needs test;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the total value of transactions or assets in the form of numerical quotas or the requirement of an economic needs test;\n\n\n\n(iii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the total number of operations or the total quantity of output expressed in terms of designated numerical units in the form of quotas or the requirement of an economic needs test;\n8\n\n\n\n\n(iv)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the participation of foreign capital in terms of maximum percentage limit on foreign shareholding or the total value of individual or aggregate foreign investment; or\n\n\n\n(v)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the total number of natural persons that may be employed in a particular sector or that an enterprise may employ and who are necessary for, and directly related to, the performance of economic activity in the form of numerical quotas or the requirement of an economic needs test; or\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0restricts or requires specific types of legal entity or joint venture through which an enterprise may carry out an economic activity.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For greater certainty, the following are consistent with paragraph 1:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a measure concerning zoning and planning regulations affecting the development or use of land, or another analogous measure;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a measure requiring the separation of the ownership of infrastructure from the ownership of the goods or services provided through that infrastructure to ensure fair competition, for example in the fields of energy, transportation and telecommunications;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a measure restricting the concentration of ownership to ensure fair competition;\n\n\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a measure seeking to ensure the conservation and protection of natural resources and the environment, including a limitation on the availability, number and scope of concessions granted, and the imposition of a moratorium or ban;\n\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a measure limiting the number of authorisations granted because of technical or physical constraints, for example telecommunications spectrum and frequencies; or\n\n\n\n(f)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a measure requiring that a certain percentage of the shareholders, owners, partners, or directors of an enterprise be qualified or practice a certain profession such as lawyers or accountants.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 8.5\n\n\n\nPerformance requirements\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party shall not impose, or enforce the following requirements, or enforce a commitment or undertaking, in connection with the establishment, acquisition, expansion, conduct, operation, and management of any investments in its territory to:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0export a given level or percentage of a good or service;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0achieve a given level or percentage of domestic content;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0purchase, use or accord a preference to a good produced or service provided in its territory, or to purchase a good or service from natural persons or enterprises in its territory;\n\n\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0relate the volume or value of imports to the volume or value of exports or to the amount of foreign exchange inflows associated with that investment;\n\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0restrict sales of a good or service in its territory that the investment produces or provides by relating those sales to the volume or value of its exports or foreign exchange earnings;\n\n\n\n(f)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0transfer technology, a production process or other proprietary knowledge to a natural person or enterprise in its territory; or\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(g)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0supply exclusively from the territory of the Party a good produced or a service provided by the investment to a specific regional or world market.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party shall not condition the receipt or continued receipt of an advantage, in connection with the establishment, acquisition, expansion, management, conduct or operation of any investments in its territory, on compliance with any of the following requirements:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0to achieve a given level or percentage of domestic content;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0to purchase, use or accord a preference to a good produced in its territory, or to purchase a good from a producer in its territory;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0to relate the volume or value of imports to the volume or value of exports or to the amount of foreign exchange inflows associated with that investment; or\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0to restrict sales of a good or service in its territory that the investment produces or provides by relating those sales to the volume or value of its exports or foreign exchange earnings.\n\n\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Paragraph 2 does not prevent a Party from conditioning the receipt or continued receipt of an advantage, in connection with an investment in its territory, on compliance with a requirement to locate production, provide a service, train or employ workers, construct or expand particular facilities, or carry out research and development in its territory.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Subparagraph 1(f) does not apply if the requirement is imposed or the commitment or undertaking is enforced by a court, administrative tribunal or competition authority to remedy a violation of competition laws.\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The provisions of:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0subparagraphs 1(a),\u00a0(b) and\u00a0(c), and 2(a) and\u00a0(b), do not apply to qualification requirements for a good or service with respect to participation in export promotion and foreign aid programs;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0this Article does not apply to procurement by a Party of a good or service purchased for governmental purposes and not with a view to commercial resale or with a view to use in the supply of a good or service for commercial sale, whether or not that procurement is \"covered procurement\" within the meaning of Article 19.2\u00a0(Scope and coverage).\n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For greater certainty, subparagraphs 2(a) and\u00a0(b) do not apply to requirements imposed by an importing Party relating to the content of a good necessary to qualify for preferential tariffs or preferential quotas.\n\n\n\n7.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This Article is without prejudice to World Trade Organization commitments of a Party.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSECTION C\n\n\n\nNondiscriminatory treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 8.6\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall accord to an investor of the other Party and to a covered investment, treatment no less favourable than the treatment it accords, in like situations to its own investors and to their investments with respect to the establishment, acquisition, expansion, conduct, operation, management, maintenance, use, enjoyment and sale or disposal of their investments in its territory.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The treatment accorded by a Party under paragraph 1 means, with respect to a government in Canada other than at the federal level, or, with respect to a government of or in a Member State of the European Union, treatment no less favourable than the most favourable treatment accorded, in like situations, by that government to investors of that Party in its territory and to investments of such investors.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 8.7\n\n\n\nMostfavourednation treatment\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall accord to an investor of the other Party and to a covered investment, treatment no less favourable than the treatment it accords in like situations, to investors of a third country and to their investments with respect to the establishment, acquisition, expansion, conduct, operation, management, maintenance, use, enjoyment and sale or disposal of their investments in its territory.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For greater certainty, the treatment accorded by a Party under paragraph 1 means, with respect to a government in Canada other than at the federal level, or, with respect to a government of or in a Member State of the European Union, treatment accorded, in like situations, by that government to investors in its territory, and to investments of such investors, of\u00a0a third country.\n\n\n\n\n\n3\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Paragraph 1 does not apply to treatment accorded by a Party providing for recognition,\u00a0including through an arrangement or agreement with a third country that recognises the accreditation of testing and analysis services and service suppliers, the accreditation of repair and maintenance services and service suppliers, as well as the certification of the qualifications of or the results of or work done by those accredited services and service suppliers.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For greater certainty, the \"treatment\" referred to in paragraphs 1 and 2 does not include procedures for the resolution of investment disputes between investors and states provided for in other international investment treaties and other trade agreements. Substantive obligations in other international investment treaties and other trade agreements do not in themselves constitute \"treatment\", and thus cannot give rise to a breach of this Article, absent measures adopted or maintained by a Party pursuant to those obligations.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 8.8\n\n\n\nSenior management and boards of directors\n\n\n\nA Party shall not require that an enterprise of that Party, that is also a covered investment, appoint to senior management or board of director positions, natural persons of any particular nationality.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSECTION D\n\n\nInvestment protection\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 8.9\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and regulatory measures\n\n\n\n1. \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purpose of this Chapter, the Parties reaffirm their right to regulate within their territories to achieve legitimate policy objectives, such as the protection of public health, safety, the environment or public morals, social or consumer protection or the promotion and protection of cultural diversity.\n\n\n\n2. \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For greater certainty, the mere fact that a Party regulates, including through a modification to its laws, in a manner which negatively affects an investment or interferes with an investor\u2019s expectations, including its expectations of profits, does not amount to a breach of an obligation under this Section. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n3. \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For greater certainty, a Party\u2019s decision not to issue, renew or maintain a subsidy: \n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in the absence of any specific commitment under law or contract to issue, renew, or maintain that subsidy;
