test.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 9.7\n\n\n\nReservations\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Articles 9.3, 9.5 and 9.6 do not apply to:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0an existing nonconforming measure that is maintained by a Party at the level of:\n\n\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the European Union, as set out in its Schedule to Annex I;\n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a national government, as set out by that Party in its Schedule to Annex I;\n\n\n\n(iii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a provincial, territorial, or regional government, as set out by that Party in its Schedule to Annex I; or\n\n\n\n(iv)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a local government.\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the continuation or prompt renewal of a nonconforming measure referred to in subparagraph\u00a0(a); or\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0an amendment to a nonconforming measure referred to in subparagraph\u00a0(a) to the extent that the amendment does not decrease the conformity of the measure, as it existed immediately before the amendment, with Articles 9.3, 9.5, and 9.6.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Articles 9.3, 9.5, and 9.6 do not apply to a measure that a Party adopts or maintains with respect to a sector, subsector or activity, as set out in its Schedule to Annex II.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 9.8\n\n\n\nDenial of benefits\n\n\n\n\n\nA Party may deny the benefits of this Chapter to a service supplier of the other Party that is an enterprise of that Party and to services of that service supplier if:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a service supplier of a third country owns or controls the enterprise; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the denying Party adopts or maintains a measure with respect to the third country that:\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0relates to maintenance of international peace and security; and\n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0prohibits transactions with the enterprise or would be violated or circumvented if the benefits of this Chapter were accorded to the enterprise.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER TEN\n\n\n\nTEMPORARY ENTRY AND STAY OF NATURAL PERSONS \nFOR BUSINESS PURPOSES\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 10.1\n\n\n\nDefinitions\n\n\n\n\n\nFor the purposes of this Chapter:\n\n\n\ncontractual services suppliers means natural persons employed by an enterprise of one Party that has no establishment in the territory of the other Party and that has concluded a bona fide contract\u00a0(other than through an agency as defined by CPC 872) to supply a service to a consumer of the other Party that requires the presence on a temporary basis of its employees in the territory of the other Party in order to fulfil the contract to supply a service;\n\n\n\nenterprise means an \"enterprise\" as defined in Article 8.1\u00a0(Definitions);\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nindependent professionals means natural persons engaged in the supply of a service and established as selfemployed in the territory of a Party who have no establishment in the territory of the other Party and who have concluded a bona fide contract\u00a0(other than through an agency as defined by CPC 872) to supply a service to a consumer of the other Party that requires the presence of the natural person on a temporary basis in the territory of the other Party in order to fulfil the contract to supply a service;\n\n\n\nkey personnel means business visitors for investment purposes, investors, or intracorporate transferees:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0business visitors for investment purposes means natural persons working in a managerial or specialist position who are responsible for setting up an enterprise but who do not engage in direct transactions with the general public and do not receive remuneration from a source located within the territory of the host Party;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0investors means natural persons who establish, develop, or administer the operation of an investment in a capacity that is supervisory or executive, and to which those persons or the enterprise employing those persons has committed, or is in the process of committing, a substantial amount of capital; and\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0intracorporate transferees means natural persons who have been employed by an enterprise of a Party or have been partners in an enterprise of a Party for at least one year and who are temporarily transferred to an enterprise\u00a0(that may be a subsidiary, branch, or head company of the enterprise of a Party) in the territory of the other Party. This natural person must belong to one of the following categories:\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0senior personnel means natural persons working in a senior position within an enterprise who:\n\n\n\n\n\n(A)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0primarily direct the management of the enterprise or direct the enterprise, or a department or subdivision of the enterprise; and\n\n\n\n(B)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0exercise wide latitude in decision making, which may include having the authority to personally recruit and dismiss or to take other personnel actions\u00a0(such as promotion or leave authorisations), and\n\n\n\n(I)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0receive only general supervision or direction principally from higher level executives, the board of directors, or stockholders of the business or their equivalent; or\n\n\n\n(II)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0supervise and control the work of other supervisory, professional or managerial employees and exercise discretionary authority over daytoday operations; or\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0specialists means natural persons working in an enterprise who possess:\n\n\n\n(A)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0uncommon knowledge of the enterprise's products or services and its application in international markets; or\n\n\n\n(B)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0an advanced level of expertise or knowledge of the enterprise's processes and procedures such as its production, research equipment, techniques, or management.\n\n\n\nIn assessing such expertise or knowledge, the Parties will consider abilities that are unusual and different from those generally found in a particular industry and that cannot be easily transferred to another natural person in the shortterm. Those abilities would have been obtained through specific academic qualifications or extensive experience with the enterprise; or\n\n\n\n(iii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0graduate trainees means natural persons who:\n\n\n\n\n\n(A)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0possess a university degree; and\n\n\n\n(B)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0are temporarily transferred to an enterprise in the territory of the other Party for career development purposes, or to obtain training in business techniques or methods; and\n\n\n\nnatural persons for business purposes means key personnel, contractual services suppliers, independent professionals, or shortterm business visitors who are citizens of a Party.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 10.2\n\n\n\nObjectives and scope\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This Chapter reflects the preferential trading relationship between the Parties as well as the mutual objective to facilitate trade in services and investment by allowing\u00a0temporary entry and stay to natural persons for business purposes and by ensuring transparency in the process.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This Chapter applies to measures adopted or maintained by a Party concerning the temporary entry and stay into its territory of key personnel, contractual services suppliers, independent professionals and shortterm business visitors. This Chapter shall not apply to measures affecting natural persons seeking access to the employment market of a Party, nor shall it apply to measures regarding citizenship, residence, or employment on a permanent basis.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Nothing in this Chapter shall prevent a Party from applying measures to regulate the entry of natural persons into, or their temporary stay in, its territory, including those measures necessary to protect the integrity of, and to ensure the orderly movement of natural persons across its borders, provided that such measures are not applied in such a manner as to nullify or impair the benefits accruing to any Party under the terms of this Chapter. The sole fact of requiring a visa for natural persons of a certain country and not for those of others shall not be regarded as nullifying or impairing benefits under this Chapter.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0To the extent that commitments are not taken in this Chapter, all other requirements of the laws of the Parties regarding entry and stay continue to apply, including those concerning period of stay.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Notwithstanding the provisions of this Chapter, all requirements of the Parties' laws regarding employment and social security measures shall continue to apply, including regulations concerning minimum wages as well as collective wage agreements.\n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This Chapter does not apply to cases where the intent or effect of the temporary entry and stay is to interfere with or otherwise affect the outcome of a labour or management dispute or negotiation, or the employment of natural persons who are involved in such dispute or negotiation.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 10.3\n\n\n\nGeneral obligations\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall allow temporary entry to natural persons for business purposes of the other Party who otherwise comply with the Party's immigration measures applicable to temporary entry, in accordance with this Chapter.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall apply its measures relating to the provisions of this Chapter in accordance with Article 10.2.1, and, in particular, shall apply those measures so as to avoid unduly impairing or delaying trade in goods or services or the conduct of investment activities under this Agreement.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall ensure that any fees for processing applications for temporary entry are reasonable and commensurate with the costs incurred.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 10.4\n\n\n\nProvision of information\n\n\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Further to Chapter TwentySeven\u00a0(Transparency), and recognising the importance to the Parties of transparency of temporary entry information, each Party shall, no later than 180 days after the date of entry into force of this Agreement, make available to the other Party explanatory material regarding the requirements for temporary entry under this Chapter that enables business persons of the other Party to be acquainted with those requirements.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If a Party collects and maintains data relating to temporary entry by category of business persons under this Chapter, the Party shall make this data available to the other Party on request, in accordance with its law related to privacy and data protection.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 10.5\n\n\n\nContact points\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties hereby establish the following contact points:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in the case of Canada:\n\n\n\nDirector\n\n\nTemporary Resident Policy\n\n\nImmigration Branch\n\n\nCitizenship and Immigration Canada\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in the case of the European Union:\n\n\n\nDirectorGeneral\n\n\nDirectorate General for Trade\n\n\nEuropean Commission\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in the case of the Member States of the European Union, the contact points listed in Annex10A or their respective successors.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The contact points for Canada and the European Union, and as appropriate the contact points for Member States of the European Union, shall exchange information pursuant to Article 10.4 and shall meet as required to consider matters pertaining to this Chapter, such as:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the implementation and administration of this Chapter, including the practice of the Parties in allowing temporary entry;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the development and adoption of common criteria as well as interpretations for the implementation of this Chapter;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the development of measures to further facilitate temporary entry of business persons; and\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0recommendations to the CETA Joint Committee concerning this Chapter.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 10.6\n\n\n\nObligations in other chapters\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This Agreement does not impose an obligation on a Party regarding its immigration measures, except as specifically identified in this Chapter and in Chapter TwentySeven\u00a0(Transparency).\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Without prejudice to any decision to allow temporary entry to natural persons of the other Party within the terms of this Chapter, including the length of stay permissible pursuant to such an allowance:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Articles 9.3\u00a0(National treatment) and 9.6\u00a0(Market access), subject to Articles 9.4\u00a0(Formal requirements) and 9.2\u00a0(Scope) but not Article 9.2.2(d), are incorporated into and made part of this Chapter and apply to the treatment of natural persons for business purposes present in the territory of the other Party under the categories of:\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0key personnel; and\n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0contractual services suppliers, and independent professionals for all sectors listed in Annex 10E; and\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Article 9.5\u00a0(Mostfavourednation treatment), subject to Articles 9.4\u00a0(Formal requirements) and 9.2\u00a0(Scope) but not Article 9.2.2(d), is incorporated into and made part of this Chapter and applies to the treatment of natural persons for business purposes present in the territory of the other Party under the categories of:\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0key personnel, contractual services suppliers, and independent professionals; and\n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0shortterm business visitors, as set out in Article 10.9.\n\n\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For greater certainty, paragraph 2 applies to the treatment of natural persons for business purposes present in the territory of the other Party and falling within the relevant categories and who are supplying financial services, as defined in Article 13.1\u00a0(Definitions) of Chapter Thirteen\u00a0(Financial Services). Paragraph 2 does not apply to measures relating to the granting of temporary entry to natural persons of a Party or of a third country.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If a Party has set out a reservation in its Schedule to Annex I, II or III, the reservation also constitutes a reservation to paragraph 2, to the extent that the measure set out in or permitted by the reservation affects the treatment of natural persons for business purposes present in the territory of the other Party.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 10.7\n\n\n\nKey personnel\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall allow the temporary entry and stay of key personnel of the other Party subject to the reservations and exceptions listed in Annex 10B.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall not adopt or maintain limitations on the total number of key personnel of the other Party allowed temporary entry, in the form of a numerical restriction or an economic needs test.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall allow the temporary entry of business visitors for investment purposes without requiring a work permit or other prior approval procedure of similar intent.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall allow the temporary employment in its territory of intracorporate transferees and investors of the other Party.\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The permissible length of\u00a0stay\u00a0of key personnel is as follows:\n\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0intracorporate transferees\u00a0(specialists and senior personnel): the lesser of three years or the length of the contract, with a possible extension of up to 18 months at the discretion of the Party granting the temporary entry and stay\n14\n;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0intracorporate transferees\u00a0(graduate trainees): the lesser of one year or the length of the contract;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0investors: one year, with possible extensions at the discretion of the Party granting the temporary entry and stay;\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0business visitors for investment purposes: 90 days within any six month period\n15\n.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 10.8\n\n\n\nContractual services suppliers and independent professionals\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0In accordance with Annex 10E, each Party shall allow the temporary entry and stay of contractual services suppliers of the other Party, subject to the following conditions:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the natural persons must be engaged in the supply of a service on a temporary basis as employees of an enterprise which has obtained a service contract for a period not exceeding\u00a012\u00a0months. If the service contract is longer than 12 months, the commitments in this Chapter only apply for the initial 12 months of the contract;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the natural persons entering the territory of the other Party must be offering those services as employees of the enterprise supplying the services for at least the year immediately preceding the date of submission of an application for entry into the territory of the other Party and must possess, at the date of the submission, at least three years of professional experience\n16\n in the sector of activity that is the subject of the contract;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the natural persons entering the territory of the other Party must possess,\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a university degree or a qualification demonstrating knowledge of an equivalent level;\n17\n\u00a0and\n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0professional qualifications, if this is required to practice an activity pursuant to the laws or requirements of the Party where the service is supplied;\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the natural persons must not receive remuneration for the provision of services other than the remuneration paid by the enterprise employing the contractual services suppliers during their stay in the territory of the other Party;\n\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the temporary entry and stay accorded under this Article relate only to the supply of a service which is the subject of the contract. Entitlement to utilise the professional title of the Party where the service is provided may be granted, as required, by the relevant authority as defined in Article 11.1\u00a0(Definitions), through a Mutual Recognition Agreement\u00a0(\"MRA\") or otherwise; and\n\n\n\n(f)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the service contract must comply with the laws and other legal requirements of the Party where the contract is executed.\n18\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0In accordance with Annex 10E, each Party shall allow the temporary entry and stay of independent professionals of the other Party, subject to the following conditions:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the natural\u00a0persons must be engaged in the supply of a service on a temporary basis as selfemployed persons established in the other Party and must have obtained a service contract for a period not exceeding 12 months. If the service contract is longer than\u00a012\u00a0months, the commitments in this Chapter shall only apply for the initial 12 months of the contract;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the natural persons entering the territory of the other Party must possess, at the date of submission of an application for entry into the other Party, at least six years professional experience in the sector of activity which is the subject of the contract;\n\n\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the natural persons entering the territory of the other Party must possess,\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a university degree or a qualification demonstrating knowledge of an equivalent level;\n19\n and\n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0professional qualifications, if this is required to practice an activity pursuant to the laws, or requirements of the Party where the service is supplied;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the temporary entry and stay accorded under the provisions of this Article relate only to the supply of a service which is the subject of the contract. Entitlement to utilise the professional title of the Party where the service is provided may be granted, as required, by the relevant authority as defined in Article 11.1\u00a0(Definitions), through an MRA or otherwise; and\n\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the service contract must comply with the laws and other legal requirements of the Party where the contract is executed.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Unless otherwise specified in Annex 10E, a Party shall not adopt or maintain a limitation on the total number of contractual services suppliers and independent professionals of the other Party allowed temporary entry, in the form of numerical restrictions or an economic needs test.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The length of stay\u00a0of contractual services supplier or independent professionals is for a cumulative period of not more than 12 months, with extensions possible at the discretion of the Party, in any 24 month period or for the duration of the contract, whichever is less.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 10.9\n\n\n\nShortterm business visitors\n\n\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0In accordance with Annex 10B, a Party shall allow the temporary entry and stay of shortterm business visitors of the other Party for the purposes of carrying out the activities listed in Annex 10D, provided that the shortterm business visitors:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0are not engaged in selling a good or a service to the general public;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0do not on their own behalf receive remuneration from a source located within the Party where the shortterm business visitors are staying temporarily; and\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0are not engaged in the supply of a service in the framework of a contract concluded between an enterprise that has no commercial presence in the territory of the Party where the shortterm business visitors are staying temporarily, and a consumer in that territory, except as provided in Annex 10D.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall allow temporary entry of shortterm business visitors without the requirement of a work permit or other prior approval procedures of similar intent.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The maximum length of stay\u00a0of shortterm business visitors is 90 days in any sixmonth period.\n20\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 10.10\n\n\n\nReview of commitments\n\n\n\nWithin five years following the entry into force of this Agreement, the Parties shall consider updating their respective commitments under Articles 10.7 through 10.9.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER ELEVEN\n\n\n\nMUTUAL RECOGNITION OF PROFESSIONAL QUALIFICATIONS\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 11.1\n\n\n\nDefinitions\n\n\n\nFor the purposes of this Chapter:\n\n\n\njurisdiction means the territory of Canada, and each of its provinces and territories, or the territory of each of the Member States of the European Union, in\u00a0so\u00a0far as this Agreement applies in these territories in accordance with Article 1.3\u00a0(Geographical scope of application);\n\n\n\nnegotiating entity means a person or body of a Party entitled or empowered to negotiate an agreement on the mutual recognition of professional qualifications\u00a0(\"MRA\");\n\n\n\nprofessional experience means the effective and lawful practice of a service;\n\n\n\n\n\nprofessional qualifications means the qualifications attested by evidence of formal qualification and/or professional experience;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nrelevant authority means an authority or body, designated pursuant to legislative, regulatory or administrative provisions to recognise qualifications and authorise the practice of a profession in a jurisdiction; and\n\n\n\nregulated profession means a service, the practice of which, including the use of a title or designation, is subject to the possession of specific qualifications by virtue of legislative, regulatory or administrative provisions.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 11.2\n\n\n\nObjectives and scope\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This Chapter establishes a framework to facilitate a fair, transparent and consistent regime for the mutual recognition of professional qualifications by the Parties and sets out the general conditions for the negotiation of MRAs.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This Chapter applies to professions which are regulated in each Party, including in all or some Member States of the European Union and in all or some provinces and territories of Canada.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party shall not accord recognition in a manner that would constitute a means of discrimination in the application of its criteria for the authorisation, licensing or certification of a service supplier, or that would constitute a disguised restriction on trade in services.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0An MRA adopted pursuant to this Chapter shall apply throughout the territories of the European Union and Canada.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 11.3\n\n\n\nNegotiation of an MRA\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall encourage its relevant authorities or professional bodies, as appropriate, to develop and provide to the Joint Committee on Mutual Recognition of Professional Qualifications\u00a0(\"MRA Committee\") established under Article 26.2.1(b) joint recommendations on proposed MRAs.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A recommendation shall provide an assessment of the potential value of an MRA, on the basis of criteria such as the existing level of market openness, industry needs, and business opportunities, for example, the number of professionals likely to benefit from the MRA, the existence of other MRAs in the sector, and expected gains in terms of economic and business development. In addition, it shall provide an assessment as to the compatibility of the licensing or qualification regimes of the Parties and the intended approach for the negotiation of an MRA.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The MRA Committee shall, within a reasonable period of time, review the recommendation with a view to ensuring its consistency with the requirements of this Chapter. If these requirements are satisfied, the MRA Committee shall establish the necessary steps to negotiate and each Party shall inform its respective relevant authorities of these steps.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The negotiating entities shall thereafter pursue the negotiation and submit a draft MRA text to the MRA Committee.\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The MRA Committee will thereafter review the draft MRA to ensure its consistency with this Agreement.\n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If in the view of the MRA Committee the MRA is consistent with this Agreement, the MRA Committee shall adopt the MRA\u00a0by means of a decision, which is conditional upon subsequent notification to the MRA Committee by each Party of the fulfilment of its respective internal requirements.\u00a0The decision becomes binding on the Parties\u00a0upon that notification to the MRA Committee by each Party.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 11.4\n\n\n\nRecognition\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The recognition of professional qualifications provided by an MRA shall allow the service supplier to practice professional activities in the host jurisdiction, in accordance with the terms and conditions specified in the MRA.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If the professional qualifications of a service supplier of a Party are recognised by the other Party pursuant to an MRA, the relevant authorities of the host jurisdiction shall accord to this service supplier\u00a0treatment no less favourable than that accorded in like situations\u00a0to a like\u00a0service supplier whose professional qualifications have been certified or attested in the Party's own jurisdiction.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Recognition under an MRA cannot be conditioned upon:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a service supplier meeting a citizenship or any form of residency requirement; or\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a service supplier's education, experience or training having been acquired in the Party's own jurisdiction.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 11.5\n\n\n\nJoint Committee on Mutual Recognition of Professional Qualifications\n\n\n\n\n\nThe MRA Committee responsible for the implementation of Article 11.3 shall:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0be composed of and cochaired by representatives of Canada and the European Union, which must be different from the relevant authorities or professional bodies referred to in Article\u00a011.3.1. A list of those representatives shall be confirmed through an exchange of\u00a0letters;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0meet within one year after this Agreement enters into force, and thereafter as necessary or as decided;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0determine its own rules of procedure;\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0facilitate the exchange of information regarding laws, regulations, policies and practices concerning standards or criteria for the authorisation, licensing or certification of regulated professions;\n\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0make publicly available information regarding the negotiation and implementation of MRAs;\n\n\n\n(f)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0report to the CETA Joint Committee on the progress of the negotiation and implementation of MRAs; and\n\n\n\n(g)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0as appropriate, provide information and complement the guidelines set out in Annex 11A.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 11.6\n\n\n\n\n\nGuidelines for the negotiation and conclusion of MRAs\n\n\n\nAs part of the framework to achieve mutual recognition of qualifications, the Parties set out in Annex 11A nonbinding guidelines with respect to the negotiation and conclusion of MRAs.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 11.7\n\n\n\nContact points\n\n\n\nEach Party shall establish one or more contact points for the administration of this Chapter.\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER TWELVE\n\n\n\nDOMESTIC REGULATION\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 12.1\n\n\n\n\n\nDefinitions\n\n\n\nFor the purposes of this Chapter:\n\n\n\nauthorisation means the granting of permission to a person to supply a service or to pursue any other economic activity;\n\n\n\ncompetent\u00a0authority means any government of a Party, or nongovernmental body in the exercise of powers delegated by any government of a Party, that grants an authorisation;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nlicensing procedures means administrative or procedural rules, including for the amendment or renewal of a licence, that must be adhered to in order to demonstrate compliance with licensing requirements;\n\n\n\nlicensing requirements means substantive requirements, other than qualification requirements, that must be complied with\u00a0in order to obtain, amend or renew an authorisation;\n\n\n\nqualification procedures means administrative or procedural rules that must be adhered to in order to demonstrate compliance with qualification requirements; and\n\n\n\nqualification requirements means substantive requirements relating to competency that must be complied with in order to obtain, amend or renew an authorisation.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 12.2\n\n\n\n\n\nScope\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This Chapter applies to a measure adopted or maintained by a Party relating to licensing requirements, licensing procedures, qualification requirements, or qualification procedures that affect:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the crossborder supply of services as defined in Article 9.1\u00a0(Definitions);\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the supply of a service or pursuit of any other economic activity, through commercial presence in the territory of the other Party, including the establishment of such commercial presence; and\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the supply of a service through the presence of a natural person of the other Party in the territory of the Party, in accordance with Article 10.6.2\u00a0(Obligations in other chapters).\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This Chapter does not apply to licensing requirements, licensing procedures, qualification requirements, or qualification procedures:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0pursuant to an existing nonconforming measure maintained by a Party as set out in its Schedule to Annex I; or\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0relating to one of the following sectors or activities:\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0for Canada, cultural industries and, as set out in its Schedule to Annex II, social services, aboriginal affairs, minority affairs, gambling and betting services, and the collection, purification, and distribution of water; and\n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0for the EU Party, audiovisual services and, as set out in its Schedule to Annex II, health, education, and social services, gambling and betting services,\n21\n and the collection, purification, and distribution of water.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 12.3\n\n\n\nLicensing and qualification requirements and procedures\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall ensure that licensing requirements, qualification requirements, licensing procedures, or qualification procedures it adopts or maintains are based on criteria that preclude the competent authority from exercising its power of assessment in an arbitrary manner.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The criteria referred to in paragraph 1 shall be:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0clear and transparent;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0objective; and\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0established in advance and made publicly accessible.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties recognise that the exercise of statutory discretion conferred on a minister with respect to a decision on the granting of an authorisation in the public interest is not inconsistent with subparagraph 2(c), provided that it is exercised consistently with the object of the applicable statute and not in an arbitrary manner, and that its exercise is not otherwise inconsistent with this Agreement.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Paragraph 3 does not apply to licensing requirements, or qualification requirements for a professional service.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall ensure that an authorisation is granted as soon as the competent authority determines that the conditions for the authorisation have been met, and once granted, that the authorisation enters into effect without undue delay, in accordance with the terms and conditions specified therein.\n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall maintain or institute judicial, arbitral, or administrative tribunals or procedures that provide for, at the request of an affected investor or service supplier, as defined in Articles 8.1\u00a0(Definitions) and 1.1\u00a0(Definitions of general application), a prompt review of, and if justified, appropriate remedies for, administrative decisions affecting the supply of a service or the pursuit of any other economic activity. If such procedures are not independent of the agency entrusted with the administrative decision concerned, each Party shall ensure that the procedures are applied in a way that provides for an objective and impartial review.\n\n\n\n7.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall ensure that licensing procedures or qualification procedures it adopts or maintains are as simple as possible, and do not unduly complicate or delay the supply of a service, or the pursuit of any other economic activity.\n\n\n\n8.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0An authorisation fee that an applicant may incur in relation to its application for an authorisation shall be reasonable and commensurate with the costs incurred, and shall not in itself restrict the supply of a service or the pursuit of any other economic activity.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n9.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Authorisation fees do not include payments for auction, the use of natural resources, royalties, tendering or other nondiscriminatory means of awarding concessions, or mandated contributions to provide a universal service.\n\n\n\n10.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall ensure that licensing procedures, or qualification procedures used by the competent authority and decisions of the competent authority in the authorisation process are impartial with respect to all applicants. The competent authority should reach its decisions in an independent manner and in particular should not be accountable to any person supplying a service or pursuing any other economic activity for which the authorisation is required.\n\n\n\n11.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If specific time periods for authorising applications exist, an applicant shall be allowed a reasonable period for the submission of an application. The competent authority shall initiate the processing of an application without undue delay. If possible, applications should be accepted in electronic format under similar conditions of authenticity as paper submissions.\n\n\n\n12.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Authenticated copies should be accepted, if considered appropriate, in place of original documents.\n\n\n\n13.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall ensure that the processing of an authorisation application, including reaching a final decision, is completed within a reasonable timeframe from the submission of a complete application. Each Party should establish the normal timeframe for the processing of an application.\n\n\n\n\n\n14.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0At the request of an applicant, a Party's competent authority shall provide, without undue delay, information concerning the status of the application.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n15.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If an application is considered incomplete, a Party's competent authority shall, within a reasonable period of time, inform the applicant, identify the additional information required to complete the application, and provide the applicant an opportunity to correct deficiencies.\n\n\n\n16.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If a Party's competent authority rejects an application, it shall inform the applicant in writing and without undue delay. Upon request of the applicant, the Party's competent authority shall also inform the applicant of the reasons the application was rejected and of the timeframe for an appeal or review against the decision. An applicant should be permitted, within reasonable time limits, to resubmit an application.\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER THIRTEEN\n\n\n\nFINANCIAL SERVICES\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 13.1\n\n\n\nDefinitions\n\n\n\n\nFor the purposes of this Chapter:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\ncrossborder financial service supplier of a Party means a person of a Party that is engaged in the business of supplying a financial service within the territory of the Party and that seeks to supply or supplies a financial service through the crossborder supply of that service;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\ncrossborder supply of financial services or crossborder trade in financial services means the supply of a financial service:\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0from the territory of a Party into the territory of the other Party; or\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in the territory of a Party by a person of that Party to a person of the other Party;\n\n\n\n\nbut does not include the supply of a service in the territory of a Party by an investment in that territory;\n\n\n\nfinancial institution means a supplier that carries out one or more of the operations defined as being financial services in this Article, if the supplier is regulated or supervised in respect of the supply of those services as a financial institution under the law of the Party in whose territory it is located, including a branch in the territory of the Party of that financial service supplier whose head offices are located in the territory of the other Party;\n\n\n\nfinancial institution of the other Party means a financial institution, including a branch, located in the territory of a Party that is controlled by a person of the other Party;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nfinancial service means a service of a financial nature, including insurance and insurancerelated services, banking and other financial services\u00a0(excluding insurance), and services incidental or auxiliary to a service of a financial nature. Financial services include the following activities:\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0insurance and insurancerelated services\n\n\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0direct insurance\u00a0(including coinsurance):\n\n\n\n(A)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0life; or\n\n\n\n(B)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0nonlife;\n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0reinsurance and retrocession;\n\n\n\n(iii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0insurance intermediation, such as brokerage and agency; or\n\n\n\n(iv)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0services auxiliary to insurance, such as consultancy, actuarial, risk assessment, and claim settlement services; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0banking and other financial services\u00a0(excluding insurance):\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0acceptance of deposits and other repayable funds from the public;\n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0lending of all types, including consumer credit, mortgage credit, factoring, and financing of commercial transactions;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(iii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0financial leasing;\n\n\n\n\n\n(iv)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0all payment and money transmission services, including credit, charge and debit cards, travellers cheques, and bankers drafts;\n\n\n\n(v)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0guarantees and commitments;\n\n\n\n(vi)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0trading for own account or for account of customers, whether on an exchange, in an overthecounter market or otherwise, the following:\n\n\n\n(A)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0money market instruments\u00a0(including cheques, bills or certificates of deposits);\n\n\n\n(B)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0foreign exchange;\n\n\n\n(C)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0derivative products including futures and options;\n\n\n\n(D)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0exchange rate and interest rate instruments, including products such as swaps and forward rate agreements;\n\n\n\n(E)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0transferable securities; or\n\n\n\n(F)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0other negotiable instruments and financial assets, including bullion;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(vii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0participation in issues of all kinds of securities, including underwriting and placement as agent\u00a0(whether publicly or privately), and supply of services related to such issues;\n\n\n\n(viii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0money broking;\n\n\n\n(ix)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0asset management, such as cash or portfolio management, all forms of collective investment management, pension fund management, custodial, depository, and trust services;\n\n\n\n(x)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0settlement and clearing services for financial assets, including securities, derivative products, and other negotiable instruments;\n\n\n\n(xi)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0provision and transfer of financial information, and financial data processing and related software; or\n\n\n\n(xii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0advisory, intermediation and other auxiliary financial services on all the activities listed in subsubparagraphs\u00a0(i) through\u00a0(xi), including credit reference and analysis, investment and portfolio research and advice, and advice on acquisitions and on corporate restructuring and strategy;\n\n\n\n\nfinancial service supplier means a person of a Party that is engaged in the business of supplying a financial service within the territory of that Party but does not include a public entity;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\ninvestment means \"investment\" as defined in Article 8.1\u00a0(Definitions), except that for the purposes of this Chapter, with respect to \"loans\" and \"debt instruments\" referred to in that Article:\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a loan to or debt instrument issued by a financial institution is an investment in that financial institution only if it is treated as regulatory capital by the Party in whose territory the financial institution is located; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a loan granted by or debt instrument owned by a financial institution, other than a loan to or debt instrument of a financial institution referred to in subparagraph\u00a0(a), is not an investment;\n\n\n\n\n\n\nfor greater certainty,\n\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Chapter Eight\u00a0(Investment) applies to a loan or debt instrument to the extent that it is not covered in this Chapter; and\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a loan granted by or a debt instrument owned by a crossborder financial service supplier, other than a loan to or debt instrument issued by a financial institution, is an investment for the purposes of Chapter Eight\u00a0(Investment) if that loan or debt instrument meets the criteria for investments set out in Article 8.1\u00a0(Definitions);\n\n\n\n\ninvestor means \"investor\" as defined in Article 8.1\u00a0(Definitions);\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nnew financial service means a financial service that is not supplied in the territory of a Party but that is supplied in the territory of the other Party and includes any new form of delivery of a financial service or the sale of a financial product that is not sold in the Party's territory;\n\n\n\nperson of a Party means \"person of a Party\" as defined in Article 1.1\u00a0(Definitions of general application) and, for greater certainty, does not include a branch of an enterprise of a third country;\n\n\n\npublic entity means:\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a government, a central bank or a monetary authority of a Party or any entity owned or controlled by a Party, that is principally engaged in carrying out governmental functions or activities for governmental purposes, but does not include an entity principally engaged in supplying financial services on commercial terms; or\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a private entity that performs functions normally performed by a central bank or monetary authority when exercising those functions; and\n\n\n\n\n\n\nselfregulatory organisation means a nongovernmental body, including any securities or futures exchange or market, clearing agency, other organisation or association, that exercises its own or delegated regulatory or supervisory authority over financial service suppliers or financial institutions.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 13.2\n\n\n\nScope\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This Chapter applies to a measure adopted or maintained by a Party relating to:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0financial institutions of the other Party;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0an investor of the other Party, and an investment of that investor, in a financial institution in the Party's territory; and\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0crossborder trade in financial services.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For greater certainty, the provisions of Chapter Eight\u00a0(Investment) apply to:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a measure relating to an investor of a Party, and an investment of that investor, in a financial service supplier that is not a financial institution; and\n\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a measure, other than a measure relating to the supply of financial services, relating to an investor of a Party or an investment of that investor in a financial institution.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Articles 8.10\u00a0(Treatment of investors and of covered investments), 8.11\u00a0(Compensation for losses), 8.12\u00a0(Expropriation), 8.13\u00a0(Transfers), 8.14\u00a0(Subrogation), 8.16\u00a0(Denial of benefits), and\u00a08.17\u00a0(Formal requirements) are incorporated into and made a part of this Chapter.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Section F of Chapter Eight\u00a0(Resolution of investment disputes between investors and states) is incorporated into and made a part of this Chapter solely for claims that a Party has breached Article 13.3 or 13.4\u00a0with respect to the expansion, conduct, operation, management, maintenance, use, enjoyment, and sale or disposal of a financial institution or an investment in a financial institution, or Article 8.10\u00a0(Treatment of investors and of covered investments), 8.11\u00a0(Compensation for losses), 8.12\u00a0(Expropriation), 8.13\u00a0(Transfers), or 8.16\u00a0(Denial of benefits).\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This Chapter does not apply to a measure adopted or maintained by a Party relating to:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0activities or services forming part of a public retirement plan or statutory system of social security; or\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0activities or services conducted for the account of the Party, with the guarantee or using the financial resources of the Party, including its public entities,\n\n\n\nexcept that this Chapter applies to the extent that a Party allows activities or services referred to in subparagraph\u00a0(a) or\u00a0(b) to be conducted by its financial institutions in competition with a public entity or a financial institution.\n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Chapter Twelve\u00a0(Domestic Regulation) is incorporated into and made a part of this Chapter. For greater certainty, Article 12.3\u00a0(Licensing and qualification requirements and procedures) applies to the exercise of statutory discretion by the financial regulatory authorities of the Parties.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n7.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The provisions of Chapter Twelve\u00a0(Domestic Regulation) incorporated into this Chapter under paragraph 6 do not apply to licensing requirements, licensing procedures, qualification requirements or qualification procedures:\n\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0pursuant to a nonconforming measure maintained by Canada, as set out in its Schedule to Annex IIIA;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0pursuant to a nonconforming measure maintained by the European Union, as set out in its Schedule to Annex I, to the extent that such measure relates to financial services; and\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0as set out in Article 12.2.2(b)\u00a0(Scope), to the extent that such measure relates to financial services.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 13.3\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Article 8.6\u00a0(National treatment) is incorporated into and made a part of this Chapter and applies to treatment of financial institutions and investors of the other Party and their investments in financial institutions.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The treatment accorded by a Party to its own investors and investments of its own investors under paragraphs 1 and 2 of Article 8.6\u00a0(National treatment) means treatment accorded to its own financial institutions and investments of its own investors in financial institutions.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 13.4\n\n\n\nMostfavourednation treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Article 8.7\u00a0(Mostfavourednation treatment) is incorporated into and made a part of this Chapter and applies to treatment of financial institutions and investors of the other Party and their investments in financial institutions.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The treatment accorded by a Party to investors of a third country and investments of investors of a third country under paragraphs 1 and 2 of Article 8.7\u00a0(Mostfavourednation treatment) means treatment accorded to financial institutions of a third country and investments of investors of a third country in financial institutions.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 13.5\n\n\n\nRecognition of prudential measures\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party may recognise a prudential measure of a third country in the application of a measure covered by this Chapter. That recognition may be:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0accorded unilaterally;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0achieved through harmonisation or other means; or\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0based upon an agreement or arrangement with the third country.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party according recognition of a prudential measure shall provide adequate opportunity to the other Party to demonstrate that circumstances exist in which there are or will be equivalent regulation, oversight, implementation of regulation and, if appropriate, procedures concerning the sharing of information between the Parties.\n\n\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If a Party recognises a prudential measure under subparagraph 1(c) and the circumstances described in paragraph 2 exist, the Party shall provide adequate opportunity to the other Party to negotiate accession to the agreement or arrangement, or to negotiate a comparable agreement or arrangement.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 13.6\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party shall not adopt or maintain, with respect to a financial institution of the other Party or with respect to market access through establishment of a financial institution by an investor of the other Party, on the basis of its entire territory or on the basis of the territory of a national, provincial, territorial, regional, or local level of government, a measure that:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0imposes limitations on:\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the number of financial institutions, whether in the form of numerical quotas, monopolies, exclusive service suppliers or the requirement of an economic needs test;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the total value of financial service transactions or assets in the form of numerical quotas or the requirement of an economic needs test;\n\n\n\n(iii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the total number of financial service operations or the total quantity of financial services output expressed in terms of designated numerical units in the form of quotas or the requirement of an economic needs test;\n\n\n\n(iv)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the participation of foreign capital in terms of maximum percentage limit on foreign shareholding in financial institutions or the total value of individual or aggregate foreign investment in financial institutions; or\n\n\n\n\n\n(v)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the total number of natural persons that may be employed in a particular financial services sector or that a financial institution may employ and who are necessary for, and directly related to, the performance of a specific financial service in the form of numerical quotas or the requirement of an economic needs test; or\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0restricts or requires specific types of legal entity or joint venture through which a financial institution may perform an economic activity.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Article 8.4.2\u00a0(Market access) is incorporated into and made a part of this Article.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For greater certainty:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a Party may impose terms, conditions, and procedures for the authorisation of the establishment and expansion of a commercial presence provided that they do not circumvent the Party's obligation under paragraph 1 and are consistent with the other provisions of this Chapter; and\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0this Article does not prevent a Party from requiring a financial institution to supply certain financial services through separate legal entities if, under the law of the Party, the range of financial services supplied by the financial institution may not be supplied through a single entity.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 13.7\n\n\n\nCrossborder supply of financial services\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Articles 9.3\u00a0(National treatment), 9.4\u00a0(Formal requirements), and 9.6\u00a0(Market access) are incorporated into and made a part of this Chapter and apply to treatment of crossborder financial service suppliers supplying the financial services specified in Annex 13A.\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The treatment accorded by a Party to its own service suppliers and services under Article\u00a09.3.2\u00a0(National treatment) means treatment accorded to its own financial service suppliers and financial services.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The measures that a Party shall not adopt or maintain with respect to service suppliers and services of the other Party under Article 9.6\u00a0(Market access) means measures relating to crossborder financial service suppliers of the other Party supplying financial services.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Article 9.5\u00a0(Mostfavourednation treatment) is incorporated into and made a part of this Chapter and applies to treatment of crossborder financial service suppliers of the other Party.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The treatment accorded by a Party to service suppliers and services of a third country under Article 9.5\u00a0(Mostfavourednation treatment) means treatment accorded to financial service suppliers of a third country and financial services of a third country.\n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall permit a person located in its territory, and a national wherever they are located, to purchase a financial service from a crossborder financial service supplier of the other Party located in the territory of that other Party. This obligation does not require a Party to permit such suppliers to do business or solicit in its territory. Each Party may define \"doing business\" and \"solicitation\" for the purposes of this Article, in conformity with paragraph 1.\n\n\n\n7.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the financial services specified in Annex 13A, each Party shall permit a crossborder financial service supplier of the other Party, on request or notification to the relevant regulator, where required, to supply a financial service through any new form of delivery, or to sell a financial product that is not sold in the Party's territory where the first Party permits its own financial service suppliers to supply such a service or to sell such a product under its law in like situations.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 13.8\n\n\n\nSenior management and boards of directors\n\n\n\n\nA Party shall not require that a financial institution of the other Party appoint to senior management or board of director positions, natural persons of any particular nationality.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 13.9\n\n\n\nPerformance requirements\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties shall negotiate disciplines on performance requirements such as those contained in Article 8.5\u00a0(Performance requirements) with respect to investments in financial institutions.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If, after three years of entry into force of this Agreement, the Parties have not agreed to such disciplines, upon request of a Party, Article 8.5\u00a0(Performance requirements) shall be incorporated into and made a part of this Chapter and shall apply to investments in financial institutions. For this purpose, \"investment\" in Article 8.5\u00a0(Performance requirements) means \"investment in a financial institution in its territory\".\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Within 180 days following the successful negotiation by the Parties on the performance requirement disciplines pursuant to paragraph 1, or following a Party's request for incorporation of Article 8.5\u00a0(Performance requirements) into this Chapter pursuant to paragraph 2, as the case may be, each Party may amend its Schedule as required. Any amendment must be limited to the listing of reservations for existing measures that do not conform with the performance requirements obligation under this Chapter, for Canada in Section A of its Schedule to Annex III and for the European Union in its Schedule to Annex I. Article 13.10.1 shall apply to such measures with respect to the performance requirement disciplines negotiated pursuant to paragraph 1, or Article\u00a08.5\u00a0(Performance requirements) as incorporated into this Chapter pursuant to paragraph 2, as the case may be.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 13.10\n\n\n\nReservations and exceptions\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Articles 13.3, 13.4, 13.6, and 13.8 do not apply to:\n\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0an existing nonconforming measure that is maintained by a Party at the level of:\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the European Union, as set out in its Schedule to Annex I;\n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a national government, as set out by Canada in Section A of its Schedule to Annex III or the European Union in its Schedule to Annex I;\n\n\n\n(iii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a provincial, territorial, or regional government, as set out by Canada in Section A of its Schedule to Annex III or the European Union in its Schedule to Annex I; or\n\n\n\n(iv)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a local government;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the\u00a0continuation or prompt renewal of a nonconforming measure referred to in subparagraph\u00a0(a); or\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0an amendment to a nonconforming measure referred to in subparagraph\u00a0(a) to the extent that the amendment does not decrease the conformity of the measure, as it existed immediately before the amendment, with Articles 13.3, 13.4, 13.6, or 13.8.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Article 13.7 does not apply to:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0an existing nonconforming measure that is maintained by a Party at the level of:\n\n\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the European Union, as set out in its Schedule to Annex I;\n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a national government, as set out by Canada in Section A of its Schedule to Annex III or the European Union in its Schedule to Annex I;\n\n\n\n(iii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a provincial, territorial, or regional government, as set out by Canada in Section A of its Schedule to Annex III or the European Union in its Schedule to Annex I; or\n\n\n\n(iv)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a local government;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the continuation or prompt renewal of a nonconforming measure referred to in subparagraph\u00a0(a); or\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0an amendment to a nonconforming measure referred to in subparagraph\u00a0(a) to the extent that the amendment does not decrease the conformity of the measure, as it existed upon the entry into force of this Agreement, with Article 13.7.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Articles 13.3, 13.4, 13.6, 13.7, and 13.8 do not apply to a measure that Canada adopts or maintains with respect to financial services as set out in Section B of its Schedule to Annex III, or to a measure that the European Union adopts or maintains with respect to financial services as set out in its Schedule to Annex II.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If a Party has set out a reservation to Articles 8.4\u00a0(Market access), 8.5\u00a0(Performance requirements), 8.6\u00a0(National treatment), 8.7\u00a0(Mostfavourednation treatment), 8.8\u00a0(Senior management and boards of directors), 9.3\u00a0(National treatment), 9.5\u00a0(Mostfavourednation treatment), or 9.6\u00a0(Market access) in its Schedule to Annex I or II, the reservation also constitutes a reservation to Articles 13.3, 13.4, 13.6, 13.7, or 13.8, or to any discipline on performance requirements negotiated pursuant to Article 13.9.1 or incorporated into this Chapter pursuant to Article 13.9.2, as the case may be, to the extent that the measure, sector, subsector or activity set out in the reservation is covered by this Chapter.\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party shall not adopt a measure or series of measures after the date of entry into force of this Agreement that are covered by Section B of Canada's Schedule to Annex III, or by the Schedule to Annex II of the European Union and that require, directly or indirectly, an investor of the other Party, by reason of nationality, to sell or otherwise dispose of an investment existing at the time the measure or series of measures became effective.\n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0In respect of intellectual property rights, a Party may derogate from Articles 13.3 and 13.4, and from any discipline on technology transfer in relation to performance requirements negotiated pursuant to Article 13.9.1 or incorporated into this Chapter pursuant to Article 13.9.2, as the case may be, if the derogation is permitted by the TRIPS Agreement, including waivers to the TRIPS Agreement adopted pursuant to Article IX of the WTO Agreement.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n7.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Articles 13.3, 13.4, 13.6, 13.7, 13.8, and 13.9 do not apply to:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0procurement by a Party of a good or service purchased for governmental purposes and not with a view to commercial resale or with a view to use in the supply of a good or service for commercial sale, whether or not that procurement is \"covered procurement\" within the meaning of Article 19.2\u00a0(Scope and coverage); or\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0subsidies, or government support relating to trade in services, provided by a Party.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 13.11\n\n\n\nEffective and transparent regulation\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall ensure that all measures of general application to which this Chapter applies are administered in a reasonable, objective, and impartial manner.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall ensure that its laws, regulations, procedures, and administrative rulings of general application with respect to any matter covered by this Chapter are promptly published or made available in such a manner as to enable an interested person and the other Party to become acquainted with them. To the extent possible, each Party shall:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0publish in advance any such measures that it proposes to adopt;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0provide an interested person and the other Party a reasonable opportunity to comment on these proposed measures; and\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0allow reasonable time between the final publication of the measures and the date they become effective.\n\n\n\nFor the purposes of this Chapter, these requirements replace those set out in Article 27.1\u00a0(Publication).\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall maintain or establish appropriate mechanisms to respond within a reasonable period of time to an inquiry from an interested person regarding measures of general application covered by this Chapter.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A regulatory authority shall make an administrative decision on a completed application of an investor in a financial institution, a crossborder financial service supplier, or a financial institution of the other Party relating to the supply of a financial service within a reasonable period of time that is justified by the complexity of the application and the normal period of time established for the processing of the application. For Canada, such a reasonable time period is 120 days. The regulatory authority shall promptly notify the applicant of the decision. If it is not practicable for a decision to be made within a reasonable period of time, the regulatory authority shall promptly notify the applicant and endeavour to make the decision as soon as possible. For greater certainty, an application is not considered complete until all relevant hearings are held and the regulatory authority has received all necessary information.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 13.12\n\n\n\nSelfregulatory organisations\n\n\n\n\nIf a Party requires a financial institution or a crossborder financial service supplier of the other Party to be a member of, participate in, or have access to, a selfregulatory organisation to supply a financial service in or into the territory of that Party, or grants a privilege or advantage when supplying a financial service through a selfregulatory organisation, then the requiring Party shall ensure that the selfregulatory organisation observes the obligations of this Chapter.\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 13.13\n\n\n\n\n\nPayment and clearing systems\n\n\n\n\nUnder terms and conditions that accord national treatment, each Party shall grant a financial service supplier of the other Party established in its territory access to payment and clearing systems operated by a Party, or by an entity exercising governmental authority delegated to it by a Party, and access to official funding and refinancing facilities available in the normal course of ordinary business. This Article does not confer access to a Party's lender of last resort facilities.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 13.14\n\n\n\nNew financial services\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall permit a financial institution of the other Party to supply any new financial service that the first Party would permit its own financial institutions, in like situations, to supply under its law, on request or notification to the relevant regulator, if required.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party may determine the institutional and juridical form through which the new financial service may be supplied and may require authorisation for the supply of the service. If authorisation is required, a decision shall be made within a reasonable period of time and the authorisation may only be refused for prudential reasons.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This Article does not prevent a financial institution of a Party from applying to the other Party to consider authorising the supply of a financial service that is not supplied within either Party's territory. That application is subject to the law of the Party receiving the application and is not subject to the obligations of this Article.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 13.15\n\n\n\n\n\nTransfer and processing of information\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall permit a financial institution or a crossborder financial service supplier of the other Party to transfer information in electronic or other form, into and out of its territory, for data processing if processing is required in the ordinary course of business of the financial institution or the crossborder financial service supplier.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall maintain adequate safeguards to protect privacy, in particular with regard to the transfer of personal information. If the transfer of financial information involves personal information, such transfers shall be in accordance with the legislation governing the protection of personal information of the territory of the Party where the transfer has originated.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 13.16\n\n\n\nPrudential carveout\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This Agreement does not prevent a Party from adopting or maintaining reasonable measures for prudential reasons, including:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the protection of investors, depositors, policyholders, or persons to whom a financial institution, crossborder financial service supplier, or financial service supplier owes a fiduciary duty;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the maintenance of the safety, soundness, integrity, or financial responsibility of a financial institution, crossborder financial service supplier, or financial service supplier; or\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0ensuring the integrity and stability of a Party's financial system.\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Without prejudice to other means of prudential regulation of crossborder trade in financial services, a Party may require the registration of crossborder financial service suppliers of the other Party and of financial instruments.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Subject to Articles 13.3 and 13.4, a Party may, for prudential reasons, prohibit a particular financial service or activity. Such a prohibition shall not apply to all financial services or to a complete financial services subsector, such as banking.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 13.17\n\n\n\nSpecific exceptions\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This Agreement does not apply to measures taken by a public entity in pursuit of monetary or exchange rate policies. This paragraph does not affect a Party's obligations under Articles 8.5\u00a0(Performance requirements), 8.13\u00a0(Transfers), or 13.9.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This Agreement does not require a Party to furnish or allow access to information relating to the affairs and accounts of individual consumers, crossborder financial service suppliers, financial institutions, or to any confidential information which, if disclosed, would interfere with specific regulatory, supervisory, or law enforcement matters, or would otherwise be contrary to public interest or prejudice legitimate commercial interests of particular enterprises.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 13.18\n\n\n\nFinancial Services Committee\n\n\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Financial Services Committee established under Article 26.2.1(f)\u00a0(Specialised committees) shall include representatives of\u00a0authorities\u00a0in charge of financial services policy with expertise in the field covered by this Chapter.\u00a0For Canada, the Committee representative is an official from the Department of Finance Canada or its successor.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Financial Services Committee shall decide by mutual consent.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Financial Services Committee shall meet annually, or as it otherwise decides, and shall:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0supervise the implementation of this Chapter;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0carry out a dialogue on the regulation of the financial services sector with a view to improving mutual knowledge of the Parties' respective regulatory systems and to cooperate in the development of international standards as illustrated by the Understanding on the dialogue on the regulation of the financial services sector contained in Annex 13C; and\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0implement Article 13.21.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 13.19\n\n\n\nConsultations\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party may request consultations with the other Party regarding any matter arising under this Agreement that affects financial services. The other Party shall give sympathetic consideration to the request.\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall ensure that when there are consultations pursuant to paragraph 1 its delegation includes officials with the relevant expertise in the area covered by this Chapter. For Canada this means officials of the Department of Finance Canada or its successor.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 13.20\n\n\n\nDispute settlement\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Chapter TwentyNine\u00a0(Dispute Settlement) applies as modified by this Article to the settlement of disputes arising under this Chapter.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If the Parties are unable to agree on the composition of the arbitration panel established for the purposes of a dispute arising under this Chapter, Article 29.7\u00a0(Composition of the arbitration panel) applies. However, all references to the list of arbitrators established under Article 29.8\u00a0(List of arbitrators) shall be understood to refer to the list of arbitrators established under this Article.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The CETA Joint Committee may establish a list of at least 15 individuals, chosen on the basis of objectivity, reliability, and sound judgement, who are willing and able to serve as arbitrators. The list shall be composed of three sublists: one sublist for each Party and one sublist of individuals, who are not nationals of either Party, to act as chairpersons. Each sublist shall include at least five individuals. The CETA Joint Committee may review the list at any time and shall ensure that the list conforms with this Article.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The arbitrators included on the list must have expertise or experience in financial services law or regulation or in the practice thereof, which may include the regulation of financial service suppliers. The arbitrators acting as chairpersons must also have experience as counsel, panellist, or arbitrator in dispute settlement proceedings. Arbitrators shall be independent, serve in their individual capacity, and shall not take instructions from any organisation or government. They shall comply with the Code of Conduct in Annex 29B\u00a0(Code of conduct).\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If an arbitration panel finds that a measure is inconsistent with this Agreement and the measure affects:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the financial services sector and any other sector, the complaining Party may suspend benefits in the financial services sector that have an effect equivalent to the effect of the measure in the Party's financial services sector; or\n\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0only a sector other than the financial services sector, the complaining Party shall not suspend benefits in the financial services sector.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 13.21\n\n\n\nInvestment disputes in financial services\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Section F of Chapter Eight\u00a0(Resolution of investment disputes between investors and states) applies, as modified by this Article and Annex 13B, to:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0investment disputes pertaining to measures to which this Chapter applies and in which an investor claims that a Party has breached Article 8.10\u00a0(Treatment of investors and of covered investments), 8.11\u00a0(Compensation for losses), 8.12\u00a0(Expropriation), 8.13\u00a0(Transfers), 8.16\u00a0(Denial of benefits), 13.3, or 13.4; or\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0investment disputes commenced pursuant to Section F of Chapter Eight\u00a0(Resolution of investment disputes between investors and states) in which Article 13.16.1 has been invoked.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0In the case of an investment dispute under subparagraph 1(a), or if the respondent invokes Article 13.16.1 within 60 days of the submission of a claim to the Tribunal under Article 8.23\u00a0(Submission of a claim to the Tribunal), a division of the Tribunal shall be composed, in accordance with Article 8.27.7 (Constitution of the Tribunal) from the list established under Article 13.20.3. If the respondent invokes Article 13.16.1 within 60 days of the submission of a claim, with respect to an investment dispute other than under subparagraph 1(a), the period of time applicable to the\u00a0composition  of a division of the Tribunal under Article\u00a08.27.7\u00a0(Constitution of the Tribunal) commences on the date the respondent invokes Article\u00a013.16.1. If the CETA Joint Committee has not made the appointments pursuant to Article 8.27.2 (Constitution of the Tribunal)  within the period of time provided in Article 8.27.17 (Constitution of the Tribunal), either disputing party may request that the SecretaryGeneral of the International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes\u00a0(\"ICSID\") select the Members of the Tribunal from the list established under Article 13.20. If the list has not been established under Article 13.20 on the date the claim is submitted pursuant to Article 8.23 (Submission of a claim to the Tribunal), the SecretaryGeneral of ICSID shall select the Members of the Tribunal from the individuals proposed by one or both of the Parties in accordance with Article 13.20.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The respondent may refer the matter in writing to the Financial Services Committee for a decision as to whether and, if so, to what extent the exception under Article 13.16.1 is a valid defence to the claim. This referral shall not be made later than the date the Tribunal fixes for the respondent to submit its countermemorial. If the respondent refers the matter to the Financial Services Committee under this paragraph the periods of time or proceedings referred to in Section F of Chapter Eight\u00a0(Resolution of investment disputes between investors and states) are suspended.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0In a referral under paragraph 3, the Financial Services Committee or the CETA Joint Committee, as the case may be, may make a joint determination as to whether and to what extent Article 13.16.1 is a valid defence to the claim. The Financial Services Committee or the CETA Joint Committee, as the case may be, shall transmit a copy of the joint determination to the investor and the Tribunal, if constituted. If the joint determination concludes that Article 13.16.1 is a valid defence to all parts of the claim in their entirety, the investor is deemed to have withdrawn its claim and the proceedings are discontinued in accordance with Article 8.35\u00a0(Discontinuance). If the joint determination concludes that Article 13.16.1 is a valid defence to only parts of the claim, the joint determination is binding on the Tribunal with respect to those parts of the claim.
