The suspension of the periods of time or proceedings described in paragraph 3 then no longer applies and the investor may proceed with the remaining parts of the claim.\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If the CETA Joint Committee has not made a joint determination within three months of referral of the matter by the Financial Services Committee, the suspension of the periods of time or proceedings referred to in paragraph 3 no longer applies and the investor may proceed with its claim.\n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0At the request of the respondent, the Tribunal shall decide as a preliminary matter whether and to what extent Article 13.16.1 is a valid defence to the claim. Failure of the respondent to make that request is without prejudice to the right of the respondent to assert Article 13.16.1 as a defence in a later phase of the proceedings. The Tribunal shall draw no adverse inference from the fact that the Financial Services Committee or the CETA Joint Committee has not agreed on a joint determination in accordance with Annex13B.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER FOURTEEN\n\n\n\nINTERNATIONAL MARITIME TRANSPORT SERVICES\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 14.1\n\n\n\nDefinitions\n\n\n\nFor the purposes of this Chapter:\n\n\n\ncustoms clearance services or customs house brokers' services means the carrying out, on a fee or contract basis, of customs formalities concerning import, export or through transport of cargo, irrespective of whether these services are the main or secondary activity of the service provider;\n\n\n\n\n\ncontainer station and depot services means the storage, stuffing, stripping or repair of containers and making them available for shipment, whether in port areas or inland;\n\n\n\ndoortodoor or multimodal transport operation means the transport of cargo under a single transport document, that uses more than one mode of transport and involves an international sealeg;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nfeeder services means the pre and onward transportation by sea of international cargo, including containerised, break bulk and dry or liquid bulk cargo,\u00a0between ports located in the territory of a Party. For greater certainty, in respect of Canada, feeder services may include transportation between sea and inland waters, where inland waters means those defined in the Customs Act, R.S.C. 1985, c.1 (2nd Supp.);\n\n\n\ninternational cargo means cargo transported by seagoing vessels between a port of a Party and a port of the other Party or of a third country, or between a port of one Member State of the European Union and a port of another Member State of the European Union;\n\n\n\ninternational maritime transport services means the transport of passengers or cargo by a seagoing vessel between a port of one Party and a port of the other Party or of a third country, or between a port of one Member State of the European Union and a port of another Member State of the European Union, as well as direct contracting with suppliers of other transport services to ensure doortodoor or multimodal transport operations, but not the supply of such other transport services;\n\n\n\ninternational maritime transport service suppliers means:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0an enterprise of a Party, as defined in Article 1.1\u00a0(Definitions of general application), and a branch of any such entity; or\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0an enterprise, as defined in Article 1.1\u00a0(Definitions of general application), of a third country owned or controlled by nationals of a Party, if its vessels are registered in accordance with the legislation of that Party and flying the flag of that Party;\u00a0or\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a branch of an enterprise of a\u00a0third country with substantive business operations\u00a0in the territory of a Party, that is engaged in the supply of international maritime transport services. For greater certainty, Chapter Eight\u00a0(Investment) does not apply to such a branch;\n\n\n\n\n\nmaritime agency services means the representation, as an agent, within a given geographic area, of the business interests of one or more shipping lines or shipping companies, for the following purposes:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0marketing and sales of maritime transport and related services, from quotation to invoicing, issuance of bills of lading on behalf of the companies, acquisition and resale of the necessary related services, preparation of documentation, and provision of business information; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0acting on behalf of the companies in organising the call of the vessel or taking control of cargo when required;\n\n\n\nmaritime auxiliary services means maritime cargo handling services, customs clearance services, container station and depot services, maritime agency services, maritime freight forwarding services, and storage and warehousing services;\n\n\n\nmaritime cargo handling services means the performance, organisation and supervision of:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the loading or discharging of cargo to or from a vessel,\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the lashing or unlashing of cargo, and\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the reception or delivery and safekeeping of cargo before shipment or after discharge,\n\n\n\nby stevedoring\u00a0or terminal operator companies, but does\u00a0not include work performed by dock labour, when this workforce is organised independently of stevedoring or terminal operator companies;\n\n\n\n\n\nmaritime freight forwarding services means the organisation and monitoring of shipments on behalf of shippers, through the supply of such services as the arrangement of transport and related services, consolidation and packing of cargo, preparation of documentation and provision of business information;\n\n\n\nstorage and warehousing services means storage services of frozen or refrigerated goods, bulk storage services of liquids or gases, and other storage or warehousing services.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 14.2\n\n\n\nScope\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This Chapter applies to a measure adopted or maintained by a Party relating to the supply of international maritime transport services.\n22\n\u00a0For greater certainty, such measure is also subject to Chapters Eight\u00a0(Investment) and Nine\u00a0(CrossBorder Trade in Services), as applicable.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For greater certainty, further to Articles 8.6\u00a0(National treatment), 8.7\u00a0(Mostfavourednation treatment), 9.3\u00a0(National treatment), and 9.5\u00a0(Mostfavourednation treatment), a Party shall not adopt or maintain a measure in respect of:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a vessel supplying an international maritime transport service and flying the flag of the other Party;\n23\n or\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0an international maritime transport service supplier of the other Party,\n\n\n\nthat accords treatment that is less favourable than that accorded by that Party in like situations to its own vessels or international maritime transport service suppliers or to vessels or international maritime transport service suppliers of a third country with regard to:\n\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0access to ports;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the use of infrastructure and services of ports such as towage and pilotage;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the use of maritime auxiliary services as well as the imposition of related fees and charges;\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0access to customs facilities; or\n\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the assignment of berths and facilities for loading and unloading.\n24\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 14.3\n\n\n\nObligations\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall permit the international maritime transport service suppliers of the other Party to reposition owned or leased empty containers that are carried on a nonrevenue basis between the ports of that Party.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party shall permit the international maritime transport service suppliers of the other Party to supply feeder services between the ports of that Party.\n\n\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party shall not adopt or maintain a cargosharing arrangement with a third country concerning any international maritime transport services, including dry and liquid bulk and liner trades.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party shall not adopt or maintain a measure that requires all or part of any international cargo to be transported exclusively by vessels registered in that Party or owned or controlled by nationals of that Party.\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party shall not adopt or maintain a measure that prevents international maritime transport service suppliers of the other Party from directly contracting with other transport service suppliers for doortodoor or multimodal transport operations.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 14.4\n\n\n\nReservations\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Article 14.3 does not apply to:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0an existing nonconforming measure that is maintained by a Party at the level of :\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the European Union, as set out in its Schedule to Annex I;\n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a national government, as set out by that Party in its Schedule to Annex I;\n\n\n\n\n\n(iii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a provincial, territorial or regional government, as set out by that Party in its Schedule to Annex I; or\n\n\n\n(iv)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a local government;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the continuation or prompt renewal of a nonconforming measure referred to in subparagraph\u00a0(a); or\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0an amendment to a nonconforming measure referred to in subparagraph\u00a0(a) to the extent that the amendment does not decrease the conformity of the measure, as it existed immediately before the amendment, with Article 14.3.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Article 14.3 does not apply to a measure that a Party adopts or maintains with respect to sectors, subsectors or activities, as set out in its Schedule to Annex II.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER FIFTEEN\n\n\n\nTELECOMMUNICATIONS\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 15.1\n\n\n\nDefinitions\n\n\n\n\n\nFor the purposes of this\u00a0Chapter:\n\n\n\ncontribution link means a link for the transmission of sound or television broadcasting signals to a programme production centre;\n\n\n\ncostoriented means based on cost and may involve different cost methodologies for different facilities or services;\n\n\n\nenterprise means an \"enterprise\" as defined in Article 8.1\u00a0(Definitions);\n\n\n\nessential facilities means facilities of a public telecommunications transport network or service that:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0are exclusively or predominantly supplied by a single or a limited number of suppliers; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0cannot feasibly be economically or technically substituted in order to supply a service;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\ninterconnection means linking\u00a0suppliers providing public telecommunications transport networks or services in order to allow the users of one supplier to communicate with the users of another supplier and to access services supplied by another supplier;\n\n\n\nintracorporate communications means telecommunications through which an enterprise communicates within the enterprise or with or among its subsidiaries, branches and, subject to a Party's law, affiliates, but does not include commercial or noncommercial services that are supplied to enterprises that are not related subsidiaries, branches or affiliates, or that are offered to customers or potential customers. For the purposes of this definition, \"subsidiaries\", \"branches\" and, where applicable, \"affiliates\" are as defined by each Party;\n\n\n\n\n\nleased circuits means telecommunications facilities between two or more designated points that are set aside for the dedicated use of or availability to a particular customer or other users of the customer's choice;\n\n\n\nmajor supplier\u00a0means a supplier which has the ability to materially affect the terms of participation, having regard to price and supply\u00a0in the relevant market for\u00a0public telecommunications transport networks or services, as a result of:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0control over essential facilities; or\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0use of its position in the market;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nnetwork termination point means the physical point at which a user is provided with access to a public telecommunications transport network;\n\n\n\nnumber portability means the ability of endusers of public telecommunications transport services to retain, at the same location, the same telephone numbers without impairment of quality, reliability or convenience when switching between suppliers of like public telecommunications transport services;\n\n\n\npublic telecommunications transport network means the public telecommunications infrastructure that permits telecommunications between and among defined network termination points;\n\n\n\npublic telecommunications transport service means a telecommunications transport service that a Party requires, explicitly or in effect, to be offered to the public generally that involves the realtime transmission of customersupplied information between two or more points without any endtoend change in the form or content of the customer's information. This service may include, among other things, voice telephone services, packetswitched data transmission services, circuitswitched data transmission services, telex services, telegraph services, facsimile services, private leased circuit services and mobile and personal communications services and systems;\n\n\n\nregulatory authority means the body responsible for the regulation of telecommunications;\n\n\n\ntelecommunications services means all services consisting of the transmission and reception of signals by any electromagnetic means but does not include the economic activity consisting of the provision of content by means of telecommunications; and\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nuser means an enterprise or natural person using or requesting a publicly available telecommunications service.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 15.2\n\n\n\nScope\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This Chapter applies to a measure adopted or maintained by a Party relating to telecommunications networks or\u00a0services, subject to a Party's right to restrict the supply of a service in accordance with its reservations as set out in its Schedule to Annex I or II.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This Chapter does not apply to a measure of a Party affecting the transmission by any means of telecommunications, including broadcast and cable distribution, of radio or television programming intended for reception by the public. For greater certainty, this Chapter applies to a contribution link.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This Chapter does not:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0require a Party to authorise a service supplier of the other Party to establish, construct, acquire, lease, operate or supply telecommunications networks or services, other than as specifically provided in this Agreement; or\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0require a Party, or require a Party to compel a service supplier, to establish, construct, acquire, lease, operate or supply telecommunications networks or services not offered to the public generally.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 15.3\n\n\n\nAccess to and use of public telecommunications transport networks or services\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party shall ensure that\u00a0enterprises of the other Party are accorded access to and use of public telecommunications transport networks or services on reasonable and nondiscriminatory terms and conditions, including with respect to quality, technical standards and specifications.\n25\n The Parties shall apply this obligation, among other things, as set out in paragraphs 2 through 6.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall ensure that enterprises of the other Party have access to and use of any public telecommunications transport network or service\u00a0offered within or across its borders, including private leased circuits, and to this end shall ensure, subject to paragraphs 5 and 6, that these enterprises\u00a0are permitted to:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0purchase or lease, and attach terminal or other equipment which interfaces with the public telecommunications transport network;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0connect private leased or owned circuits with public telecommunications transport networks and services of that Party or with circuits leased or owned by another enterprise;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0use operating protocols of their choice; and\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0perform switching, signalling, and processing functions.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall ensure that\u00a0enterprises\u00a0of the other Party may use public telecommunications transport networks and services\u00a0for the movement of information in its territory or across its borders, including for intracorporate communications of these\u00a0enterprises, and for access to information contained in data bases or otherwise stored in machinereadable form in the territory of either Party.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Further to Article 28.3\u00a0(General exceptions), and\u00a0notwithstanding paragraph 3, a Party shall take appropriate measures to protect:\n\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the security and confidentiality of public telecommunications transport services; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the privacy of users of public telecommunications transport services,\n\n\n\nsubject to the requirement that these measures are not applied in a manner that would constitute a means of arbitrary or unjustifiable discrimination or a disguised restriction on trade.\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall ensure that no condition is imposed on access to and use of public telecommunications transport networks or services\u00a0other than as necessary to:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0safeguard the public service responsibilities of suppliers of public telecommunications transport networks or services, in particular their ability to make their networks or services available to the public generally;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0protect the technical integrity of public telecommunications transport networks or services; or\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0ensure that service suppliers of the other Party do not supply services limited by the Party's reservations as set out in its Schedule to Annex I or II.\n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Provided that they satisfy the criteria in paragraph 5, conditions for access to and use of public telecommunications transport networks or services\u00a0may include:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0restrictions on resale or shared use of these services;\n\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a requirement to use specified technical interfaces, including interface protocols, for connection with such networks or services;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0requirements, where necessary, for the interoperability of these services;\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0type approval of terminal or other equipment that interfaces with the network and technical requirements relating to the attachment of that equipment to the networks;\n\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0restrictions on connection of private leased or owned circuits with these networks or services or with circuits leased or owned by another enterprise; and\n\n\n\n(f)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0notification, registration and licensing.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 15.4\n\n\n\nCompetitive safeguards on major suppliers\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall maintain appropriate measures to prevent suppliers that, alone or together, are a major supplier from engaging in or continuing anticompetitive practices.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The anticompetitive practices referred to in paragraph 1 include:\n\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0engaging in anticompetitive crosssubsidisation;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0using information obtained from competitors with anticompetitive results; and\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0not making available to other service suppliers, on a timely basis, technical information about essential facilities and commercially relevant information which are necessary for them to supply services.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 15.5\n\n\n\nAccess to essential facilities\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall ensure that a major supplier in its territory makes available its essential facilities, which may include, among other things, network elements, operational support systems or support structures, to suppliers of telecommunications services of the other Party on reasonable and nondiscriminatory terms and conditions and costoriented rates.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party may determine, in accordance with its laws, those essential facilities required to be made available in its territory.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 15.6\n\n\n\nInterconnection\n\n\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall ensure that a major supplier in its territory provides interconnection:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0at any technically feasible point in the network;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0under nondiscriminatory terms, conditions, including technical standards and specifications, and rates;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0of a quality no less favourable than that provided for its own like services or for like services of nonaffiliated service suppliers or of its subsidiaries or other affiliates;\n\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in a timely fashion, on terms, conditions,\u00a0(including technical standards and specifications) and costoriented rates that are transparent, reasonable, having regard to economic feasibility, and sufficiently unbundled so that a supplier need not pay for network components or facilities that it does not require for the services to be supplied; and\n\n\n\n(f)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0upon request, at points in addition to the network termination points offered to the majority of users, subject to charges that reflect the cost of construction of necessary additional facilities.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A supplier that is authorised to supply telecommunications services has the right to negotiate a new interconnection agreement with other suppliers of public telecommunications transport networks and services. Each Party shall ensure that major suppliers are required to establish a reference interconnection offer or negotiate interconnection agreements with other suppliers of telecommunications networks and services.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall ensure that suppliers of public telecommunications transport services that acquire information from another such supplier during the process of negotiating interconnection arrangements use that information solely for the purpose for which it was supplied and respect at all times the confidentiality of information transmitted or stored.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall ensure that the procedures applicable for interconnection to a major supplier shall be made publicly available.\n\n\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall ensure that a major supplier makes publicly available either its interconnection agreements or reference interconnection offer if it is appropriate.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 15.7\n\n\n\nAuthorisation to supply telecommunications services\n\n\n\nEach Party should ensure that the authorisation to supply telecommunications services,\u00a0wherever possible, is based upon a simple notification procedure.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 15.8\n\n\n\nUniversal service\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party has the right to define the kind of universal service obligations it wishes to maintain.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall ensure that any measure on universal service that it adopts or maintains is administered in a transparent, objective, nondiscriminatory and competitively neutral manner. Each Party shall also ensure that any universal service obligation it imposes is not more burdensome than necessary for the kind of universal service that the Party has defined.\n\n\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0All suppliers should be eligible to ensure universal service. If a supplier is to be designated as the supplier of a universal service, a Party shall ensure that the selection is made through an efficient, transparent and nondiscriminatory mechanism.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 15.9\n\n\n\nScarce resources\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall administer its procedures for the allocation and use of scarce resources, including frequencies, numbers and rights of way, in an objective, timely, transparent and nondiscriminatory manner.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Notwithstanding Articles 8.4\u00a0(Market access) and 9.6\u00a0(Market access), a Party may adopt or maintain a measure that allocates and assigns spectrum and that manages frequencies. Accordingly, each Party retains the right to establish and apply its spectrum and frequency management policies that may limit the number of suppliers of public telecommunications transport services.\u00a0Each Party also retains the right to allocate frequency bands taking into account present and future needs.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall make the current state of allocated frequency bands publicly available but shall not be required to provide detailed identification of frequencies allocated for specific government use.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 15.10\n\n\n\nNumber portability\n\n\n\nEach Party shall ensure that suppliers of public telecommunications transport services in its territory provide number portability on reasonable terms and conditions.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 15.11\n\n\n\nRegulatory authority\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall ensure that its regulatory authority is legally distinct and functionally independent from any supplier of telecommunications transport networks, services or equipment, including if a Party retains ownership or control of a supplier of telecommunications transport networks or services.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall ensure that its regulatory authority's decisions and procedures are impartial with respect to all market participants and are administered in a transparent and timely manner.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall ensure that its regulatory authority is sufficiently empowered to regulate the sector, including by ensuring that it has the power to:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0require suppliers of telecommunications transport networks or services to submit any information the regulatory authority considers necessary for the administration of its responsibilities; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0enforce its decisions relating to the obligations set out in Articles 15.3 through 15.6 through appropriate sanctions that may include financial penalties, corrective orders or the suspension or revocation of licences.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 15.12\n\n\n\n\n\nResolution of telecommunication disputes\n\n\n\nRecourse to regulatory authorities\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Further to Articles 27.3\u00a0(Administrative proceedings) and 27.4\u00a0(Review and appeal), each Party shall ensure that:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0enterprises have timely recourse to its regulatory authority to resolve disputes with suppliers of public telecommunications transport networks or services regarding the matters covered in Articles 15.3 through 15.6 and that, under the law of the Party, are within the regulatory authority's jurisdiction. As appropriate, the regulatory authority shall issue a binding decision to resolve the dispute within a reasonable period of time; and\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0suppliers of telecommunications networks or services of the other Party requesting access to essential facilities or interconnection with a major supplier in the Party's territory have, within a reasonable and publicly specified period of time, recourse to a regulatory authority to resolve disputes regarding the appropriate terms, conditions and rates for interconnection or access with that major supplier.\n\n\n\nAppeal and review of regulatory authority determinations or decisions\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall ensure that an enterprise whose interests are adversely affected by a determination or decision of a regulatory authority may obtain review of the determination or decision by an impartial and independent judicial, quasijudicial or administrative authority, as provided in the law of the Party. The judicial, quasijudicial or administrative authority shall provide the enterprise with written reasons supporting its determination or decision. Each Party shall ensure that these determinations or decisions, subject to appeal or further review, are implemented by the regulatory authority.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0An application for judicial review does not constitute grounds for noncompliance with the determination or decision of the regulatory authority unless the relevant judicial authority stays this determination or decision.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 15.13\n\n\n\n\n\nTransparency\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Further to Articles 27.1\u00a0(Publication) and 27.2\u00a0(Provision of information), and in addition to the other provisions in this Chapter relating to the publication of information, each Party shall make publicly available:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the responsibilities of a regulatory authority in an easily accessible and clear form, in particular where those responsibilities are given to more than one body;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0its measures relating to public telecommunications transport networks or services, including:\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0regulations of its regulatory authority, together with the basis for these regulations;\n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0tariffs and other terms and conditions of services;\n\n\n\n(iii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0specifications of technical interfaces;\n\n\n\n(iv)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0conditions for attaching terminal or other equipment to the public telecommunications transport networks;\n\n\n\n(v)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0notification, permit, registration, or licensing requirements, if any; and\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0information on bodies responsible for preparing, amending and adopting standardsrelated\u00a0measures.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 15.14\n\n\n\nForbearance\n\n\n\nThe Parties recognise the importance of a competitive market to achieve legitimate public policy objectives for telecommunications services. To this end, and to the extent provided in its law, each Party may refrain from applying a regulation to a telecommunications service when, following analysis of the market, it is determined that effective competition is achieved.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 15.15\n\n\n\nRelation to other chapters\n\n\n\nIf there is any inconsistency between this Chapter and another Chapter, this Chapter prevails to the extent of the inconsistency.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER SIXTEEN\n\n\n\n\n\nELECTRONIC COMMERCE\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 16.1\n\n\n\nDefinitions\n\n\n\nFor the purposes of this Chapter:\n\n\n\ndelivery means a computer program, text, video, image, sound recording or other delivery that is digitally encoded; and\n\n\n\nelectronic commerce means commerce conducted through telecommunications, alone or in conjunction with other information and communication technologies.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 16.2\n\n\n\nObjective and scope\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties recognise that electronic commerce increases economic growth and trade opportunities in many sectors and confirm the applicability of the WTO rules to electronic commerce. They agree to promote the development of electronic commerce between them, in particular by cooperating on the issues raised by electronic commerce under the provisions of this Chapter.\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This Chapter does not impose an obligation on a Party to allow a delivery transmitted by electronic means except in accordance with the Party's obligations under another provision of this Agreement.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 16.3\n\n\n\nCustoms duties on electronic deliveries\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party shall not impose a customs duty, fee, or charge on a delivery transmitted by electronic means.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For greater certainty, paragraph 1 does not prevent a Party from imposing an internal tax or other internal charge on a delivery transmitted by electronic means, provided that the tax or charge is imposed in a manner consistent with this Agreement.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 16.4\n\n\n\nTrust and confidence in electronic commerce\n\n\n\nEach Party should adopt or maintain laws, regulations or administrative measures for the protection of personal information of users engaged in electronic commerce and, when doing so, shall\u00a0take into due consideration international standards of data protection\u00a0of relevant international organisations of which\u00a0both Parties are a member.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 16.5\n\n\n\nGeneral provisions\n\n\n\nConsidering the potential of electronic commerce as a social and economic development tool, the Parties recognise the importance of:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0clarity, transparency and predictability in their domestic regulatory frameworks in facilitating, to the maximum extent possible, the development of electronic commerce;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0interoperability, innovation and competition in facilitating electronic commerce; and\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0facilitating the use of electronic commerce by small and medium sized enterprises.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 16.6\n\n\n\nDialogue on electronic commerce\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Recognising the global nature of electronic commerce, the Parties agree to maintain a dialogue on issues raised by electronic commerce, which will address, among other things:\n\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the recognition of certificates of electronic signatures issued to the public and the facilitation of crossborder certification services;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the liability of intermediary service suppliers with respect to the transmission, or the storage of information;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the treatment of unsolicited electronic commercial communications; and\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the protection of personal information and the protection of consumers and businesses\u00a0from fraudulent and deceptive commercial practices in the sphere of electronic commerce.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The dialogue in paragraph 1 may take the form of exchange of information on the Parties' respective laws, regulations, and other measures on these issues, as well as sharing experiences on the implementation of such laws, regulations and other measures.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Recognising the global nature of electronic commerce, the Parties affirm the importance of actively participating in multilateral fora to promote the development of electronic commerce.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 16.7\n\n\n\nRelation to other chapters\n\n\n\nIn the event of an inconsistency between this Chapter and another chapter of this Agreement, the other chapter prevails to the extent of the inconsistency.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER SEVENTEEN\n\n\n\nCOMPETITION POLICY\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 17.1\n\n\n\nDefinitions\n\n\n\nFor the purposes of this Chapter:\n\n\n\nanticompetitive business conduct means anticompetitive agreements, concerted practices or arrangements by competitors, anticompetitive practices by an enterprise that is dominant in a market, and mergers with substantial anticompetitive effects; and,\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nservice of general economic interest means, for the European Union, a service that cannot be provided satisfactorily and under conditions, such as price, objective quality characteristics, continuity, and access to the service, consistent with the public interest, by an undertaking operating under normal market conditions. The operation of a service of general economic interest must be entrusted to one or more undertakings by the state by way of a public service assignment that defines the obligations of the undertakings in question and of the state.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 17.2\n\n\n\n\n\nCompetition policy\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties recognise the importance of free and undistorted competition in their trade relations. The Parties acknowledge that anticompetitive business conduct has the potential to distort the proper functioning of markets and undermine the benefits of trade liberalisation.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties shall take appropriate measures to proscribe anticompetitive business conduct, recognising that such measures will enhance the fulfilment of the objectives of this Agreement.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties shall cooperate on matters relating to the proscription of anticompetitive business conduct in the free trade area in accordance with the Agreement between the European Communities and the Government of Canada Regarding the Application of their Competition Laws, done at Bonn on 17 June 1999.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The measures referred to in paragraph 2 shall be consistent with the principles of transparency, nondiscrimination, and procedural fairness. Exclusions from the application of competition law shall be transparent. A Party shall make available to the other Party public information concerning such exclusions provided under its competition law.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 17.3\n\n\n\nApplication of competition policy to enterprises\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party shall ensure that the measures referred to in Article 17.2.2 apply to the Parties to the extent required by its law.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For greater certainty:\n\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in Canada, the Competition Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. C34 is binding on and applies to an agent of Her Majesty in right of Canada, or of a province, that is a corporation, in respect of commercial activities engaged in by the corporation in competition, whether actual or potential, with other persons to the extent that it would apply if the agent were not an agent of Her Majesty. Such an agent may include state enterprises, monopolies, and enterprises granted special or exclusive rights or privileges; and\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in the European Union, state enterprises, monopolies, and enterprises granted special rights or privileges are subject to the European Union's rules on competition. However, enterprises entrusted with the operation of services of general economic interest or having the character of a revenueproducing monopoly are subject to these rules, in so far as the application of these rules does not obstruct the performance, in law or in fact, of the particular tasks assigned to them.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 17.4\n\n\n\nDispute settlement\n\n\n\nNothing in this Chapter shall be subject to any form of dispute settlement pursuant to this Agreement.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER EIGHTEEN\n\n\n\nSTATE ENTERPRISES, MONOPOLIES, \nAND ENTERPRISES GRANTED SPECIAL RIGHTS OR PRIVILEGES\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 18.1\n\n\n\nDefinitions\n\n\n\nFor the purposes of this Chapter:\n\n\n\ncovered entity means:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a monopoly;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a supplier of a good or service, if it is one of a small number of goods or services suppliers authorised or established by a Party, formally or in effect, and the Party substantially prevents competition among those suppliers in its territory;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0any entity to which a Party has granted, formally or in effect, special rights or privileges to supply a good or service, substantially affecting the ability of any other enterprise to supply the same good or service in the same geographical area under substantially equivalent conditions, and allowing the entity to escape, in whole or in part, competitive pressures or market constraints;\n26\n\u00a0or\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a state enterprise;\n\n\n\ndesignate means to establish or authorise a monopoly, or to expand the scope of a monopoly to cover an additional good or service;\n\n\n\nin accordance with commercial considerations means consistent with customary business practices of a privately held enterprise in the relevant business or industry; and\n\n\n\n\n\nnondiscriminatory treatment means the better of national treatment and mostfavourednation treatment as set out in this Agreement.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 18.2\n\n\n\nScope\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties confirm their rights and obligations under Articles XVII:1 through XVII:3 of the GATT 1994, the Understanding on the Interpretation of Article XVII of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade 1994, and Articles VIII:1 and VIII:2 of GATS, all of which are hereby incorporated into and made part of this\u00a0Agreement.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This Chapter does not apply to the procurement by a Party of a good or service purchased for governmental purposes and not with a view to commercial resale or with a view to use in the supply of a good or service for commercial sale, whether or not that procurement is a \"covered procurement\" within the meaning of Article 19.2\u00a0(Scope and coverage).\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Articles 18.4 and 18.5 do not apply to the sectors set out in Article 8.2\u00a0(Scope) and Article 9.2\u00a0(Scope).\n\n\n\n4\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Articles 18.4 and 18.5 do not apply to a measure of a covered entity if a reservation of a Party, taken against a national treatment or mostfavoured nation treatment obligation, as set out in that Party's Schedule to Annex I, II, or III, would be applicable if the same measure had been adopted or maintained by that Party.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 18.3\n\n\n\n\n\nState enterprises, monopolies and enterprises granted special rights or privileges\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Without prejudice to the Parties' rights and obligations under this Agreement, nothing in this Chapter prevents a Party from designating or maintaining a state enterprise or a monopoly or from granting an enterprise special rights or privileges.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party shall not require or encourage a covered entity to act in a manner inconsistent with this Agreement.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 18.4\n\n\n\nNondiscriminatory treatment\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall ensure that in its territory a covered entity accords nondiscriminatory treatment to a covered investment, to a good of the other Party, or to a service supplier of the other Party in the purchase or sale of a good or service.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If a covered entity described in paragraphs\u00a0(b) through\u00a0(d) of the definition of \"covered entity\" in Article 18.1 acts in accordance with Article 18.5.1, the Party in whose territory the covered entity is located shall be deemed to be in compliance with the obligations set out in paragraph 1 in respect of that covered entity.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 18.5\n\n\n\n\n\nCommercial considerations\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall ensure that a covered entity in its territory acts in accordance with commercial considerations in the purchase or sale of goods, including with regard to price, quality, availability, marketability, transportation, and other terms and conditions of purchase or sale, as well as in the purchase or supply of services, including when such goods or services are supplied to or by an investment of an investor of the other Party.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Provided that a covered entity's conduct is consistent with Article 18.4 and Chapter Seventeen\u00a0(Competition Policy), the obligation contained in paragraph 1 does not apply:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in the case of a monopoly, to the fulfilment of the purpose for which the monopoly has been created or for which special rights or privileges have been granted, such as a public service obligation or regional development; or,\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in the case of a state enterprise, to the fulfilment of its public mandate.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER NINETEEN\n\n\n\nGOVERNMENT PROCUREMENT\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE\u00a019.1\n\n\n\nDefinitions\n\n\n\n\n\nFor the purposes of this Chapter:\n\n\n\ncommercial goods or services means goods or services of a type generally sold or offered for sale in the commercial marketplace to, and customarily purchased by, nongovernmental buyers for nongovernmental purposes;\n\n\n\nconstruction service means a service that has as its objective the realisation by whatever means of civil or building works, based on Division\u00a051 of the United Nations Provisional Central Product Classification\u00a0(CPC);\n\n\n\nelectronic auction means an iterative process that involves the use of electronic means for the presentation by suppliers of either new prices, or new values for quantifiable nonprice elements of the tender related to the evaluation criteria, or both, resulting in a ranking or reranking of tenders;\n\n\n\nin writing or written means any worded or numbered expression that can be read, reproduced and later communicated. It may include electronically transmitted and stored information;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nlimited tendering means a procurement method whereby the procuring entity contacts a supplier or suppliers of its choice;\n\n\n\nmeasure means any law, regulation, procedure, administrative guidance or practice, or any action of a procuring entity relating to a covered procurement;\n\n\n\nmultiuse list means a list of suppliers that a procuring entity has determined satisfy the conditions for participation in that list, and that the procuring entity intends to use more than once;\n\n\n\nnotice of intended procurement means a notice published by a procuring entity inviting interested suppliers to submit a request for participation, a tender, or both;\n\n\n\n\n\noffset means any condition or undertaking that encourages local development or improves a Party's balanceofpayments accounts, such as the use of domestic content, the licensing of technology, investment, countertrade and similar action or requirement;\n\n\n\nopen tendering means a procurement method whereby all interested suppliers may submit a tender;\n\n\n\nperson means \"person\" as defined in Article 1.1\u00a0(Definitions of general application);\n\n\n\nprocuring entity means an entity covered under Annexes\u00a0191,\u00a0192\u00a0or\u00a0193 of a Party's Market Access Schedule for this Chapter;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nqualified supplier means a supplier that a procuring entity recognises as having satisfied the conditions for participation;\n\n\n\nselective tendering means a procurement method whereby only qualified suppliers are invited by the procuring entity to submit a tender;\n\n\n\nservices includes construction services, unless otherwise specified;\n\n\n\nstandard means a document approved by a recognised body that provides for common and repeated use, rules, guidelines or characteristics for goods or services, or related processes and production methods, with which compliance is not mandatory. It may also include or deal exclusively with terminology, symbols, packaging, marking or labelling requirements as they apply to a good, service, process or production method;\n\n\n\nsupplier means a person or group of persons that provides or could provide goods or services; and\n\n\n\ntechnical specification means a tendering requirement that:\n\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0lays down the characteristics of a good or a service to be procured, including quality, performance, safety and dimensions, or the processes and methods for their production or provision; or\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0addresses terminology, symbols, packaging, marking or labelling requirements, as they apply to a good or a service.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE\u00a019.2\n\n\n\nScope and coverage\n\n\n\nApplication of this Chapter\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This Chapter applies to any measure relating to a covered procurement, whether or not it is conducted exclusively or partially by electronic means.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purposes of this Chapter, covered procurement means procurement for governmental purposes:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0of a good, a service, or any combination thereof:\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0as specified in each Party's Annexes to its Market Access Schedule for this Chapter; and\n\n\n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0not procured with a view to commercial sale or resale, or for use in the production or supply of a good or a service for commercial sale or resale;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0by any contractual means, including: purchase; lease; and rental or hire purchase, with or without an option to buy;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0for which the value, as estimated in accordance with paragraphs\u00a06 through 8, equals or exceeds the relevant threshold specified in a Party's Annexes to its Market Access Schedule for this Chapter, at the time of publication of a notice in accordance with Article\u00a019.6;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0by a procuring entity; and\n\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0that is not otherwise excluded from coverage in paragraph 3 or a Party's Annexes to its Market Access Schedule for this Chapter.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Except as otherwise provided in a Party's Annexes to its Market Access Schedule for this Chapter, this Chapter does not apply to:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the acquisition or rental of land, existing buildings or other immovable property or the rights thereon;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0noncontractual agreements or any form of assistance that a Party provides, including cooperative agreements, grants, loans, equity infusions, guarantees and fiscal incentives;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the procurement or acquisition of fiscal agency or depository services, liquidation and management services for regulated financial institutions or services related to the sale, redemption and distribution of public debt, including loans and government bonds, notes and other securities;\n\n\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0public employment contracts;\n\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0procurement conducted:\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0for the specific purpose of providing international assistance, including development aid;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0under the particular procedure or condition of an international agreement relating to the stationing of troops or relating to the joint implementation by the signatory countries of a project; or\n\n\n\n(iii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0under the particular procedure or condition of an international organisation, or funded by international grants, loans or other assistance if the applicable procedure or condition would be inconsistent with this Chapter.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A procurement subject to this Chapter shall be all procurement covered by the Market Access Schedules of Canada and the European Union, in which each Party's commitments are set out as follows:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in Annex\u00a0191, the central government entities whose procurement is covered by this Chapter;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in Annex\u00a0192, the subcentral government entities whose procurement is covered by this Chapter;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in Annex\u00a0193, all other entities whose procurement is covered by this Chapter;\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in Annex 194, the goods covered by this Chapter;\n\n\n\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in Annex\u00a0195, the services, other than construction services, covered by this Chapter;\n\n\n\n(f)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in Annex\u00a0196, the construction services covered by this Chapter;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(g)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in Annex\u00a0197, any General Notes; and\n\n\n\n(h)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in Annex 198, the means of publication used for this Chapter.\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If a procuring entity, in the context of covered procurement, requires a person not covered under a Party's Annexes to its Market Access Schedule for this Chapter to procure in accordance with particular requirements, Article\u00a019.4 shall apply mutatis\u00a0mutandis to such requirements.\n\n\n\nValuation\n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0In estimating the value of a procurement for the purpose of ascertaining whether it is a covered procurement, a procuring entity shall:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0neither divide a procurement into separate procurements nor select or use a particular valuation method for estimating the value of a procurement with the intention of totally or partially excluding it from the application of this Chapter; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0include the estimated maximum total value of the procurement over its entire duration, whether awarded to one or more suppliers, taking into account all forms of remuneration, including:\n\n\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0premiums, fees, commissions and interest; and\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0if the procurement provides for the possibility of options, the total value of such options.\n\n\n\n7.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If an individual requirement for a procurement results in the award of more than one contract, or in the award of contracts in separate parts\u00a0(\"recurring contracts\") the calculation of the estimated maximum total value shall be based on:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the value of recurring contracts of the same type of good or service awarded during the preceding 12\u00a0months or the procuring entity's preceding fiscal year, adjusted, if possible, to take into account anticipated changes in the quantity or value of the good or service being procured over the following 12\u00a0months; or\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the estimated value of recurring contracts of the same type of good or service to be awarded during the 12\u00a0months following the initial contract award or the procuring entity's fiscal year.\n\n\n\n8.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0In the case of procurement by lease, rental or hire purchase of a good or a service, or procurement for which a total price is not specified, the basis for valuation shall be:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in the case of a fixedterm contract:\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0if the term of the contract is 12\u00a0months or less, the total estimated maximum value for its duration; or\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0if the term of the contract exceeds 12\u00a0months, the total estimated maximum value, including any estimated residual value;\n\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0if the contract is for an indefinite period, the estimated monthly instalment multiplied by 48; and\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0if it is not certain whether the contract is to be a fixedterm contract, subparagraph\u00a0(b) shall be used.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE\u00a019.3\n\n\n\nSecurity and general exceptions\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Nothing in this Chapter shall be construed to prevent a Party from taking any action or from not disclosing any information that it considers necessary for the protection of its essential security interests relating to the procurement:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0of arms, ammunition\n27\n or war material;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0or to procurement indispensable for national security; or\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0for national defence purposes.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Subject to the requirement that such measures are not applied in a manner that would constitute a means of arbitrary or unjustifiable discrimination between Parties where the same conditions prevail or a disguised restriction on international trade, nothing in this Chapter shall be construed to prevent a Party from\u00a0imposing or enforcing measures:\n\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0necessary to protect public morals, order or safety;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0necessary to protect human, animal or plant life or health;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0necessary to protect intellectual property; or\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0relating to goods or services of persons with disabilities, of philanthropic institutions or of prison labour.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 19.4\n\n\n\nGeneral principles\n\n\n\nNonDiscrimination\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0With respect to any measure regarding covered procurement, each Party, including its procuring entities, shall accord immediately and unconditionally to the goods and services of the other Party and to the suppliers of the other Party offering such goods or services, treatment no less favourable than the treatment the Party, including its procuring entities, accords to its own goods, services and suppliers. For greater certainty, such treatment includes:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0within Canada, treatment no less favourable than that accorded by a province or territory, including its procuring entities, to goods and services of, and to suppliers located in,\u00a0that province or territory; and\n\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0within the European Union, treatment no less favourable than\u00a0that accorded by a Member State or a\u00a0subcentral region of a Member State, including its procuring entities, to goods and services of, and suppliers located in, that Member\u00a0State or subcentral region, as the case may be.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0With respect to any measure regarding covered procurement, a Party, including its procuring entities, shall not:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0treat a locally established supplier less favourably than another locally established supplier on the basis of the degree of foreign affiliation or ownership; or\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0discriminate against a locally established supplier on the basis that the goods or services offered by that supplier for a particular procurement are goods or services of the other Party.\n\n\n\nUse of Electronic Means\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0When conducting covered procurement by electronic means, a procuring entity shall:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0ensure that the procurement is conducted using information technology systems and software, including those related to authentication and encryption of information, that are generally available and interoperable with other generally available information technology systems and software; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0maintain mechanisms that ensure the integrity of requests for participation and tenders, including establishment of the time of receipt and the prevention of inappropriate access.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nConduct of Procurement\n\n\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A procuring entity shall conduct covered procurement in a transparent and impartial manner\u00a0that:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0is consistent with this Chapter, using methods such as open tendering, selective tendering and limited tendering;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0avoids conflicts of interest; and\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0prevents corrupt practices.\n\n\n\nRules of Origin\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purposes of covered procurement, a Party shall not apply rules of origin to goods or services imported from or supplied from the other Party that are different from the rules of origin the Party applies at the same time in the normal course of trade to imports or supplies of the same goods or services from the same Party.\n\n\n\nOffsets\n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0With regard to covered procurement, a Party, including its procuring entities, shall not seek, take account of, impose or enforce any offset.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures Not Specific to Procurement\n\n\n\n7.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Paragraphs\u00a01\u00a0and\u00a02 shall not apply to: customs duties and charges of any kind imposed on, or in connection with, importation; the method of levying such duties and charges; other import regulations or formalities and measures affecting trade in services other than measures governing covered procurement.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE\u00a019.5\n\n\n\nInformation on the procurement system\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0promptly publish any law, regulation, judicial decision, administrative ruling of general application, standard contract clause mandated by law or regulation and incorporated by reference in notices or tender documentation and procedure regarding covered procurement, and any modifications thereof, in an officially designated electronic or paper medium that is widely disseminated and remains readily accessible to the public; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0provide an explanation thereof to the other Party, on request.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall list, in Annex 198 of its Market Access Schedule:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the electronic or paper media in which the Party publishes the information described in paragraph\u00a01;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the electronic or paper media in which the Party publishes the notices required by Articles 19.6, 19.8.7 and 19.15.2; and\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the website address or addresses where the Party publishes:\n\n\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0its procurement statistics pursuant to Article 19.15.5; or\n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0its notices concerning awarded contracts pursuant to Article 19.15.6.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall promptly notify the Committee on Government Procurement of any modification to the Party's information listed in Annex 198.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE\u00a019.6\n\n\n\nNotices\n\n\n\nNotice of Intended Procurement\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For each covered procurement a procuring entity shall publish a notice of intended procurement, except in the circumstances described in Article\u00a019.12.\n\n\n\nAll the notices of intended procurement shall be directly accessible by electronic means free of charge through a single point of access subject to paragraph 2. The notices may also be published in an appropriate paper medium that is widely disseminated and those notices shall remain readily accessible to the public, at least until expiration of the timeperiod indicated in the notice.\n\n\n\nThe appropriate paper and electronic medium is listed by each Party in Annex 198.\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party may apply a transitional period of up to 5 years from the date of entry into force of this Agreement to entities covered by Annexes 192 and 193 that are not ready to participate in a single point of access referred to in paragraph 1. Those entities shall, during such transitional period, provide their notices of intended procurement, if accessible by electronic means, through links in a gateway electronic site that is accessible free of charge and listed in Annex 198.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Except as otherwise provided in this Chapter, each notice of intended procurement shall include:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the name and address of the procuring entity and other information necessary to contact the procuring entity and obtain all relevant documents relating to the procurement, and their cost and terms of payment, if any;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a description of the procurement, including the nature and the quantity of the goods or services to be procured or, if the quantity is not known, the estimated quantity;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0for recurring contracts, an estimate, if possible, of the timing of subsequent notices of intended procurement;\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a description of any options;\n\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the timeframe for delivery of goods or services or the duration of the contract;\n\n\n\n(f)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the procurement method that will be used and whether it will involve negotiation or electronic auction;\n\n\n\n(g)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0if applicable, the address and any final date for the submission of requests for participation in the procurement;\n\n\n\n\n\n(h)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the address and the final date for the submission of tenders;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the language or languages in which tenders or requests for participation may be submitted, if they may be submitted in a language other than an official language of the Party of the procuring entity;\n\n\n\n(j)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a list and brief description of any conditions for participation of suppliers, including any requirements for specific documents or certifications to be provided by suppliers in connection therewith, unless such requirements are included in tender documentation that is made available to all interested suppliers at the same time as the notice of intended procurement;\n\n\n\n(k)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0if, pursuant to Article\u00a019.8, a procuring entity intends to select a limited number of qualified suppliers to be invited to tender, the criteria that will be used to select them and, if applicable, any limitation on the number of suppliers that will be permitted to tender; and\n\n\n\n(l)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0an indication that the procurement is covered by this Chapter.\n\n\n\nSummary Notice\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For each case of intended procurement, a procuring entity shall publish a summary notice that is readily accessible, at the same time as the publication of the notice of intended procurement, in English or French. The summary notice shall contain at least the following information:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the subjectmatter of the procurement;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the final date for the submission of tenders or, if applicable, any final date for the submission of requests for participation in the procurement or for inclusion on a multiuse list; and\n\n\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the address from which documents relating to the procurement may be requested.\n\n\n\nNotice of Planned Procurement\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Procuring entities are encouraged to publish in the appropriate electronic, and, if available, paper medium listed in Annex 198 as early as possible in each fiscal year a notice regarding their future procurement plans\u00a0(\"notice of planned procurement\"). The notice of planned procurement shall also be published in the single point of access site listed in Annex 198, subject to paragraph 2. The notice of planned procurement should include the subjectmatter of the procurement and the planned date of the publication of the notice of intended procurement.\n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A procuring entity covered under Annexes 192\u00a0or 193 may use a notice of planned procurement as a notice of intended procurement provided that the notice of planned procurement includes as much of the information referred to in paragraph\u00a03 as is available to the entity and a statement that interested suppliers should express their interest in the procurement to the procuring entity.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE\u00a019.7\n\n\n\nConditions for participation\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A procuring entity shall limit any conditions for participation in a procurement to those that are essential to ensure that a supplier has the legal and financial capacities and the commercial and technical abilities to undertake the relevant procurement.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0In establishing the conditions for participation, a procuring entity:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0shall not impose the condition that, in order for a supplier to participate in a procurement, the supplier has previously been awarded one or more contracts by a procuring entity of a Party;\n\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0may require relevant prior experience if essential to meet the requirements of the procurement; and\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0shall not require prior experience in the territory of the Party to be a condition of the procurement.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0In assessing whether a supplier satisfies the conditions for participation, a procuring entity:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0shall evaluate the financial capacity and the commercial and technical abilities of a supplier on the basis of that supplier's business activities both inside and outside the territory of the Party of the procuring entity; and\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0shall base its evaluation on the conditions that the procuring entity has specified in advance in notices or tender documentation.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If there is supporting evidence, a Party, including its procuring entities, may exclude a supplier on grounds such as:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0bankruptcy;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0false declarations;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0significant or persistent deficiencies in performance of any substantive requirement or obligation under a prior contract or contracts;\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0final judgments in respect of serious crimes or other serious offences;\n\n\n\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0professional misconduct or acts or omissions that adversely reflect on the commercial integrity of the supplier; or\n\n\n\n(f)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0failure to pay taxes.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE 19.8\n\n\n\nQualification of suppliers\n\n\n\nRegistration Systems and Qualification Procedures\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party, including its procuring entities, may maintain a supplier registration system under which interested suppliers are required to register and provide certain information.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall ensure that:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0its procuring entities make efforts to minimise differences in their qualification procedures; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0if its procuring entities maintain registration systems, the entities make efforts to minimise differences in their registration systems.\n\n\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party, including its procuring entities, shall not adopt or apply a registration system or qualification procedure with the purpose or the effect of creating unnecessary obstacles to the participation of suppliers of the other Party in its procurement.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSelective Tendering\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If a procuring entity intends to use selective tendering, the entity shall:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0include in the notice of intended procurement at least the information specified in Article\u00a019.6.3(a),\u00a0(b),\u00a0(f),\u00a0(g),\u00a0(j),\u00a0(k) and\u00a0(l) and invite suppliers to submit a request for participation; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0provide, by the commencement of the timeperiod for tendering, at least the information in Article\u00a019.6.3(c),\u00a0(d),\u00a0(e),\u00a0(h) and\u00a0(i) to the qualified suppliers that it notifies as specified in Article\u00a019.10.3(b).\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A procuring entity shall allow all qualified suppliers to participate in a particular procurement, unless the procuring entity states in the notice of intended procurement any limitation on the number of suppliers that will be permitted to tender and the criteria for selecting the limited number of suppliers.\n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If the tender documentation is not made publicly available from the date of publication of the notice referred to in paragraph\u00a04, a procuring entity shall ensure that those documents are made available at the same time to all the qualified suppliers selected in accordance with paragraph\u00a05.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMultiUse Lists\n\n\n\n7.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A procuring entity may maintain a multiuse list of suppliers, provided that a notice inviting interested suppliers to apply for inclusion on the list is:\n\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0published annually; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0if published by electronic means, made available continuously,\n\n\n\nin the appropriate medium listed in Annex 198.\n\n\n\n8.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The notice provided for in paragraph\u00a07 shall include:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a description of the goods or services, or categories thereof, for which the list may be used;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the conditions for participation to be satisfied by suppliers for inclusion on the list and the methods that the procuring entity will use to verify that a supplier satisfies the conditions;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the name and address of the procuring entity and other information necessary to contact the entity and obtain all relevant documents relating to the list;\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the period of validity of the list and the means for its renewal or termination, or if the period of validity is not provided, an indication of the method by which notice will be given of the termination of use of the list; and\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0an indication that the list may be used for procurement covered by this Chapter.\n\n\n\n\n\n9.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Notwithstanding paragraph\u00a07, if a multiuse list will be valid for three years or less, a procuring entity may publish the notice referred to in paragraph\u00a07 only once, at the beginning of the period of validity of the list, provided that the notice:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0states the period of validity and that further notices will not be published; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0is published by electronic means and is made available continuously during the period of its validity.\n\n\n\n10.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A procuring entity shall allow suppliers to apply at any time for inclusion on a multiuse list and shall include on the list all qualified suppliers within a reasonably short time.\n\n\n\n11.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If a supplier that is not included on a multiuse list submits a request for participation in a procurement based on a multiuse list and all required documents, within the timeperiod provided for in Article\u00a019.10.2, a procuring entity shall examine the request. The procuring entity shall not exclude the supplier from consideration in respect of the procurement on the grounds that the entity has insufficient time to examine the request, unless, in exceptional cases, due to the complexity of the procurement, the entity is not able to complete the examination of the request within the timeperiod allowed for the submission of tenders.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nProcuring Entities of Annex\u00a0192 and Annex\u00a0193\n\n\n\n12.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A procuring entity covered under Annexes 192\u00a0or 193 may use a notice inviting suppliers to apply for inclusion on a multiuse list as a notice of intended procurement, provided that:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the notice is published in accordance with paragraph 7 and includes the information required under paragraph\u00a08, as much of the information required under Article\u00a019.6.3 as is available and a statement that it constitutes a notice of intended procurement or that only the suppliers on the multiuse list will receive further notices of procurement covered by the multiuse list; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the entity promptly provides to suppliers that have expressed an interest in a given procurement to the entity, sufficient information to permit them to assess their interest in the procurement, including all remaining information required in Article\u00a019.6.3, to the extent such information is available.\n\n\n\n13.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A procuring entity covered under Annexes 192\u00a0or 193 may allow a supplier that has applied for inclusion on a multiuse list in accordance with paragraph\u00a010 to tender in a given procurement, if there is sufficient time for the procuring entity to examine whether the supplier satisfies the conditions for participation.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nInformation on Procuring Entity Decisions\n\n\n\n14.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A procuring entity shall promptly inform any supplier that submits a request for participation in a procurement or application for inclusion on a multiuse list of the procuring entity's decision with respect to the request or application.\n\n\n\n15.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If a procuring entity rejects a supplier's request for participation in a procurement or application for inclusion on a multiuse list, ceases to recognise a supplier as qualified, or removes a supplier from a multiuse list, the entity shall promptly inform the supplier and, on request of the supplier, promptly provide the supplier with a written explanation of the reasons for its decision.\n\n\n\n\nARTICLE\u00a019.9\n\n\n\nTechnical specifications and tender documentation\n\n\n\nTechnical Specifications\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A procuring entity shall not prepare, adopt or apply any technical specification or prescribe any conformity assessment procedure with the purpose or the effect of creating unnecessary obstacles to international trade.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0In prescribing the technical specifications for the goods or services being procured, a procuring entity shall, if appropriate:\n\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0set out the technical specification in terms of performance and functional requirements, rather than design or descriptive characteristics; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0base the technical specification on international standards, if they exist; otherwise, on national technical regulations, recognised national standards or building codes.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If design or descriptive characteristics are used in the technical specifications, a procuring entity should indicate, if appropriate, that it will consider tenders of equivalent goods or services that demonstrably fulfil the requirements of the procurement by including words such as \"or equivalent\" in the tender documentation.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A procuring entity shall not prescribe technical specifications that require or refer to a particular trademark or trade name, patent, copyright, design, type, specific origin, producer or supplier, unless there is no other sufficiently precise or intelligible way of describing the procurement requirements and provided that, in such cases, the entity includes words such as \"or equivalent\" in the tender documentation.\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A procuring entity shall not seek or accept, in a manner that would have the effect of precluding competition, advice that may be used in the preparation or adoption of any technical specification for a specific procurement from a person that may have a commercial interest in the procurement.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For greater certainty, a Party, including its procuring entities, may prepare, adopt or apply technical specifications to promote the conservation of natural resources or protect the environment, provided that it does so in accordance with this Article.\n\n\n\nTender Documentation\n\n\n\n7.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A procuring entity shall make available to suppliers tender documentation that includes all information necessary to permit suppliers to prepare and submit responsive tenders.
