Veterinary certification\n\n\n\n\nEgg Products \u2013 Import Procedures, AHPD-DSAE-IE-2001-5-3, December 20, 1995\n\n\n\n\nDirectives\n\n\n90/539\n\n\n2002/99\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nHorizontal issues\n\n\n\n\n\n\nListing of establishments\n\n\n\n\nRegulations\n\n\n2004/852\n\n\n2004/853\n\n\n2004/854\n\n\n\n\n- Meat Inspection Act\n\n\n- Meat Inspection Regulations, 1990\n\n\n- Fish Inspection Act\u00a0\n\n\n- Fish Inspection Regulations\n\n\n- Canada Agricultural Products Act\n\n\n- Dairy Products Regulations\u00a0\n\n\n\n\nListing required for fresh meat and meat products\n\n\n\n\n- Meat Inspection Act\n\n\n- Meat Inspection Regulations, 1990\n\n\n- Fish Inspection Act\u00a0\n\n\n- Fish Inspection Regulations\u00a0\n\n\n- Canada Agricultural Products Act\n\n\n- Dairy Products Regulations\n\n\n\n\nRegulations\n\n\n2004/852\n\n\n2004/853\n\n\n2004/854\n\n\n\n\nThe following conditions apply to all animals and animal product commodities with public health recognition where a list of establishments is required:\n\n\n1. Lists of Canadian establishments and plants are entered into the TRACES system by Canada; and, \n\n\n2. Canada provides guarantees that the establishments fulfil the conditions as laid down in this Chapter, in its entirety. \n\n\nThe European Union updates and publishes the list of establishments without undue delay.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nWater\n\n\n\n\nDirective\n\n\n98/83\n\n\n\n\n- Canada Agricultural Products Act\n\n\n- Dairy Products Regulations\u00a0\n\n\n- Fish Inspection Act\u00a0\n\n\n- Fish Inspection Regulations\u00a0\n\n\n- Food and Drugs Act\n\n\n- Food and Drug Regulations\n\n\n- Meat Inspection Act\n\n\n- Meat Inspection Regulations, 1990\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n- Canada Agricultural Products Act\n\n\n- Dairy Products Regulations\u00a0\n\n\n- Fish Inspection Act\u00a0\n\n\n- Fish Inspection Regulations\u00a0\n\n\n- Food and Drugs Act\n\n\n- Food and Drug Regulations\n\n\n- Meat Inspection Act\n\n\n- Meat Inspection Regulations, 1990\n\n\n\n\nDirective\n\n\n98/83\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nAPPENDIX A \n\n\n\nSPECIAL CONDITIONS \nWITH RESPECT TO CERTAIN EXPORTS \nFROM CANADA TO THE EUROPEAN UNION\n\n\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Compliance with European Union rules on transmissible spongiform encephalopathy;\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Shrouds not to be used on carcases;\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Compliance with European Union rules on decontamination;\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Compliance with microbiological testing for export to Finland and Sweden as laid down in the Commission Regulation (EC) No 1688/2005.\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Ante-mortem inspection\n\n\n\nRoutine ante-mortem inspection procedures apply provided a CFIA veterinarian is present on premises when ante-mortem inspection is conducted on animals intended to be slaughtered for export to the European Union; \n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Post-mortem inspection\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Pork: \n\n\n\nin accordance with the Commission Implementing Regulation (EC) No 2015/1375: \n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0skeletal muscle is tested for Trichinella by using a validated digestion method approved by the CFIA in a CFIA laboratory or a laboratory certified by the CFIA for that purpose; or,\n\n\n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0skeletal muscle is submitted to cold treatment by using a treatment approved by the CFIA;\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Bovine over 6 weeks old:\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0liver: incision of the gastric surface and at the base of the caudate lobe to examine the bile ducts;\n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0head: two incisions in the external masseters parallel to the mandible;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Domestic solipeds: \n\n\n\nin accordance with the Commission Implementing Regulation (EC) No 2015/1375, skeletal muscle is tested for Trichinella by using a validated digestion method approved by the CFIA in a CFIA laboratory or a laboratory certified by the CFIA for that purpose;\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Farmed game - wild boar:\n\n\n\nin accordance with the Commission Implementing Regulation (EC) No 2015/1375, skeletal muscle is tested for Trichinella by using a validated digestion method approved by the CFIA in a CFIA laboratory or a laboratory certified by the CFIA for that purpose;\n\n\n\n7.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Regular check on general hygiene: \n\n\nin addition to Canadian operational and preoperational sanitation requirements, the products testing requirements for E. coli and Salmonella for the United States of America (USA) as is written in Annex T:  Testing for Escherichia coli (E. coli) in Slaughter Establishments and Annex U:  USDA Performance Standards for Salmonella of USA section of Chapter 11 of the CFIA's Meat Hygiene Manual of Procedures are implemented; and\n\n\n\n8.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Compliance with microbiological food safety criteria of the importing Party.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSECTION B\n\n\n\nPhytosanitary Measures\n\n\n\nTo be agreed at a later stage.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nANNEX5F\n\n\n\n\nAPPROVAL OF ESTABLISHMENTS OR FACILITIES\n\n\n\nThe conditions and procedures for the purpose of Article 5.7.4(b) are as follows:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the import of the product has been authorised, if so required, by the competent authority of the importing Party;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the establishment or facility concerned has been approved by the competent authority of the exporting Party;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the competent authority of the exporting Party has the authority to suspend or withdraw the approval of the establishment or facility; and\n\n\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the exporting Party has provided relevant information requested by the importing Party.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nANNEX 5G\n\n\n\n\nPROCEDURE RELATED \nTO SPECIFIC IMPORT REQUIREMENTS FOR PLANT HEALTH\n\n\n\nA key objective of this procedure is that the importing Party establishes and maintains, to the best of its ability, a list of regulated pests for commodities where a phytosanitary concern exists in its territory.\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If the Parties jointly identify a specific commodity as a priority, the importing Party should establish a preliminary list of pests for that commodity, within a period of time determined by the Parties, once it receives from the exporting Party:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0information on the pest status in the territory of the exporting Party that relates to the pests regulated by at least one of the Parties; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0information on the pest status of other pests occurring in its territory based on international databases and other available sources.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The preliminary list of pests of an importing Party may include pests that are already regulated in its territory. It may also include potential quarantine pests for which the importing Party may require a pest risk analysis should a commodity be confirmed as a priority in accordance with paragraph\u00a03.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For a commodity:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0for which a preliminary list of pests has been established pursuant to paragraph\u00a02;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0which the Parties confirm is a priority; and\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0for which the exporting Party has provided all relevant information required by the importing Party,\n\n\n\nthe importing Party should undertake the steps necessary to establish its regulated pest list as well as the specific import requirements for that commodity.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If the importing Party provides for more than one phytosanitary measure to meet the specific import requirements for a specific commodity, the competent authority of the exporting Party should communicate to the competent authority of the importing Party which measure or measures it will use as the basis for certification.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nANNEX 5H\n\n\n\n\nPRINCIPLES AND GUIDELINES TO CONDUCT AN AUDIT OR VERIFICATION\n\n\n\nTo be agreed at a later stage.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nANNEX 5I\n\n\n\n\nEXPORT CERTIFICATION\n\n\n\nModel attestation for health certificates for animals and animal products\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Official health certificates shall cover consignments of products being traded between the Parties.\n\n\n\nHealth attestations\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Equivalence agreed: Model health attestation to be used (equivalence for measures or certification systems). Refer to Annex\u00a05E;\n\n\n\n\"The [insert product] herein described, complies with the relevant [European Union/Canada] (*) SPS measure(s) and requirement(s) which have been recognised as equivalent to the [Canada/European Union] (*) SPS measure(s) and requirement(s) as prescribed in Annex 5-E of the Canada-European Union Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement [and the special condition(s) as set out in Annex 5-E](*).\n\n\n\n*\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Delete as appropriate.\"\n\n\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Until certificates on the basis of equivalence have been adopted,\u00a0existing certification shall continue to be used.\n\n\n\nOfficial languages for certification\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For import into the European Union, the certificate must be drawn up in at least one of the official languages of the Member State of the border inspection post of introduction of the consignment into the European Union; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0for import into Canada, the certificate must be drawn up in one of the official languages of Canada.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeans of certification\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The exchange of original certificate information may occur by a paperbased system or a secure method of electronic data transmission that offers an equivalent certification guarantee. The exporting Party may elect to provide electronic official certification if the importing Party has determined that equivalent security guarantees are being provided, including the use of a digital signature and a nonrepudiation mechanism. The importing Party's agreement for the exclusive use of electronic certification can either be recorded through correspondence in one of the annexes to this Chapter or by correspondence in accordance with Article\u00a05.14.8.\n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The European Union may set out its import certificates for live animals and animal products from Canada with an equivalence status referred to in Annex\u00a05E in Trade and Control Export System (\"TRACES\").\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nANNEX 5J\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIMPORT CHECKS AND FEES\n\n\n\n\nSECTION A\n\n\n\nFrequencies of checks\n\n\n\nThe Parties may modify any frequency rate, within their responsibilities, as appropriate, taking into account the nature of checks applied by the exporting Party prior to export, the importing Party's past experience with products imported from the exporting Party, progress made toward the recognition of equivalence, or as a result of other actions or consultations provided for in this Agreement.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nTable 1 \u2013 Frequencies of frontier checks on consignments of live animals, animal products and animal byproducts\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of frontier check\n\n\n\n\nNormal rate as referred to in Article\u00a05.10.1\n\n\n\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Documentary and identity\n\n\nEach Party performs documentary and identity checks on all consignments\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Physical Checks\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLive animals\n\n\n\n\n100 per cent\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSemen, embryos or ova\n\n\n\n\n10 per cent\n\n\n\n\n\n\nAnimal products for human consumption\n\n\nFresh meat including offal, and products of the bovine, ovine, caprine, porcine and equine species defined in Council Directive 92/5/EEC\n\n\nWhole eggs\n\n\nLard and rendered fats\n\n\nAnimal casings\n\n\nGelatin\n\n\nPoultry meat and poultry meat products\n\n\nRabbit meat, game meat (wild/farmed) and products\n\n\nMilk and milk products\n\n\nEgg products\n\n\nHoney\n\n\nBone and bone products\n\n\nMeat preparations and minced meat\n\n\nFrogs' legs and snails\n\n\n\n\n10 per cent\n\n\n\n\n\n\nAnimal products not for human consumption\n\n\nLard and rendered fats\n\n\nAnimal casings\n\n\nMilk and milk products\n\n\nGelatin\n\n\nBone and bone products\n\n\nHides and skins ungulates\n\n\nGame trophies\n\n\nProcessed petfood\n\n\nRaw material for the manufacture of petfood\n\n\nRaw material, blood, blood products, glands and organs for pharmaceutical or technical use\n\n\nProcessed animal protein (packaged)\n\n\nBristles, wool, hair and feathers\n\n\nHorns, horn products, hooves and hoof products\n\n\nApiculture products\n\n\nHatching eggs\n\n\nManure\n\n\nHay and straw\n\n\n\n\n10 per cent\n\n\n\n\n\n\nProcessed animal protein not for human consumption (bulked)\n\n\n\n\n100\u00a0per cent for six consecutive consignments (as per Commission Regulation (EU) No\u00a0142/2011 implementing Regulation (EC) No\u00a01069/2009), if these consecutive tests prove negative, random sampling shall be reduced to 20\u00a0per cent of subsequent bulk consignments from the same source. If one of these random sampling proves positive, the competent authority must sample each consignment from the same source until six consecutive tests again prove negative.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLive bivalve molluscan shellfish\n\n\n\n\n15 per cent\n\n\n\n\n\n\nFish and fishery products for human consumption\n\n\nFish products in hermetically sealed containers intended to render them stable at ambient temperatures, fresh and frozen fish, dry fisheries products, salted fisheries products, or dry and salted fisheries products\n\n\nOther fishery products\n\n\nLive crustaceans or fresh headed and degutted fish without other manual processing\n\n\n\n\n\n15 per cent\n\n\n\n\n\n2 per cent\n\n\n\n\n\n\nFor the purposes of this Annex, \"consignment\" means a quantity of products of the same type, covered by the same health certificate or document, conveyed by the same means of transport, consigned by a single consignee and originating from the same exporting Party or part of that Party.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSECTION B\n\n\n\n\n\nFees\n\n\n\nTo be agreed at a later stage.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nANNEX 8A\n\n\n\n\nEXPROPRIATION\n\n\n\nThe Parties confirm their shared understanding that:\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Expropriation may be direct or indirect:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0direct expropriation occurs when an investment is nationalised or otherwise directly expropriated through formal transfer of title or outright seizure; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0indirect expropriation occurs if a measure or series of measures of a Party has an effect equivalent to direct expropriation, in that it substantially deprives the investor of the fundamental attributes of property in its investment, including the right to use, enjoy and dispose of its investment, without formal transfer of title or outright seizure.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The determination of whether a measure or series of measures of a Party, in a specific fact situation, constitutes an indirect expropriation requires a casebycase, factbased inquiry that takes into consideration, among other factors:\n\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the economic impact of the measure or series of measures, although the sole fact that a measure or series of measures of a Party has an adverse effect on the economic value of an investment does not establish that an indirect expropriation has occurred;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the duration of the measure or series of measures of a Party;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the extent to which the measure or series of measures interferes with distinct, reasonable investmentbacked expectations; and\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the character of the measure or series of measures, notably their object, context and intent.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For greater certainty, except in the rare circumstance when the impact of a measure or series of measures is so severe in light of its purpose that it appears manifestly excessive, nondiscriminatory measures of a Party that are designed and applied to protect legitimate public welfare objectives, such as health, safety and the environment, do not constitute indirect expropriations.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nANNEX 8B\n\n\n\nPUBLIC DEBT\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purposes of this Annex:\n\n\n\n\n\nnegotiated restructuring means the restructuring or rescheduling of debt of a Party that has been effected through \n\n\n\n(a) a modification or amendment of debt instruments, as provided for under their terms, including\u00a0their\u00a0governing law, or\n\n\n\n(b) a debt exchange or other similar process in which the holders of no less than 75 per cent of the aggregate principal amount of the outstanding debt subject to restructuring have consented to such debt exchange or other process; and\n\n\n\ngoverning law of a debt instrument means a jurisdiction's laws applicable to that debt instrument.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0No claim that a restructuring of debt of a Party breaches an obligation under Sections C and D may be submitted, or if already submitted continue, under Section F if the restructuring is a negotiated restructuring at the time of submission, or becomes a negotiated restructuring after such submission, except for a claim that the restructuring violates Article 8.6 or 8.7.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Notwithstanding Article 8.22.1(b) and subject to paragraph 2, an investor of a Party may not submit a claim under Section F that a restructuring of debt of a Party breaches an obligation under Sections C and D (other than Article 8.6 or 8.7)\n1\n unless 270 days have elapsed from the date of submission by the claimant\u00a0of the written request for consultations pursuant to Article 8.19.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For greater certainty, debt of a Party means a debt instrument of any level of government of a Party.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nANNEX 8C\n\n\n\n\nEXCLUSIONS FROM DISPUTE SETTLEMENT\n\n\n\nA decision by Canada following a review under the Investment Canada Act, R.S.C. 1985, c.\u00a028 (1st\u00a0Supp.), regarding whether or not to permit an investment that is subject to review, is not subject to the dispute settlement provisions under Section F, or to Chapter TwentyNine (Dispute Settlement). For greater certainty, this exclusion is without prejudice to the right of a Party to have recourse to Chapter TwentyNine (Dispute Settlement) with respect to the consistency of a measure with a Party's reservations, as set out in the Party's Schedule to Annexes\u00a0I, II or\u00a0III, as appropriate.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nANNEX 8D\n\n\n\n\nJoint Declaration concerning Article 8.12.6\n\n\n\nMindful that the Tribunal for the resolution of investment disputes between investors and states\u00a0is meant to enforce the obligations referred to in Article 8.18.1, and is not an appeal mechanism for the decisions of domestic courts, the Parties recall that the domestic courts of each Party are responsible for the determination of the existence and validity of intellectual property rights. The Parties further recognise that each Party shall be free to determine the appropriate method of implementing the provisions of this Agreement regarding intellectual property within their own legal system and practice.\u00a0The Parties agree to review the relation between intellectual property rights and investment disciplines within three years after entry into force of this Agreement or at the request of a Party.\u00a0Further to this review and to the extent required, the Parties may issue binding interpretations to ensure the proper interpretation of the scope of investment protection under this Agreement in accordance with the provisions of Article 8.31.3.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nANNEX 8E\n\n\n\n\nJoint Declaration on Articles 8.16, 9.8, and 28.6\n\n\n\nWith respect to Articles 8.16, 9.8 (Denial of benefits) and 28.6 (National security), the Parties confirm their understanding that measures that are \"related to the maintenance of international peace and security\" include the protection of human rights.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nANNEX 8F\n\n\n\n\nDeclaration by Canada on the Investment Canada Act\n\n\n\nCanada will increase the threshold for review under the Investment Canada Act, R.S.C. 1985, c.\u00a028 (1st\u00a0Supp.) (\"ICA\") to CAD $1.5 billion once this Agreement is implemented.\n\n\n\nAny future amendments to the ICA would be subject to the requirement that such amendments could not decrease the conformity of the ICA with the investment obligations of this Agreement.\n\n\n\nAs set out in Canada's ICA reservation (Annex I-C-1), the higher threshold will apply to an acquisition of a Canadian enterprise by an investor of the European Union that is not a state enterprise. The determination of whether the acquirer is an investor of the European Union would be based on whether a national of the European Union controls the acquirer in law, or in the absence of a majority ownership, whether nationals of the European Union control the acquirer in fact such as through the ownership of voting interests or through the nationality of members of the board of directors. Moreover, enterprises of the European Union that are controlled by nationals from Canada's existing Free Trade Agreement partners with which Canada has taken investment commitments would also benefit from the higher threshold.\n\n\n\nCanada will amend its ICA to provide for the changes necessary for the higher review threshold stated above upon the entry into force of this Agreement.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nANNEX 9A\n\n\n\n\nUNDERSTANDING ON NATIONAL TREATMENT \nWITH RESPECT TO THE CROSSBORDER SUPPLY OF SERVICES\n\n\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The EU Party and Canada share the following understanding with respect to the application of Article 9.3 to treatment accorded by a provincial or territorial government in Canada, or by a government of or in a Member State of the European Union with respect to the cross-border supply of services as defined in Article 9.1 or the supply of a service by a natural person of a Party in the territory of the other Party.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Pursuant to Article 9.3, treatment \"no less favourable than the most favourable treatment accorded, in like situations, by that government to its own service suppliers and services\" does not apply to a person of the other Party, or to a service supplied by this person if:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in the case of Canada, a provincial or territorial government of Canada accords more favourable treatment to a service supplier which is a person of another provincial or territorial government of Canada, or to a service supplied by this supplier; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in the case of the EU Party:\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a government of a Member\u00a0State of the European Union accords more favourable treatment to a service supplier which is a person of another Member\u00a0State or to a service supplied by this supplier;\n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a regional government of a Member\u00a0State of the European Union accords more favourable treatment to a service supplier which is a person of another regional government of that Member\u00a0State, or to a service supplied by this supplier; and\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the more favourable treatment referred to in subparagraphs (a) and (b) is accorded pursuant to specific mutual rights and obligations applicable between these governments.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the EU Party, paragraph 2 includes in particular treatment accorded pursuant to the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, done at Lisbon on 13\u00a0December\u00a02007 in respect of the free movement of persons and services, as well as to treatment accorded by any measure adopted pursuant to that Treaty. A government of or in a Member\u00a0State of the European Union may accord more favourable treatment pursuant to the Treaty\u00a0on the Functioning of the European Union to those natural persons who are nationals of another Member\u00a0State of the European Union, or to enterprises formed in accordance with the law of another Member\u00a0State of the European Union and having their registered office, central administration or principal place of business within the European Union, and to the services supplied by these natural persons or enterprises.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For Canada, paragraph 2 includes in particular treatment accorded pursuant to the Canadian Agreement on Internal Trade, dated 18 July 1994, between the Government of Canada and the governments of the provinces and territories of Canada (\"AIT\") as well as to treatment accorded by any measure adopted pursuant to the AIT and from regional agreements on the free movement of persons and services. A provincial or territorial government in Canada may accord a more favourable treatment pursuant to the AIT and these regional agreements to those natural persons who are residents in the territory of a party to the AIT or regional agreement or to enterprises formed in accordance with the law of a party to the AIT or regional agreement that have their registered office, central administration or principal place of business within Canada, and to the services supplied by these natural persons or enterprises.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nANNEX 9B\n\n\n\n\nUNDERSTANDING ON NEW SERVICES \nNOT CLASSIFIED IN THE UNITED NATIONS PROVISIONAL \nCENTRAL PRODUCT CLASSIFICATION (CPC), 1991\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties agree that Chapter Twelve (Domestic Regulation) and Articles 9.3, 9.5, and 9.6\u00a0do not apply to a measure relating to a new service that cannot be classified in the CPC 1991.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0To the extent possible, each Party shall notify the other Party prior to adopting a measure inconsistent with Chapter Twelve (Domestic Regulation), and Articles 9.3, 9.5, and 9.6 with respect to a new service, as referred to in paragraph 1.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0At the request of a Party, the Parties shall enter into negotiations to incorporate the new service into the scope of this Agreement.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For greater certainty, paragraph\u00a01 does not apply to an existing service that could be classified in the CPC\u00a01991, but that could not previously be supplied on a crossborder basis due to lack of technical feasibility.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nANNEX 9C\n\n\n\n\nUNDERSTANDING ON COURIER SERVICES\n\n\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties share the following understanding with respect to the application of Articles\u00a08.2.2(a) (Scope) and\u00a09.2.2(e) (Scope).\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties confirm that courier services are covered by Chapters Eight (Investment) and Nine (CrossBorder Trade in Services), subject to applicable reservations as set out in the Parties' Schedules to Annexes I and II. For greater certainty, the treatment offered to courier services under Chapters Eight and Nine does not include the grant of air traffic rights for courier service suppliers. These rights are subject to the Agreement on Air Transport between Canada and the European Community and its Member\u00a0States, done at Brussels on 17\u00a0December\u00a02009 and Ottawa on December\u00a018, 2009.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nANNEX 10A\n\n\n\n\nLIST OF CONTACT POINTS \nOF THE MEMBER STATES OF THE EUROPEAN UNION\n\n\n\nFor the purposes of this Annex, the abbreviations are as defined in paragraph 8 of Annex 10E.\n\n\n\nAT\n\n\nFor residence and visa issues:\n\n\nDepartment III/4 - Residence, Civil Status and Citizenship Matters\n\n\nFederal Ministry of the Interior\n\n\n\nFor labour market issues:\n\n\n\n\nEU labour market laws and international affairs of labour market laws\n\n\nFederal Ministry for Labour, Social Affairs and Consumer Protection\n\n\n\nBE\n\n\nDirection Migration Policy\n\n\nImmigration and Border Policy Directorate\n\n\nHome Office\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nANNEX 10-B\n\n\n\n\nRESERVATIONS AND EXCEPTIONS \nAPPLYING IN SPECIFIC MEMBER STATES \nOF THE EUROPEAN UNION FOR KEY PERSONNEL AND \nSHORTTERM BUSINESS VISITORS\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Articles\u00a010.7 and 10.9 do not apply to any existing nonconforming measure listed in this Annex, to the extent of the nonconformity.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A measure listed in this Annex may be maintained, continued, promptly renewed, or amended, provided that the amendment does not decrease the conformity of the measure with Articles\u00a010.7 or 10.9, as it existed immediately before the amendment.\n2\n\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Business visitors for investment purposes\n\n\n\n\n\n\nAll sectors\n\n\n\n\nAT: Business visitor needs to be employed by an enterprise other than a nonprofit organisation, otherwise: Unbound.\n\n\nCZ: Business visitor for investment purposes needs to be employed by an enterprise other than a nonprofit organisation, otherwise: Unbound.\n\n\nSK: Business visitor for investment purposes needs to be employed by an enterprise other than a nonprofit organisation, otherwise: Unbound. Work permit required, including economic needs test.\n\n\nUK: Permissible length of stay: up to 90 days in any twelve month period. Business visitor needs to be employed by an enterprise other than a nonprofit organisation, otherwise: Unbound.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Investors\n\n\n\n\n\n\nAll sectors\n\n\n\n\nAT: Economic needs test.\n\n\nCZ, SK: Work permit, including economic needs test, required in case of investors employed by an enterprise.\n\n\nDK: Maximum stay of 90 days within any six month period. If investors wish to establish a business in Denmark as selfemployed, a work permit is required.\n\n\nFI: Investors need to be employed by an enterprise other than a nonprofit organisation, in a position of middle or top management.\n\n\nHU: Maximum length of stay 90 days where the investor is not employed by an enterprise in Hungary. Economic needs test required where the investor is employed by an enterprise in Hungary.\n\n\nIT: Economic needs test required where the investor is not employed by an enterprise.\n\n\nLT, NL, PL: the category of investors is not recognised with regard to natural persons representing the investor.\n\n\nLV: For preinvestment phase maximum length of stay is limited to 90 days within any six months period. Extension in postinvestment phase to one year, subject to criteria in national legislation such as field and amount of investment made.\n\n\nUK: The category of investors is not recognised: Unbound.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Intracorporate transferees (specialists and senior personnel)\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nAll sectors\n\n\n\n\nBG: The number of foreign natural persons employed within a Bulgarian enterprise may not exceed ten per cent of the average annual number of citizens of the European Union employed by the respective Bulgarian enterprise. Where less than 100 persons are employed, the number may, subject to authorisation, exceed ten per cent.\n\n\nAT, CZ, SK, UK: Intracorporate transferees need to be employed by an enterprise other than a nonprofit organisation, otherwise: Unbound.\n\n\nFI: Senior personnel needs to be employed by an enterprise other than a nonprofit organisation.\n\n\nHU: Natural persons who have been a partner in an enterprise do not qualify to be transferred as intracorporate transferees.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Intracorporate transferees (graduate trainees)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nAll sectors\n\n\n\n\nAT, CZ, FR, DE, ES, HU, SK: The training which is to be delivered as a result of the transfer of a graduate trainee to an enterprise must be linked to the university degree which has been obtained by the graduate trainee.\n\n\nBG, HU: Economic needs test.\n\n\nCZ, FI, SK, UK: Graduate trainee needs to be employed by an enterprise other than a nonprofit organisation, otherwise: Unbound.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n7.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Shortterm business visitors\n\n\n\n\n\n\nAll activities in Annex 10D\n\n\n\n\nDK, HR: Work permit, including economic needs test, required in case the shortterm business visitor provides a service in the territory of Denmark or Croatia, respectively.\n\n\nLV: Work permit required for operations/activities to be performed on the basis of a contract.\n\n\nSK: In case of providing a service in the territory of Slovakia, a work permit, including economic needs test, is required beyond seven days in a month or 30\u00a0days in calendar year.\n\n\nUK: The category of shortterm business visitors is not recognised: Unbound.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nResearch and Design\n\n\n\n\nAT: Work permit, including economic needs test, required, except for research activities of scientific and statistical researchers.\n\n\nNL: Work permit required, including economic needs test.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMarketing research\n\n\n\n\nAT: Work permit required, including economic needs test. Economic needs test is waived for research and analysis activities for up to seven days in a month or 30 days in a calendar year. University degree required.\n\n\nNL: Work permit required, including economic needs test.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nTrade Fairs and Exhibitions\n\n\n\n\nAT: Work permit, including economic needs test, required for activities beyond seven days in a month or 30\u00a0days in a calendar year.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nAfterSales or AfterLease Service\n\n\n\n\nAT: Work permit required, including economic needs test. Economic needs test is waived for natural persons training workers to perform services and possessing uncommon knowledge.\n\n\nCZ: Work permit is required beyond seven days in a month or 30 days in calendar year.\n\n\nFI: Depending on the activity, a residence permit may be required.\n\n\nSE: Work permit required, except for (i) people who participate in training, testing, preparation or completion of deliveries, or similar activities within the framework of a business transaction, or (ii) fitters or technical instructors in connection with urgent installation or repair of machinery for up to two months, in the context of an emergency. No economic needs test performed.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nCommercial Transactions\n\n\n\n\nAT: Work permit, including economic needs test, required for activities beyond seven days in a month or 30\u00a0days in a calendar year.\n\n\nFI: The natural person needs to be providing services as an employee of an enterprise located in the territory of the other Party.\n\n\nNL: Work permit required, including economic needs test.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nTourism personnel\n\n\n\n\nNL: Work permit required, including economic needs test.\n\n\nFI: The natural person needs to be providing services as an employee of an enterprise located in the territory of the other Party.\n\n\nPL: Unbound.\n\n\nSE: Work permit required, except for drivers and staff of tourist buses. No economic needs test performed.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nTranslation and Interpretation\n\n\n\n\nAT, NL: Work permit required, including economic needs test.\n\n\nPL: Unbound.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nANNEX 10C\n\n\n\n\nEQUIVALENT QUALIFICATIONS FOR ENGINEERING TECHNOLOGISTS AND SCIENTIFIC TECHNOLOGISTS\n\n\n\nFor the purpose of this Agreement:\n\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0for engineering technologists (CPC 8672, and 8673): completion of a three year postsecondary degree from an officially recognised institution in engineering technology is considered equivalent to a university degree; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0for scientific technologists (CPC 881, 8671, 8674, 8676, 851, 852, 853, 8675, and 883): completion of a three year postsecondary degree from an officially recognised institution in the disciplines of agriculture, architecture, biology, chemistry, physics, forestry, geology, geophysics, mining and energy is considered equivalent to a university degree.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nANNEX 10D\n\n\n\n\nACTIVITIES OF SHORTTERM BUSINESS VISITORS\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0meetings and consultations: natural persons attending meetings or conferences, or engaged in consultations with business associates;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0research and design: technical, scientific and statistical researchers conducting independent research or research for an enterprise located in the territory of the other Party;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0marketing research: market researchers and analysts conducting research or analysis for an enterprise located in the territory of the other Party;\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0training seminars: personnel of an enterprise who enter the territory of the other Party to receive training in techniques and work practices who are employed by companies or organisations in that Party, provided that the training received is confined to observation, familiarisation and classroom instruction only;\n\n\n\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0trade fairs and exhibitions: personnel attending a trade fair for the purpose of promoting their company or its products or services;\n\n\n\n(f)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0sales: representatives of a supplier of services or goods taking orders or negotiating the sale of services or goods or entering into agreements to sell services or goods for that supplier, but not delivering goods or supplying services themselves. Shortterm business visitors do not engage in making direct sales to the general public;\n\n\n\n(g)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0purchasing: buyers purchasing goods or services for an enterprise, or management and supervisory personnel, engaging in a commercial transaction carried out in the territory of the other Party;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(h)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0aftersales or afterlease service: installers, repair and maintenance personnel, and supervisors, possessing specialised knowledge essential to a seller's contractual obligation, performing services or training workers to perform services, pursuant to a warranty or other service contract incidental to the sale or lease of commercial or industrial equipment or machinery, including computer software, purchased or leased from an enterprise located outside the territory of the Party into which temporary entry is sought, throughout the duration of the warranty or service contract;\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0commercial transactions:\u00a0management and supervisory personnel and financial services personnel (including insurers, bankers and investment brokers) engaging in a commercial transaction for an enterprise located in the territory of the other Party;\n\n\n\n(j)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0tourism personnel: tour and travel agents, tour guides or tour operators attending or participating in conventions or accompanying a tour that has begun in the territory of the other Party; and\n\n\n\n(k)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0translation and interpretation:\u00a0translators or interpreters performing services as employees of an enterprise located in the territory of the other Party.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nANNEX 10E\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSECTORAL COMMITMENTS ON CONTRACTUAL SERVICE SUPPLIERS AND INDEPENDENT PROFESSIONALS\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall allow the supply of services in its territory by contractual services suppliers or independent professionals of the other Party through the presence of natural persons, in accordance with Article 10.8, for the sectors listed in this Annex, and subject to the relevant limitations.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The list of reservations is composed of the following elements:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the first column indicates the sector or subsector in which the reservation applies; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the\u00a0second column describes the applicable limitations.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For Canada, sectoral commitments apply to occupations listed under level \"0\" and \"A\" of Canada's National Occupational Classification (\"NOC\").\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0In addition to the list of reservations in this Annex, each Party may adopt or maintain a measure relating to qualification requirements, qualification procedures, technical standards, licensing requirements or licensing procedures that does not constitute a limitation within the meaning of Article 10.8. These measures, which include requirements to obtain a licence, obtain recognition of qualifications in regulated sectors or to pass specific examinations, such as language examinations, even if not listed in this Annex, apply in any case to contractual services suppliers or independent professionals of the Parties.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the European Union, in the sectors where an economic needs test is applied, the main criteria is the assessment of the relevant market situation in the Member State of the European Union or the region where the service is provided, including with respect to the number of, and the impact on, existing services suppliers.\n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The European Union takes commitments with respect to Article 10.8 differentiated by its Member States, as set out in the list of reservations included in this Annex.\n\n\n\n7.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The rights and obligations that arise from this Annex have no selfexecuting effect and confer no rights directly on natural or juridical persons.\n\n\n\n\n\n8.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The following abbreviations are used in the list of reservations included in this Annex:\n\n\n\nAT\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Austria\n\n\n\nBE\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Belgium\n\n\n\nBG\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Bulgaria\n\n\n\nCY\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Cyprus\n\n\n\nCZ\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Czech Republic\n\n\n\nDE\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Germany\n\n\n\nDK\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Denmark\n\n\n\nEE\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Estonia\n\n\n\nES\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Spain\n\n\n\n\n\nEU\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0European Union, including all its Member\u00a0States\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nFI\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Finland\n\n\n\nFR\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0France\n\n\n\nEL\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Greece\n\n\n\nHR\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Croatia\n\n\n\nHU\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Hungary\n\n\n\nIE\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Ireland\n\n\n\nIT\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Italy\n\n\n\nLV\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Latvia\n\n\n\n\n\nLT\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Lithuania\n\n\n\nLU\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Luxembourg\n\n\n\nMT\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Malta\n\n\n\nNL\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Netherlands\n\n\n\nPL\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Poland\n\n\n\nPT\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Portugal\n\n\n\nRO\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Romania\n\n\n\nSK\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Slovak Republic\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSI\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Slovenia\n\n\n\nSE\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Sweden\n\n\n\n\n\nUK\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0United Kingdom\n\n\n\nCAN\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Canada\n\n\n\nCSS: Contractual Service Suppliers\n\n\n\nIP: Independent Professionals\n\n\n\n9.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Article 10.8.1\u00a0applies to the following sectors or subsectors:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Legal advisory services in respect of public international law and foreign law\n3\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Accounting and bookkeeping services\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Taxation advisory services\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Architectural services and urban planning and landscape architectural services\n\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Engineering services and integrated engineering services\n\n\n\n\n\n(f)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Medical and dental services\n\n\n\n(g)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Veterinary services\n\n\n\n(h)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Midwives services\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Services provided by nurses, physiotherapists and paramedical personnel\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(j)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Computer and related vessels\n\n\n\n(t)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Maintenance and repair of rail transport equipment\n\n\n\n(u)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Maintenance and repair of motor vehicles, motorcycles, snowmobiles and road services\n\n\n\n(gg)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Other financial services advisory and consulting services\n\n\n\n(hh)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Transport advisory and consulting and consulting services\n\n\n\n10.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Article 10.8.2 applies to the following sectors or subsectors:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Legal advisory services in respect of public international law and foreign law\n4\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Architectural services and urban planning and landscape architectural services\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Engineering services\n\n\n\n\n\n(f)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Market research and opinion polling\n\n\n\n(g)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Management consulting services\n\n\n\n(h)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Services related to management consulting services\n\n\n\n(o)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Other financial services advisory and consulting services\n\n\n\n\n\n(p)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Transport advisory and consulting services\n\n\n\n(q)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Manufacturing advisory and consulting services\n\n\n\n\n\n11.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0List of reservations\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSector or subsector\n\n\n\n\nDescription of reservations\n\n\n\n\n\n\nEU - ALL SECTORS\n\n\n\n\nLength of stay\n\n\nIn AT, UK: Maximum stay for CSS and IP shall be for a cumulative period of not more than six months in any 12 month period or for the duration of the contract, whichever is less.\n\n\nIn LT: Maximum stay for CSS and IP shall be for a period of six months renewable once for an additional period of six months, or for the duration of the contract, whichever is less.\n\n\nIn BE, CZ, MT, PT: Maximum stay for CSS and IP shall be for a period of not more than 12 consecutive months or for the duration of the contract, whichever is less.\n\n\nTechnologists\n\n\nAnnex 10C applies to the EU with the exception of: AT, DE, EL, ES, HU, IT, LT, NL, PT, SK, UK.\n\n\nIn CY: Annex 10C applies only with regard to technologists active in subsectors CPC 8676, 851, 852, 853, and 883.\n\n\nIn FI: Economic needs test.\n\n\nIn FR: Annex 10C applies only with regard to technologists active in subsector CPC 86721.\n\n\nIn PL: Technologist must possess as a minimum a degree equivalent to bachelor's degree.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nCAN \u2013 ALL SECTORS\n\n\n\n\nTechnologists\n\n\nCAN: Annex 10C applies.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLegal advisory services in respect of public international law and foreign law\n\n\n(part of CPC 861)\n\n\n\n\nCSS:\n\n\nIn AT, BE, CY, DE, EE, EL, ES, FR, HR, IE, IT, LU, NL, PL, PT, SE, UK: None.\n\n\nIn BG, CZ, DK, FI, HU, LT, LV, MT, RO, SI, SK: Economic needs test.\n\n\nCAN: None.\n\n\n\nIP:\n\n\nIn AT, CY, DE, EE, FR, HR, IE, LU, LV, NL, PL, PT, SE, UK: None.\n\n\nIn BE, BG, CZ, DK, EL, ES, FI, HU, IT, LT, MT, RO, SI, SK: Economic needs tests.\n\n\nCAN: None.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nAccounting and bookkeeping services\n\n\n(CPC 86212 other than \"auditing services\", 86213, 86219 and 86220)\n\n\n\n\nCSS:\n\n\nIn AT, BE, CY, DE, EE, ES, HR, IE, IT, LU, NL, PL, PT, SI, SE, UK: None.\n\n\nIn BG, CZ, DK, EL, FI, FR, HU, LT, LV, MT, RO, SK: Economic needs test.\n\n\nCAN: None.\n\n\n\nIP:\n\n\nEU: Unbound.\n\n\nCAN: Unbound.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nTaxation advisory services\n\n\n(CPC 863)\n5\n\n\n\n\n\nCSS:\n\n\nIn AT, BE, CY, DE, EE, ES, FR, HR, IE, IT, LU, NL, PL, SI, SE, UK: None.\n\n\nIn BG, CZ, DK, EL, FI, HU, LT, LV, MT, RO, SK: Economic needs test.\n\n\nIn PT: Unbound.\n\n\nCAN: None.\n\n\n\nIP:\n\n\nEU: Unbound.\n\n\nCAN: Unbound.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nArchitectural services\n\n\nand\n\n\nUrban planning and landscape architectural services\n\n\n(CPC 8671 and 8674)\n\n\n\n\nCSS:\n\n\nIn BE, CY, EE, ES, EL, FR, HR, IE, IT, LU, MT, NL, PL, PT, SI, SE, UK: None.\n\n\nIn FI: None, except: The natural person must demonstrate that he or she possesses special knowledge relevant to the service being supplied.\n\n\nIn BG, CZ, DE, HU, LT, LV, RO, SK: Economic needs test.\n\n\nIn DK: Economic needs test, except for CSS stays of up to three months.\n\n\nIn AT: Urban planning services only, where: Economic needs test.\n\n\nCAN: None.\n\n\n\nIP:\n\n\nIn CY, DE, EE, EL, FR, HR, IE, LU, LV, MT, NL, PL, PT, SI, SE, UK:\u00a0None.\n\n\nIn FI: None, except: The natural person must demonstrate that he or she possesses special knowledge relevant to the service being supplied.\n\n\nIn BE, BG, CZ, DK, ES, HU, IT, LT, RO, SK: Economic needs test.\n\n\nIn AT: Urban planning services only, where: Economic needs test.\n\n\nCAN: None.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nEngineering services\n\n\nand\n\n\nIntegrated engineering services\n\n\n(CPC 8672 and 8673)\n\n\n\n\nCSS:\n\n\nIn BE, CY, EE, ES, EL, FR, HR, IE, IT, LU, MT, NL, PL, PT, SI, SE, UK: None.\n\n\nIn FI: None, except: The natural person must demonstrate that he or she possesses special knowledge relevant to the service being supplied.\n\n\nIn BG, CZ, DE, LT, LV, RO, SK: Economic needs test.\n\n\nIn DK: Economic needs test, except for CSS stays of up to three months.\n\n\nIn AT: Planning services only, where: Economic needs test.\n\n\nIn HU: Economic needs test.\n\n\nCAN: None.\n\n\n\nIP:\n\n\nIn CY, DE, EE, EL, FR, HR, IE, LU, LV, MT, NL, PL, PT, SI, SE, UK: None.\n\n\nIn FI: None, except: The natural person must demonstrate that he or she possesses special knowledge relevant to the service being supplied.\n\n\nIn BE, BG, CZ, DK, ES, IT, LT, RO, SK: Economic needs test.\n\n\nIn AT: Planning services only, where: Economic needs test.\n\n\nIn HU: Economic needs test.\n\n\nCAN: None.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMedical (including psychologists) and dental services\n\n\n(CPC 9312 and part of 85201) \n\n\n\n\nCSS:\n\n\nIn SE: None.\n\n\nIn CY, CZ, DE, DK, EE, ES, IE, IT, LU, MT, NL, PL, PT, RO, SI: Economic needs test.\n\n\nIn FR: Economic needs test, except for psychologists, where: Unbound.\n\n\nIn AT: Unbound, except for psychologists and dental services, where: Economic needs Economic needs test.\n\n\nIn BE, BG, FI, HR, HU, SK, UK: Unbound.\n\n\nCAN: Unbound.\n\n\n\nIP:\n\n\nEU: Unbound.\n\n\nCAN: Unbound.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nComputer and related services\n\n\n(CPC Services\n\n\n(CPC 851, 852 excluding psychologists services\n6\n, and\u00a0853)\n\n\n\n\nCSS:\n\n\nEU except in SE: A hosting agreement with an approved research organisation is required\n7\n.\n\n\nEU except in CZ, DK, SK: None\n\n\nIn CZ, DK, SK: Economic needs test.\n\n\nCAN: None.\n\n\n\nIP:\n\n\nEU except in SE: A hosting agreement with an approved research organisation is required\n8\n.\n\n\nEU except in\u00a0BE, CZ, DK, IT, SK: None\n\n\nIn BE, CZ, DK, IT, SK: Economic needs test.\n\n\nCAN: None.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nAdvertising services\n\n\n(CPC 871)\n\n\n\n\nCSS:\n\n\nIn BE, CY, DE, EE, ES, FR, HR, IE, IT, LU, NL, PL, PT, SI, SE, UK: None.\n\n\nIn AT, BG, CZ, DK, EL, FI, HU, LT, LV, MT, RO, SK: Economic needs test.\n\n\nCAN: None.\n\n\n\nIP:\n\n\nEU: Unbound.\n\n\nCAN: Unbound.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMarket research and opinion polling services\n\n\n(CPC 864)\n\n\n\n\nCSS:\n\n\nIn BE, CY, DE, EE, ES, FR, IE, IT, LU, NL, PL, SE, UK: None.\n\n\nIn AT, BG, CZ, DK, EL, FI, HR, LV, MT, RO, SI, SK: Economic needs test.\n\n\nIn PT: None, except for public opinion polling services (CPC 86402), where: Unbound.\n\n\nIn HU, LT: Economic needs test, except for public opinion polling services (CPC 86402), where: Unbound.\n\n\nCAN: None.\n\n\n\nIP:\n\n\nIn CY, DE, EE, FR, IE, LU, NL, PL, SE, UK: None.\n\n\nIn AT, BE, BG, CZ, DK, EL, ES, FI, HR, IT, LV, MT, RO, SI, SK: Economic needs test.\n\n\nIn PT: None, except for public opinion polling services (CPC 86402), where: Unbound.\n\n\nIn HU, LT: Economic needs test, except for public opinion polling services (CPC\u00a086402), where: Unbound.\n\n\nCAN: None.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nManagement consulting services\n\n\n(CPC 865)\n\n\n\n\nCSS:\n\n\nIn BE, CY, DE, EE, EL, ES, FI, FR, HR, IE, IT,
