Each Party shall be given the opportunity to provide written comments on the other Party's reply within five working days of the date of receipt.\n\n\n\n\n\nTransparency and confidentiality\n\n\n\n38.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Subject\u00a0to paragraph\u00a039, each Party shall make its submissions publicly available and, unless the Parties decide otherwise, the hearings of the arbitration panel shall be open to the public.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n39.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The arbitration panel shall meet in closed session when the submission and arguments of a Party contain confidential business information. The Parties shall maintain the confidentiality of the arbitration panel hearings when they are held in closed session. Each Party and its advisers shall treat as confidential any information submitted by the other Party to the arbitration panel which that Party has designated as confidential. Where a Party's submission to the arbitration panel contains confidential information, that Party shall also provide, within\u00a015 days, a nonconfidential version of the submission that could be disclosed to the public.\n\n\n\nEx parte contacts\n\n\n\n40.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The arbitration panel shall not meet or contact a Party in the absence of the other Party.\n\n\n\n41.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0No arbitrator may discuss any aspect of the subjectmatter of the proceeding with a Party or the Parties in the absence of the other arbitrators.\n\n\n\nInformation and technical advice\n\n\n\n42.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Upon the request of a disputing Party, or on its own initiative, the arbitration panel may seek information and technical advice from any person or body that it deems appropriate, subject to any terms and conditions agreed by the Parties. Any information obtained in this manner must be disclosed to each Party and submitted for their comments.\n\n\n\nAmicus curiae submissions\n\n\n\n43.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Nongovernmental persons established in a Party may submit amicus curiae briefs to the arbitration panel in accordance with the following paragraphs.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n44.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Unless the Parties agree otherwise within five days of the date of the establishment of the arbitration panel, the arbitration panel may receive unsolicited written submissions, provided that they are made within\u00a010 days of the date of the establishment of the arbitration panel, and in no case longer than\u00a015 typed pages, including any annexes, and that they are directly relevant to the issue under consideration by the arbitration panel.\n\n\n\n45.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The submission shall contain a description of the person making the submission, whether natural or legal, including the nature of that person's activities and the source of that person's financing, and specify the nature of the interest that that person has in the arbitration proceeding. It shall be drafted in the languages chosen by the Parties in accordance with paragraphs\u00a048 and\u00a049.\n\n\n\n46.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The arbitration panel shall list in its ruling all the submissions it has received that conform to these Rules. The arbitration panel shall not be obliged to address in its ruling the arguments made in such submissions. The arbitration panel shall submit to the Parties for their comments any submission it obtains.\n\n\n\nUrgent cases\n\n\n\n47.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0In cases of urgency referred to in Article\u00a029.11, the arbitration panel, after consulting the Parties, shall adjust the time limits referred to in these Rules as appropriate and shall notify the Parties of such adjustments.\n\n\n\nWorking language for the proceeding, translation and interpretation\n\n\n\n48.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0During the consultations referred to in Article\u00a029.7.2, and no later than the meeting referred to in paragraph\u00a08, the Parties shall endeavour to agree on a common working language for the proceeding before the arbitration panel.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n49.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If the Parties are unable to agree on a common working language, each Party shall arrange for and bear the costs of the translation of its written submissions into the language chosen by the other Party. The responding Party shall arrange for the interpretation of oral submissions into the languages chosen by the Parties.\n\n\n\n50.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Arbitration panel rulings shall be issued in the language or languages chosen by the Parties.\n\n\n\n\n\n51.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Any costs incurred for translation of an arbitration panel ruling into the language or languages chosen by the Parties shall be borne equally by the Parties.\n\n\n\n52.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party may provide comments on the accuracy of any translated version of a document drawn up in accordance with these Rules.\n\n\n\nCalculation of time limits\n\n\n\n53.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0All time limits set out in this Chapter and in this Annex including the limits for the arbitration panels to notify their rulings, shall be counted in calendar days from the day following the act or fact to which they refer, unless otherwise specified.\n\n\n\n54.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Where, by reason of the application of paragraph\u00a06, a Party receives a document on a date other than the date on which this document is received by the other Party, any period of time that is calculated on the basis of the date of receipt of that document shall be calculated from the last date of receipt of that document.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nOther procedures\n\n\n\n55.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The time limits set out in these Rules shall be adjusted in line with the special time limits provided for the adoption of a ruling by the arbitration panel in the proceedings under Articles\u00a029.14 and\u00a029.15.\n\n\n\n56.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0In the event that the original arbitration panel, or some of its arbitrators, are unable to reconvene for the proceedings established under Article\u00a029.14 and\u00a029.15, the procedure set out in Article\u00a029.7 shall apply. The time limit for the notification of the ruling shall be extended by\u00a020 days.\n\n\n\n\n________________\n\n\n\n\n\nANNEX\u00a029B\n\n\n\nCODE OF CONDUCT FOR ARBITRATORS AND MEDIATORS\n\n\n\nDefinitions\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For this Chapter and under this Code of Conduct:\n\n\n\narbitrator means a member of an arbitration panel established under Article\u00a029.7;\n\n\n\nassistant means a natural person who, under the terms of appointment of an arbitrator, conducts research or provides assistance to the arbitrator;\n\n\n\ncandidate means an individual whose name is on the list of arbitrators referred to in Article\u00a029.8 and who is under consideration for selection as an arbitrator under Article\u00a029.7;\n\n\n\nmediator means a natural person who conducts a mediation in accordance with Article\u00a029.5;\n\n\n\n\n\nproceeding, unless otherwise specified, means an arbitration proceeding;\n\n\n\n\n\nstaff, in respect of an arbitrator, means natural persons under the direction and control of the arbitrator, other than assistants.\n\n\n\nResponsibilities of candidates and arbitrators\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Every candidate and arbitrator shall avoid impropriety and the appearance of impropriety, shall be independent and impartial, shall avoid direct and indirect conflicts of interests and shall observe high standards of conduct so that the integrity and impartiality of the dispute settlement mechanism is preserved. Former arbitrators must comply with the obligations established in paragraphs\u00a016 through\u00a019.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDisclosure obligations\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Prior to confirmation of her or his selection as an arbitrator under this Chapter, a candidate shall disclose any interest, relationship or matter that is likely to affect her or his independence or impartiality or that might reasonably create an appearance of impropriety or bias in the proceeding. To this end, a candidate shall make all reasonable efforts to become aware of such interests, relationships and matters.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, candidates shall disclose the following interests, relationships and matters:\n\n\n\n(1)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0any financial interest of the candidate:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in the proceeding or in its outcome, and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in an administrative proceeding, a domestic court proceeding or another panel or committee proceeding that involves issues that may be decided in the proceeding for which the candidate is under consideration;\n\n\n\n\n\n(2)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0any financial interest of the candidate's employer, partner, business associate or family member:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in the proceeding or in its outcome, and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in an administrative proceeding, a domestic court proceeding or another panel or committee proceeding that involves issues that may be decided in the proceeding for which the candidate is under consideration;\n\n\n\n(3)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0any past or existing financial, business, professional, family or social relationship with the interested parties in the proceeding, or their counsel, or such relationship involving a candidate's employer, partner, business associate or family member; and\n\n\n\n(4)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0public advocacy or legal or other representation concerning an issue in dispute in the proceeding or involving the same matters.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A candidate or arbitrator shall communicate matters concerning actual or potential violations of this Code of Conduct to the CETA Joint Committee for consideration by the Parties.\n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Once selected, an arbitrator shall continue to make all reasonable efforts to become aware of interests, relationships or matters referred to in paragraph\u00a03 and shall disclose them. The disclosure obligation is a continuing duty which requires an arbitrator to disclose such interests, relationships or matters that may arise during all stages of the proceeding. The arbitrator shall disclose such interests, relationships or matters by informing the CETA Joint Committee promptly, in writing, for consideration by the Parties.\n\n\n\nDuties of arbitrators\n\n\n\n7.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Upon selection an arbitrator shall be available to perform and shall perform her or his duties thoroughly and expeditiously throughout the course of the proceeding, and with fairness and diligence.\n\n\n\n8.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0An arbitrator shall consider only those issues raised in the proceeding and necessary for a ruling and shall not delegate this duty to any other person.\n\n\n\n\n\n9.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0An arbitrator shall take all appropriate steps to ensure that her or his assistant and staff are aware of, and comply with, paragraphs\u00a02 through\u00a06, and\u00a017 through\u00a019.\n\n\n\n10.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0An arbitrator shall not engage in ex parte contacts concerning the proceeding.\n\n\n\nIndependence and impartiality of arbitrators\n\n\n\n11.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0An arbitrator shall avoid creating an appearance of bias and shall not be influenced by selfinterest, outside pressure, political considerations, public clamour, loyalty to a Party, or fear of criticism.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n12.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0An arbitrator shall not, directly or indirectly, incur any obligation or accept any benefit that would in any way interfere, or appear to interfere, with the proper performance of her or his duties.\n\n\n\n13.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0An arbitrator may not use her or his position on the arbitration panel to advance any personal or private interests and shall avoid actions that may create the impression that others are in a special position to influence her or him.\n\n\n\n14.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0An arbitrator may not allow financial, business, professional, family or social relationships or responsibilities to influence her or his conduct or judgement.\n\n\n\n15.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0An arbitrator must avoid entering into any relationship or acquiring any financial interest that is likely to affect her or his impartiality or that might reasonably create an appearance of impropriety or bias.\n\n\n\nObligations of former arbitrators\n\n\n\n\n\n16.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0All former arbitrators must avoid actions that may create the appearance that they were biased in carrying out their duties or derived advantage from the decision or ruling of the arbitration panel.\n\n\n\nConfidentiality\n\n\n\n17.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0No arbitrator or former arbitrator shall at any time disclose or use any nonpublic information concerning a proceeding or acquired during a proceeding except for the purposes of that proceeding and shall not, in any case, disclose or use any such information to gain personal advantage or advantage for others or to adversely affect the interest of others.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n18.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0An arbitrator shall not disclose an arbitration panel ruling or parts thereof prior to its publication in accordance with this Chapter.\n\n\n\n19.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0An arbitrator or former arbitrator shall not at any time disclose the deliberations of an arbitration panel, or any member's view.\n\n\n\nExpenses\n\n\n\n20.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each arbitrator shall keep a record and render a final account of the time devoted to the procedure and of her or his expenses as well as the time and expenses of her or his assistant.\n\n\n\nMediators\n\n\n\n21.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This Code of Conduct applies, mutatis mutandis, to mediators.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n________________\n\n\n\nANNEX\u00a029C\n\n\n\nRULES OF PROCEDURE FOR MEDIATION\n\n\n\nArticle\u00a01\n\n\n\nObjective\n\n\n\nFurther to Article\u00a029.5, the objective of this Annex is to facilitate the finding of a mutually agreed solution through a comprehensive and expeditious procedure with the assistance of a mediator.\n\n\n\n\nSECTION A\n\n\n\nMediation proceeding\n\n\n\n\nArticle\u00a02\n\n\n\n\n\nInitiation of the proceeding\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party may request, at any time, that the Parties enter into a mediation proceeding. Such request shall be addressed to the other Party in writing. The request shall be sufficiently detailed to present clearly the concerns of the requesting Party and shall:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0identify the specific measure at issue;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0provide a statement of the alleged adverse effects that the requesting Party believes the measure has, or will have, on trade or investment between the Parties; and\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0explain how the requesting Party considers that those effects are linked to the measure.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The mediation proceeding may only be initiated by mutual consent of the Parties. When a Party requests mediation pursuant to paragraph\u00a01, the other Party shall give good faith consideration to the request and reply in writing within\u00a010 days of receiving it.\n\n\n\n\nArticle\u00a03\n\n\n\nSelection of the mediator\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Upon the start of the mediation proceeding, the Parties shall agree on a mediator, if possible, no later than\u00a015 days after the receipt of the reply to the request for mediation.\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A mediator shall not be a citizen of either Party, unless the Parties agree otherwise.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The mediator shall assist, in an impartial and transparent manner, the Parties in bringing clarity to the measure and its possible trade effects, and in reaching a mutually agreed solution. Further to paragraph\u00a021 of Annex\u00a029B, the Code of Conduct of Arbitrators and Mediators applies to mediators. Paragraphs\u00a03 through\u00a07 and\u00a048 through\u00a054 of the Rules of Procedure for Arbitration in Annex\u00a029A shall also apply, mutatis mutandis.\n\n\n\n\nArticle\u00a04\n\n\n\nRules of procedure for mediation\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Within\u00a010 days after the appointment of the mediator, the Party requesting the mediation procedure shall present, in writing, a detailed description of the problem to the mediator and to the other Party, in particular of the operation of the measure at issue and its trade effects. Within\u00a020 days after the date of delivery of this submission, the other Party may provide, in writing, its comments to the description of the problem. Either Party may include in its description or comments any information that it deems relevant.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The mediator may decide on the most appropriate way of bringing clarity to the measure concerned and its possible traderelated impact. In particular, the mediator may organise meetings between the Parties, consult the Parties jointly or individually, seek the assistance of or consult with relevant experts\n2\n and stakeholders and provide any additional support requested by the Parties. However, before seeking the assistance of or consulting with relevant experts and stakeholders, the mediator shall consult with the Parties.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The mediator may offer advice and propose a solution for the consideration of the Parties which may accept or reject the proposed solution or may agree on a different solution. However, the mediator may not advise or comment on the consistency of the measure at issue with this Agreement.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The procedure shall take place in the territory of the Party to which the request was addressed, or, by mutual consent of the Parties, in any other location or by any other means.\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties shall endeavour to reach a mutually agreed solution within\u00a060 days from the appointment of the mediator. Pending a final agreement, the Parties may consider possible interim solutions, especially if the measure relates to perishable goods.\n\n\n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The solution may be adopted by means of a decision of the CETA Joint Committee. Mutually agreed solutions shall be made publicly available. However, the version disclosed to the public may not contain any information that a Party has designated as confidential.\n\n\n\n7.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0On request of the Parties, the mediator shall issue to the Parties, in writing, a draft factual report, providing a brief summary of the measure at issue in the proceeding, the procedure followed and any mutually agreed solution reached as the final outcome of the proceeding, including possible interim solutions. The mediator shall provide the Parties\u00a015 days to comment on the draft report.\u00a0After considering the comments of the Parties submitted within the period, the mediator shall submit, in writing, a final factual report to the Parties within\u00a015 days. The factual report shall not include any interpretation of this Agreement.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n8.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The proceeding shall be terminated:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0by the adoption of a mutually agreed solution by the Parties, on the date of adoption.\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0by a written declaration of the mediator, after consulting with the Parties, that further efforts at mediation would be to no avail;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0by a written declaration of a Party after exploring mutually agreed solutions under the mediation proceeding and after having considered any advice and proposed solutions by the mediator. Such declaration may not be issued before the period set out in Article\u00a04.5 has expired; or\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0at any stage of the procedure by mutual agreement of the Parties.\n\n\n\n\n\nSECTION B\n\n\n\nImplementation\n\n\n\n\n\n\nArticle\u00a05\n\n\n\nImplementation of a mutually agreed solution\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Where the Parties have agreed to a solution, each Party shall take the measures necessary to implement the mutually agreed solution within the agreed timeframe.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The implementing Party shall inform the other Party in writing of any steps or measures taken to implement the mutually agreed solution.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSECTION C\n\n\n\nGeneral provisions\n\n\n\n\nArticle\u00a06\n\n\n\nConfidentiality and relationship to dispute settlement\n\n\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Unless the Parties agree otherwise, and without prejudice to Article\u00a04.6, all stages of the proceeding, including any advice or proposed solution, are confidential. However, any Party may disclose to the public that mediation is taking place. The obligation of confidentiality does not extend to factual information already existing in the public domain.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The mediation proceeding is without prejudice to the Parties' rights and obligations under the provisions on Dispute Settlement in this Agreement or any other agreement.\n\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Consultations are not required before initiating the mediation proceeding. However, a Party should normally avail itself of the other relevant cooperation or consultation provisions in this Agreement before initiating the mediation proceeding.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party shall not rely on or introduce as evidence in other dispute settlement proceedings under this Agreement or any other agreement, nor shall an arbitration panel take into consideration:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0positions taken by the other Party in the course of the mediation proceeding or information gathered under Article\u00a04.2;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the fact that the other Party has indicated its willingness to accept a solution to the measure subject to mediation; or\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0advice given or proposals made by the mediator.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A mediator may not serve as a panellist in a dispute settlement proceeding under this Agreement or under the WTO Agreement involving the same matter for which she or he has been a mediator.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nArticle\u00a07\n\n\n\nTime limits\n\n\n\nAny time limit referred to in this Annex may be modified by mutual consent between the Parties.\n\n\n\n\nArticle\u00a08\n\n\n\nCosts\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall bear its costs of participation in the mediation proceeding.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties shall share jointly and equally the costs of organisational matters, including the remuneration and expenses of the mediator. Remuneration of the mediator shall be in accordance with that of the chairperson of an arbitration panel in paragraph\u00a08 of Annex\u00a029A.\n\n\n\n\nArticle\u00a09\n\n\n\nReview\n\n\n\n\n\nFive years after the date of entry into force of this Agreement, the Parties shall consult each other on the need to modify the mediation mechanism in light of the experience gained and the development of any corresponding mechanism in the WTO.\n\n\n\n\n________________\n\n\n\nANNEX\u00a030A\n\n\n\nLIST OF BILATERAL INVESTMENT TREATIES \nBETWEEN CANADA \nAND MEMBER STATES OF THE EUROPEAN UNION\n\n\n\nAgreement between the Government of the Republic of Croatia and the Government of Canada for the Promotion and Protection of Investments, done at Ottawa on\u00a03\u00a0February\u00a01997.\n\n\n\nAgreement between the Czech Republic and Canada for the Promotion and Protection of Investments, done at Prague on\u00a06\u00a0May\u00a02009.\n\n\n\nAgreement between the Government of the Republic of Hungary and the Government of Canada for the Promotion and Reciprocal Protection of Investments, done at Ottawa on\u00a03\u00a0October\u00a01991.\n\n\n\nAgreement between the Government of the Republic of Latvia and the Government of Canada for the Promotion and Protection of Investments, done at Riga on\u00a05\u00a0May\u00a02009.\n\n\n\nExchange of Notes between the Government of Canada and the Government of the Republic of Malta Constituting an Agreement Relating to Foreign Investment Insurance, done at Valletta on\u00a024\u00a0May\u00a01982.\n\n\n\nAgreement between the Government of the Republic of Poland and the Government of Canada for the Promotion and Reciprocal Protection of Investments, done at Warsaw on\u00a06\u00a0April\u00a01990.\n\n\n\n\n\nAgreement between the Government of Romania and the Government of Canada for the Promotion and Reciprocal Protection of Investments, done at Bucharest on\u00a08\u00a0May\u00a02009.\n\n\n\nAgreement between the Slovak Republic and Canada for the Promotion and Protection of Investments, done at Bratislava on\u00a020\u00a0July\u00a02010.\n\n\n\n\n________________\n\n\n\nANNEX\u00a030B\n\n\n\nAMENDMENTS \nTO THE\u00a01989 ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES AGREEMENT \nAND THE\u00a02003 WINES AND SPIRIT DRINKS AGREEMENT\n\n\n\n\nSECTION A\n\n\n\nArticle\u00a01 of the\u00a01989 Alcoholic Beverages Agreement, as amended by Annex VIII to the\u00a02003 Wines and Spirit Drinks Agreement, shall have the following definition added:\n\n\n\n\"\"competent authority\" means a government or commission, board or other governmental agency of a Party that is authorised by law to control the sale of wines and distilled spirits.\"\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSECTION B\n\n\n\nArticle\u00a02.2(b) of the\u00a01989 Alcoholic Beverages Agreement, as amended by Annex VIII to the\u00a02003 Wines and Spirit Drinks Agreement, is replaced with:\n\n\n\n\"(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0requiring off site private wine store outlets in Ontario and British Columbia to sell only wines produced by Canadian wineries. The number of these off site private wine store outlets authorised to sell only wines produced by Canadian wineries in these provinces shall not exceed\u00a0292 in Ontario and\u00a060 in British Columbia.\"\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSECTION C\n\n\n\nArticle\u00a04 of the\u00a01989 Alcoholic Beverages Agreement, as amended by Annex VIII to the\u00a02003 Wines and Spirit Drinks Agreement, is replaced with:\n\n\n\n\"Article\u00a04\n\n\n\nCommercial Treatment\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Competent authorities shall, in exercising their responsibilities for the purchase, distribution and retail sale of products of the other Party, adhere to the provisions of GATT Article XVII concerning State trading enterprises, in particular to make any such decisions solely in accordance with commercial considerations and shall afford the enterprises of the other Party adequate opportunity, in accordance with customary business practice, to compete for participation in such purchases.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall take all possible measures to ensure that an enterprise that has been granted a monopoly in the trade and sale of wines and spirit drinks within its territory does not use its monopoly position to engage, either directly or indirectly, including through its dealings with its parent, subsidiaries or other enterprises with common ownership, in the sale of wine and spirit drinks in a market outside the territory where the enterprise has a monopoly position that causes an anticompetitive effect causing an appreciable restriction of competition in that market.\"\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSECTION D\n\n\n\nArticle\u00a04a of the\u00a01989 Alcoholic Beverages Agreement, as amended by Annex VIII to the\u00a02003 Wines and Spirit Drinks Agreement, is replaced with:\n\n\n\n\"4a \u2013 Pricing\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Competent authorities of the Parties shall ensure that any markup, cost of service or other pricing measure is nondiscriminatory, applies to all retail sales and is in conformity with Article\u00a02.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A cost of service differential may be applied to products of the other Party only in so far as it is no greater than the additional costs necessarily associated with the marketing of products of the other Party, taking into account additional costs resulting from, inter alia, delivery methods and frequency.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall ensure that a cost of service is not applied to a product of the other Party on the basis of the value of the product.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The cost of service differential shall be justified in line with standard accounting procedures by independent auditors on the basis of an audit completed on the request of the other Party within one year of the entry into force of the\u00a02003 Wines and Spirit Drinks Agreement and thereafter on request of that Party at intervals of not less than four years. The audits shall be made available to either Party within one year of a request being made.\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Competent authorities shall update cost of service differential charges, as required, to reflect the commitment made in subparagraph\u00a04a(2).\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Competent authorities shall make available applicable cost of service differential charges through publicly accessible means, such as their official website.\n\n\n\n\n\n7.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Competent authorities shall establish a contact point for questions and concerns originating from the other Party with respect to cost of service differential charges. A Party will respond to a request from the other Party in writing within\u00a060 days of the receipt of the request.\"\n\n\n\n\nSECTION E\n\n\n\nThe\u00a01989 Alcoholic Beverages Agreement, as amended by Annex VIII to the\u00a02003 Wines and Spirit Drinks Agreement, is modified by adding Article\u00a04b:\n\n\n\n\"Article\u00a04b\n\n\n\nBlending Requirements\n\n\n\nNeither Party may adopt or maintain any measure requiring that distilled spirits imported from the territory of the other Party for bottling be blended with any distilled spirits of the importing Party.\"\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSECTION F\n\n\n\nThe\u00a02003 Wines and Spirit Drinks Agreement shall be amended as follows:\n\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Article\u00a027.3 (Joint Committee), first indent, is replaced with \"adopting amendments to the Annexes of this Agreement by means of a decision by the Joint Committee.\"\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Title VIII (Dispute settlement) is deleted;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The last two sentences of Article\u00a08.1 (Objection procedure) are replaced with \"A Contracting Party may seek consultations as provided under Article\u00a029.4 (Consultations) of the CanadaEuropean\u00a0Union Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (\"CETA\"). If the consultations fail to resolve the matter, a Contracting Party may notify, in writing, the other Contracting Party of its decision to refer the issue to arbitration under Articles\u00a029.6 through\u00a029.10 of CETA.\"\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The chapeau of Article\u00a09.2 (Modification of Annex I), is replaced with: \"By way of derogation from paragraph\u00a01, if a Contracting Party has invoked the objection procedure provided for in Article\u00a08 (Objection procedure), the Contracting Parties shall act in accordance with the outcome of the consultations, unless the matter is referred to the arbitration procedure under Articles\u00a029.6 through\u00a029.10 of CETA, in which case:\u201d\n\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A third paragraph is added to Article 9 (Modification of Annex I): \u201c3. When Articles\u00a029.6 through\u00a029.10 of CETA are applied in the course of the procedure referred to in paragraph 2, they shall apply mutatis mutandis.\n\n\n\n\n________________\n\n\n\nANNEX\u00a030C\n\n\n\nJOINT DECLARATION ON WINES AND SPIRITS\n\n\n\nThe Parties acknowledge the effort and progress that has been made on Wines and Spirits in the context of the negotiations of this Agreement. These efforts have led to mutually agreed solutions on a number of issues of high importance.\n\n\n\nThe Parties agree to discuss through the appropriate mechanisms, without delay and in view to find mutually agreed solutions, any other issue of concern related to Wines and Spirits, and notably the desire of the European\u00a0Union to seek the elimination of the differentiation of provincial markups applied on domestic wines and wines bottled in Canada in private wine outlets.\n\n\n\n\n\nAt the end of the fifth year following the entry into force of this Agreement, the Parties agree to review the progress made on the elimination of the differentiation referred to in the previous paragraph, based on the examination of all developments in the sector, including the consequences of any granting to third countries of a more favourable treatment in the framework of other trade negotiations involving Canada.\n\n\n\n\n________________\n\n\n\nANNEX\u00a030D\n\n\n\nJOINT DECLARATION \nOF THE PARTIES ON COUNTRIES \nTHAT HAVE ESTABLISHED A CUSTOMS UNION \nWITH THE EUROPEAN UNION\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The European\u00a0Union recalls the obligations of the countries that have established a customs union with the European\u00a0Union to align their trade regime to that of the European\u00a0Union, and for certain of them, to conclude preferential agreements with countries that have preferential agreements with the European\u00a0Union.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0In this context, Canada shall endeavour to start negotiations with the countries which,\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0have established a customs union with the European\u00a0Union, and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0whose goods do not benefit from the tariff concessions under this Agreement,\n\n\n\nwith a view to conclude a comprehensive bilateral agreement establishing a free trade area in accordance with the relevant WTO Agreement provisions on goods and services, provided that those countries agree to negotiate an ambitious and comprehensive agreement comparable to this Agreement in scope and ambition. Canada shall endeavour to start negotiations as soon as possible with a view to have such an agreement enter into force as soon as possible after the entry into force of this Agreement.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n________________\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(1)\nThe use of spelling variations in English or French shall be permitted, including \"Tyrol\", \"Tiroler\", \"Tyroler\", and \"Tirolien\".\n\n\n\n(2)\nA Party may not object to an expert being consulted in a dispute settlement proceeding under this Chapter or under the WTO Agreement solely on the ground that the expert has been consulted under this paragraph.\n\n\n\n\n\nTop  \n\n\n\n\n\n\nEUROPEAN COMMISSION\nStrasbourg, 5.7.2016\nCOM(2016) 444 final\nANNEX\n\nto the \nProposal or a Council Decision\non the signing on behalf of the European Union of the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement between Canada of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nProtocol on rules of origin and origin procedures\n\n\n\n\nSECTION A\n\n\n\nGENERAL PROVISIONS\n\n\n\n\nArticle 1\n\n\n\nDefinitions\n\n\n\nFor the purposes of this Protocol:\n\n\n\naquaculture means the farming of aquatic organisms, including fish, molluscs, crustaceans, other aquatic invertebrates and aquatic plants, from seedstock such as eggs, fry, fingerlings and larvae, by intervention in the rearing or growth processes to enhance production, such as regular stocking, feeding, or protection from predators; \n\n\n\nclassified means the classification of a product under a particular heading or subheading of the HS;\n\n\n\n\n\ncustoms authority means any governmental authority that is responsible under the law of a Party for the administration and application of customs laws or, for the EU, where provided for, the competent services of the European Commission;\n\n\n\ncustoms value means the value as determined in accordance with the Customs Valuation Agreement; \n\n\n\ndetermination of origin means a determination as to whether a product qualifies as an originating product in accordance with this Protocol;\n\n\n\nexporter means an exporter located in the territory of a Party;\n\n\n\n\nidentical originating products means products that are the same in all respects, including physical characteristics, quality, and reputation, irrespective of minor differences in appearance that are not relevant to a determination of origin of those products under this Protocol;\n\n\n\nimporter means an importer located in the territory of a Party;\n\n\n\nmaterial means any ingredient, component, part, or product that is used in the production of another product;\n\n\n\nnet weight of nonoriginating material means the weight of the material as it is used in the production of the product, not including the weight of the material's packaging; \n\n\n\nnet weight of the product means the weight of a product not including the weight of packaging. In addition, if the production includes a heating or drying operation, the net weight of the product may be the net weight of all materials used in its production, excluding water of heading 22.01 added during production of the product; \n\n\n\nproducer means a person who engages in any kind of working or processing including such operations as growing, mining, raising, harvesting, fishing, trapping, hunting, manufacturing, assembling, or disassembling a product; \n\n\n\n\n\nproduct means the result of production, even if it is intended for use as a material in the production of another product;\n\n\n\nproduction means any kind of working or processing, including such operations as growing, mining, raising, harvesting, fishing, trapping, hunting, manufacturing, assembling, or disassembling a product;\n\n\n\ntransaction value or exworks price of the product means the price paid or payable to the producer of the product at the place where the last production was carried out, and must include the value of all materials. If there is no price paid or payable or if it does not include the value of all materials, the transaction value or exworks price of the product:\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0must include the value of all materials and the cost of production employed in producing the product, calculated in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0may include amounts for general expenses and profit to the producer that can be reasonably allocated to the product.\n\n\n\nAny internal taxes which are, or may be, repaid when the product obtained is exported are excluded. If the transaction value or exworks price of the product includes costs incurred subsequent to the product leaving the place of production, such as transportation, loading, unloading, handling, or insurance, those costs are to be excluded; and\n\n\n\nvalue of nonoriginating materials means the customs value of the material at the time of its importation into a Party, as determined in accordance with the Customs Valuation Agreement. The value of the nonoriginating material must include any costs incurred in transporting the material to the place of importation, such as transportation, loading, unloading, handling, or insurance. If the customs value is not known or cannot be ascertained, the value of nonoriginating materials will be the first ascertainable price paid for the materials in the European Union or in Canada. \n\n\n\n\nSECTION B\n\n\n\nRULES OF ORIGIN\n\n\n\n\n\n\nArticle 2\n\n\n\nGeneral requirements\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purposes of this Agreement, a product is originating in the Party where the last production took place if, in the territory of a Party or in the territory of both of the Parties in accordance with Article 3, the product:\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0has been wholly obtained within the meaning of Article 4; \n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0has been produced exclusively from originating materials; or\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0has undergone sufficient production within the meaning of Article 5. \n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Except as provided for in paragraphs 8 and 9 of Article 3, the conditions set out in this Protocol relating to the acquisition of originating status must be fulfilled without interruption in the territory of one or both of the Parties.\n\n\n\n\nArticle 3\n\n\n\nCumulation of origin\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A product that originates in a Party is considered originating in the other Party when used as a material in the production of a product in that other Party.\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0An exporter may take into account production carried out on a nonoriginating material in the other Party for the purposes of determining the originating status of a product.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Paragraphs 1 and 2 do not apply if the production carried out on a product does not go beyond the operations referred to in Article 7 and the object of this production, as demonstrated on the basis of a preponderance of evidence, is to circumvent financial or fiscal legislation of the Parties. \n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If an exporter has completed an origin declaration for a product referred to in paragraph 2, the exporter must possess a completed and signed supplier's statement from the supplier of the nonoriginating materials used in the production of the product.\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A supplier's statement may be the statement set out in Annex 3 or an equivalent document that contains the same information describing the nonoriginating materials concerned in sufficient detail for their identification.\n\n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If a supplier's statement referred to in paragraph 4 is in electronic format, it does not need to be signed, provided that the supplier is identified to the satisfaction of the customs authorities in the Party where the supplier's statement was completed.\n\n\n\n7.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A supplier's statement applies to a single invoice or multiple invoices for the same material that is supplied within a period that does not exceed 12 months from the date set out in the supplier's statement.\n\n\n\n8.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Subject to paragraph\u00a09, if, as permitted by the WTO Agreement, each Party has a free trade agreement with the same third country, a material of that third country may be taken into consideration by the exporter when determining whether a product is originating under this Agreement. \n\n\n\n9.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall apply paragraph 8 only if equivalent provisions are in force between each Party and the third country and upon agreement by the Parties on the applicable conditions.\n\n\n\n10.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Notwithstanding paragraph 9, if each Party has a free trade agreement with the United States, and upon agreement by both Parties on the applicable conditions, each Party shall apply paragraph 8 when determining whether a product of Chapter 2 or 11, heading 16.01 through 16.03, Chapter 19, heading 20.02 or 20.03, or subheading 3505.10 is originating under this Agreement. \n\n\n\n\n\n\nArticle 4\n\n\n\nWholly obtained products\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The following products shall be considered as wholly obtained in a Party:\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0mineral products and other nonliving natural resources extracted or taken from there;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0vegetables, plants, and plant products harvested or gathered there;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0live animals born and raised there;\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0products obtained from live animals there; \n\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0products from slaughtered animals born and raised there;\n\n\n\n(f)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0products obtained by hunting, trapping, or fishing conducted there, but not beyond the outer limits of the Party's territorial sea; \n\n\n\n(g)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0products of aquaculture raised there; \n\n\n\n\n\n(h)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0fish, shellfish, and other marine life taken beyond the outer limits of any territorial sea by a vessel;\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0products made aboard factory ships exclusively from products referred to in subparagraph (f);\n\n\n\n(j)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0mineral products and other nonliving natural resources, taken or extracted from the seabed, subsoil, or ocean floor of:\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the exclusive economic zone of Canada or the European Union's Member States, as determined by domestic law and consistent with Part V of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, done at Montego Bay on 10 December 1982 (\"UNCLOS\"); \n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the continental shelf of Canada or the European Union's Member States, as determined by domestic law and consistent with Part VI of UNCLOS; or \n\n\n\n(iii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the Area as defined in Article 1(1) of UNCLOS,\n\n\n\nby a Party or a person of a Party, provided that that Party or person of a Party has rights to exploit such seabed, subsoil, or ocean floor;\n\n\n\n\n(k)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0raw materials recovered from used products collected there, provided that these products are fit only for such recovery;\n\n\n\n(l)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0components recovered from used products collected there, provided that these products are fit only for such recovery, when the component is:\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0incorporated into another product; or\n\n\n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0further produced resulting in a product with a performance and life expectancy equivalent or similar to those of a new product of the same type; \n\n\n\n(m)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0products, at any stage of production, produced there exclusively from products specified in subparagraphs (a) through (j).\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purpose of subparagraphs 1(f) and (g), the following conditions apply to the vessel or factory ship: \n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the vessel or factory ship must be:\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0registered in a Member State of the European Union or in Canada; or\n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0listed in Canada, if such vessel:\n\n\n\n(A)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0immediately prior to its listing in Canada, is entitled to fly the flag of a Member State of the European Union and must sail under that flag; and \n\n\n\n(B)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0fulfills the conditions of subsubparagraphs 2(b)(i) or 2(b)(ii);\n\n\n\n(iii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0entitled to fly the flag of a Member State of the European Union or of Canada and must sail under that flag; and\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0with respect to the European Union, the vessel or factory ship must be:\n\n\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0at least 50 per cent owned by nationals of a Member State of the European Union; or\n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0owned by companies that have their head office and their main place of business in a Member State of the European Union, and that are at least 50 per cent owned by a Member State of the European Union, public entities or nationals of a Member State of the European Union; or\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0with respect to Canada, the vessel or factory ship must take the fish, shellfish, or other marine life under the authority of a Canadian fishing licence. Canadian fishing licences include Canadian commercial fishing licences and Canadian aboriginal fishing licences issued to aboriginal organisations. The holder of the Canadian fishing licence must be:\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a Canadian national;\n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0an enterprise that is no more than 49\u00a0per\u00a0cent foreign owned and has a commercial presence in Canada; \n\n\n\n(iii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a fishing vessel owned by a person referred to in subsubparagraph (i) or (ii) that is registered in Canada, entitled to fly the flag of Canada and must sail under that flag; or\n\n\n\n(iv)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0an aboriginal organisation located in the territory of Canada. A person fishing under the authority of a Canadian aboriginal fishing licence must be a Canadian national.\n\n\n\n\nArticle 5\n\n\n\nSufficient production\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purpose of Article 2, products that are not wholly obtained are considered to have undergone sufficient production when the conditions set out in Annex 5 are fulfilled.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If a nonoriginating material undergoes sufficient production, the resulting product shall be considered as originating and no account shall be taken of the nonoriginating material contained therein when that product is used in the subsequent production of another product.\n\n\n\n\nArticle 6\n\n\n\nTolerance\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Notwithstanding Article 5.1, and except as provided in paragraph 3, if the nonoriginating materials used in the production of a product do not fulfil the conditions set out in Annex 5, the product shall be considered an originating product provided that:\u00a0\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the total value of those nonoriginating materials does not exceed 10\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the transaction value or exworks price of the product; \n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0any of the percentages given in Annex 5 for the maximum value or weight of nonoriginating materials are not exceeded through the application of this paragraph; and\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the product satisfies all other applicable requirements of this Protocol.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Paragraph 1 does not apply to products wholly obtained in a Party within the meaning of Article 4. If the rule of origin specified in Annex 5 requires that the materials used in the production of a product be wholly obtained, the tolerance provided for in paragraph 1 applies to the sum of these materials.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Tolerance for textile and apparel products of Chapter 50 through 63 of the HS shall be determined in accordance with Annex 1.\n\n\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Paragraphs 1 through 3 are subject to Article 8(c).\n\n\n\n\n\nArticle 7\n\n\n\nInsufficient production\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Without prejudice to paragraph 2, the following operations are insufficient to confer origin on a product, whether or not the requirements of Articles 5\u00a0or 6 are satisfied:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0operations exclusively intended to preserve products in good condition during storage and transport;\n1\n\u00a0\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0breakingup or assembly of packages;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0washing, cleaning, or operations to remove dust, oxide, oil, paint, or other coverings from a product;\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0ironing or pressing of textiles or textile articles of Chapter 50 through 63 of the HS;\n\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0simple painting or polishing operations;\n\n\n\n(f)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0husking, partial or total bleaching, polishing, or glazing of cereals or rice of Chapter 10 that does not result in a change of chapter; \n\n\n\n\n\n(g)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0operations to colour or flavour sugar of heading 17.01 or 17.02; operations to form sugar lumps of heading 17.01; partial or total grinding of crystal sugar of heading 17.01; \n\n\n\n(h)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0peeling, stoning, or shelling of vegetables of Chapter 7, fruits of Chapter 8, nuts of heading 08.01 or 08.02 or groundnuts of heading 12.02, if these vegetables, fruits, nuts, or groundnuts remain classified within the same chapter; \n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0sharpening, simple grinding, or simple cutting;\n\n\n\n(j)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0simple sifting, screening, sorting, classifying, grading, or matching;\n\n\n\n\n(k)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0simple packaging operations, such as placing in bottles, cans, flasks, bags, cases, boxes, or fixing on cards or boards;\n\n\n\n(l)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0affixing or printing marks, labels, logos, and other like distinguishing signs on the products or their packaging;\n\n\n\n(m)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0mixing of sugar of heading 17.01 or 17.02 with any material;\n\n\n\n(n)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0simple mixing of materials, whether or not of different kinds; simple mixing does not include an operation that causes a chemical reaction as defined in the notes to Chapter 28 or 29 of Annex 5;\n\n\n\n(o)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0simple assembly of parts of articles to constitute a complete article of Chapter 61, 62, or\u00a082 through 97 of the HS or disassembly of complete articles of Chapter 61, 62, or 82 through 97 into parts;\n\n\n\n(p)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a combination of two or more operations specified in subparagraphs (a) to (o); and\n\n\n\n\n\n(q)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0slaughter of animals.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0In accordance with Article 3, all production carried out in the European Union and in Canada on a product is considered when determining whether the production undertaken on that product is insufficient within the meaning of paragraph 1.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purpose of paragraph 1, an operation shall be considered simple when neither special skills, nor machines, apparatus, or tools especially produced or installed for those operations are required for their performance or when those skills, machines, apparatus, or tools do not contribute to the product's essential characteristics or properties.\n\n\n\n\n\nArticle 8\n\n\n\nUnit of classification\n\n\n\nFor the purpose of this Protocol:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the tariff classification of a particular product or material shall be determined according to the HS;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0when a product composed of a group or assembly of articles or components is classified pursuant to the terms of the HS under a single heading or subheading, the whole shall constitute the particular product; and\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0when a shipment consists of a number of identical products classified under the same heading or subheading of the HS, each product shall be considered separately.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nArticle 9\n\n\n\nPackaging and packing materials and containers\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If, under General Rule 5 of the HS, packaging is included with the product for classification purposes, it is considered in determining whether all the nonoriginating materials used in the production of the product satisfy the requirements set out in Annex 5.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Packing materials and containers in which a product is packed for shipment shall be disregarded in determining the origin of that product.\n\n\n\n\n\nArticle 10\n\n\n\nAccounting segregation of fungible materials or products\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If originating and nonoriginating fungible materials are used in the production of a product, the determination of the origin of the fungible materials does not need to be made through physical separation and identification of any specific fungible material, but may be determined on the basis of an inventory management system; or \n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0if originating and nonoriginating fungible products of Chapter 10, 15, 27, 28, 29, heading 32.01 through 32.07, or heading 39.01 through 39.14 of the HS are physically combined or mixed in inventory in a Party before exportation to the other Party, the determination of the origin of the fungible products does not need to be made through physical separation and identification of any specific fungible product, but may be determined on the basis of an inventory management system.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The inventory management system must:\n\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0ensure that, at any time, no more products receive originating status than would have been the case if the fungible materials or fungible products had been physically segregated; \n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0specify the quantity of originating and nonoriginating materials or products, including the dates on which those materials or products were placed in inventory and, if required by the applicable rule of origin, the value of those materials or products;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0specify the quantity of products produced using fungible materials, or the quantity of fungible products, that are supplied to customers who require evidence of origin in a Party for the purpose of obtaining preferential treatment under this Agreement, as well as to customers who do not require such evidence; and\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0indicate whether an inventory of originating products was available in sufficient quantity to support the declaration of originating status.\n\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party may require that an exporter or producer within its territory that is seeking to use an inventory management system pursuant to this Article obtain prior authorisation from that Party in order to use that system. The Party may withdraw authorisation to use an inventory management system if the exporter or producer makes improper use of it.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purpose of paragraph 1, \"fungible materials\" or \"fungible products\" means materials or products that are of the same kind and commercial quality, with the same technical and physical characteristics, and which cannot be distinguished from one another for origin purposes.\n\n\n\n\nArticle 11\n\n\n\nAccessories, spare parts and tools\n\n\n\nAccessories, spare parts, and tools delivered with a product that form part of its standard accessories, spare parts, or tools, that are not invoiced separately from the product and which quantities and value are customary for the product, shall be:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0taken into account in calculating the value of the relevant nonoriginating materials when the rule of origin of Annex 5 applicable to the product contains a percentage for the maximum value of nonoriginating materials; and \n\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0disregarded in determining whether all the nonoriginating materials used in the production of the product undergo the applicable change in tariff classification or other requirements set out in Annex 5.\n\n\n\n\nArticle 12\n\n\n\nSets\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Except as provided in Annex 5, a set, as referred to in General Rule 3 of the HS, is originating provided that:\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0all of the set's component products are originating; or \n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0when the set contains a nonoriginating component product, at least one of the component products or all of the packaging material and containers for the set is originating; and\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the value of the nonoriginating component products of Chapter 1 through 24 of the Harmonized System does not exceed 15\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the transaction value or exworks price of the set;\n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the value of the nonoriginating component products of Chapter 25 through 97 of the HS does not exceed 25\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the transaction value or exworks price of the set; and\n\n\n\n(iii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the value of all of the set's nonoriginating component products does not exceed 25\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the transaction value or exworks price of the set.\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The value of nonoriginating component products is calculated in the same manner as the value of nonoriginating materials.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The transaction value or exworks price of the set shall be calculated in the same manner as the transaction value or exworks price of the product.\n\n\n\n\nArticle 13\n\n\n\nNeutral elements\n\n\n\nFor the purpose of determining whether a product is originating, it is not necessary to determine the origin of the following which might be used in its production:\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0energy and fuel;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0plant and equipment;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0machines and tools; or\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0materials which do not enter and which are not intended to enter into the final composition of the product.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nArticle 14\n\n\n\nTransport through a third country\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A product that has undergone production that satisfies the requirements of Article 2 shall be considered originating only if, subsequent to that production, the product:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0does not undergo further production or any other operation outside the territories of the Parties, other than unloading, reloading, or any other operation necessary to preserve it in good condition or to transport the product to the territory of a Party; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0remains under customs control while outside the territories of the Parties.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The storage of products and shipments or the splitting of shipments may take place where carried out under the responsibility of the exporter or of a subsequent holder of the products and the products remain under customs control in the country or countries of\u00a0transit.\n\n\n\n\n\nArticle 15\n\n\n\nReturned originating products\n\n\n\nIf an originating product exported from a Party to a third\u00a0country returns, it shall be considered as nonoriginating, unless it can be demonstrated to the satisfaction of the customs authorities that the returning product:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0is the same as that exported; and\n\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0has not undergone any operation beyond that necessary to preserve it in good condition.\n\n\n\n\nArticle 16\n\n\n\nSugar\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If a rule of origin requires that the net weight of nonoriginating sugar used in production not exceed a specified threshold, the product satisfies this condition if the total net weight of all monosaccharides and disaccharides contained in the product, or in the materials used in production, does not exceed this threshold.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The product also satisfies the condition in paragraph 1 if the threshold is not exceeded by the net weight of nonoriginating sugar classified in heading 17.01 or subheading 1702.30 through 1702.60 or 1702.90 other than maltodextrin, chemically pure maltose, or \"colouring\" caramel, as described in the explanatory notes to heading 17.02, when used as such in the production of:\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the product; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the nonoriginating sugarcontaining materials classified in subheading 1302.20, 1704.90, 1806.10, 1806.20, 1901.90, 2101.12, 2101.20, 2106.90, and 3302.10 that are used as such in the production of the product. Alternatively, the net weight of all monosaccharides and disaccharides contained in any of these sugarcontaining materials may also be used. If the net weight of the nonoriginating sugar used in the production of these sugar containing materials or the net weight of monosaccharides and disaccharides contained in these sugarcontaining materials is not known, the total net weight of these materials used as such in production must apply. \n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The net weight of any nonoriginating sugar as referred to in paragraph 2 may be calculated on a dry weight basis.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purpose of the rules of origin for heading 17.04 and 18.06, the value of nonoriginating sugar refers to the value of the nonoriginating material referred to in paragraph 2 that is used in production of the product. \n\n\n\n\n\n\nArticle 17\n\n\n\nNet cost\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purpose of this Article, the following definitions apply, in addition to those set out in Article 1:\n\n\n\nmotor vehicle means a product of subheading 8703.21 through 8703.90; \n\n\n\nnet cost means total cost minus sales promotion, marketing and aftersales service costs, royalty, shipping and packing costs, and nonallowable interest cost that are included in the total cost; \n\n\n\n\nnonallowable interest cost means interest costs incurred by a producer that exceed 700 basis points above the applicable national government interest rate identified for comparable maturities;\n\n\n\nroyalty means payments of any kind, including payments under technical assistance or similar agreements, made as consideration for the use or right to use any copyright, literary, artistic, or scientific work, patent, trademark, design, model, plan, secret formula or process, excluding those payments under technical assistance or similar agreements that can be related to specific services such as: \n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0personnel training, without regard to where it is performed; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0if performed in the territory of one or both of the Parties, engineering, tooling, diesetting, software design and similar computer services, or other services;\n\n\n\nsales promotion, marketing, and aftersales service costs means the following costs related to sales promotion, marketing, and aftersales service: \n\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0sales and marketing promotion; media advertising; advertising and market research; promotional and demonstration materials; exhibits; sales conferences, trade shows and conventions; banners; marketing displays; free samples; sales, marketing and aftersales service literature (product brochures, catalogues, technical literature, price lists, service manuals and sales aid information); establishment and protection of logos and trademarks; sponsorships; wholesale and retail restocking charges; entertainment; \n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0sales and marketing incentives; consumer, retailer or wholesaler rebates; merchandise incentives; \n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0salaries and wages; sales commissions; bonuses; benefits (for example, medical, insurance, and pension); travelling and living expenses; and membership and professional fees for sales promotion, marketing, and aftersales service personnel; \n\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0recruiting and training of sales promotion, marketing, and aftersales service personnel, and aftersales training of customers' employees, if those costs are identified separately for sales promotion, marketing, and aftersales service of products on the financial statements or cost accounts of the producer; \n\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0product liability insurance; \n\n\n\n(f)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0office supplies for sales promotion, marketing, and aftersales service of products, if those costs are identified separately for sales promotion, marketing, and aftersales service of products on the financial statements or cost accounts of the producer; \n\n\n\n(g)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0telephone, mail, and other communications, if those costs are identified separately for sales promotion, marketing, and aftersales service of products on the financial statements or cost accounts of the producer; \n\n\n\n(h)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0rent and depreciation of sales promotion, marketing, and aftersales service offices and distribution centres; \n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0property insurance premiums, taxes, cost of utilities, and repair and maintenance of sales promotion, marketing, and aftersales service offices and distribution centres, where such costs are identified separately for sales promotion, marketing, and aftersales service of products on the financial statements or cost accounts of the producer; and \n\n\n\n(j)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0payments by the producer to other persons for warranty repairs; \n\n\n\n\n\nshipping and packing costs means the costs incurred in packing a product for shipment and shipping the product from the point of direct shipment to the buyer, excluding costs of preparing and packaging the product for retail sale; and\n\n\n\ntotal cost means all product costs, period costs and other costs incurred in relation to the production of a product in Canada when: \n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0product costs means those costs that are associated with the production of a product and include the value of materials, direct labour costs, and direct overhead. \n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0period costs means those costs other than product costs that are expensed in the period in which they are incurred, including selling expenses and general and administrative expenses. \n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0other costs means all costs recorded on the books of the producer that are not product costs or period costs.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purpose of calculating the net cost of a product under Table D.1 (Annual Quota Allocation for Vehicles Exported from Canada to the European Union) in Annex 5A, the producer of the product may: \n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0calculate the total cost incurred with respect to all products produced by that producer, subtract any sales promotion, marketing and aftersales service costs, royalty, shipping and packing costs, and nonallowable interest cost that is included in the total cost of all those products, and then reasonably allocate the resulting net cost of those products to the product; \n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0calculate the total cost incurred with respect to all products produced by that producer, reasonably allocate the total cost to the product, and then subtract any sales promotion, marketing and aftersales service costs, royalty, shipping and packing costs and nonallowable interest cost that is included in the portion of the total cost allocated to the product; or \n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0reasonably allocate each cost that forms part of the total cost incurred by that producer with respect to the product so that the aggregate of these costs does not include any sales promotion, marketing and aftersales service costs, royalty, shipping and packing costs, or nonallowable interest cost.\n\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purpose of calculating the net cost of a product under paragraph 1, the producer may average its calculation over its fiscal year using any one of the following categories, on the basis of either all motor vehicles produced by that producer in the category or only those motor vehicles in the category that are produced by that producer and exported to the territory of the other Party:\n\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the same model line of motor vehicles in the same class of vehicles produced in the same plant in the territory of a Party;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the same model line of motor vehicles produced in the same plant in the territory of a Party;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the same model line of motor vehicles produced in the territory of a Party;\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the same class of motor vehicles produced in the same plant in the territory of a Party; or\n\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0any other category as the Parties may decide.\n\n\n\n\nSection C\n\n\n\nOrigin Procedures\n\n\n\n\nArticle 18\n\n\n\nProof of origin\n\n\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Products originating in the European Union, on importation into Canada, and products originating in Canada, on importation into the European Union, benefit from preferential tariff treatment of this Agreement on the basis of a declaration (\"origin declaration\"). \n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The origin declaration is provided on an invoice or any other commercial document that describes the originating product in sufficient detail to enable its identification.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The different linguistic versions of the text of the origin declaration are set out in Annex 2.\n\n\n\n\nArticle 19\n\n\n\nObligations regarding exportations\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0An origin declaration as referred to in Article\u00a018.1 shall be completed:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in the European Union, by an exporter in accordance with the relevant European Union legislation; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in Canada, by an exporter in accordance with Part V of the Customs Act,\u00a0R.S.C., 1985, c. 1 (2nd Supp.).\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The exporter completing an origin declaration shall at the request of the customs authority of the Party of export submit a copy of the origin declaration and all appropriate documents proving the originating status of the products concerned, including supporting documents or written statements from the producers or suppliers, and fulfil the other requirements of this Protocol. \n\n\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0An origin declaration shall be completed and signed by the exporter unless otherwise provided. \n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party may allow an origin declaration to be completed by the exporter when the products to which it relates are exported, or after exportation if the origin declaration is presented in the importing Party within two years after the importation of the products to which it relates or within a longer period of time if specified in the laws of the importing Party.\n\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The customs authority of the Party of import may allow the application of an origin declaration to multiple shipments of identical originating products that take place within a period of time that does not exceed 12 months as set out by the exporter in that declaration.\n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0An exporter that has completed an origin declaration and becomes aware or has reason to believe that the origin declaration contains incorrect information shall immediately notify the importer in writing of any change affecting the originating status of each product to which the origin declaration applies. \n\n\n\n7.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties may allow the establishment of a system that permits an origin declaration to be submitted electronically and directly from the exporter in the territory of a Party to an importer in the territory of the other Party, including the replacement of the exporter's signature on the origin declaration with an electronic signature or identification code.\n\n\n\n\nArticle 20\n\n\n\nValidity of the origin declaration\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0An origin declaration shall be valid for 12 months from the date it was completed by the exporter, or for such longer period of time as provided by the Party of import. The preferential tariff treatment may be claimed, within this validity period, to the customs authority of the Party of import.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Party of import may accept an origin declaration submitted to its customs authority after the validity period referred to in paragraph 1 for the purpose of preferential tariff treatment in accordance with that Party's laws.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nArticle 21\n\n\n\nObligations regarding importations\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purpose of claiming preferential tariff treatment, the importer shall:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0submit the origin declaration to the customs authority of the Party of import as required by and in accordance with the procedures applicable in that Party;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0if required by the customs authority of the Party of import, submit a translation of the origin declaration; and\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0if required by the customs authority of the Party of import, provide for a statement accompanying or forming a part of the import declaration, to the effect that the products meet the conditions required for the application of this Agreement.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0An importer that becomes aware or has reason to believe that an origin declaration for a product to which preferential tariff treatment has been granted contains incorrect information shall immediately notify the customs authority of the Party of import in writing of any change affecting the originating status of that product and pay any duties owing. \n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0When an importer claims preferential tariff treatment for a good imported from the territory of the other Party, the importing Party may deny preferential tariff treatment to the good if the importer fails to comply with any requirement under this Protocol.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party shall, in conformity with its laws, provide that, if a product would have qualified as an originating product when it was imported into the territory of that Party but the importer did not have an origin declaration at the time of importation, the importer of the product may, within a period of time of no less than three years after the date of importation, apply for a refund of duties paid as a result of the product not having been accorded preferential tariff treatment. \n\n\n\n\n\nArticle 22\n\n\n\n\n\nProof related to transport through a third country\n\n\n\nEach Party, through its customs authority, may require an importer to demonstrate that a product for which the importer claims preferential tariff treatment was shipped in accordance with Article 14 by providing: \n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0carrier documents, including bills of lading or waybills, indicating the shipping route and all points of shipment and transhipment prior to the importation of the product; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0when the product is shipped through or transhipped outside the territories of the Parties, a copy of the customs control documents indicating to that customs authority that the product remained under customs control while outside the territories of the Parties.\n\n\n\n\nArticle 23\n\n\n\nImportation by instalments\n\n\n\nEach Party shall provide that if dismantled or nonassembled products within the meaning of General Rule 2(a) of the HS falling within Sections XVI and XVII or heading 7308 and 9406 of the HS are imported by instalments at the request of the importer and on the conditions set out by the customs authority of the Party of import, a single origin declaration for these products shall be submitted, as required, to that customs authority upon importation of the first instalment. \n\n\n\n\n\nArticle 24\n\n\n\nExemptions from origin declarations\n\n\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party may, in conformity with its laws, waive the requirement to present an origin declaration as referred to in Article 21, for low value shipments of originating products from another Party and for originating products forming part of the personal luggage of a traveller coming from another Party.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party may exclude any importation from the provisions of paragraph 1 when the importation is part of a series of importations that may reasonably be considered to have been undertaken or arranged for the purpose of avoiding the requirements of this Protocol related to origin declarations. \n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties may set value limits for products referred to in paragraph 1, and shall exchange information regarding those limits.\n\n\n\n\nArticle 25\n\n\n\nSupporting documents\n\n\n\nThe documents referred to in Article 19.2 may include documents relating to the following:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the production processes carried out on the originating product or on materials used in the production of that product; \n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the purchase of, the cost of, the value of, and the payment for the product;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the origin of, the purchase of, the cost of, the value of, and the payment for all materials, including neutral elements, used in the production of the product; and\n\n\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the shipment of the product.\n\n\n\n\n\nArticle 26\n\n\n\nPreservation of records\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0An exporter that has completed an origin declaration shall keep a copy of the origin declaration, as well as the supporting documents referred to in Article 25, for three years after the completion of the origin declaration or for a longer period of time as the Party of export may specify. \n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If an exporter has based an origin declaration on a written statement from the producer, the producer shall be required to maintain records in accordance with paragraph 1. \n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0When provided for in laws of the Party of import, an importer that has been granted preferential tariff treatment shall keep documentation relating to the importation of the product, including a copy of the origin declaration, for three years after the date on which preferential treatment was granted, or for a longer period of time as that Party may specify.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party
