shall permit, in accordance with that Party's laws, importers, exporters, and producers in its territory to maintain documentation or records in any medium, provided that the documentation or records can be retrieved and printed.\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party may deny preferential tariff treatment to a product that is the subject of an origin verification when the importer, exporter, or producer of the product that is required to maintain records or documentation under this Article:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0fails to maintain records or documentation relevant to determining the origin of the product in accordance with the requirements of this Protocol; or\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0denies access to those records or documentation.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nArticle 27\n\n\n\nDiscrepancies and formal errors\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The discovery of slight discrepancies between the statements made in the origin declaration and those made in the documents submitted to the customs authorities for the purpose of carrying out the formalities for importing the products shall not, because of that fact, render the origin declaration null and void if it is established that this document corresponds to the products submitted.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Obvious formal errors such as typing errors on an origin declaration shall not cause this document to be rejected if these errors do not create doubts concerning the correctness of the statements made in the document.\n\n\n\n\nArticle 28\n\n\n\nCooperation\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties shall cooperate in the uniform administration and interpretation of this Protocol and, through their customs authorities, assist each other in verifying the originating status of the products on which an origin declaration is based.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purpose of facilitating the verifications or assistance referred to in paragraph 1, the customs authorities of the Parties shall provide each other, through the European Commission, with addresses of the responsible customs authorities.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0It is understood that the customs authority of the Party of export assumes all expenses in carrying out paragraph 1. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0It is further understood that the customs authorities of the Parties will discuss the overall operation and administration of the verification process, including forecasting of workload and discussing priorities. If there is an unusual increase in the number of requests, the customs authorities of the Parties will consult to establish priorities and consider steps to manage the workload, taking into consideration operational requirements.\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0With respect to\u00a0products considered originating in accordance with Article 3, the Parties may cooperate with a third country to develop customs procedures based on the principles of this Protocol.\n\n\n\n\nArticle 29\n\n\n\nOrigin verification\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purpose of ensuring the proper application of this Protocol, the Parties shall assist each other, through their customs authorities, in verifying whether products are originating and ensuring the accuracy of claims for preferential tariff treatment.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A Party's request for an origin verification concerning whether a product is originating or whether all other requirements of this Protocol are fulfilled shall be:\u00a0\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0based on risk assessment methods applied by the customs authority of the Party of import, which may include random selection; or\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0made when the Party of import has reasonable doubts about whether the product is originating or whether all other requirements of this Protocol have been fulfilled. \n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The customs authority of the Party of import may verify whether a product is originating by requesting, in writing, that the customs authority of the Party of export conduct a verification concerning whether a product is originating. When requesting a verification, the customs authority of the Party of import shall provide the customs authority of the Party of export with:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the identity of the customs authority issuing the request;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the name of the exporter or producer to be verified;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the subject and scope of the verification; and\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a copy of the origin declaration and, where applicable, any other relevant documentation.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0When appropriate, the customs authority of the Party of import may request, pursuant to paragraph 3, specific documentation and information from the customs authority of the Party of export.\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A request made by the customs authority of the Party of import pursuant to paragraph 3 shall be provided to the customs authority of the Party of export by certified or registered mail or any other method that produces a confirmation of receipt by that customs authority.\n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The customs authority of the Party of export shall proceed to the origin verification. For this purpose, the customs authority may, in accordance with its laws, request documentation, call for any evidence, or visit the premises of an exporter or a producer to review the records referred to in Article 25 and observe the facilities used in the production of the product.\n\n\n\n7.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If an exporter has based an origin declaration on a written statement from the producer or supplier, the exporter may arrange for the producer or supplier to provide documentation or information directly to the customs authority of the Party of export upon that Party's request.\n\n\n\n8.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0As soon as possible and in any event within 12 months after receiving the request referred to in paragraph 4, the customs authority of the Party of export shall complete a verification of whether the product is originating and fulfils the other requirements of this Protocol, and shall:\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0provide to the customs authority of the Party of import, by certified or registered mail or any other method that produces a confirmation of receipt by that customs authority, a written report in order for it to determine whether the product is originating or not, and that contains:\n\n\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the results of the verification; \n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the description of the product subject to verification and the tariff classification relevant to the application of the rule of origin;\n\n\n\n(iii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a description and explanation of the production sufficient to support the rationale concerning the originating status of the product;\n\n\n\n(iv)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0information on the manner in which the verification was conducted; and\n\n\n\n(v)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0where appropriate, supporting documentation; and\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0subject to its laws, notify the exporter of its decision concerning whether the product is originating.\n\n\n\n9.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The period of time referred to in paragraph 8 may be extended by mutual consent of the customs authorities concerned.\n\n\n\n10.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Pending the results of an origin verification conducted pursuant to paragraph 8, or consultations under paragraph 13, the customs authority of the Party of import, subject to any precautionary measures it deems necessary, shall offer to release the product to the importer. \n\n\n\n11.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If the result of an origin verification has not been provided in accordance with paragraph 8, the customs authority of the importing Party may deny preferential tariff treatment to a product if it has reasonable doubt or when it is unable to determine whether the product is originating.\n\n\n\n\n12.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If there are differences in relation to the verification procedures of this Article or in the interpretation of the rules of origin in determining whether a product qualifies as originating, and these differences cannot be resolved through consultations between the customs authority requesting the verification and the customs authority responsible for performing the verification, and if the customs authority of the importing Party intends to make a determination of origin that is inconsistent with the written report provided under paragraph 8(a) by the customs authority of the exporting Party, the importing Party shall notify the exporting Party within 60 days of receiving the written report.\n\n\n\n\n\n13.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0At the request of either Party, the Parties shall hold and conclude consultations within 90 days from the date of the notification referred to in paragraph 12 to resolve those differences. The period of time for concluding consultations may be extended on a case by case basis by mutual written consent between the Parties. The customs authority of the importing Party may make its determination of origin after the conclusion of these consultations. The Parties may also seek to resolve those differences within the Joint Customs Cooperation Committee referred to in Article 34.\n\n\n\n14.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0In all cases, the settlement of differences between the importer and the customs authority of the Party of import shall be under the law of the Party of import.\n\n\n\n15.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This Protocol does not prevent a customs authority of a Party from issuing a determination of origin or an advance ruling relating to any matter under consideration by the Joint Customs Cooperation Committee or the Committee on Trade in Goods established under Article 26.2(a) (Specialised Committees) or from taking any other action that it considers necessary, pending a resolution of the matter under this Agreement.\n\n\n\n\n\nArticle 30\n\n\n\nReview and appeal\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall grant substantially the same rights of review and appeal of determinations of origin and advance rulings issued by its customs authority as it provides to importers in its territory, to any person who: \n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0has received a determination on origin in the application of this Protocol; or \n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0has received an advance ruling pursuant to Article 33.1.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Further to Articles 27.3 (Administrative proceedings) and 27.4 (Review and appeal), each Party shall provide that the rights of review and appeal referred to in paragraph 1 include access to at least two levels of appeal or review including at least one judicial or quasijudicial level.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nArticle 31\n\n\n\nPenalties\n\n\n\nEach Party shall maintain measures imposing criminal, civil or administrative penalties for violations of its laws relating to this Protocol.\n\n\n\n\nArticle 32\n\n\n\nConfidentiality\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This Protocol does not require a Party to furnish or allow access to business information or to information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person, the disclosure of which would impede law enforcement or would be contrary to that Party's law protecting business information and personal data and privacy. \n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall maintain, in conformity with its law, the confidentiality of the information collected pursuant to this Protocol and shall protect that information from disclosure that could prejudice the competitive position of the person providing the information. If the Party receiving or obtaining the information is required by its laws to disclose the information, that Party shall notify the person or Party who provided that information.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall ensure that the confidential information collected pursuant to this Protocol shall not be used for purposes other than the administration and enforcement of determination of origin and of customs matters, except with the permission of the person or Party who provided the confidential information.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Notwithstanding paragraph 3, a Party may allow information collected pursuant to this Protocol to be used in any administrative, judicial, or quasijudicial proceedings instituted for failure to comply with customs related laws implementing this Protocol. A Party shall notify the person or Party who provided the information in advance of such use.\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties shall exchange information on their respective law concerning data protection for the purpose of facilitating the operation and application of paragraph 2. \n\n\n\n\n\n\nArticle 33\n\n\n\nAdvance rulings relating to origin\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall, through its customs authority, provide for the expeditious issuance of written advance rulings in accordance with its law, prior to the importation of a product into its territory, concerning whether a product qualifies as an originating product under this Protocol.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall adopt or maintain procedures for the issuance of advance rulings, including a detailed description of the information reasonably required to process an application for a ruling.\n\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall provide that its customs authority:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0may, at any time during the course of an evaluation of an application for an advance ruling, request supplemental information from the person requesting the ruling;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0issue the ruling within 120 days from the date on which it has obtained all necessary information from the person requesting the advance ruling; and \n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0provide, to the person requesting the advance ruling, a full explanation of the reasons for the ruling.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0When an application for an advance ruling involves an issue that is the subject of: \n\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a verification of origin; \n\n\n\n(b\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a review by, or appeal to, a customs authority; or \n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a judicial or quasijudicial review in the customs authority's territory; \n\n\n\nthe customs authority, in accordance with its laws, may decline or postpone the issuance of the ruling.\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Subject to paragraph 7, each Party shall apply an advance ruling to importations into its territory of the product for which the ruling was requested on the date of its issuance or at a later date if specified in the ruling. \n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall provide, to any person requesting an advance ruling, the same treatment as it provided to any other person to whom it issued an advance ruling, provided that the facts and circumstances are identical in all material respects.\n\n\n\n7.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Party issuing an advance ruling may modify or revoke an advance ruling: \n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0if the ruling is based on an error of fact;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0if there is a change in the material facts or circumstances on which the ruling is based; \n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0to conform with an amendment of Chapter Two (National Treatment and Market Access for Goods), or this Protocol; or\n\n\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0to conform with a judicial decision or a change in its law. \n\n\n\n8.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each Party shall provide that a modification or revocation of an advance ruling is effective on the date on which the modification or revocation is issued, or on a later date if specified in the ruling, and shall not be applied to importations of a product that have occurred prior to that date, unless the person to whom the advance ruling was issued has not acted in accordance with its terms and conditions.\n\n\n\n9.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Notwithstanding paragraph 8, the Party issuing the advance ruling may, in conformity with its law, postpone the effective date of a modification or revocation for no more than six months.\n\n\n\n10.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Subject to paragraph 7, each Party shall provide that an advance ruling remains in effect and is honoured.\n\n\n\n\nArticle 34\n\n\n\nCommittee\n\n\n\nThe Joint Customs Cooperation Committee (\"JCCC\"), granted authority to act under the auspices of the CETA Joint Committee as a specialised committee pursuant to Article 26.2.1 (Specialised Committees) may review this Protocol and recommend amendments to its provisions to the CETA Joint Committee. The JCCC shall endeavour to decide upon:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the uniform administration of the rules of origin, including tariff classification and valuation matters relating to this Protocol;\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0technical, interpretative, or administrative matters relating to this Protocol; or\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the priorities in relation to origin verifications and other matters arising from origin verifications.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n________________\n\n\nANNEX 1\n\n\n\nTOLERANCE FOR TEXTILE AND APPAREL PRODUCTS\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purpose of this Annex, the following definitions apply:\n\n\n\nnatural fibres means fibres other than artificial or synthetic fibres that have not been spun. Natural fibres include waste, and, unless otherwise specified, include fibres which have been carded, combed or otherwise processed, but not spun. Natural fibres include horsehair of heading 05.11, silk of heading 50.02 through 50.03, woolfibres and fine or coarse animal hair of heading 51.01 through 51.05, cotton fibres of heading 52.01 through 52.03, and other vegetable fibres of heading 53.01 through 53.05;\n\n\ntextile pulp, chemical materials, and papermaking materials means materials, not classified in Chapter 50 through 63, which can be used to manufacture artificial, synthetic or paper fibres or yarns; and\n\n\n\nmanmade staple fibres means synthetic or artificial filament tow, staple fibres or waste, of heading 55.01 through 55.07.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For greater certainty, nonoriginating materials of Chapter 1 through 49 or 64 through 97, including materials that contain textiles, may be disregarded for the purpose of determining whether all the nonoriginating materials used in the production of a product of Chapter 50 through 63 satisfies the applicable rule of origin set out in Annex\u00a05.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Subject to paragraph 7, if the nonoriginating materials used in the production of a product of Chapter 50 through 63 do not fulfil the conditions set out in Annex 5, the product is nonetheless an originating product provided that: \n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the product is produced using two or more of the basic textile materials listed in Table\u00a01; \n\n\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the net weight of nonoriginating basic textile materials listed in Table 1 does not exceed 10\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the net weight of the product; and\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the product satisfies all other applicable requirements of this Protocol.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Subject to paragraph 7, in the case of a product of Chapter 50 through 63 produced using one or more basic textile materials listed in Table 1, and nonoriginating yarn made of polyurethane segmented with flexible segments of polyether, the product is nonetheless an originating product provided that:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the weight of the nonoriginating yarn made of polyurethane segmented with flexible segments of polyether does not exceed 20\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the weight of the product; and \n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the product satisfies all other applicable requirements of this Protocol.\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Subject to paragraph 7, in the case of a product of Chapter 50 through 63 produced using one or more basic textile materials listed in Table 1 and nonoriginating strip consisting of a core of aluminium foil or of a core of plastic film whether or not coated with aluminium powder, of a width not exceeding 5 mm, sandwiched by means of a transparent or coloured adhesive between two layers of plastic film, the product is nonetheless an originating product provided that:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the weight of the nonoriginating strip consisting of a core of aluminium foil or of a core of plastic film whether or not coated with aluminium powder, of a width not exceeding 5 mm, sandwiched by means of a transparent or coloured adhesive between two layers of plastic film does not exceed 30\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the weight of the product; and \n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the product satisfies all other applicable requirements of this Protocol.\n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Subject to paragraph 7, if the nonoriginating materials used in the production of a product of Chapter 61 through 63 do not fulfil the conditions set out in Annex 5, the product is nonetheless an originating product provided that:\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the nonoriginating materials are classified in a heading other than that of the product;\n\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the value of the nonoriginating materials does not exceed 8\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the transaction value or exworks price of the product; and\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the product satisfies all other applicable requirements of this Protocol.\n\n\n\nThis paragraph does not apply to nonoriginating materials used in the production of linings or interlinings of a product of Chapter 61 through 63.\n\n\n\n7.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The tolerance provided for in paragraphs 2 through 6 does not apply to nonoriginating materials used in the production of a product if those materials are subject to a rule of origin that includes a percentage for their maximum value or weight.\n\n\n\nTable 1 \u2013 Basic textile materials\n\n\n\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0silk\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0wool\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0coarse animal hair\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0fine animal hair\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0horsehair\n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0cotton\n\n\n\n7.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0papermaking materials and paper\n\n\n\n8.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0flax\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n9.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0true hemp\n\n\n\n10.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0jute and other textile bast fibres\n\n\n\n11.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0sisal and other textile fibres of the genus Agave\n\n\n\n12.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0coconut, abaca, ramie, and other vegetable textile fibres\n\n\n\n13.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0synthetic manmade filaments\n\n\n\n14.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0artificial manmade filaments\n\n\n\n15.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0currentconducting filaments\n\n\n\n16.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0synthetic manmade staple fibres of polypropylene\n\n\n\n17.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0synthetic manmade staple fibres of polyester\n\n\n\n18.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0synthetic manmade staple fibres of polyamide\n\n\n\n19.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0synthetic manmade staple fibres of polyacrylonitrile\n\n\n\n20.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0synthetic manmade staple fibres of polyimide\n\n\n\n21.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0synthetic manmade staple fibres of polytetrafluoroethylene\n\n\n\n22.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0synthetic manmade staple fibres of poly(phenylene sulphide)\n\n\n\n23.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0synthetic manmade staple fibres of poly(vinyl chloride)\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n24.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0other synthetic manmade staple fibres\n\n\n\n25.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0artificial manmade staple fibres of viscose\n\n\n\n26.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0other artificial manmade staple fibres\n\n\n\n27.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0yarn made of polyurethane segmented with flexible segments of polyether, whether or not gimped\n\n\n\n28.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0yarn made of polyurethane segmented with flexible segments of polyester, whether or not gimped\n\n\n\n29.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a material of heading 56.05 (metallised yarn) incorporating strip consisting of a core of aluminium foil or of a core of plastic film whether or not coated with aluminium powder, of a width not exceeding 5 mm, sandwiched by means of a transparent or coloured adhesive between two layers of plastic film\n\n\n\n30.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0any other material of heading 56.05\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n________________\n\n\nANNEX 2\n\n\n\nText of the origin Declaration\n\n\n\nThe origin declaration, the text of which is given below, must be completed in accordance with the footnotes. However, the footnotes do not have to be reproduced.\n\n\n\n\n\n(Period: from___________ to __________(1))\n\n\n\nThe exporter of the products covered by this document (customs authorisation No ...(2)) declares that, except where otherwise clearly indicated, these products are of ...(3) preferential origin.\n\n\n\n\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026.............................................(4)\n\n\n(Place and date)\n\n\n\n...\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026..............................(5)\n\n\n(Signature and printed name of the exporter)\u00a0\n\n\n\n___________________\n\n\n(1)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0When the origin declaration is completed for multiple shipments of identical originating products within the meaning of Article 19.5, indicate the period of time for which the origin declaration will apply. The period of time must not exceed 12\u00a0months. All importations of the product must occur within the period indicated. Where a period of time is not applicable, the field can be left blank. \n\n\n(2)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For EU exporters: When the origin declaration is completed by an approved or registered exporter the exporter's customs authorisation or registration number must be included. A customs authorisation number is required only if the exporter is an approved exporter. When the origin declaration is not completed by an approved or registered exporter, the words in brackets must be omitted or the space left blank. \n\n\nFor Canadian exporters: The exporter's Business Number assigned by the Government of Canada must be included. Where the exporter has not been assigned a business number, the field may be left blank.\n\n\n(3)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\"Canada/EU\" means products qualifying as originating under the rules of origin of the CanadaEuropean Union Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement. When the origin declaration relates, in whole or in part, to products originating in Ceuta and Melilla, the exporter must clearly indicate the symbol \"CM\".\n\n\n(4)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0These indications may be omitted if the information is contained on the document itself.\n\n\n(5)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Article 19.3 provides an exception to the requirement of the exporter's signature. Where the exporter is not required to sign, the exemption of signature also implies the exemption of the name of the signatory.\n\n\n\nBulgarian version\n\n\n(\u041f\u0435\u0440\u0438\u043e\u0434: \u043e\u0442 _______\u0434\u043e_________(1))\n\n\n\n\n\n\u0418\u0437\u043d\u043e\u0441\u0438\u0442\u0435\u043b\u044f\u0442 \u043d\u0430 \u043f\u0440\u043e\u0434\u0443\u043a\u0442\u0438\u0442\u0435, \u043e\u0431\u0445\u0432\u0430\u043d\u0430\u0442\u0438 \u043e\u0442 \u0442\u043e\u0437\u0438 \u0434\u043e\u043a\u0443\u043c\u0435\u043d\u0442 (\u043c\u0438\u0442\u043d\u0438\u0447\u0435\u0441\u043a\u043e \u0440\u0430\u0437\u0440\u0435\u0448\u0435\u043d\u0438\u0435 \u2116 \u2026 (2)), \u0434\u0435\u043a\u043b\u0430\u0440\u0438\u0440\u0430, \u0447\u0435 \u043e\u0441\u0432\u0435\u043d \u043a\u043e\u0433\u0430\u0442\u043e \u0435 \u043e\u0442\u0431\u0435\u043b\u044f\u0437\u0430\u043d\u043e \u0434\u0440\u0443\u0433\u043e, \u0442\u0435\u0437\u0438 \u043f\u0440\u043e\u0434\u0443\u043a\u0442\u0438 \u0441\u0430 \u0441/\u0441\u044a\u0441 \u2026 \u043f\u0440\u0435\u0444\u0435\u0440\u0435\u043d\u0446\u0438\u0430\u043b\u0435\u043d \u043f\u0440\u043e\u0438\u0437\u0445\u043e\u0434 (3).\n\n\n\nSpanish version \n\n\n(Per\u00edodo comprendido entre contrario, estos productos gozan de un origen preferencial. \u2026(3).\n\n\n\nCzech version\n\n\n(Obdob\u00ed: od _______do_________(1))\n\n\n\nV\u00fdvozce v\u00fdrobk\u016f uveden\u00fdch v tomto nonoriginating products\n\n\n\nStatement:\n\n\n\n\n\nI, the undersigned, supplier of the products covered by the annexed document, declare that:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The following materials which do not originate in the European Union/in Canada(1) have been used in the European Union/in Canada to produce the following supplied nonoriginating products.\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Any used\n\n\n\n\n5\n\n\n\nHS tariff classification of nonoriginating material(s) used\n\n\n\n\n6\n\n\n\nValue of nonoriginating materials and and position, name and address of company)\n\n\n\n\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\n\n\n\n(Signature)\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n_______________\n\n\n\n(1)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Strikethrough the Party not applicable, as the case may be.\n\n\n(2)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For each nonoriginating product supplied and nonoriginating material used, specify the value per unit of the products and materials described in columns 3 and 6, respectively.\n\n\n\n\n________________\n\n\nANNEX 4\n\n\n\nMATTERS APPLICABLE TO CEUTA AND MELILLA\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purpose of this Protocol, in the case of the European Union, the term \"Party\" does not include Ceuta and Melilla. \n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Products originating in Canada, when imported into Ceuta and Melilla, shall in all respects be subject to the same customs regime, including preferential tariff treatment, as that which is applied to products originating in the customs territory of the European Union under Protocol 2 of the Act of Accession of the Kingdom of Spain and the Portuguese Republic to the European Communities. Canada shall apply to imports of products covered by this Agreement and originating in Ceuta and Melilla the same customs regime, including preferential tariff treatment, as that which is applied to products imported from and originating in the European Union.\n\n\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The rules of origin applicable to Canada under this Protocol shall apply in determining the origin of products exported from Canada to Ceuta and Melilla. The rules of origin applicable to the European Union under this Protocol shall apply in determining the origin of products exported from Ceuta and Melilla to Canada.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The provisions of this Protocol concerning the issuance, use and subsequent verification of origin shall apply to products exported from Canada to Ceuta and Melilla and to products exported from Ceuta and Melilla to Canada.\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The provisions on cumulation of origin of this Protocol shall apply to the import and export of products between the European Union, Canada and Ceuta and Melilla.\n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purposes mentioned in paragraphs 2, 3, 4 and 5, Ceuta and Melilla shall be regarded as a single territory.\n\n\n\n7.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Spanish customs authorities shall be responsible for the application of this Annex in Ceuta and Melilla.\n\n\n\n\n________________\n\n\nANNEX 5\n\n\n\nPRODUCTSPECIFIC RULES OF ORIGIN\n\n\n\nIntroductory Notes to Annex 5\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This Annex sets out the conditions required for a product to be considered originating within the meaning of Article 5 (Sufficient Production).\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The following definitions apply:\n\n\n\nchapter means a chapter of the Harmonized System;\u00a0\n\n\n\nheading means any fourdigit number, or the first four digits of any number, used in the Harmonized System;\n\n\n\nsection means a section of the Harmonized System; \n\n\n\nsubheading means any sixdigit number, or the first six digits of any number, used in the Harmonized System; and\n\n\n\ntariff provision means a chapter, heading, or subheading of the Harmonized System.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The productspecific rule of origin, or set of rules of origin, that applies to a product classified in a particular heading, subheading, or group of headings or subheadings is set out immediately adjacent to that heading, subheading, or group of headings or subheadings.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Unless otherwise specified, a requirement of a change in tariff classification or any other condition set out in a productspecific rule of origin applies only to nonoriginating material.\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Section, chapter, heading, or subheading notes, where applicable, are found at the beginning of each new section, chapter, heading, or subheading. These notes must be read in conjunction with the productspecific rules of origin for the applicable section, chapter, heading, or subheading and may impose further conditions on, or provide an alternative to, the productspecific rules of origin.\n\n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Unless otherwise specified, reference to weight in a productspecific rule of origin means the net weight, which is the weight of a material or a product not including the weight of packaging as set out in the definitions of \"net weight of nonoriginating material\" and \"net weight of the product\" in Article 1 (Definitions) of this Protocol.\n\n\n\n\n\n7.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A reference to nonoriginating sugar in a productspecific rule of origin means the nonoriginating material referred to in Article 16 (Sugar) of this Protocol. \n\n\n\n8.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If a productspecific rule of origin requires:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a change from any other chapter, heading, or subheading, or a change to product x\n2\n from any other chapter, heading, or subheading, only nonoriginating material classified in a chapter, heading, or subheading other than that of the product may be used in the production of the product;\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a change from within a heading or subheading, or from within any one of these headings or subheadings, nonoriginating material classified within the heading or subheading may be used in the production of the product, as well as nonoriginating material classified in a chapter, heading, or subheading other than that of the product;\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a change from any heading or subheading outside a group, only nonoriginating material classified outside the group of headings or subheadings may be used in the production of the product;\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0that a product is wholly obtained, the product must be wholly obtained within the meaning of Article 4 (Wholly Obtained Products). If a shipment consists of a number of identical products classified under tariff provision x, each product shall be considered separately;\n\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0production in which all the material of tariff provision x used is wholly obtained, all of the material of tariff provision x used in production of the product must be wholly obtained within the meaning of Article 4 (Wholly Obtained Products); \n\n\n\n\n(f)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a change from tariff provision x, whether or not there is also a change from any other chapter, heading or subheading, the value of any nonoriginating material that satisfies the change in tariff classification specified in the phrase commencing with the words \"whether or not\" is not considered when calculating the value of nonoriginating materials. If two or more productspecific rules of origin are applicable to a heading, subheading, or group of headings or subheadings, the change in tariff classification specified in this phrase reflects the change specified in the first rule of origin; \n\n\n\n(g)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0that the value of nonoriginating materials of tariff provision x does not exceed x\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the transaction value or exworks price of the product, only the value of the nonoriginating material specified in this rule of origin is considered when calculating the value of nonoriginating materials. The percentage for the maximum value of nonoriginating materials as set out in this rule of origin may not be exceeded through the use of Article 6 (Tolerance);\u00a0\n\n\n\n(h)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0that the value of nonoriginating materials classified in the same tariff provision as the final product does not exceed x\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the transaction value or exworks price of the product,\u00a0nonoriginating material classified in a tariff provision other than that of the product may be used in the production of the product. Only the value of the nonoriginating materials classified in the same tariff provision as the final product is considered when calculating the value of nonoriginating materials. The percentage for the maximum value of nonoriginating materials as set out in this rule of origin may not be exceeded through the use of Article 6 (Tolerance);\n\n\n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0that the value of all nonoriginating materials does not exceed x\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the transaction value or exworks price of the product, the value of all nonoriginating materials is considered when calculating the value of nonoriginating materials. The percentage for the maximum value of nonoriginating materials as set out in this rule of origin may not be exceeded through the use of Article 6 (Tolerance); and \n\n\n\n\n(j)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0that the net weight of nonoriginating material of tariff provision x used in production does not exceed x\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the net weight of the product, the specified nonoriginating materials may be used in the production of the product, provided that it does not exceed the specified percentage of the net weight of the product in accordance with the definition of \"net weight of the product\" in Article 1. The percentage for the maximum weight of nonoriginating material as set out in this rule of origin may not be exceeded through the use of Article 6 (Tolerance). \n\n\n\n9.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The productspecific rule of origin represents the minimum amount of production required on nonoriginating material for the resulting product to achieve originating status. A greater amount of production than that required by the productspecific rule of origin for that product also confers originating status.\n\n\n\n10.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If a productspecific rule of origin provides that a specified nonoriginating material may not be used, or that the value or weight of a specified nonoriginating material cannot exceed a specific threshold, these conditions do not apply to nonoriginating material classified elsewhere in the Harmonized System.\n\n\n\n11.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0In accordance with Article 5 (Sufficient Production), when a material obtains originating status in the territory of a Party and this material is further used in the production of a product for which origin is being determined, no account will be taken of any nonoriginating material used in the production of that material. This applies whether or not the material has acquired originating status inside the same factory where the product is produced.\n\n\n\n12.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The productspecific rules of origin set out in this Annex also apply to used products.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nHarmonized System classification\n\n\n\n\nProduct specific rule for sufficient production pursuant to Article 5\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSection I\n\n\n\n\nLive Animals; Animal Products\n\n\n\n\n\n\nChapter 1\n\n\n\n\nLive animals \n\n\n\n\n\n\n01.0101.06\n\n\n\n\nAll animals of Chapter 1 are wholly obtained.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nChapter 2\n\n\n\n\nMeat and edible meat offal\n\n\n\n\n\n\n02.0102.10\n\n\n\n\nProduction in which all the material of Chapter 1 or 2 used is wholly obtained.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nChapter 3\n\n\n\n\nFish and crustaceans, molluscs and other aquatic invertebrates\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nNote: \n\n\nAquaculture products of Chapter 3 will only be considered as originating in a Party if they are raised in the territory of that Party from nonoriginating or originating seedstock such as eggs, fry, fingerlings or larvae.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n03.0103.08\n\n\n\n\nProduction in which all the material of Chapter 3 used is wholly obtained.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nChapter 4\n\n\n\n\nDairy produce; birds' eggs; natural honey; edible products of animal origin, not elsewhere specified or included\n\n\n\n\n\n\n04.01\n\n\n\n\nA used is wholly obtained.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n0402.10\n\n\n\n\nA change from any other chapter, except from dairy preparations of subheading 1901.90 containing more than 10\u00a0per\u00a0cent by dry weight of milk solids, provided that:\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0all the material of Chapter 4 used is wholly obtained, and \n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the net weight of nonoriginating sugar used in production does not exceed 40\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the net weight of the product.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n0402.210402.99\n\n\n\n\nA change from any other chapter, except from dairy preparations of subheading 1901.90 containing more than 10\u00a0per\u00a0cent by dry weight of milk solids, provided that: \n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0all the material of Chapter 4 used is wholly obtained, and \n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the net weight of nonoriginating sugar used in production does not exceed 20\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the net weight of the product.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n04.0304.06\n\n\n\n\nA change from any other chapter, except from dairy preparations of subheading 1901.90 containing more than 10\u00a0per\u00a0cent by dry weight of milk solids, provided that: \n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0all the material of Chapter 4 used is wholly obtained, and\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the net weight of nonoriginating sugar used in production does not exceed 20\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the net weight of the product.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n04.0704.10\n\n\n\n\nProduction in which: \n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0all the material of Chapter 4 used is wholly obtained; and\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the net weight of nonoriginating sugar used in production does not exceed 20\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the net weight of the product.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nChapter 5\n\n\n\n\nProducts of animal origin, not elsewhere specified or weight of nonoriginating sugar used in production does not exceed\u00a020\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the net weight of the product.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n1904.90\n\n\n\n\nA change from any other heading, provided that: \n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the net weight of nonoriginating material of heading 10.06 or 11.01 through 11.08 used in production does not exceed 20\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the net weight of the product, \n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the net weight of nonoriginating sugar used in production does not exceed\u00a030\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the net weight of the product, \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the net weight of nonoriginating material of Chapter 4 used in production does not exceed 20\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the net weight of the product, and \n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the net weight of nonoriginating sugar and nonoriginating material of Chapter 4 used in production does not exceed 40\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the net weight of the product.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n19.05\n\n\n\n\nA change from any other heading, provided that: \n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the net weight of nonoriginating material of heading 10.06 or 11.01 through 11.08 used in production does not exceed 20\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the net weight of the product, \n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the net weight of nonoriginating sugar used in production does not exceed 40\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the net weight of the product, \n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the net weight of nonoriginating material of Chapter 4 used in production does not exceed 20\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the net weight of the product, and\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the net weight of nonoriginating sugar and nonoriginating material of Chapter 4 used in production does not exceed 50\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the net weight of the product.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nChapter 20\n\n\n\n\nPreparations of vegetables, fruit, nuts or other parts of plants\n\n\n\n\n\n\n20.01\n\n\n\n\nA change from any other heading. 24\n\n\n\n\nTobacco and manufactured tobacco substitutes\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nNote: \n\n\nAgricultural and horticultural products grown in the territory of a Party shall be treated as originating in the territory of that Party even if grown from seed, bulbs, rootstock, cuttings, slips, grafts, shoots, buds or other live parts of plants imported from a third country.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n24.01\n\n\n\n\nProduction in which all the material of heading 24.01 used is wholly obtained.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2402.10\n\n\n\n\nA change from any other heading, provided that the net weight of nonoriginating material of Chapter 24 used in production does not exceed 30\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the net weight of all the material of Chapter 24 used in the production of the product.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2402.20\n\n\n\n\nA change from any other heading, except from subheading 2403.10, provided that the net weight of the material of heading 24.01 that is wholly obtained is at least 10\u00a0per\u00a0cent by net weight of all the material of Chapter 24 used in the production of the product.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2402.90\n\n\n\n\nA change from any other heading, provided that the net weight of nonoriginating material of Chapter 24 used in production does not exceed 30\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the net weight of all the material of Chapter 24 used in the production of the product. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n24.03\n\n\n\n\nA change from any other heading, provided that the net weight of nonoriginating material of Chapter 24 used in production does not exceed 30\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the net weight of all the material of Chapter 24 used in the production of the product.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSection V\n\n\n\n\nMineral Products\n\n\n\n\n\n\nChapter 25\n\n\n\n\nSalt; sulphur; earths and stone; change from within this heading or any other heading, except from biodiesel of subheading 3824.90 or heading 38.26.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n27.1127.16\n\n\n\n\nA change from within any one of these headings or any other heading.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSection VI\n\n\n\n\nProducts of the Chemical or Allied Industries\n\n\n\n\n\n\nChapter 28\n\n\n\n\nInorganic chemicals; organic or inorganic compounds of precious metals, of rareearth metals, of radioactive elements or of isotopes\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nNote 1: \n\n\nA product of this Chapter is an originating product if it is the result of any one of the following:\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0an applicable change in tariff classification specified in the rules of origin of this Chapter;\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a chemical reaction as described in Note 2 below; or\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0purification as described in Note 3 below.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nNote 2: Chemical reaction and change of Chemical Abstract Service number\n\n\nA product of this Chapter shall be treated as an originating product if it is the result of a chemical reaction and that chemical reaction results in a change of Chemical Abstract Service (CAS) number. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nFor the purposes of this Chapter, a \"chemical reaction\" is a process (including a biochemical process) that results in a molecule with a new structure by breaking intramolecular bonds and by forming new intramolecular bonds or by altering the spatial arrangement of atoms in a molecule.\n\n\nThe following are not considered to be chemical reactions for the purposes of determining whether a product is originating:\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0dissolution in water or in another solvent;\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the elimination of solvents, including solvent water; or\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the addition or elimination of water of crystallization.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nNote 3: Purification\n\n\nA product of this Chapter that is subject to purification shall be treated as an originating product provided that the purification occurs in the territory of one or both of the Parties and results in the elimination of not less than 80\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the impurities.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nNote 4: Separation prohibition\n\n\nA product that meets the applicable change in tariff classification in the territory of one or both of the Parties as a result of the separation of one or more materials from a manmade mixture shall not be treated as an originating product unless the isolated material underwent a chemical reaction in the territory of one or both of the Parties.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2801.102853.00\n\n\n\n\nA change from any other subheading; or\n\n\nA change from within any one of these subheadings, whether or not there is also a change from any other subheading, provided that the value of nonoriginating materials classified in the same subheading as the final product does not exceed 20\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the transaction value or exworks price of the product.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nChapter 29 \n\n\n\n\nOrganic Chemicals\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nNote 1:\u00a0\n\n\nA product of this Chapter is an originating product if it is the result of any one of the following:\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0an applicable change in tariff classification specified in the rules of origin of this Chapter;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a chemical reaction as described in Note 2 below; or\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0purification as described in Note 3 below.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nNote 2: Chemical reaction and change of Chemical Abstract Service number\u00a0\n\n\nA product of this Chapter shall be treated as an originating product if it is the result of a chemical reaction and that chemical reaction results in a change of Chemical Abstract Service (CAS) number.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nFor the purposes of this Chapter, a \"chemical reaction\" is a process (including a biochemical process) that results in a molecule with a new structure by breaking intramolecular bonds and by forming new intramolecular bonds or by altering the spatial arrangement of atoms in a molecule.\n\n\nThe following are not considered to be chemical reactions for the purposes of determining whether a product is originating:\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0dissolution in water or in another solvent;\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the elimination of solvents, including solvent water; or\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the addition or elimination of water of crystallization.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nNote 3: Purification\n\n\nA product of this Chapter that is subject to purification shall be treated as an originating product provided that the purification occurs in the territory of one or both of the Parties and results in the elimination of not less than 80\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the impurities.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nNote 4: Separation prohibition\n\n\nA product that meets the applicable change in tariff classification in the territory of one or both of the Parties as a result of the separation of one or more materials from a manmade mixture shall not be treated as an originating product unless the isolated material underwent a chemical reaction in the territory or one or both of the Parties.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2901.102942.00\n\n\n\n\nA change from any other subheading; or\n\n\nA change from within any one of these subheadings, whether or not there is also a change from any other subheading, provided that the value of nonoriginating materials classified in the same subheading as the final product does not exceed 20\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the transaction value or exworks price of the product.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nChapter 30\n\n\n\n\nPharmaceutical products\n\n\n\n\n\n\n3001.203005.90\n\n\n\n\nA change from within any one of these subheadings or heading.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n________________\n\n\nANNEX 5A\n\n\n\nORIGIN QUOTAS AND ALTERNATIVES TO \nTHE PRODUCTSPECIFIC RULES OF ORIGIN IN ANNEX 5\n\n\n\n\n\nCommon Provisions\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Annex 5A applies to the products identified in the following Sections:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Section A: Agricultural Products\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Section B: Fish and Seafood\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Section C: Textiles and Apparel\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Section D: Vehicles\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the products listed in the tables within each Section, the corresponding rules of origin are alternatives to those set out in Annex 5 \u2013 ProductSpecific Rules of Origin, within the limits of the applicable annual quota.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The importing Party shall manage the origin quotas on a firstcome firstserved basis and shall calculate the quantity of products entered under these origin quotas on the basis of that Party's imports.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0All exports under the origin quotas must make reference to Annex 5A. The Parties shall not count any products against the annual origin quota without such reference.\n\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Canada shall notify the European Union if any Canadianissued documentation requirements are established for:\n\n\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0products exported from Canada under the applicable origin quota; or \n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0products imported into Canada under the applicable origin quota.\n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If the European Union receives notification pursuant to paragraph 5(a), the European Union shall allow for only those products accompanied by such documentation to claim the preferential tariff treatment based on the alternative rule of origin specified in Annex 5A.\n\n\n\n7.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties shall administer the origin quotas on a calendar year basis with the full inquota quantity to be made available on January 1st of each year. For the administration of these origin quotas in Year 1, the Parties shall calculate the quota volumes of these origin quotas by discounting the volume corresponding to the period running between the 1st of January and the date of entry into force of this Agreement.\n\n\n\n8.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0With respect to the European Union, any quantities referred to in this Annex shall be managed by the European Commission, which shall take all administrative actions it deems advisable for their efficient management in respect of the applicable legislation of the European Union.\n\n\n\n9.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties shall consult as needed to ensure that Annex 5A is administered effectively and shall cooperate in the administration of Annex 5A. The Parties shall consult to discuss possible modifications to Annex 5A. \n\n\n\n10.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Additional provisions, such as review or growth of the origin quotas, are provided separately for each Section.\n\n\n\n\nSection A \u2013 Agriculture\n\n\n\nTable A.1 \u2013 Annual Quota Allocation for HighSugar Containing\n8\n Products Exported from Canada to the European Union\n9\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nHarmonized System classification\n\n\n\n\nProduct description\n\n\n\n\nSufficient production\n\n\n\n\nAnnual quota for exports from Canada into the European Union (metric tonnes, net weight)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nex 1302.20\n\n\n\n\nPectic substances, pectinates and pectates, containing added sugar of subheading 1701.91 through 1701.99\n\n\n\n\nA change from within this subheading or any other subheading, except from subheading 1701.91 through 1701.99. \n\n\n\n\n30,000\n\n\n\n\n\n\nex 1806.10\n\n\n\n\nCocoa powder, containing added sugar of subheading 1701.91 through 1701.99\n\n\n\n\nA change from any other subheading, except from subheading 1701.91 through 1701.99.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nex 1806.20\n\n\n\n\nPreparations containing added sugar of subheading 1701.91 through 1701.99 for the preparation of chocolate beverages\n\n\n\n\nA change from within this subheading or any other subheading, except from subheading 1701.91 through 1701.99.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nex 2101.12\n\n\n\n\nPreparations with a basis of extracts, essences or concentrates of coffee or with a basis of coffee containing added sugar of subheading 1701.91 through 1701.99\n\n\n\n\nA change from any other subheading, except from subheading 1701.91 through 1701.99.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nex 2101.20\n\n\n\n\nPreparations with a basis of extracts, essences or concentrates of tea or mat\u00e9, or with a basis of tea or mat\u00e9 containing added sugar of subheading 1701.91 through 1701.99\n\n\n\n\nA change from within this subheading or any other subheading, except from subheading 1701.91 through 1701.99.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nex 2106.90\n\n\n\n\nFood preparations containing added sugar of subheading 1701.91 through 1701.99\n\n\n\n\nA change from within this subheading or any other subheading, except from subheading 1701.91 through 1701.99.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReview and Growth Provisions Related to Table A.1\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties shall review the origin quota level in Table A.1 at the end of every five year period for the first three consecutive five year periods following the entry into force of this Agreement. \n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0At the end of each five year period for the first three consecutive five year periods following the entry into force of this Agreement, the origin quota volume in Table A.1 will be increased by 20\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the volume set in the previous period, provided that:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in any one year during the first five year period the fillrate is at least 60\u00a0per\u00a0cent; \n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in any one year during the second five year period the fillrate is at least 70\u00a0per\u00a0cent; and\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in any one year during the third five year period the fillrate is at least 80\u00a0per\u00a0cent.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Any increase in the origin quota volume will be implemented in the first quarter of the subsequent calendar year.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This review will be conducted by the Committee on Agriculture. At the end of the review, if applicable, the Parties shall notify each other in writing of an increase in the origin quota under paragraph 2 and the date on which the increase applies under paragraph 3. The Parties shall ensure that an increase in the origin quota and the date it becomes applicable are publicly available. \n\n\n\n\nTable A.2 \u2013 Annual Quota Allocation for Sugar Confectionery and Chocolate Preparations Exported from Canada to the European Union\n\n\n\n\n\n\nHarmonized System classification\n\n\n\n\nProduct description\n\n\n\n\nSufficient production\n\n\n\n\nAnnual quota for exports from Canada into the European Union (metric tonnes, net weight)\n\n\n\n\n\n\n17.04\n\n\n\n\nSugar confectionery (including white chocolate), not containing cocoa \n\n\n\n\nA change from any other heading.\n\n\n\n\n10,000\n\n\n\n\n\n\n1806.31\n\n\n\n\nChocolate and other food preparations containing cocoa, in blocks, slabs or bars, filled, weighing no more than 2 kilograms\n\n\n\n\nA change from any other subheading, provided that the change is the result of more than packaging.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n1806.32\n\n\n\n\nChocolate and other food preparations containing cocoa, in blocks, slabs or bars, not filled, weighing no more than 2 kilograms \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n1806.90\n\n\n\n\nChocolate and other food preparations containing cocoa other than those of subheading 1806.10 through 1806.32\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReview and Growth Provisions Related to Table A.2\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties shall review the origin quota in Table A.2 at the end of every five year period following the entry into force of this Agreement, provided that in any one year during the previous 5 year period, the origin quota fillrate is at least 60\u00a0per\u00a0cent. \n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The review will be conducted with a view to increasing the volume based on the examination of all relevant factors, in particular the fill rate, growth in Canadian exports to the world, growth in total European Union imports, and any other significant trends in trade of the products to which the origin quota applies. \n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The rate of increase in the origin quota will be established for the subsequent period of five years, and will not be greater than 10\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the volume set in the previous period. \n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This review will be conducted by the Committee on Agriculture. Any recommendation of the Committee on Agriculture to increase the origin quota volume shall be submitted to the CETA Joint Committee for a decision in accordance with Article 30.2.2.\n\n\n\n\n\nTable A.3 \u2013 Annual Quota Allocation for Processed Foods Exported from Canada to the European Union\n\n\n\n\n\n\nHarmonized System classification\n\n\n\n\nProduct description\n\n\n\n\nSufficient production\n\n\n\n\nAnnual quota for exports from Canada into the European Union (metric tonnes net weight)\n\n\n\n\n\n\n19.01\n\n\n\n\nMalt extract; or \n\n\nA change from within this heading, whether or not there is also a change from any other heading, provided that the weight of the nonoriginating materials of this heading does not exceed 30\u00a0per\u00a0cent of either the net weight of the product or the net weight of all material used in production.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n1904.20\n\n\n\n\nPrepared foods obtained from unroasted cereal flakes or from mixtures of unroasted cereal flakes and roasted cereal flakes or swelled cereals\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n1904.90\n\n\n\n\nPrepared foods other than those of subheading 1904.10 through 1904.30\n\n\n\n\nA change from any other heading. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n19.05\n\n\n\n\nBread, pastry, cakes, biscuits and other bakers' wares, whether or not containing cocoa; communion wafers, empty cachets of a kind suitable for pharmaceutical use, sealing wafers, rice paper and similar products\n\n\n\n\nA change from any other heading.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2009.81\n\n\n\n\nCranberry juice\n\n\n\n\nA change from any other heading.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nex 2009.89\n\n\n\n\nBlueberry juice\n\n\n\n\nA change from any other heading.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2103.90\n\n\n\n\nOther sauces and preparations therefor, other mixed condiments and mixed seasonings\n\n\n\n\nA change from any other heading. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nex 2106.10\n\n\n\n\nProtein concentrates and textured protein substances, not containing added sugar of subheading 1701.91 through 1701.99 or containing less than 65\u00a0per\u00a0cent by net weight of added sugar of subheading 1701.91 through 1701.99 \n\n\n\n\nA change from any other subheading; or \n\n\nA change from within the same subheading, whether or not there is also a change from any other subheading, provided that the net weight of nonoriginating material from within that subheading does not exceed 30\u00a0per\u00a0cent of either the net weight of the product or the net weight of all material used in production. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nex 2106.90\n\n\n\n\nOther food preparations not elsewhere specified or included, not containing added sugar of subheading 1701.91 through 1701.99 or containing less than 65\u00a0per\u00a0cent by net weight of added sugar of subheading 1701.91 through 1701.99\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReview and Growth Provisions Related to Table A.3\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties shall review the origin quota in Table A.3 at the end of every five year period following the entry into force of this Agreement, provided that in any one year during the previous five year period, the origin quota fillrate is at least 60\u00a0per\u00a0cent. \n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The review will be conducted with a view to increasing the volume based on the examination of all relevant factors, in particular the fillrate, growth in Canadian exports to the world, growth in total European Union imports, and any other significant trends in trade of the products to which the origin quota applies. \n\n\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The rate of increase in the origin quota will be established for the subsequent period of five years, and will not be greater than 10\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the volume set in the previous period. \n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This review will be conducted by the Committee on Agriculture. Any recommendation of the Committee on Agriculture to increase the origin quota volume shall be submitted to the CETA Joint Committee for a decision in accordance with Article 30.2.2.\n\n\n\n\nTable A.4 \u2013 Annual Quota Allocation for Dog and Cat Food Exported from Canada to the European Union\n\n\n\n\n\n\nHarmonized System classification\n\n\n\n\nProduct description\n\n\n\n\nSufficient production\n\n\n\n\nAnnual quota for exports from Canada into the European Union (metric tonnes, net weight)\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2309.10\n\n\n\n\nDog or cat food, put up for retail sale\n\n\n\n\nA change from subheading 2309.90 or any other heading, except from dog or cat food of subheading 2309.90.\n\n\n\n\n60,000\n\n\n\n\n\n\nex 2309.90\n\n\n\n\nDog or cat food, not put up for retail sale\n\n\n\n\nA change from within this subheading or any other heading, except from dog or cat food from within this subheading.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReview and Growth Provisions Related to Table A.4\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Parties shall review the origin quota in Table A.4 at the end of every five year period following the entry into force of this Agreement, provided that in any one year during the previous five year period, the origin quota fillrate is at least 60\u00a0per\u00a0cent. \n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The review will be conducted with a view to increasing the volume based on the examination of all relevant factors, in particular the fillrate, growth in Canadian exports to the world, growth in total European Union imports, and any other significant trends in trade of the products to which the origin quota applies. \n\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The rate of increase in the origin quota will be established for the subsequent period of five years, and will not be greater than 10\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the volume set in the previous period. \n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This review will be conducted by the Committee on Agriculture. Any recommendation of the Committee on Agriculture to increase the origin quota volume shall be submitted to the CETA Joint Committee for a decision in accordance with Article 30.2.2.\n\n\n\nSection B \u2013 Fish and Seafood\n\n\n\n\n\nTable B.1 \u2013 Annual Quota Allocation for Fish and Seafood Exported from Canada to the European Union\n\n\n\n\n\n\nHarmonized System classification\n\n\n\n\nProduct description\n\n\n\n\nAnnual quota for exports from Canada into the European Union (metric tonnes, net weight)\n\n\n\n\nSufficient production\n\n\n\n\n\n\nex 0304.83\n\n\n\n\nFrozen fillets of halibut, other than Reinhardtius hippoglossoides\n\n\n\n\n10\n\n\n\n\nA change from any other heading.\n10\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nex 0306.12\n\n\n\n\nCooked and frozen lobster \n\n\n\n\n2,000\n\n\n\n\nA change from any other subheading. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n1604.11\n\n\n\n\nPrepared or preserved salmon\n\n\n\n\n3,000\n\n\n\n\nA change from any other chapter.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n1604.12\n\n\n\n\nPrepared or preserved herring \n\n\n\n\n50\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nex 1604.13\n\n\n\n\nPrepared or preserved sardines, sardinella and brisling or sprats, excluding Sardina pilchardus\n\n\n\n\n200\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nex 1605.10\n\n\n\n\nPrepared or preserved crab, other than Cancer pagurus\n\n\n\n\n44\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n1605.211605.29\n\n\n\n\nPrepared or preserved shrimps and prawns\n\n\n\n\n5,000\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n1605.30\n\n\n\n\nPrepared and preserved lobster \n\n\n\n\n240\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nGrowth Provisions Related to Table B.1\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For each of the products listed in Table B.1, if more than 80\u00a0per\u00a0cent of an origin quota assigned to a product is used during a calendar year, the origin quota allocation will be increased for the following calendar year. The increase will be 10\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the origin quota assigned to the product in the previous calendar year. The growth provision will apply for the first time after the expiry of the first complete calendar year following the entry into force of this Agreement and will be applied for four consecutive years in total. \n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Any increase in the origin quota volume will be implemented in the first quarter of the subsequent calendar year. The importing Party shall notify the Party of export in writing if the condition in paragraph 1 is met, and if so, the increase in the origin quota and the date on which the increase is applicable. The Parties shall ensure that the increased origin quota and the date on which it becomes applicable are publicly available.\n\n\n\nReview Provision Related to Table B.1\n\n\n\nAfter the completion of the third calendar year following the entry into force of this Agreement, at the request of a Party, the Parties will engage in a discussion on possible revisions to this Section.\n\n\n\n\nSection C
