the Community code relating to veterinary medicinal products;\n\n\n\nDirective 2001/20/EC of European Parliament and of the Council of 4 April 2001 on the approximation of the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States relating to the implementation of good clinical practice in the conduct of clinical trials on medicinal products for human use;\n\n\n\nRegulation (EU) 536/2014 of 16 April 2014\u00a0on clinical trials on medicinal products for human use, and repealing Directive 2001/20/EC;\n\n\n\nCommission Directive 2003/94/EC of 8 October 2003 laying down the principles and guidelines of good manufacturing practice in respect of medicinal products for human use and investigational medicinal products for human use;\n\n\n\nCommission Directive 91/412/EEC of 23 July 1991 laying down the principles and guidelines of good manufacturing practice for veterinary medicinal products;\n\n\n\n\nCommission delegated Regulation (EU) 1252/2014 of 28 May 2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council with regard to principles and guidelines of good manufacturing practice for active substances for medicinal products for human use;\n\n\n\nCurrent version of the Guide to good manufacturing practices contained in volume IV of Rules governing medicinal products in the European Union and compilation of the community procedures on inspections and exchange of information;\n\n\n\n\n\nFor Canada:\n\n\n\nFood and Drugs Act, R.S.C., 1985, c. F-27.\n\n\n\n\n_________________\n\n\n\n\n\nTop  \n\n\n\n\n\n\nEUROPEAN COMMISSION\nStrasbourg, 5.7.2016\nCOM(2016) 444 final\nANNEX\n\nto the \nProposal for a Council Decision\non the signing on behalf of the European Union of the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement between Canada of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nANNEX I\n\n\n\nHeadnote\n\n\n\nReservations for existing measures and liberalisation commitments\n\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Schedule of a Party to this Annex sets out, under Articles 8.15 (Reservations and exceptions), 9.7 (Reservations), 14.4 (Reservations), and, for the European Union, Article 13.10 (Reservations and exceptions), the reservations taken by that Party with respect to existing measures that do not conform with obligations imposed by:\n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Articles 8.6 (National treatment), 9.3 (National treatment) or, for the European Union, Article 13.3 (National treatment);\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Articles 8.7 (Most-favoured-nation treatment), 9.5 (Most-favoured-nation treatment) or, for the European Union, Article 13.4 (Most-favoured-nation treatment);\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Articles 8.4 (Market access), 9.6 (Market access) or, for the European Union, Article 13.6 (Market access);\n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Article 8.5 (Performance requirements); \n\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Article 8.8 (Senior management and boards of directors) or, for the European Union, Article 13.8 (Senior management and boards of directors); \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(f)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the European Union, Article 13.7 (Cross-border supply of financial services); or \n\n\n\n(g)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Article 14.3 (Obligations);\n\n\n\nand, in certain cases, sets out commitments for immediate or future liberalisation.\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The reservations of a Party are without prejudice to the rights and obligations of the Parties under the GATS.\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Each reservation sets out the following elements: \n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Sector refers to the general\u00a0sector in which the reservation is taken; \n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Sub-Sector refers to the specific sector in which the reservation is taken; \n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Industry Classification refers, where applicable, to the activity covered by the reservation according to the CPC, ISIC rev 3.1, or as expressly otherwise described in a Party's reservation; \n\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Type of Reservation specifies the obligation referred to in paragraph 1 for which a reservation is taken; \n\n\n\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Level of Government indicates the level of government maintaining the measure for which a reservation is taken;\n\n\n\n(f)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Measures identifies the laws or other measures, as qualified, where indicated, by the Description element, for which the reservation is taken. A measure cited in the Measures element: \n\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0means the measure as amended, continued or renewed as of the date of entry into force of this Agreement; \n\n\n\n\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0includes any subordinate measure adopted or maintained under the authority of and consistent with the measure; and \n\n\n\n(iii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0includes:\n\n\n\n(A)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0for a European Union Directive, any laws or other measures which implement the Directive at Member State level; and\n\n\n\n(B)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0for Canada, any laws or other measures at the national or sub-national level that implement agreements between the federal government and the provinces and territories; and\n\n\n\n(g)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Description sets out the non-conforming aspects of the existing measure for which the reservation is taken. It may also set out commitments for liberalisation.\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0In the interpretation of a reservation, all elements of the reservation shall be considered. A reservation shall be interpreted in the light of the relevant obligations of the Chapters, against which the reservation is taken. To the extent that: \n\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the Measures element is qualified by a liberalisation commitment from the Description element, the Measures element as so qualified shall prevail over all other elements; and \n\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the Measures element is not so qualified, the Measures element shall prevail over other elements, unless a discrepancy between the Measures element and the other elements considered in their totality is so substantial and material that it would be unreasonable to conclude that the Measures element prevails, in which case the other elements shall prevail to the extent of that discrepancy.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Where a Party maintains a measure that requires that a service supplier be a natural person, citizen, permanent\u00a0resident or resident of its territory as a condition to the supply of a service in its territory, a reservation for that measure taken with respect to cross-border trade in services shall operate as a reservation with respect to investment, to the extent of that measure. \n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A reservation for a measure that requires a service supplier be a natural person, citizen, permanent resident, or resident of its territory as a condition to the supply of a financial service in its territory taken with respect to Article 13.7 (Cross-border supply of financial services) shall operate as a reservation with respect to Articles 13.3 (National treatment), 13.4 (Most-favoured-nation treatment), 13.6 (Market access), and 13.8 (Senior management and boards of \u200edirectors), to\u00a0the\u00a0extent\u00a0of\u00a0that\u00a0measure.\n\n\n\n7.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purposes of this Annex, including each Party's Schedule to this Annex: \n\n\n\n\nISIC rev 3.1 means the International Standard Industrial Classification of all Economic Activities as set out in Statistical Office of the United Nations, Statistical Papers, Series M, N\u00b0 4, ISIC rev 3.1, 2002.\n\n\n\n8.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The following abbreviations are used in the European Union's Schedule to this Annex:\n\n\n\nAT\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Austria\n\n\n\nBE\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Belgium\n\n\n\nBG\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Bulgaria\n\n\n\n\n\nCY\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Cyprus\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nCZ\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Czech Republic\n\n\n\nDE\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Germany\n\n\n\nDK\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Denmark\n\n\n\nEU\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0European Union\n\n\n\nES\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Spain\n\n\n\nEE\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Estonia\n\n\n\nFI\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Finland\n\n\n\nFR\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0France\n\n\n\nEL\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Greece\n\n\n\n\n\nHR\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Croatia\n\n\n\nHU\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Hungary\n\n\n\nIE\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Ireland\n\n\n\nIT\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Italy\n\n\n\nLV\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Latvia\n\n\n\nLT\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Lithuania\n\n\n\nLU\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Luxembourg\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMT\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Malta\n\n\n\nNL\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Netherlands\n\n\n\n\n\nPL\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Poland\n\n\n\nPT\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Portugal\n\n\n\nRO\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Romania\n\n\n\nSK\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Slovakia\n\n\n\nSI\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Slovenia\n\n\n\nSE\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Sweden\n\n\n\nUK\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0United Kingdom\n\n\n\nSchedule of Canada - Federal\n\n\nReservations applicable in Canada\n\n\n(applicable in all Provinces and Territories)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-C-1\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nAll sectors\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector: \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access \n\n\nPerformance requirements \n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\nSenior management and boards of directors\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nNational\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment Canada Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. 28 (1st Supp.) \n\n\nInvestment Canada Regulations, S.O.R./85-611\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Except as set out in paragraphs 3 and 7, the Director of Investments will review a direct \"acquisition of control\", as defined in the Investment Canada Act, of a Canadian business by an investor of the European Union if the value of the Canadian business is not less than CAD $1.5 billion, adjusted in accordance with the applicable methodology in January of each subsequent year as set out in the Investment Canada Act.\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Notwithstanding the definition of \"investor\" in Article 8.1 (Definitions), only investors who are nationals of the European Union or entities controlled by nationals of the European Union as provided for in the Investment Canada Act may benefit from the higher review threshold.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The higher threshold in paragraph 1 does not apply to a direct acquisition of control by a state-owned enterprise of a Canadian business. Such acquisitions are subject to review by the Director of Investments if the value of the Canadian business is not less than CAD $369 million in 2015, adjusted in accordance with the applicable methodology in January of each subsequent year as set out in the Investment Canada Act. \n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0An investment subject to review under the Investment Canada Act may not be implemented unless the Minister responsible for the Investment Canada Act advises the applicant that the investment is likely to be of net benefit to Canada. This determination is made in accordance with six factors described in the Act, summarised as follows: \n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the effect of the investment on the level and nature of economic activity in Canada, including the effect on employment, on the use of parts, components and services produced in Canada and on exports from Canada; \n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the degree and significance of participation by Canadians in the investment; \n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the effect of the investment on productivity, industrial efficiency, technological development and product innovation in Canada; \n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the effect of the investment on competition within an industry\u00a0in Canada; \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the compatibility of the investment with national industrial, economic and cultural policies, taking into consideration industrial, economic and cultural policy objectives enunciated by the government or legislature of a province likely to be significantly affected by the investment; and \n\n\n(f)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the contribution of the investment to Canada's ability to compete in world markets. \n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0In making a net benefit determination, the Minister, through the Director of Investments, may review plans under which the applicant demonstrates the net benefit to Canada of the proposed acquisition. An applicant may also submit undertakings to the Minister in connection with a proposed acquisition that is the subject of review. In the event of noncompliance with an undertaking by an applicant, the Minister may seek a court order directing compliance or any other remedy authorised under the Investment Canada Act. \n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A non-Canadian who establishes or acquires a Canadian business, other than those that are subject to review, as described above, must notify the Director of Investments.\n\n\n7.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The review thresholds set out in paragraphs 1 and 3, do not apply to an acquisition of a cultural business. \n\n\n8.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0In addition, the specific acquisition or establishment of a new business in designated types of business activities relating to Canada's cultural heritage or national identity, which are normally notifiable, may be subject to review if the Governor in Council authorises a review in the public interest. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n9.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0An indirect \"acquisition of control\" of a Canadian business by an investor of the European Union other than a cultural business is not reviewable. \n\n\n10.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Notwithstanding Article 8.5 (Performance requirements), Canada may impose a requirement or enforce a commitment or undertaking in connection with the establishment, acquisition, expansion, conduct, operation, or management of any investment of an investor of the European Union or of a third country for the transfer of technology, production process or other proprietary knowledge to a national or enterprise, affiliated to the transferor, in Canada in connection with the review of an acquisition of an investment under the Investment Canada Act. \n\n\n11.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Except for requirements, commitments or undertakings relating to technology transfer as set out in paragraph 10 of this reservation, Article 8.5 (Performance requirements) applies to requirements, commitments or undertakings imposed or enforced under the Investment Canada Act. \n\n\n12.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purposes of this reservation, a \"non-Canadian\"\u00a0means an individual, government or agency thereof or an entity that is not Canadian; and \"Canadian\" means a Canadian citizen or permanent resident, a government in Canada or agency thereof, or a Canadian-controlled entity as described in the Investment Canada Act. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-C-2\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nAll sectors\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector: \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access \n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\nSenior management and boards of directors\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nNational \n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nAs set out in the Description element\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Canada or a province or territory, when selling or disposing of its equity interests in, or the assets of, an existing government enterprise or an existing governmental entity, may prohibit or impose limitations on the ownership of such interests or assets and on the ability of owners of such interests or assets to control a resulting enterprise by investors of the European Union or of a third country or their investments. With respect to such a sale or other disposition, Canada or a province or territory may adopt or maintain a measure relating to the nationality of senior management or members of the board of directors. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purposes of this reservation: \n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a measure maintained or adopted after the date of entry into force of this Agreement that, at the time of sale or other disposition, prohibits or imposes a limitation on the\u00a0ownership of equity interests or assets or imposes a nationality requirement described in this reservation is an existing measure; and \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0government enterprise means an enterprise owned or controlled through ownership interests by Canada or a province or territory, and includes an enterprise established after the date of entry into force of this Agreement solely for the purposes of selling or disposing of equity interests in, or the assets of, an existing state enterprise or governmental entity. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-C-3\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nAll sectors\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector: \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access \n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nNational\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nCanada Business Corporations Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. C-44 \n\n\nCanada Business Corporations Regulations, 2001, S.O.R./2001-512 \n\n\nCanada Cooperatives Act, S.C. 1998, c. 1\n\n\nCanada Cooperatives Regulations, S.O.R./99-256\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A corporation may place constraints on the issue, transfer and ownership of shares in a federally incorporated corporation. The object of those constraints is to permit a corporation to meet Canadian ownership or control requirements, under certain laws set out in the Canada Business Corporations Regulations, 2001, in sectors where Canadian ownership or control is required as a condition to receive licences, permits, grants, payments or other benefits. In order to maintain certain Canadian ownership levels, a corporation is permitted to sell shareholders' shares without the consent of those shareholders, and to purchase its own shares on the open market. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Canada Cooperatives Act provides that constraints may be placed on the issue or transfer of investment shares of a cooperative to persons not resident in Canada, to permit cooperatives to meet Canadian ownership requirements to obtain a licence to carry on a business, to become a publisher of a Canadian newspaper or periodical or to acquire investment shares of a financial intermediary and in sectors where ownership or control is a required condition to receive licences, permits, grants, payments and other benefits. Where the ownership or control of investment shares would adversely affect the ability of a cooperative to maintain a level of Canadian ownership or control, the Canada Cooperatives Act provides for the limitation of the number of investment shares that may be owned or for the prohibition of the ownership of investment shares. \n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purposes of this reservation Canadian means \"Canadian\" as defined in the Canada Business Corporations Regulations, 2001 or in the Canada Cooperatives Regulations.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-C-4\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nAll sectors\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector: \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment \n\n\nSenior management and boards of directors\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nNational\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nCanada Business Corporations Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. C-44 \n\n\nCanada Business Corporations Regulations, 2001, S.O.R./2001-512\n\n\nCanada Cooperatives Act, S.C. 1998, c. 1\n\n\nCanada Cooperatives Regulations, S.O.R./99-256\n\n\nCanada Corporations Act, R.S.C. 1970, c. C-32\n\n\nSpecial Acts of Parliament incorporating specific companies \n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Canada Business Corporations Act requires, for most federally incorporated corporations, that 25 per cent of directors be resident Canadians and, if such corporations have fewer than four directors, at least one director must be a resident Canadian. As provided in the Canada Business Corporations Regulations, 2001, a simple majority of resident Canadian directors is required for corporations in the following sectors: uranium mining; book publishing or distribution; book sales, if the sale of books is the primary part of the corporation's business; and film or video distribution. Similarly, corporations that, by an Act of Parliament or Regulation, are individually subject to minimum Canadian ownership requirements are required to have a majority of resident Canadian directors. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purposes of the Canada Business Corporations Act, resident Canadian means an individual who is a Canadian citizen ordinarily resident in Canada, a Canadian citizen who is not ordinarily resident in Canada who is a member of a class set out in the Canada Business Corporations Regulations, 2001, or a \"permanent resident\" as defined in the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27,\u00a0other than a permanent resident who has been ordinarily resident in Canada for more than one year after becoming eligible to apply for Canadian citizenship. \n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0In the case of a holding corporation, not more than one-third of the directors need to be resident Canadians if the earnings in Canada of the holding corporation and its subsidiaries are less than five per cent of the gross earnings of the holding corporation and its subsidiaries. \n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Canada Cooperatives Act requires that not less than two-thirds of the directors be members of the cooperative. At least 25 per cent of directors of a cooperative must be resident in Canada; if a cooperative has only three directors, at least one director must be resident in Canada. \n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purposes of the Canada Cooperatives Act, a resident of Canada is defined in the Canada Cooperatives Regulations as an individual who is a Canadian citizen and who is ordinarily resident in Canada; a Canadian citizen who is not ordinarily resident in Canada and who is a member of a class set out in the Canada Cooperatives Regulations, or a \"permanent resident\" as defined in the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, other than a permanent resident who has been ordinarily resident in Canada for more than one year after becoming eligible to apply for Canadian citizenship.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-C-5\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nAll sectors\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector: \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nNational \n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nCitizenship Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. C-29\n\n\nForeign Ownership of Land Regulations, S.O.R./79-416 \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Foreign Ownership of Land Regulations are made pursuant to the Citizenship Act and the Agricultural and Recreational Land Ownership Act, R.S.A. 1980, c. A-9. In Alberta, an ineligible person or foreign owned or controlled corporation may only hold an interest in controlled land consisting of a maximum of two parcels containing, in the aggregate, a maximum of 20 acres. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purposes of this reservation: \n\n\nineligible person means: \n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a natural person who is not a Canadian citizen or permanent resident; \n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a foreign government or foreign government agency; or \n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a corporation incorporated in a country other than Canada; and\n\n\ncontrolled land means land in Alberta, but does not include: \n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0land of the Crown in right of Alberta; \n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0land within a city, town, new town, village or summer village; and \n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0mines or minerals.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-C-6\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nAll sectors\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector: \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nNational\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nAir Canada Public Participation Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. 35 (4th Supp.) \n\n\nCanadian Arsenals Limited Divestiture Authorization Act, S.C. 1986, c. 20 \n\n\nEldorado Nuclear Limited Reorganization and Divestiture Act, S.C. 1988, c. 41 \n\n\nNordion and Theratronics Divestiture Authorization Act, S.C. 1990, c. 4 \n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A \"non-resident\" or \"non-residents\" may not own more than a specified percentage of the voting shares of the corporation to which each Act applies. For some companies the restrictions apply to individual shareholders, while for others the restrictions may apply in the aggregate. If there are limits on the percentage that an individual Canadian investor can own, these limits also apply to non-residents. The restrictions are as follows: \n\n\nAir Canada: 25 per cent in the aggregate; \n\n\nCameco Limited (formerly Eldorado Nuclear Limited): 15 per cent per non-resident natural person, 25 per cent in the aggregate; \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nNordion International Inc.: 25 per cent in the aggregate;\n\n\nTheratronics International Limited: 49 per cent in the aggregate; and \n\n\nCanadian Arsenals Limited: 25 per cent in the aggregate.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purposes of this reservation, non-resident includes: \n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a natural person who is not a Canadian citizen and not ordinarily resident in Canada; \n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a corporation incorporated, formed or otherwise organised outside Canada; \n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the government of a foreign State or a political subdivision of a government of a foreign State, or a person empowered to perform a function or duty on behalf of such a government; \n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a corporation that is controlled directly or indirectly by a person or an entity referred to in subparagraphs (a) through (c); \n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a trust: \n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0established by a person or an entity referred to in subparagraphs (b) through (d), other than a trust for the administration of a pension fund for the benefit of natural persons the majority of whom are resident in Canada; or \n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0in which a person or an entity referred to in subparagraphs (a) through (d) has more than 50 per cent of the beneficial interest; and \n\n\n(f)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a corporation that is controlled directly or indirectly by a trust referred to in subparagraph (e).\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-C-7\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nAll sectors\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector: \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nNational\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nExport and Import Permits Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. E-19\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nCross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\nOnly a natural person ordinarily resident in Canada, an enterprise with its head office in Canada or a branch office in Canada of a foreign enterprise may apply for and be issued an import or export permit or transit authorisation certificate for a good or related service subject to controls under the Export and Import Permits Act.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-C-8\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nSocial services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector: \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\nMost-favoured-nation treatment\n\n\nPerformance requirements \n\n\nSenior management and boards of directors\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nNational \n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and Cross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Canada reserves the right to maintain a measure with respect to the provision of social services not otherwise reserved under Reservation II-C-9 in respect of social services.\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This reservation against most-favoured-nation treatment does not apply to the provision of private education services.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-C-9\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nCommunication services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector: \n\n\n\n\nTelecommunications transport networks and services\n\n\nradiocommunications\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 752\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\nSenior management and boards of directors\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nNational\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nTelecommunications Act, S.C. 1993, c. 38 \n\n\nCanadian Telecommunications Common Carrier Ownership and Control Regulations, S.O.R./94-667 \n\n\nRadiocommunications Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. R-2 \n\n\nRadiocommunication Regulations, S.O.R./96-484 \n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Foreign investment in facilities-based telecommunications service suppliers is restricted to a maximum, cumulative total of 46.7 per cent voting interest, based on 20 per cent direct investment and 33.3 per cent indirect investment.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Facilities-based telecommunications service suppliers must be controlled in fact by Canadians. \n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0At least 80 per cent of the members of the board of directors of facilities-based telecommunications service suppliers must be Canadians.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Notwithstanding the restrictions described above: \n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0foreign investment is allowed up to 100 per cent for suppliers conducting operations under an international submarine cable licence; \n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0mobile satellite systems of a foreign service supplier may be used by a Canadian service supplier to provide services in Canada; \n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0fixed satellite systems of a foreign service supplier may be used to provide services between points in Canada and all points outside Canada;\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0foreign investment is allowed up to 100 per cent for suppliers conducting operations under a satellite authorisation; and\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0foreign investment is allowed up to 100 per cent for facilities-based telecommunications service suppliers that have revenues, including those of its affiliates, from the supply of telecommunications services in Canada representing less than 10 per cent of the total telecommunications services revenues in Canada.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-C-10\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nTransport services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector: \n\n\n\n\nCustoms brokers \n\n\nOther supporting and auxiliary transport services \n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 749\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\nSenior management and boards of directors\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nNational\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nCustoms Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. 1 (2nd Supp.) \n\n\nCustoms Brokers Licensing Regulations, S.O.R./86-1067 \n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and Cross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\nTo be a licenced customs broker in Canada: \n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a natural person must be a Canadian national; \n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a corporation must be incorporated in Canada with a majority of its directors being Canadian nationals; and \n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a partnership must be composed of persons who are Canadian nationals, or corporations incorporated in Canada with a majority of their directors being Canadian nationals.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-C-11\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nDistribution services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector: \n\n\n\n\nDuty free shops\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 631, 632 (limited to duty-free shops)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nNational\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nCustoms Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. 1 (2nd Supp.) \n\n\nDuty Free Shop Regulations, S.O.R./86-1072\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and Cross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0To be a licenced duty free shop operator at a land border crossing in Canada, a natural person must: \n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0be a Canadian national; \n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0be of good character; \n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0be principally resident in Canada; and \n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0have resided in Canada for at least 183 days of the year preceding the year of application for the licence. \n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0To be a licenced duty free shop operator at a land border crossing in Canada, a corporation must: \n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0be incorporated in Canada; and \n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0have all of its shares beneficially owned by Canadian nationals who meet the requirements of paragraph 1. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-C-12\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nBusiness services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector: \n\n\n\n\nExamination services relating to the export and import of cultural property \n\n\nMuseum services except for historical sites and buildings (limited to cultural property examination services)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 96321, 87909 (limited to cultural property examination services)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nNational\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nCultural Property Export and Import Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. C-51\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and Cross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Only a resident of Canada or an institution in Canada may be designated as an expert examiner of cultural property for the purposes of the Cultural Property Export and Import Act. \n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purposes of this reservation: \n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0institution means an entity that is publicly owned and operated solely for the benefit of the public, that is established for educational or cultural purposes and that conserves objects and exhibits them; and\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0resident of Canada means a natural person who is ordinarily resident in Canada, or a corporation that has its head office in Canada or maintains an establishment in Canada to which employees employed in connection with the business of the corporation ordinarily report for work.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-C-13\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nBusiness services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector: \n\n\n\n\nPatent agents \n\n\nPatent agents providing legal advisory and representation services \n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 8921\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nNational\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nPatent Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. P-4 \n\n\nPatent Rules, S.O.R./96-423 \n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nCross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\nTo represent a person in the\u00a0prosecution of a patent application or in other business before the Patent Office, a patent agent must be resident in Canada and registered by the Patent Office.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-C-14\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nBusiness services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector: \n\n\n\n\nTrade-mark agents \n\n\nTrade-mark agents providing legal advisory and representation services in statutory procedures \n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 8922\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nNational\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nTrade-marks Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. T-13 \n\n\nTrade-marks Regulations, S.O.R./96-195 \n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nCross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\nTo represent a person in the prosecution of an application for a trade-mark or in other business before the Trade-marks Office, a trade-mark agent must be resident in Canada and registered by the Trade-marks Office.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-C-15\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nEnergy (oil and gas)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector: \n\n\n\n\nCrude petroleum and natural gas industries \n\n\nServices incidental to mining \n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 120, 883\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nNational\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nCanada Petroleum Resources Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. 36 (2nd\u00a0Supp.) \n\n\nTerritorial Lands Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. T-7 \n\n\nFederal Real Property and Federal Immovables Act, S.C. 1991, c. 50 \n\n\nCanada-Newfoundland Atlantic Accord Implementation Act, S.C. 1987, c. 3 \n\n\nCanada-Nova Scotia Offshore Petroleum Resources Accord Implementation Act, S.C. 1988, c. 28 \n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This reservation applies to production licences issued for \"frontier lands\" and \"offshore areas\" (areas not under provincial jurisdiction) as defined in the applicable measures. \n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A person who holds an oil and gas production licence or shares therein must be a corporation incorporated in Canada. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-C-16\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nEnergy (oil and gas)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector: \n\n\n\n\nCrude petroleum and natural gas industries \n\n\nServices incidental to mining \n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 120, 883\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\nPerformance requirements\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nNational\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nCanada Oil and Gas Production and Conservation Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. O-7, as amended by the Canada Oil and Gas Operations Act, S.C. 1992, c. 35 \n\n\nCanada - Nova Scotia Offshore Petroleum Resources Accord Implementation Act, S.C. 1988, c. 28 \n\n\nCanada - Newfoundland Atlantic Accord Implementation Act, S.C. 1987, c. 3 \n\n\nMeasures implementing the Canada-Yukon Oil and Gas Accord, including the Canada-Yukon Oil and Gas Accord Implementation Act, 1998, c.5, s. 20 and the Oil and Gas Act, RSY 2002, c. 162 \n\n\nMeasures implementing the Northwest Territories Oil and Gas Accord, including implementing measures that apply to or are adopted by Nunavut as the successor territories to the former Northwest Territories\n\n\nMeasures implementing the Canada-Quebec Gulf of St. Lawrence Petroleum Resources Accord\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and Cross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Under the Canada Oil and Gas Operations Act, a \"benefits plan\" must be approved by the Minister in order to be authorised to proceed with an oil and gas development project. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A benefits plan means a plan for the employment of Canadians and for providing Canadian manufacturers, consultants, contractors and service companies with a full and fair opportunity to participate on a competitive basis in the supply of goods and services used in proposed work or activity referred to in the benefits plan. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The benefits plan contemplated by the Canada Oil and Gas Operations Act permits the Minister to impose on the applicant an additional requirement to ensure that disadvantaged individuals or groups have access to training and employment opportunities or can participate in the supply of goods and services used in proposed work referred to in the benefits plan. \n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Provisions continuing those set out in the Canada Oil and Gas Operations Act are included in laws which implement the Canada-Yukon Oil and Gas Accord.\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Provisions continuing those set out in the Canada Oil and Gas Operations Act will be included in laws or regulations to implement accords with various provinces and territories, including implementing legislation by provinces and territories (for example, the Northwest Territories Oil and Gas Accord, the Canada-Quebec Gulf of St. Lawrence Petroleum Resources Accord, and the New Brunswick Oil and Gas Accord).\u00a0For the purposes of this reservation these accords and implementing legislation shall be deemed, once concluded, to be existing measures.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Canada-Nova Scotia Offshore Petroleum Resources Accord Implementation Act and the Canada-Newfoundland Atlantic Accord Implementation Act have the same requirement for a benefits plan but also require that the benefits plan ensures that: \n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the corporation or other body submitting the plan establishes in the applicable province an office where appropriate levels of decision-making are to take place, prior to carrying out work or an activity in the offshore area; \n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0expenditures be made for research and development to be carried out in the province, and for education and training to be provided in the province; and \n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0first consideration be given to goods produced or services provided from within the province, where those goods or services are competitive in terms of fair market price, quality and delivery. \n\n\n7.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Boards administering the benefits plan under these Acts may also require that the plan include provisions to ensure that disadvantaged individuals or groups, or corporations owned or cooperatives operated by them, participate in the supply of goods and services used in proposed work or activity referred to in the plan. \n\n\n8.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0In addition, Canada may impose a requirement or enforce a commitment or undertaking for the transfer of technology, a production process or other proprietary knowledge to a person of Canada in connection with the approval of development projects under the applicable Acts.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-C-17\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nEnergy (oil and gas)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector: \n\n\n\n\nCrude petroleum and natural gas industries \n\n\nServices incidental to mining \n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 120, 883\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nPerformance requirements\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nNational\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nCanada-Newfoundland Atlantic Accord Implementation Act, S.C. 1987, c. 3 \n\n\nHibernia Development Project Act, S.C. 1990, c. 41 \n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Under the Hibernia Development Project Act, Canada and the Hibernia Project Owners may enter into agreements. Those agreements may require the Project Owners to undertake to perform certain work in Canada and Newfoundland and to use their best efforts to achieve specific Canadian and Newfoundland target levels in relation to the provisions of a \"benefits plan\" required under the Canada-Newfoundland Atlantic Accord Implementation Act. \"Benefits plans\" are further described in Canada's Reservation I-C-16. \n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0In addition, Canada may, in connection with the Hibernia Project, impose a requirement or enforce a commitment or undertaking for the transfer of technology, a production process or other proprietary knowledge to a national or enterprise in Canada.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-C-18\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nBusiness services \n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector: \n\n\n\n\nUranium mines \n\n\nServices incidental to mining \n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 883\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\nMost-favoured-nation treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nNational\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment Canada Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. 28 (1st Supp.) \n\n\nInvestment Canada Regulations, S.O.R./85-611 \n\n\nNon-Resident Ownership Policy in the Uranium Mining Sector, 1987 \n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Ownership by \"non-Canadians\", as defined in the Investment Canada Act, of a uranium mining property is limited to 49 per cent at the stage of first production. Exceptions to this limit may be permitted if it can be established that the property is in fact \"Canadian controlled\", as defined in the Investment Canada Act. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Exemptions from the Non-Resident Ownership Policy in the Uranium Mining Sector are permitted, subject to approval of the Governor in Council, only in cases where Canadian participants in the ownership of the property are not available. Investments in properties by non-Canadians, made prior to December 23, 1987 and that are beyond the permitted ownership level, may remain in place. No increase in non-Canadian ownership is permitted. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0In considering a request for an exemption from the Policy from an investor of the European Union, Canada will not require that it be demonstrated that a Canadian partner cannot be found.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-C-19\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nBusiness services \n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector: \n\n\n\n\nAuditing\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 862\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nNational\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nBank Act, S.C. 1991, c. 46 \n\n\nInsurance Companies Act, S.C. 1991, c. 47 \n\n\nCooperative Credit Associations Act, S.C. 1991, c. 48 \n\n\nTrust and Loan Companies Act, S.C. 1991, c. 45 \n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nCross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Banks are required to have a firm of accountants to be auditors of the bank. A firm of accountants must be qualified as set out in the Bank Act. Among the qualifications required is that two or more members of the firm must be ordinarily resident in Canada and that the member of the firm jointly designated by the firm and the bank to conduct the audit must be ordinarily resident in Canada. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0An insurance company, a cooperative credit association, and a trust or loan company require an auditor who can either be a natural person or a firm of accountants. An auditor of such an institution must be qualified as set out in the Insurance Companies Act, the Cooperative Credit Associations Act or the Trust and Loan Companies Act. If a natural person is appointed to be the auditor of such a financial institution, among the qualifications required is that the person must be ordinarily resident in Canada. If a firm of accountants is appointed to be the auditor of such a financial institution, the member of the firm jointly designated by the firm and the financial institution to conduct the audit must be ordinarily resident in Canada.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-C-20\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nTransport\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector: \n\n\n\n\nAir transport services (passenger and freight) \n\n\n\"Specialty air services\" (as set out in the Description element below) \n\n\nCourier services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 73, 7512, \"specialty air services\" (as set out in the \n\n\nDescription element below)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access \n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\nSenior management and board of directors \n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nNational\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nCanada Transportation Act, S.C. 1996, c. 10\n\n\nAeronautics Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. A-2\n\n\nCanadian Aviation Regulations, S.O.R./96-433:\n\n\nPart II, Subpart 2 - \"Aircraft Markings and Registration\";\n\n\nPart IV \"Personnel Licensing and Training\"; and\n\n\nPart VII \"Commercial Air Services\"\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Canada Transportation Act, in section 55, defines \"Canadian\" in the following manner: \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\"... 'Canadian' means a Canadian citizen or a permanent resident within the meaning of subsection 2(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, a government in Canada or an agent of such a government or a corporation or other entity that is incorporated or formed under the laws of Canada or a province, that is controlled in fact by Canadians and of which at least seventy-five per cent, or such lesser percentage as the Governor in Council may by regulation specify, of the voting interests are owned and controlled by Canadians\u2026\"\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Regulations made under the Aeronautics Act incorporate by reference the definition of \"Canadian\" found in the Canada Transportation Act. These Regulations require that a Canadian operator of commercial air services operate Canadian-registered aircraft. These Regulations require an operator to be Canadian in order to obtain a Canadian Air Operator Certificate and to qualify to register aircraft as \"Canadian\".\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Only Canadians may provide the following commercial air transportation services:\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0domestic services (air services between points, or from and to the same point, in the territory of Canada, or between a point in the territory of Canada and a point not in the territory of another country);\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0scheduled international services (scheduled air services between a point in the territory of Canada and a point in the territory of another country) where those services have been reserved to Canadian carriers under existing or future air services agreements;\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0non-scheduled international services (non-scheduled air services between a point in the territory of Canada and a point in the territory of another country) where those services have been reserved to Canadian carriers under the Canada Transportation Act; and \n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0specialty air services include aerial mapping, aerial surveying, aerial photography, forest fire management, fire-fighting, aerial advertising, glider towing, parachute jumping, aerial construction, heli-logging, aerial inspection, aerial surveillance, flight training, aerial sightseeing and aerial crop spraying.\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0No foreign individual is qualified to be the registered owner of a Canadian-registered aircraft.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Further to the Canadian Aviation Regulations, a corporation incorporated in Canada, but that does not meet the Canadian ownership and control requirements, may only register an aircraft for private use where a significant majority of use of the aircraft (at least 60 per cent) is in Canada.\n\n\n7.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Canadian Aviation Regulations also have the effect of limiting foreign-registered private aircraft registered to non-Canadian corporations to be present in Canada for a maximum of 90 days per twelve-month period. The foreign-registered private aircraft shall be limited to private use, as would be the case for Canadian-registered aircraft requiring a private operating certificate.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-C-21\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nTransport\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector: \n\n\n\n\nAircraft repair and maintenance services\n\n\nGround handling services (line maintenance only) as defined in the Chapters on Cross-Border Trade in Services and Investment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\n\"Aircraft repair and maintenance services\" and \"ground handling service\" (line maintenance only), as defined in Articles 8.1 (Definitions) and 9.1 (Definitions)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nNational\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nAeronautics Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. A-2\n\n\nCanadian Aviation Regulations, S.O.R./96-433:\n\n\nPart IV \"Personnel Licensing and Training\";\n\n\nPart V \"Airworthiness\";\n\n\nPart VI \"General Operating and Flight Rules\"; and\n\n\nPart VII \"Commercial Air Services\"\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nCross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\nAircraft and other aeronautical product repair, overhaul or maintenance activities (including line maintenance) required to maintain the airworthiness of Canadian-registered aircraft and other aeronautical products must be performed by persons meeting Canadian aviation regulatory requirements (that is, approved maintenance organisations and aircraft maintenance engineers). Certifications are not provided for persons located outside Canada, except sub-organisations of approved maintenance organisations that are located in Canada.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-C-22\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nTransport\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector: \n\n\n\n\nScheduled and non-scheduled passenger and freight transportation by road, including courier services.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 7121, 7122, 7123, 7512\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nNational\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nMotor Vehicle Transport Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. 29 (3rd Supp.), as amended by S.C. 2001, c. 13.\n\n\nCanada Transportation Act, S.C. 1996, c. 10\n\n\nCustoms Tariff, S.C. 1997, c. 36\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nCross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\nOnly persons of Canada using Canadian-registered and either Canadian-built or duty-paid trucks or buses, may provide truck or bus services between points in the territory of Canada.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-C-23\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nTransport\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector: \n\n\n\n\nWater transport services (passengers and freight) by sea-going and non-sea-going vessels \n\n\nSupporting and other services for water transport\n\n\nConstruction for waterways, harbors, dams and other water works\n\n\nAny other commercial marine activity undertaken from a vessel \n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 721, 722, 745, 5133, 5223, and any other commercial marine activity undertaken from a vessel \n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nNational\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nObligations\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nCanada Shipping Act, 2001, S.C. 2001, c. 26\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment, Cross-Border Trade in Services, and International Maritime Transport Services\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0To register a vessel in Canada, the owner of that vessel or the person who has exclusive possession of that vessel must be:\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a Canadian citizen or a permanent resident within the meaning of subsection 2(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act,\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a corporation incorporated under the law of Canada or a province\u00a0or territory; or \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0when the vessel is not already registered in another country, a corporation incorporated under the laws of a country other than Canada if one of the following is acting with respect to all matters relating to the vessel, namely:\n\n\n(i)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a subsidiary of the corporation that is incorporated under the law of Canada or a province\u00a0or territory;\n\n\n(ii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0an employee or director in Canada of any branch office of the corporation that is carrying on business in Canada; or \n\n\n(iii)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a ship management company incorporated under the law of Canada or a province or territory.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A vessel registered in a foreign country which has been bareboat chartered may be listed in Canada for the duration of the charter while the vessel's registration is suspended in its country of registry, if the charterer is:\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a Canadian citizen or permanent resident, as defined in subsection 2(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act; or\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a corporation incorporated under the law of Canada or a province or territory.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-C-24\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nTransport\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector: \n\n\n\n\nWater transport services (passengers and freight) by sea-going and non-sea-going vessels \n\n\nSupporting and other services for water transport\n\n\nConstruction for waterways, harbors, dams and other water works\n\n\nAny other commercial marine activity undertaken from a vessel\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 721, 722, 745, 5133, 5223, and any other commercial marine activity undertaken from a vessel \n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nNational\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nObligations\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nCanada Shipping Act, 2001, S.C. 2001, c. 26\n\n\nMarine Personnel Regulations, S.O.R./2007-115\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nCross-Border Trade in Services, and International Maritime Transport Services\n\n\nMasters, mates, engineers and certain other seafarers must hold a certificate granted by the Minister of Transport as a requirement of service on Canadian registered vessels. These certificates may be granted only to Canadian citizens or permanent residents.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-C-25\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nTransport\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector: \n\n\n\n\nPilotage and berthing services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 74520\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nNational\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nObligations\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nPilotage Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. P-14\n\n\nGeneral Pilotage Regulations, S.O.R./2000-132\n\n\nAtlantic Pilotage Authority Regulations, C.R.C. c. 1264\n\n\nLaurentian Pilotage Authority Regulations, C.R.C. c. 1268\n\n\nGreat Lakes Pilotage Regulations, C.R.C. c. 1266\n\n\nPacific Pilotage Regulations, C.R.C. c. 1270\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nCross-Border Trade in Services, and International Maritime Transport Services\n\n\nSubject to Canada's Reservation II-C-15, a licence or a pilotage certificate issued by the relevant regional Pilotage Authority is required to provide pilotage services in the compulsory pilotage waters of the territory of Canada. Only a Canadian citizen or permanent resident may obtain a licence or pilotage certificate. A permanent resident of Canada who has been issued a pilot's licence or pilotage certificate must become a Canadian citizen within five years of receipt of that licence or pilotage certificate in order to retain it.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-C-26\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nTransport\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector: \n\n\n\n\nTransportation services by sea-going and non-sea-going vessels \n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 721, 722\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nNational\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMost-favoured-nation treatment\n\n\nObligations\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nCoasting Trade Act, S.C. 1992, c. 31\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nCross-Border Trade in Services, and International Maritime Transport Services\n\n\nThe prohibitions under the Coasting Trade Act, set out in Canada's Reservation II-C-14, do not apply to any vessel that is owned by the Government of the United States of America, when used solely for the purpose of transporting goods owned by the Government of the United States of America from the territory of Canada to supply Distant Early Warning sites.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-C-27\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nTransport\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector: \n\n\n\n\nScheduled or non-scheduled passenger transportation by road \n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 7121, 7122\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nNational\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment \n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nMotor Vehicle Transport Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. 29 (3rd\u00a0Supp.), as amended by S.C. 2001, c. 13\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and Cross-Border Trade in Services \n\n\nProvincial agencies have been delegated authority to permit persons to provide extra-provincial (inter-provincial and cross-border) bus services in their respective provinces and territories on the same basis as local bus services. Most provincial agencies permit the provision of local bus services on the basis of a public convenience and necessity test. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-C-28\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nTransport\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector: \n\n\n\n\nAll transportation sub-sectors\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 7\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nNational\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nCanada Transportation Act, S.C. 1996, c. 10\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\nPursuant to the Canada Transportation Act, any proposed transaction that involves a transportation undertaking that raises issues with respect to the public interest as it relates to national transportation as determined by the Minister requires approval by the Governor in Council.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-C-29\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nTransport\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector: \n\n\n\n\nPostal services, mail transportation by any mode of transport.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 71124, 71235, 7321, 7511\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nNational\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nCanada Post Corporation Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. C-10\n\n\nLetter Definition Regulations, S.O.R./83-481\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and Cross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\nThe sole and exclusive privilege of collecting, transmitting and delivering \"letters\" within Canada, as defined in the Letter Definition Regulations is reserved for the postal monopoly.\n\n\nFor greater certainty, activities relating to the sole and exclusive privilege may also be restricted, including the issuance of postage stamps and the installation, erection or relocation in a public place of a mail receptacle or device to be used for the collection, delivery or storage of mail.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nTop  \n\n\n\n\n\n\nEUROPEAN COMMISSION\nStrasbourg, 5.7.2016\nCOM(2016) 444 final\nANNEX\n\nto the \nProposal for a Council Decision\non the signing on behalf of the European Union of the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement between Canada of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSchedule of Canada \u2013 Provincial and Territorial\n\n\n\nReservations applicable in Alberta\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-1\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nBusiness services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nAccounting\n\n\nAuditing and bookkeeping services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 862\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Alberta\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nRegulated Accounting Profession Act, R.S.A. 2000, c. R12\n\n\nCertified General Accountants Regulation, Alta. Reg.\u00a0176/2001\n\n\nCertified Management\u00a0Accountants Regulation, Alta.\u00a0Reg.\u00a0177/2001\n\n\nChartered Accountants Regulation, Alta. Reg. 178/2001\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nCrossBorder Trade in Services\n\n\nAn applicant for registration as a regulated member must provide proof of Canadian citizenship or proof of having been lawfully admitted to and entitled to work in Canada. Each office in Alberta of a registrant engaged in a public accounting practice shall be under the personal charge and management of a member who shall normally be accessible to meet the needs of clients during such times as the office is open to the public.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-2\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nBusiness services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nVeterinary services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 932\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial  Alberta\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nVeterinary Profession Act, R.S.A. 2000, c. V2\n\n\nGeneral Regulation, Alta. Reg. 44/86\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nCrossBorder Trade in Services\n\n\nOnly Canadian citizens or persons lawfully admitted into and entitled to work in Canada may be approved for registration by the Registration Committee, upon production of satisfactory evidence to this effect.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-3\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nReal estate\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector: \n\n\n\n\nReal estate services involving own or leased property or on a fee or contract basis\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 821, 822, 81331\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Alberta\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nReal Estate Act, R.S.A. 2000, c. R\u20135\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nCross-Border Trade in Services \n\n\nService suppliers are authorised through a brokerage which must maintain a registered business office in the Province. The registered business office must be: the location from which the person conducts business; under the control of the service supplier; and the location of the records required to be maintained by the Act.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-4\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nBusiness services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nLand surveying\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 8675\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Alberta\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nLand Surveyors Act, R.S.A. 2000, c. L3\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\nFor services that are provided through a corporation, commercial presence must take the form of a surveyor's corporation.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-5\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nAlcoholic beverages\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nCommission agents' services\n\n\nWholesale trade services\n\n\nRetailing services (liquor, wine and beer, liquor wine and beer stores)\n\n\nManufacture of alcoholic beverages\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 24 (other than 244), 62112, 62226, 63107, 643, 88411 \n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\nPerformance requirements\n\n\nSenior management and boards of directors \n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Alberta\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nGaming and Liquor Act,\u00a0R.S.A. 2000, c. G1\n\n\nGaming and Liquor Regulation, Alta. Reg. 143/96\n\n\nAlberta Gaming and Liquor Commission Board Policies\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and CrossBorder Trade in Services\n\n\nThe above measures permit Alberta to control the manufacture, import, sale, purchase, possession, storage, transportation, use and consumption of liquor, including through permits and licences that may include citizenship, residency and other limitations on the establishment, operation and provision of these activities.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-6\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nAgriculture\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nLand\n\n\nServices incidental to agriculture\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 8811 (other than rental of agricultural equipment with operator), 531\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Alberta\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial Parks Act, R.S.A. 2000, c. P35\n\n\nProvincial Parks (Dispositions) Regulations, Alta. Reg.\u00a0241/77\n\n\nProvincial Parks (General) Regulation, Alta. Reg. 102/85\n\n\nDispositions and Fees Regulation, Alta. Reg. 54/2000\n\n\nSpecial Areas Disposition Regulation, Alta. Reg. 137/2001\n\n\nDeclaration Regulation,\u00a0Alta. Reg. 195/2001\n\n\nForest Reserves Regulation, Alta. Reg. 42/2005\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\nDispositions of Crown land, including within provincial parks\u00a0are limited to residents of Alberta who are Canadian citizens or permanent residents within the meaning of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-7\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nHunting\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nServices incidental to hunting\n\n\nOwnaccount hunting guides\n\n\nOther cultural services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 0297, 8813, 96419, 9633\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Alberta\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nWildlife Act, R.S.A. 2000, c. W10\n\n\nWildlife Regulation, Alta. Reg. 143/97\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and Cross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\nCitizenship or permanent residency requirements may be imposed as a condition for designations, permits or licences relating to guiding and outfitting for wildlife hunting. Citizenship or permanent residency requirements may also be imposed as a condition for permits or licences for zookeeping, taxidermy, tanning, fur dealing or fur management.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-8\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nTransport\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nRoad transport services\n\n\nPassenger transportation\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 7121, 7122\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Alberta\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nMotor Transport Act, R.S.A. 2000, c. M21\n\n\nMotor Vehicle Administration Act, R.S.A. 2000, M23\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and Cross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\nA public convenience and needs test may be imposed prior to approving a licence to provide interurban bus transport and nonscheduled/scheduled services, including applying some or all of the following criteria: adequacy of current levels of service; market conditions establishing the requirement for expanded service; effect of new entrants on public convenience, including the continuity and quality of service, and the fitness, willingness and ability of the applicant to provide proper service.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-9\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nAll sectors\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\nPerformance requirements\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Alberta\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nIndustrial benefits policy\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and CrossBorder Trade in Services\n\n\nPerformance requirements may be imposed on applicants (such as a first consideration being given to service suppliers from within Alberta or Canada, if competitive in terms of price and quality) in the case of all large scale projects requiring Industrial Development, Forest Management, Oil Sands, Power Plant or Gas Plant and Coal Development Permits.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-10\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nAll sectors\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\nSenior management and boards of directors\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Alberta\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nBusiness Corporations Act, R.S.A. 2000, c. B9\n\n\nBusiness Corporations Regulation, Alta. Reg. 118/2000\n\n\nCompanies Act, R.S.A. 2000, c. C21\n\n\nCooperatives Act, S.A. 2001, c. C28.1\n\n\nPartnership Amendment Act, R.S.A. 2000 (Supp.), c. P25\n\n\nSocieties Act, R.S.A. 2000, c. S14\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0At least 25 per cent of the directors of an Alberta corporation must be resident Canadians.\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the purposes of these measures, \"resident Canadian\" means an individual who is:\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a Canadian citizen ordinarily resident in Canada;\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a Canadian citizen, not ordinarily resident in Canada, who is a member of a prescribed class of persons; or\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a permanent resident within the meaning of the\u00a0Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C.\u00a02001, c.\u00a027 and ordinarily resident in Canada.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-11\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nAll sectors\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Alberta\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nLand Titles Act, R.S.A. 2000, c. L4\n\n\nAgricultural and Recreational Land Ownership Act, R.S.A. 2000, c.\u00a0A9\n\n\nRegulations Respecting the Ownership of Agricultural and Recreational Land in Alberta, Alta. Reg. 160/79\n\n\nPublic Lands Act, R.S.A. 2000, c. P40\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\nPublic lands cannot be sold to:\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0person who is not a Canadian citizen or a permanent resident as defined in the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27;\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a corporation that is not a Canadian corporation; or\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a person or corporation acting as a trustee for a person who is not a Canadian citizen or a permanent resident as defined in the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, or for a corporation that is not a Canadian corporation.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-12\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nRecreational, cultural and sporting services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nGambling and betting\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 96492\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\nPerformance requirements\n\n\nSenior management and boards of directors\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Alberta\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nGaming and Liquor Act, R.S.A. 2000, c. G1\n\n\nHorse Racing Alberta Act, RSA 2000, c. H11.3\n\n\nGaming and Liquor Regulation, Alta. Reg. 143/1996\n\n\nAlberta Gaming and Liquor Commission Board Policies\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and CrossBorder Trade in Services\n\n\nThe above measures permit Alberta to regulate and authorise services, suppliers of services, manufacturing, suppliers of materials, operations and repairs relating to lottery schemes, gaming terminals, games of chance, races, bingo and casinos, and similar activities including through permits and licences that may include citizenship, residency and other limitations on the establishment, operation and provision of these activities.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-13\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nBusiness services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nServices incidental to animal husbandry\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 8812\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Alberta\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nStray Animals Act, R.S.A. 2000, c. S20\n\n\nHorse Capture Regulation, Alta. Reg. 59/94\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nCrossBorder Trade in Services\n\n\nOnly a Canadian citizen or a person lawfully admitted into Canada for permanent residence may apply for, obtain or hold a licence to capture, bait, chase, pursue, follow after or on the trail of or stalk horses on public land in Alberta designated for the licenced capture of horses.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservations applicable in British Columbia\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-14\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nForestry\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nForestry and logging products\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 03\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nPerformance requirements\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 British Columbia\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nForest Act, R.S.B.C. 1996, c.\u00a0157\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\nAll timber harvested from provincial land must be either used in the Province or manufactured within the Province into other goods. However, the Province may authorise an exemption to this requirement if the timber is surplus to the requirements of processing facilities in the Province, if it cannot be processed economically near the harvesting area and cannot be transported economically to another facility in the Province, or if an exemption would prevent waste or improve the utilisation of the wood.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-15\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nBusiness services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nLegal services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 8611\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 British Columbia\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nEvidence Act, R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 124\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and CrossBorder Trade in Services\n\n\nA person must be a Canadian citizen or a permanent resident to be appointed as a commissioner for taking affidavits.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-16\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nBusiness services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nAccounting, auditing and bookkeeping\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 862\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 British Columbia\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nAccountants (Certified General) Act, R.S.B.C. 1996. c. 2\n\n\nAccountants (Chartered) Act, R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 3\n\n\nAccountants (Management) Act, R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 4\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\nAccounting offices must be under the management of a resident of British Columbia.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-17\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nAll sectors\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\nSenior management and boards of directors\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 British Columbia\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nCooperative Association Act, S.B.C. 1999, c. 28\n\n\nSociety Act, R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 433\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Under the Cooperative Association Act, the majority of directors of an association incorporated under the Act must be resident Canadians and at least one director must be resident in the Province.\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Under the Society Act, at least one director of a society incorporated under the Act must be resident in the Province.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-18\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nBusiness services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nLawyers and notaries\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 861\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 British Columbia\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nNotaries Act, R.S.B.C.\u00a01996, c. 334\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and Cross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\nOnly Canadian citizens or
