permanent residents of Canada may be certified as a notary public in British Columbia. The Notaries Act puts limitations on the ability of notaries to provide services through a notary corporation. Trust funds must be held by regulated provincial or federal financial institutions.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-19\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nTourism\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nServices incidental to hunting (hunting guides; outfitters; angling guides)\n\n\nServices incidental to fishing\n\n\nTravel agency, tour operator and tourist guides\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 8813, 882, 96419\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 British Columbia\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nWildlife Act, R.S.B.C.\u00a01996, c. 488\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and CrossBorder Trade in Services\n\n\nOnly Canadian citizens or permanent residents of Canada are eligible to be issued guide outfitter and angling guide licences.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-20\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nForestry\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSubSector:\n\n\n\n\nOther professional services\n\n\nForestry and logging products\n\n\nServices incidental to forestry and logging\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 03, 8814\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 British Columbia\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nForesters Act, S.B.C. 2003, c. 19\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and CrossBorder Trade in Services\n\n\nIn order to obtain registration as a professional forester, at least 24\u00a0months of relevant work experience must first be gained in British Columbia. In some cases, professional foresters already registered in other Canadian jurisdictions are exempt from this requirement.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-21\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nForestry\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nServices incidental to manufacturing\n\n\nChristmas tree permits\n\n\nLog salvage permits\n\n\nWoodlot licences\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 03, 8814\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 British Columbia\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nForest Act, R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 157\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Only Canadian citizens, permanent residents, or a corporation controlled by persons who are Canadian citizens or permanent residents of Canada, may be granted a Christmas tree permit.\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Only Canadian citizens or landed immigrants may apply for log salvage permits.\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Only Canadian citizens, permanent residents, or a corporation, other than a society, that is controlled by persons who are Canadian citizens or permanent residents may apply for woodlot licences.\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Proximity of private residence from the proposed woodlot licence, and distance and size of private land to be included in the proposed woodlot are two of the criteria used to award a licence.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-22\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nForestry\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nForestry and logging\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 03\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 British Columbia\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nForest Act, R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 157\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Only the following entities may enter into a community forest agreement:\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A society incorporated under the Society Act, R.S.B.C.\u00a01996, c. 433;\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0An association as defined in the Cooperative Association Act, S.B.C. 1999, c. 28;\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A corporation, if the corporation is established by or under an enactment, or registered as an extraprovincial company under the Business Corporations Act, S.B.C.\u00a02002, c. 57;\n\n\n(d)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A partnership, if the partnership is comprised of municipalities or regional districts, societies, associations, companies or extraprovincial companies, or a combination of the foregoing; or\n\n\n(e)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A municipality or regional district.\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Community forest agreements may be directly awarded.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-23\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nAgriculture\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nProducts of agriculture\n\n\nHorticulture and market gardening\n\n\nServices incidental to agriculture (other than rental of agricultural equipment with operator)\n\n\nServices incidental to animal husbandry\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 01, 8811 (other than rental of agricultural equipment with operator), 8812\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 British Columbia\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nRange Act, S.B.C. 2004, c. 71\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\nAn applicant who can demonstrate local presence shall be given preference in the granting of grazing licences and permits.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-24\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nForestry\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nForestry and logging\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 03\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nPerformance requirements \n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 British Columbia\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nForest Act, R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 157\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\nAn applicant may be required to commit to the establishment of a manufacturing facility to qualify for a forest licence.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-25\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nForestry\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nForestry and logging\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 03\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\nPerformance requirements\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 British Columbia\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nForest Act, R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 157\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\nThe granting of a community salvage licence is limited to specific groups, notably societies and cooperative associations, for purposes such as providing social and economic benefits to British Columbia, contributing to government revenues, providing opportunities for achieving a range of community objectives, including employment and other social, environmental and economic benefits, encouraging cooperation within the community and among stakeholders, providing for the use of qualifying timber, and other factors that the Minister or a person authorised by the Minister specifies in the invitation or advertising.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-26\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nForestry\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nForestry and logging\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 03\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nPerformance requirements \n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 British Columbia\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nForest Act, R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 157\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\nOnly a limited number of restricted forest licences are granted. The granting of such licences may be subject to performance requirements, including the requirement to own or lease processing facilities in the Province.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-27\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nAll sectors\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\nPerformance requirements \n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 British Columbia\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nLand Act, R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 245\n\n\nMinistry of Forest and Range Policy - Grazing Lease Policy dated November 15, 2004\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Land Act restricts Crown grants to Canadian citizens and to permanent residents. Crown land may also be granted in some circumstances to a government corporation, municipality, regional district, hospital board, university, college, board of education, francophone education authority as defined in the School Act, R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 412, other government related body or to the South Coast British Columbia Transportation Authority continued under the South Coast British Columbia Transportation Authority Act, S.B.C.\u00a01998, c. 30, or any of its subsidiaries.\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Only Canadian citizens may hold grazing lease tenures. Performance requirements are imposed on companies as a condition for the granting of grazing lease tenures.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-28\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nFisheries\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nFish and other fishing products\n\n\nServices incidental to fishing\n\n\nLand\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 04, 531, 882\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 British Columbia\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nFisheries Act, R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 149\n\n\nLand Act, R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 245\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\nOnly a citizen or permanent resident of Canada is entitled to a Crown grant for aquaculture operations, unless the person's application for a disposition of Crown land was allowed prior to May\u00a01,\u00a01970.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-29\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nFisheries\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nServices incidental to fishing\n\n\nWholesale trade services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 04, 62112, 62224, 882 \n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\nPerformance requirements\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 British Columbia\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nFisheries Act, R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 149\n\n\nCommercial Fisheries and Mariculture: A Policy for the 1980s\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and CrossBorder Trade in Services\n\n\nResidency, citizenship and performance requirements may be imposed as a condition of licensing to undertake the harvesting of fish, marine plants or wild oysters, or to undertake fish processing, buying or brokering. Offshore processing or processing at sea is limited to fishermen who process their own catches and if the fish species cannot be economically processed in existing shore based facilities.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-30\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nTransport\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nRoad transport services\n\n\nPassenger transportation\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 7121, 7122\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 British Columbia\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nPassenger Transportation Act, S.B.C. 2004, c. 39\n\n\nMotor Vehicle Act, R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 318\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Passenger Transportation Act requires a person to obtain a passenger transportation licence from the Passenger Transportation Board to provide taxi or intercity bus services in British Columbia. The Board may approve an application for a licence if the Board considers that:\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0there is a public need for the service;\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the applicant is \"fit and proper\" and capable of providing the service; and\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the application, if granted, would promote sound economic conditions in the passenger transportation business in British Columbia.\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Passenger Transportation Board has the power to impose terms and conditions on a licence. If the licence is to include an authorisation to operate motor vehicles as intercity buses, the terms and conditions of the licence include routes and minimum route frequencies for that operation. If the licence is to include an authorisation to operate motor vehicles as passenger directed vehicles (such as taxis and limousines), the terms and conditions of the licence include fleet size, rates and geographic operating area.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-31\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nTransport\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nRoad transport services: public transit \n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 7121, 7122\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 British Columbia\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nBritish Columbia Transit Act, R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 38\n\n\nSouth Coast British Columbia Transportation Authority Act, S.B.C.\u00a01998, c. 30\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0British Columbia Transit is a Crown corporation with the exclusive authority to plan, acquire, and construct public passenger transportation systems that support regional growth strategies, official community plans and the economic development of the transit service areas in all areas of British Columbia, except the transportation service region supported by the South Coast British Columbia Transportation Authority.\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The South Coast British Columbia Transportation Authority has exclusive authority to provide a regional transportation system for all municipalities and rural areas located in the Greater Vancouver Regional District that moves people and goods, and supports the regional growth strategy, provincial and regional environmental objectives (including air quality and greenhouse gas emission reduction objectives), and the economic development of the transportation service region.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-32\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nEnergy\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nElectricity\n\n\nServices incidental to energy distribution\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 171, 887\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\nPerformance requirements\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 British Columbia\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nBC Hydro Public Power Legacy and Heritage Contract Act, S.B.C.\u00a02003. c. 86\n\n\nClean Energy Act, S.B.C. 2010, c. 22\n\n\nUtilities Commission Act, R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 473\n\n\nHydro and Power Authority Act, R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 212\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and Cross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0In British Columbia, electric utilities operate as regulated monopoly distributors of electricity within the area they service.\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0British Columbia Hydro and Power Authority (\"BC Hydro\") is a Crown corporation that owns most of the generation, transmission and distribution facilities in British Columbia. BC Hydro receives differential treatment under provincial law and is exempted from British Columbia Utilities Commission review in some instances. BC Hydro is prohibited from disposing of (including by way of sale) any of its heritage assets, unless they are no longer used or useful.\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Subject to direction from the Lieutenant Governor in Council, rates for the sale of electricity within the Province are regulated by the British Columbia Utilities Commission.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-33\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nBusiness services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nFree miner\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 8675\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment \n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 British Columbia\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nMineral Tenure Act, R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 292\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nCrossBorder Trade in Services\n\n\nTo obtain a free miner certificate a person must be a resident of Canada for at least 183 days in each calendar year, or be authorised to work in Canada, or be a Canadian corporation or a partnership consisting of qualified individuals or Canadian corporations.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservations applicable in Manitoba\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-34\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nCommunity and personal services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nFuneral\n\n\nCremation and undertaking services \n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 9703\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment \n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Manitoba\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nThe Prearranged Funeral Services Act, C.C.S.M. c. F200\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nCrossBorder Trade in Services\n\n\nAnyone supplying prearranged funeral plans, on a forprofit basis, must have a licence. Only a person who regularly carries on the business of supplying funeral services and maintains an establishment in Manitoba for this purpose may apply for such a licence. Prearranged funeral plans can only be offered through the establishment associated with the licence.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-35\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nService of membership organizations\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nLegal documentation and certification \n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 8613, 95910\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment \n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Manitoba\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nThe Marriage Act, C.C.S.M. c. M50\n\n\nPolicy Respecting Residency or Citizenship of Appointees\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nCross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\nUnder The Marriage Act, the Minister responsible may appoint a person as a marriage commissioner for the Province, or any part thereof specified by the Minister, and that person may solemnize ceremonies of marriage in accordance with the tenor of the appointment. The Minister may afford preferential treatment to Canadian citizens or permanent residents of Manitoba.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-36\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nEducation\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nOther education services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 9290\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment \n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Manitoba\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nThe Manitoba Registered Music Teachers' Association\n\n\nIncorporation Act, R.S.M. 1990, c. 100 \n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nCross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\nNo person may be admitted as a member of the Manitoba Registered Music Teachers' Association and thus use the title \"Registered Music Teacher\", unless that person can demonstrate six months' prior residence in Manitoba.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-37\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nAll sectors\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Manitoba\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nThe Community Development Bonds Act, C.C.S.M. c. C160\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0All directors of a community development bond corporation must be residents of Manitoba. Incorporators of the corporation must be residents of the municipality in which the corporation's head office is located or of a municipality nearby.\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If the Government of Manitoba has provided a guarantee of the bond, only eligible bondholders may call on the guarantee. Eligible bondholders are those with a connection to Manitoba or Canada when they purchased the bond: for example, individuals resident in Manitoba, a Manitoba corporation established under the Canada Business Corporations Act, R.S.C., 1985, c. C44, a corporation with a head office in Manitoba, a trust if the majority of trustees or beneficiaries are residents in Manitoba, or a Manitoba municipality.\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The proceeds raised from the issue of community development bonds must be invested in \"eligible businesses\". These are corporations or cooperatives:\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0incorporated under The Corporations Act, C.C.S.M., c. C225 or the Canada Business Corporations Act or The Cooperatives Act, C.C.S.M., c. C223, as the case may be;\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0that carry on or are about to carry on business, on a forprofit basis, in Manitoba; and\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0the Manitoba assets of which are (or will be, when the entity commences business) be controlled by persons resident in Manitoba (among other tests not involving a Manitoba presence or control or ownership by Manitoba residents).\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-38\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nAgriculture\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nAgricultural land\n\n\nForest and other wooded land\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 531\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment \n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Manitoba\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nThe Farm Lands Ownership Act, C.C.S.M. c. F35\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\nOnly individuals who are citizens of Canada or permanent residents of Canada within the meaning of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27 (\"eligible individuals\"), corporations, trusts, partnerships or other business entities entirely owned by active or retired farmers or eligible individuals, or a combination of these, governments (municipal and provincial) or government agencies, or qualified immigrants who are entitled and intend to become eligible individuals within two years after acquiring the farm land, may own more than 40\u00a0acres of Manitoba farmland.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-39\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nAll sectors\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\nPerformance requirements\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Manitoba\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nThe Laboursponsored Venture Capital Corporations Act,\n\n\nC.C.S.M. c. L12\n\n\nThe Corporations Act, C.C.S.M. c. C225\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Laboursponsored Venture Capital Corporations are required to invest in active businesses (with assets valued at less than CAD $50 million) of which at least 50 per cent of the fulltime employees are employees employed in Manitoba, or if at least 50 per cent of employees' wages and salaries are attributable to services rendered in Manitoba by the employees.\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The corporations must be registered under the Act, and only corporations that have been incorporated under The\u00a0Corporations Act may apply to be registered. This means that at least 25 per cent of the corporation's directors must be residents of Canada (or at least one, where there are three or fewer directors), pursuant to The Corporations Act.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-40\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nAll sectors\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment \n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Manitoba\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nThe Cooperatives Act, C.C.S.M. c. C223\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\nA majority of directors of a cooperative must be resident in Canada. For a directors' meeting of a cooperative to be properly constituted, a majority of the directors at the meeting must be residents in Canada. A director who is a resident of Canada but not present at the meeting can approve the business transacted at a meeting, if the requisite majority would have been present had that director been present. The managing director of a cooperative must be resident in Canada. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-41\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nAgriculture\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nAgricultural land\n\n\nForest and other wooded land\n\n\nCrown land leases and permits\n\n\nServices incidental to agriculture\n\n\nServices incidental to animal husbandry\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 531, 8811 (other than rental of agricultural equipment with operator), 8812\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Manitoba\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nThe Crown Lands Act, C.C.S.M. c. C340\n\n\nAgricultural Crown Land Leases Regulation, 168/2001\n\n\nAgricultural Crown Land Grazing and Hay Permits Regulation, 288/88\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0To be eligible to obtain a forage lease of agricultural Crown lands, the tenant must be a Canadian citizen or have landed Canadian immigrant status, and a resident of Manitoba. If the tenant is a partnership or forage cooperative, every partner or member, as the case may be, must be a Canadian citizen or have landed Canadian immigrant status and must be a resident of Manitoba. If the tenant is a corporation, every shareholder must be a Canadian citizen or have landed Canadian immigrant status, and be a resident of Manitoba, and the corporation must be registered to carry on business in Manitoba.\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A grazing permit or hay permit on agricultural Crown lands may only be granted to a person who is ordinarily resident in or near where the land described in the permit is situated.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-42\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nAgriculture\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nAgricultural land\n\n\nForest and other wooded land\n\n\nRecreational and other open land\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 531, 533\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment \n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Manitoba\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nThe Crown Lands Act, C.C.S.M. c. C340\n\n\nPolicy respecting allocation, sale and lease of cottage lots and development of commercial establishments in provincial parks and on other Crown land\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\nThe Minister may afford preferential treatment to Manitoba residents over nonresidents in the allocation, sale and lease of cottage lots and development of commercial establishments in provincial parks and on other Crown land.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-43\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nFisheries\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nServices incidental to fishing\n\n\nWholesale trade services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 04, 62224, 882\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\nPerformance requirements \n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Manitoba\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nThe Fisheries Act, C.C.S.M. c. F-90\n\n\nFishing Licensing Regulation, Man. Reg. 124/97\n\n\nPolicy respecting the allocation of commercial fishing licences\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and CrossBorder Trade in Services\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Unless otherwise authorised by regulation or by the Freshwater Fish Marketing Corporation (the \"Corporation\"), or in certain limited circumstances, no person is permitted to sell or purchase fish caught in Manitoba for delivery in Manitoba except through the Corporation.\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Minister has full discretion to issue commercial fishing licences and to place conditions on the licences. The current Policy specifies that commercial fishing licences are to be allocated, reallocated and renewed according to the value of the benefits generated, in order of priority, to:\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0local;\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0regional; and\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0provincial economies.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-44\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nBusiness services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nLand surveyors \n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 8675\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment \n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Manitoba\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nThe Land Surveyors Act, C.C.S.M. c. L60\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and Cross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A \"Manitoba land surveyor\" must be a natural person. Manitoba land surveyors are not permitted to provide land surveying services through a corporation. Commercial presence of a Manitoba land surveyor must take the form of a sole proprietorship or partnership.\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A surveyor who practiced land surveying in Manitoba and subsequently became the citizen or subject of a foreign country must be renaturalised in accordance with the provisions of the Citizenship Act\u00a0R.S.C., 1985, c. C29 prior to resuming practice in Manitoba.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-45\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nBusiness services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nLegal advisory and representation services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 8612\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment \n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Manitoba\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nThe Legal Profession Act, C.C.S.M. c. L-107\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nCross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\nThe provision of legal services to the public in Manitoba, concerning Manitoba laws, by interjurisdictional law firms is permissible only if, among other things, the firm maintains an office in Manitoba and in at least one other Canadian or foreign jurisdiction, and if at least one member of the firm is entitled to, and does, practice law principally in Manitoba.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-46\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nWholesale trade\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nPharmaceutical and medical goods\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 62251\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment \n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Manitoba\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nThe Hearing Aid Act, C.C.S.M. c. H-38\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and Cross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\nThe Hearing Aid Board has the authority to certify hearing aid dealers and to prescribe preferential access to, and preferential conditions on, applicants for certification resident in Manitoba or Canada.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-47\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nTransport\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nPassenger transit systems\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 71213, 71223\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access \n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Manitoba\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nThe Highway Traffic Act, C.C.S.M. c. H-60 \n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and Cross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\nThe Manitoba Transport Board may limit the number of certificates granted to public passenger motor carriers on public roads in Manitoba. The Board may limit new public passenger motor carriers from entering the public service vehicle market or require motor carriers to take on less profitable routes if it considers public availability of the service to be essential.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-48\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nBusiness services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nAccounting, auditing and bookkeeping services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 862\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Manitoba\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nThe Chartered Accountants Act; C.C.S.M. c. C70\n\n\nThe Certified General Accountants Act, C.C.S.M. c. C46\n\n\nThe Certified Management Accountants Act, C.C.S.M. c. C46.1\n\n\nThe Corporations Act, C.C.S.M. c. C225\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\nThe first three Acts cited above indicate that an accounting, auditing, and bookkeeping corporation cannot be issued a corporate permit to offer services in Manitoba, unless incorporated under The\u00a0Corporations Act. This means that at least 25\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the corporation's directors must be residents of Canada (or at least one, if there are three or fewer directors).\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-49\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nBusiness services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nAuditing services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 8621\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Manitoba\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nThe Chartered Accountants Act, C.C.S.M. c. C70\n\n\nThe Certified General Accountants Act, C.C.S.M. c. C46\n\n\nThe Certified Management Accountants Act, C.C.S.M. c. C46.1\n\n\nThe Addictions Foundation Act, C.C.S.M. c. A60\n\n\nThe Convention Centre Act, S.M. 198889 c. 39 amended\n\n\nThe Crown Corporations Public Review and Accountability Act, C.C.S.M. c. P250 amended\n\n\nThe Trustee Act, C.C.S.M. c. T160 amended\n\n\nThe City of Winnipeg Charter, S.M. 2002, c. 39 amended\n\n\nThe Concordia Hospital Incorporation Act, R.S.M. 1990, c. 39\n\n\nThe Hudson Bay Mining Employees' Health Association Incorporation Act, R.S.M. 1990, c. 68\n\n\nThe Investors Syndicate Limited Incorporation Act, R.S.M. 1990, c.\u00a077\n\n\nThe Mount Carmel Clinic Act, R.S.M. 1990, c. 120\n\n\nL'\u0152uvre des bourses du Coll\u00e8ge de SaintBoniface Incorporation Act, R.S.M. 1990, c. 132\n\n\nThe Seven Oaks General Hospital Incorporation Act, R.S.M. 1990, c.\u00a0180\n\n\nThe United Health Services Corporation Incorporation Act, R.S.M.\u00a01990, c. 201\n\n\nThe Winnipeg Art Gallery Incorporation Act, R.S.M. 1990, c. 216\n\n\nThe Winnipeg Clinic Incorporation Act, R.S.M. 1990, c. 220\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and Cross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\nThe above listed Acts require that auditing services be performed by a person who is authorised to practice as an accountant under either The Chartered Accountants Act, The Certified General Accountants Act or The Certified Management Accountants Act.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-50\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nAll sectors\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Manitoba\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nThe Corporations Act, C.C.S.M. c. C-225\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\nAt least 25 per cent of a corporation's directors must be residents of Canada (or at least one, if there are three or fewer directors). Directors must not transact business at a meeting of directors unless at least 25 per cent of the directors present are residents of Canada (or if there are only three directors, at least one of the directors present is a resident of Canada). If the directors delegate any of their powers to a managing director or to a committee, the managing director or a majority of the members of the committee, as the case may be, must be a resident or residents of Canada.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-51\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nHunting\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector: \n\n\n\n\nServices incidental to hunting\n\n\nHunting, fishing and trapping industries\n\n\nTourist guide agencies\n\n\nOwn-account hunting\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 7472, 8813, 96419\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Manitoba\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nThe Wildlife Act, C.C.S.M. c. R119.5\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and Cross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\nPursuant to the above Acts and Regulations the Minister, and the Administrator appointed by the Minister, has the discretion to issue permits or licences required under the Acts to a person, subject to such terms and conditions as the Minister or Administrator considers advisable, and to make regulations ancillary to the foregoing. The Regulations may prescribe preferential access to permits and licences, and preferential conditions on such permits and licences, for residents of Manitoba or Canada.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-52\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nAgriculture\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nProducts of agriculture\n\n\nServices incidental to agriculture\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 01, 8811 (other than rental of agricultural equipment with operator)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Manitoba\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nThe Wild Rice Act, C.C.S.M. c. W140\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and CrossBorder Trade in Services\n\n\nOnly persons who have been resident in Manitoba for at least one year are entitled to apply for a licence, permit, load slip or export certificate under this Act.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-53\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nForestry\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nForestry and logging products\n\n\nServices incidental to manufacturing\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 0311, 0312, 8843\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\nPerformance requirements\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Manitoba\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nThe Forest Act, C.C.S.M. c.\u00a0F150\n\n\nForest Use and Management Regulation, Man. Reg. 227/88R\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and Cross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\nPursuant to the above Act and Regulation, the Minister is responsible for regulating all forestry matters in accordance with the Act and Regulation, and has the discretion to make grants or issue permits or licences required under the Act to a person, subject to such terms and conditions as the Minister considers advisable. Timber cutting rights must be granted in a way that the Minister believes secures the maximum benefit for Manitoba's forestry industry. Manitoba residents or Canadian citizens may be given preference if such grants are made or permits or licences are issued.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-54\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nTransport\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nPassenger road transport (taxicabs)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 71221\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Manitoba\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nThe Taxicab Act, C.C.S.M. c. T10\n\n\nThe Highway Traffic Act, C.C.S.M. c. H60\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and CrossBorder Trade in Services\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Taxicab Act requires all persons seeking to operate a taxi or carry on a taxi business to apply for and obtain a taxicab business licence from the Taxicab Board. The Board has the power to impose terms and conditions on a taxicab business licence it issues. In deciding whether or not to grant a licence, the Board must apply tests of public convenience and necessity in respect of the number of taxicabs required in The\u00a0City of Winnipeg.\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Highway Traffic Act\u00a0requires all persons seeking to operate a taxi across municipal boundaries to apply for and obtain a certificate from the Motor Transport Board. The Board has the power to impose terms and conditions on a certificate it issues. In deciding whether or not to grant a certificate, the Board must consider if the existing facilities for transportation are insufficient or that the public convenience will be promoted by the establishment or continuance from year to year of the proposed transportation service.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-55\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nAgriculture\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nProducts of agriculture\n\n\nLive animals and animal products\n\n\nMeats and dairy products\n\n\nOther food products n.e.c.\n\n\nServices incidental to agriculture\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 01, 02, 21, 22, 239, 8811 (other than rental of agricultural equipment with operator)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment \n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Manitoba\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nThe Farm Products Marketing Act, C.C.S.M. c. F47\n\n\nDairy Farmers of Manitoba Marketing Plan Regulation, Man.\u00a0Reg.\u00a089/2004\n\n\nManitoba Egg and Pullet Producers Marketing Plan Regulation, Man. Reg. 70/2005\n\n\nManitoba Chicken Broiler Producers Marketing Plan Regulation, Man. Reg. 246/2004\n\n\nManitoba Turkey Producers Marketing Plan Regulation, Man.\u00a0Reg.\u00a038/2004\n\n\nManitoba Vegetable Producers Marketing Plan Regulation, Man.\u00a0Reg. 117/2009\n\n\nThe Milk Prices Review Act, C.C.S.M. c. M130\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and CrossBorder Trade in Services\n\n\nThe boards and commissions under the above measures may afford preferences to permanent residents of Manitoba or Canadian citizens.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-56\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nEnergy\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nElectrical power\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 17, 887\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Manitoba\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nThe Manitoba Hydro Act, C.C.S.M. c. H190\n\n\nThe Public Utilities Board Act, C.C.S.M. c. P280\n\n\nThe Water Power Act, C.C.S.M. c. W60\n\n\nThe Environment Act, C.C.S.M. c. E125\n\n\nThe Crown Corporations Public Review and Accountability Act, C.C.S.M. c. C336\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and CrossBorder Trade in Services\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The above measures, among other things, permit the Government of Manitoba or Manitoba Hydro to:\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0regulate, and issue various licences, authorisations or approvals relating to the generation, transmission, distribution, importation, exportation and supply and sale of electricity, if generated from renewable energy sources or from other goods, forces or sources from which it is possible to generate electricity;\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0regulate the development, construction or maintenance of power plants, generating stations, substations, transmission lines, transmission towers and other facilities or structures or equipment required in connection with any of the activities set out in paragraph (a); and\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0transfer or grant real property or interests in real property in Manitoba, or transfer personal property or interests in personal property, in connection with any of the activities set out in paragraphs (a) or (b).\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, these measures may involve discrimination in favour of Manitoba residents or entities formed in accordance with the laws of Canada (and having a place of business in Manitoba).\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-57\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nAlcoholic beverages\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nCommission agents' services\n\n\nWholesale trade services\n\n\nRetailing services (liquor, wine and beer, liquor wine and beer stores)\n\n\nManufacture of alcoholic beverages \n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 24 (other than 244), 62112, 62226, 63107\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment \n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Manitoba\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nThe Liquor and Gaming Control Act, C.C.S.M. c. L160\n\n\nThe Corporations Act, C.C.S.M. c. C225\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and Cross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\nThe Liquor and Gaming Control Authority of Manitoba has the discretion to grant licences to sell alcoholic beverages. If the applicant is an individual, the licence may only be issued to an adult natural person who is a Canadian citizen or has permanent residence status and resides in Canada. If the applicant is a partnership, all of its members must meet this requirement. If the applicant is a corporation, it must be incorporated or authorised to carry on its business in Manitoba under Manitoba law. If the applicant is incorporated under Manitoba law, 25 per cent of the corporation's directors must be residents of Canada (or at least one, if there are three or fewer directors).\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-58\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nRecreational, cultural and sporting services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nGambling and betting \n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 96492\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment \n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Manitoba\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nThe Liquor and Gaming Control Act, C.C.S.M. c. G5\n\n\nThe Manitoba Liquor and Lotteries Corporation Act, C.C.S.M. c.\u00a0L210\n\n\nThe Manitoba Horse Racing Commission Act, C.C.S.M. c. H90\n\n\nRules of Thoroughbred Racing and Commission Directives, 2011\n\n\nRules of Standardbred Racing and Commission Directives, 2010\n\n\nCommission Quarterhorse Directives, 2011\n\n\nPariMutuel Betting Supervision Regulations, SOR 91365\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and Cross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\nGaming Activities by Charitable and Religious Organisations, Fairs and Exhibitions and Concession and Amusement Operators\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Charitable and religious organisations, fairs and exhibitions and concession and amusement operators may not carry on gaming activities in Manitoba unless they are licenced to do so by the Liquor and Gaming Control Authority of Manitoba or by another body authorised by Manitoba. The Liquor and Gaming Control Authority has discretion to issue these licences subject to such terms and conditions as it considers advisable, and may afford preferential treatment to applicants with a presence in Manitoba.\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0No one may become an employee of The Manitoba Liquor and Lotteries Corporation or of a Manitoba gaming operator, or regularly be in a premises in Manitoba if the gaming activity is taking place for the purpose of providing a gaming service, unless they have been registered for this purpose by the Liquor and Gaming Control Authority. The Liquor and Gaming Control Authority has discretion to register a person, subject to such terms and conditions as it considers advisable, and may afford preferential treatment to Canadian citizens or permanent residents of Manitoba.\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0No proprietor, business entity or association may become a Manitoba gaming operator, a Manitoba video lottery terminal siteholder, a Manitoba lottery ticket retailer or a supplier of gaming supplies or gaming services in Manitoba unless they have been registered for this purpose by the Liquor and Gaming Control Authority. The Liquor and Gaming Control Authority has discretion to register a proprietor, business entity or association, subject to such terms and conditions as it considers advisable, and may afford preferential treatment to Canadian citizens or permanent residents of Manitoba or to business entities or associations with a presence in Manitoba.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nGaming Activities \u2013 Lottery Schemes\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Only the Government of Manitoba is authorised to conduct and manage lottery schemes in Manitoba that fall outside the authority of the Liquor and Gaming Control Authority or other bodies authorised to issue licences to conduct and manage lottery schemes in Manitoba. Manitoba conducts and manages lottery schemes within Manitoba through The Manitoba Liquor and Lotteries Corporation, as agent for Manitoba. Manitoba also conducts and manages lottery schemes in Manitoba and one or more other Canadian jurisdictions in cooperation with the governments of those other jurisdictions through Western Canada Lottery Corporation and Interprovincial Lottery Corporation. The Manitoba Liquor and Lotteries Corporation, Western Canada Lottery Corporation and Interprovincial Lottery Corporation are collectively referred to as the \"Corporations\".\n\n\n5.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Manitoba and the Corporations may afford preferential treatment to Canadian citizens or permanent residents of Manitoba or to business entities with a presence in Manitoba in connection with any of the foregoing activities.\n\n\nHorse Racing and Betting\n\n\n6.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0No one may operate a race track or a parimutuel betting theatre or act as a concessionaire on a race track or in a betting theatre in Manitoba unless they are licenced to do so by the Horse Racing Commission. The Commission has discretion to issue licences to any person or business entity, subject to such terms and conditions as it considers advisable, and may afford preferential treatment to Canadian citizens or permanent residents of Manitoba or business entities with an office in Manitoba.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservations applicable in New Brunswick\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-59\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nForestry\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nAgricultural, forest and other wooded land\n\n\nForestry and logging products\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 03, 531\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nPerformance requirements \n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 New Brunswick\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nCrown Lands and Forest Act, S.N.B. 1980, c. C38.1\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\nSubject to certain exceptions every licence or permit authorising the cutting of Crown timber shall be granted on condition that all timber cut thereunder must be processed in New Brunswick into lumber, pulp or other wood products.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-60\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nMining\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nMining\n\n\nQuarrying and oil well industries\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nPerformance requirements\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 New Brunswick\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nMining Act, S.N.B. 1985, c. M14.1\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\nIf required to do so by the Minister at the time a mining lease is granted or at any time thereafter, a lessee shall process or further process in the Province any minerals mined in the Province under the mining lease.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-61\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nAlcoholic beverages\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nCommission agents' services\n\n\nWholesale trade services\n\n\nRetailing services (liquor, wine and beer, liquor wine and beer stores)\n\n\nManufacture of alcoholic beverages\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 24 (other than 244), 62112, 62226, 63107\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\nPerformance requirements\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 New Brunswick\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nLiquor Control Act, R.S.N.B. 1973, c. L10\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and Cross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The New Brunswick Liquor Commission (\"ANBL\") is a Government of New Brunswick Crown agency that is the sole importer and wholesaler, retailer, and distributor of alcoholic beverages in New Brunswick. The above measures permit New Brunswick to regulate and authorise the importation, purchase, production, distribution, supply, marketing and sale of alcoholic beverages in New Brunswick. The ANBL sets, at its discretion, performance requirements that must be met or exceeded in order for the importation, distribution and retail relationship to continue with any given supplier be they domestic or international.\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The ANBL reserves the right to preferentially promote and market locally produced alcoholic beverage products.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservations applicable in Newfoundland and Labrador\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-62\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nEnergy\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nCrude petroleum and natural gas\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 120, 7112, 71232, 7131, 7422, 8675, 883, 887\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access (CPC 71232 and 7422 only)\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\nPerformance requirements\n\n\nSenior management and boards of directors \n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Newfoundland and Labrador\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nCanadaNewfoundland and Labrador Atlantic Accord Implementation Newfoundland and Labrador Act, R.S.N.L. 1990, c.\u00a0C2\n\n\nCanadaNewfoundland Atlantic Accord \u2013 February 11, 1985\n\n\nEnergy Corporation Act, S.N.L. 2007, c. E11.01\n\n\nPetroleum and Natural Gas Act, RSNL 1990, c. P10\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and Cross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\nThe above measures permit the Government of Newfoundland and Labrador to regulate and issue various authorisations relating to the exploration, production, extraction, development and transportation of hydrocarbons, and the granting of exclusive rights to operate hydrocarbon distribution systems and storage facilities, including, related hydrocarbon pipelines, marine distribution, transshipment facilities and transport services. Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, these measures may involve discretionary decisions based on various factors, limitations on market access, imposition of performance requirements or discrimination in favour of residents of Newfoundland and Labrador or entities established in accordance with the laws of Canada or a province or territory thereof and having a place of business and substantive operations within Newfoundland and Labrador.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-63\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nEnergy\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nElectricity\n\n\nServices incidental to energy distribution\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 171, 887\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\nPerformance requirements\n\n\nSenior management and boards of directors \n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Newfoundland and Labrador\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nElectric Power Control Act, 1994, S.N.L. 1994, c. W401\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and Cross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The above measures, among other things, permit the Government of Newfoundland and Labrador to:\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0regulate and issue various authorisations relating to the production, generation, development, transmission (including system control), distribution, delivery, supply and exportation of electricity, and provide for the construction and maintenance of related facilities;\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0provide for the granting of the lands or waters within the domain of the Province for a good, source or force of energy from which it is possible to produce electricity, including the installation of wind turbines and hydroelectric developments; and\n\n\n(c)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0set and modify rates for electricity.\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, these measures may involve discretionary decisions based on various factors, imposition of performance requirements or discrimination in favour of residents of Newfoundland and Labrador or entities established in accordance with the laws of Canada or a province or territory thereof and having a place of business and substantive operations within Newfoundland and Labrador.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-64\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nForestry\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nWood in the rough\n\n\nProducts of wood, cork, straw and plaiting materials\n\n\nForestry and logging products\n\n\nPulp, paper and paper products\n\n\nManufacture of wood and of products of wood and cork, except furniture \n\n\nManufacture of articles of straw and plaiting materials, on a fee or contract basis\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 031, 31, 321, 88430\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access (CPC 31 only)\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\nPerformance requirements\n\n\nSenior management and boards of directors \n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Newfoundland and Labrador\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nForestry Act, R.S.N.L. 1990, c. These measures provide for the imposition of performance requirements in certain circumstances.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-67\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nAll sectors\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\nSenior management and boards of directors \n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Newfoundland and Labrador\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nCorporations Act, R.S.N.L 1990, c. C36\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0At least 25 per cent of the directors of all corporations incorporated under the Corporations Act must be resident Canadians, except:\n\n\n(a)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a corporate body that was incorporated under The\u00a0Companies Act and was continued under the Corporation Act, and maintains the same proportion of nonresident directors after January\u00a01, 1987 that it had before January\u00a01, 1987; or\n\n\n(b)\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0a corporation that earns no income in Canada.\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Directors of a corporation incorporated under the Corporations Act must not transact a business at a meeting of directors unless at least 25 per cent of directors present are resident Canadians, except if a resident Canadian director who is unable to be present approves, in writing or by telephone or other communications facilities, of the business transacted, and at least 25 per cent of the directors at the meeting would have been resident Canadian had that director been present.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-68\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nBusiness services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nSurface surveying services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 86753\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Newfoundland and Labrador\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nLand Surveyors Act, 1991, S.N.L. 1991, c. W8\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and Cross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Nonresidents of the Province must employ licenced guides while undertaking certain licenced hunting activities within the Province.\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Nonresidents of the Province are not permitted to obtain certain types of licences, and are required to obtain nonresident licences to undertake certain fishing activities within the Province.\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Canadian residency is required in order to obtain registration as a guide.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-71\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nLand\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nRecreational and other open land\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 5330\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment \n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Newfoundland and Labrador\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nLands Act, S.N.L. 1991, c. 36\n\n\nPolicy Directive FT. 004 (Amendment 1), 2001\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\nOnly permanent residents of the Province are eligible to receive residential cottage licences for Crown land.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-72\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nTransport\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nRailroad transportation services \n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 711\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nPerformance requirements\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Newfoundland and Labrador\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nRail Service Act, 2009, S.N.L. 2009, c. R1.2\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\nA person seeking to purchase, operate or construct a rail service within the Province must first obtain Provincial approval. This approval may be granted on terms and conditions the Province considers appropriate. Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, this approval may involve discretionary decisions based on various factors, including the imposition of performance requirements.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-73\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nTransport\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nOther land transportation services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 712\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nPerformance requirements \n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Newfoundland and Labrador\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nAquaculture Act, R.S.N.L. 1990, c. A13\n\n\nFisheries Act, S.N.L. 1995, c. F12.1\n\n\nFish Inspection Act, R.S.N.L. 1990, c. F12\n\n\nLiquor Corporation Act, R.S.N.L. 1990, c. L19\n\n\nLiquor Control Act, R.S.N.L. 1990, c. L18\n\n\nMotor Carrier Act, R.S.N. 1990, c. M19\n\n\nProfessional Fish Harvesters Act, S.N.L. 1996, c. P26.1\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\nPublic convenience and needs tests are applied to passenger transportation and to some subsectors of freight transportation within the Province. The criteria relating to approval include: the adequacy of current levels of service, market conditions establishing the requirement for the expanded service, the effect of new entrants on public convenience, and the fitness, willingness and ability of the applicant to provide proper service. Performance requirements may be imposed.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-74\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nAll sectors\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\nPerformance requirements\n\n\nSenior management and boards of directors\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Newfoundland and Labrador\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nLabour Relations Act, R.S.N.L. 1990, c. L1\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\nThe above measure allows the Lieutenant Governor in Council of Newfoundland and Labrador to issue Special Project Orders. Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, these Orders may involve discretionary decisions based on various factors and limitations on or linkages to investment or market access, imposition of performance requirements or discrimination in favour of residents of Newfoundland and Labrador or entities established in accordance with the laws of Canada or a province or territory thereof and having a place of business and substantive operations within Newfoundland and Labrador.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-75\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nRecreational, cultural, sporting and Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 8844, 885, 96492\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access (CPC 8844 and 885 only)\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\nPerformance requirements\n\n\nSenior management and boards of directors\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Newfoundland and Labrador\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nLotteries Act, S.N.L. 1991, c. 53\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and Cross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The above measure permits the Government of Newfoundland and Labrador to regulate and issue various authorisations relating to services, suppliers of services, manufacturing, suppliers of materials, operations and repairs relating to lotteries, lottery schemes, amusement machines, video lottery machines, games of chance, races, betting theatres, bingo casinos and promotional contests.\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, these measures may involve discretionary decisions based on various factors, limitations on market access, imposition of performance requirements or discrimination in favour of residents of Newfoundland and Labrador or entities established in accordance with the laws of Canada or a province or territory thereof and having a place of business and substantive operations within Newfoundland and Labrador.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-76\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nAlcoholic beverages\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nCommission agents' services\n\n\nWholesale trade services\n\n\nRetailing services (liquor, wine and beer, liquor wine and beer stores)\n\n\nManufacture of alcoholic beverages\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 24 (other than 244), 62112, 62226, 63107, 643 and 88411\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\nPerformance requirements\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Newfoundland and Labrador\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nLiquor Corporation Act, R.S.N.L. 1990, c. L19\n\n\nLiquor Control Act, R.S.N.L. 1990, c. L18\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and Cross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The above measures permit the Government of Newfoundland and Labrador to regulate and issue various authorisations relating to the production, distribution, supply, sale, and marketing of alcoholic beverages.\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Newfoundland Liquor Corporation operates as a monopoly responsible for the distribution, supply, transport, sale and marketing of alcoholic beverages.\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, these measures may involve discretionary decisions based on various factors, limitations on market access, imposition of performance requirements or discrimination in favour of residents of Newfoundland and Labrador or entities established in accordance with the laws of Canada or a province or territory thereof and having a place of business and substantive operations within Newfoundland and Labrador.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-77\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nBusiness services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nLegal services (notaries)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 861\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Newfoundland and Labrador\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nNotaries Public Act, R.S.N.L. 1990, c. N5\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and Cross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\nOnly a Canadian citizen that is resident in the Province is eligible to become a notary public for the Province.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservations applicable in the Northwest Territories\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-78\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nBusiness services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nLegal services (notaries public)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 861\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment \n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nTerritorial \u2013 Northwest Territories\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nEvidence Act, R.S.N.W.T. 1988, c. E8, s. 79\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and Cross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\nA person who seeks appointment as a notary public must reside in the Northwest Territories and be either a citizen of Canada or a person who has the status of a permanent resident of Canada.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation applicable in Nova Scotia\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-79\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nBusiness services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nAccounting services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 862\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Nova Scotia\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nCertified General Accountants Act, S. N.S. 1998, c. 10\n\n\nCertified Management and Accountants of Nova Scotia Act, S.N.S.\u00a02005, c. 35\n\n\nPublic Accountants Act, R.S.N.S. 1989, c. 369\n\n\nChartered Accountants Act, S.N.S. 1994, c. 14\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nCross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\nOnly residents of Canada are eligible to be licenced to practice as a public accountant in Nova Scotia and to use the designation \"Public Accountant\".\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-80\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nTourism and recreational services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nService incidental to hunting\n\n\nTour guide agencies\n\n\nOwnaccount hunting\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 7472, 8813, 96419\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Nova Scotia\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nWildlife Act, R.S.N.S. 1989, c. 504\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nCross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\nOnly Nova Scotia residents are eligible to receive a fur harvesters' or moose hunting licence. Nonresidents may be subject to supervision by a qualified guide while hunting or fishing in designated rivers.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-81\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nTransport\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nHighway freight transport\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 7123\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nPerformance requirements\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Nova Scotia\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nThe Public Utilities Act, R.S., c. 380, s. 1\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\nPublic convenience and needs tests are applied to some subsectors of freight transportation within the Province. The criteria relating to approval include the adequacy of current levels of service, market conditions establishing the requirement for the expanded service, the effect of new entrants on public convenience, and the fitness, willingness and ability of the applicant to provide proper service. Performance requirements may be imposed.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-82\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nTransport\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nInterurban motor bus transport and scheduled services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 7121\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nPerformance requirements\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Nova Scotia\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nPublic Utilities Act, R.S.N.S. 1989, c. 380\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and Cross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\nLicencing of new entrants to this service is subject to public convenience and needs tests which includes: the examination of the adequacy of current levels of service; market conditions establishing the requirement for expanded service; the effect of new entrants on public convenience, including the continuity and quality of service; and the fitness, willingness and ability of the applicant to provide proper service. Performance requirements may be imposed.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-83\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nLand\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nOther land\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 539\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Nova Scotia\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nLand Titles Clarification Act, R.S.N.S. 1989, c. 250\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\nAn applicant who claims land in a land titles clarification area based on historical adverse possession must be a resident of Nova Scotia.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-84\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nCredit and collection services\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nCredit reporting and collection agency services\n\n\nConsumer reporting agencies\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIndustry Classification:\n\n\n\n\nCPC 87901, 87902, 87909\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nMarket access\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLevel of Government:\n\n\n\n\nProvincial \u2013 Nova Scotia\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeasures:\n\n\n\n\nConsumer Creditors' Conduct Act, R.S.N.S., c. 91\n\n\nConsumer Protection Act, R.S.N.S., c. 92\n\n\nConsumer Reporting Act, R.S.N.S., c. 93\n\n\nConsumer Services Act, R.S.N.S., c. 94\n\n\nDirect Sellers Licensing and Regulation Act, R.S.N.S. 1989, c. 129\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and Cross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Whether as an individual or partnership, an applicant for registration as a consumer reporting agency must be a Canadian citizen or lawfully admitted to Canada and ordinarily resident. A corporate applicant must be incorporated in Canada and registered to do business in Nova Scotia. A consumer reporting agency, whether an individual, partnership, or corporation, shall operate from the fixed place of business in Nova Scotia, that shall be open to the public during normal business hours.\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Credit Reporting and Collection Agency Services must be supplied through a commercial presence.\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Permanent residency is required to provide Consumer Agents Services\n\n\n4.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A licence application requires an address for service in Nova Scotia with direct sellers maintaining a permanent place of business in Nova Scotia.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation I-PT-85\n\n\n\n\n\nSector:\n\n\n\n\nAlcoholic beverages\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSub-Sector:\n\n\n\n\nCommission agents' services\n\n\nWholesale trade 18\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Except for testing, no person shall remove from the Province to a place outside of Canada for processing an output from a mine in the Province without first obtaining the consent of the Minister.\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A penalty equal to three times the royalty an operator would otherwise be required to pay may be ordered for failure to obtain consent.\n\n\n3.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Differential royalties also apply for mine output processed outside Nova Scotia.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation reissue a licence in respect of a funeral home for any reasonable cause.\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The regulation provides that a person applying for an apprentice embalmer's licence must have completed one of two courses of study in Nova Scotia. If a person has completed a course of study in a jurisdiction other than Nova Scotia, the Board has the discretion not to approve or accept the course of study.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation R.S.N.S. 1989, c. 342\n\n\nPetroleum Resources Removal Permit Act, S.N.S. 1999, c. 7\n\n\nPipeline Act, R.S.N.S. 1989, c. 345\n\n\nPublic Utilities Act, R.S.N.S. 1989, c. 380\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescription:\n\n\n\n\nInvestment and Cross-Border Trade in Services\n\n\n1.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Government of Nova Scotia regulates and issues various authorisations relating to the exploration, production, extraction, processing, development and transportation of hydrocarbons, and the granting of exclusive rights to operate hydrocarbon distribution systems and storage facilities, including related hydrocarbon pipelines, marine distribution, transshipment facilities and transport services.\n\n\n2.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The granting of authorisations may involve in accordance with the laws of Canada or a province or territory thereof and having a place of business and substantive business activities within Nova Scotia.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nReservation than rental of agricultural equipment with operator and 8814), 882\n\n\n\n\n\n\nType of Reservation:\n\n\n\n\nNational treatment\n\n\nPerformance requirements\n\n\nSenior management and boards of
